webTitle: Players safety in question after Becks abuse

fields.headline: Players safety in question after Becks abuse
fields.trailText: The Professional Footballers Association have voiced their concerns about players' safety after David Beckham and his family were abused by West Ham supporters as he drove home from Old Trafford following Sunday's FA Cup tie.
fields.body:
The Professional Footballers Association have voiced their concerns about players' safety after David Beckham and his family were abused by West Ham supporters as he drove home from Old Trafford following Sunday's FA Cup tie.

The fans shouted obscenities and hammered on the tinted windows of the Manchester United midfielder's car as it left the ground.

Beckham, who was with his wife and parents, has denied allegations that he spat in the face of a fan.

Gordon Taylor, the PFA's chief executive, said: "It's just not an easy situation where there's a car which is easily identifiable.It's unfortunate that in this day and age there is always somebody ready to have a go.

"We would not want to have the same protection for sportsman as we do have for presidents, but it is a difficult one. We may have to camouflage coaches and camouflage cars so that people have no idea who is in them, but I believe that would be a sad reflection on how bad things have got."

United's director of communications Paddy Harverson said: "The club considers the safety and security of the players of paramount importance. We always do our utmost to make sure they are escorted when they arrive and leave the ground."

webTitle: Taribo West delayed getting out of Africa

fields.headline: West delay in getting out of Africa
fields.trailText: Taribo West's English representative has insisted there is nothing sinister in the Derby County defender's late return from international duty with Nigeria.
fields.body:
Taribo West's English representative has insisted there is nothing sinister in the Derby County defender's late return from international duty with Nigeria.

West was expected back to play in County's 2-1 defeat at Charlton on Tuesday but had failed to arrive by yesterday.

"He's now expected back this evening and nothing should be read into his late arival," said the player's agent Ian Anderson. "Sometimes it's very difficult to get out of Africa."

The Derby manager Jim Smith will wait to hear West's explanation before deciding what, if any, action to take.

"If he's been kidnapped in the Congo then that's obviously out of his control," Smith said. "But if he's late back for no good reason then that's a different matter."

West joined Derby for three months after his release from Internazionale and, with the short-term contract almost at an end, Smith was concerned the player had absented himself to talk to another Italian club."The Italian window for signings closes tonight and we hold the player's registration. So time is running out for an Italian club to get in touch with us asking for it," Smith explained.

"He's agreed to stay with us until the end of the season and the contract just needs his signature. He's an important part of my plans and we need him to stay with us."

webTitle: Premier League deal nipped in the Bud

fields.headline: Premier deal nipped in the Bud
fields.trailText: Budweiser has withdrawn its interest in succeeding Carling as the Premier League's title sponsor next season.
fields.body:
Budweiser has withdrawn its interest in succeeding Carling as the Premier League's title sponsor next season.

The American brewing company had been seen as the favourite to take over from Carling, which last month pulled out of negotiations to renew its deal. But Budweiser said yesterday that it would not be involved in the "final bidding process" now under way.

The Premier League is expected to name its new sponsor in the next fortnight. Coca-Cola and Pepsi are thought to be among the front runners but other companies are understood still to be negotiating.

Budweiser's decision comes after it had discussed a deal worth about £15m-20m a year. It appears finance was behind its withdrawal. Reports that it had demanded American football-style conditions, such as grounds with no other perimeter advertising and a guarantee of top players always being available for interview, were wide of the mark.

Budweiser said yesterday it would focus on its role as official beer sponsor of the 2002 World Cup.

Wolves made the first major signing since Dave Jones became their manager last month when they paid Sunderland £1m for the Republic of Ireland defender Paul Butler. Butler, 28, who has signed a 3-year deal, played five games for Wolves on loan before Christmas but a permanent move was delayed when Colin Lee was sacked as manager.

Stan Collymore has completed his free transfer from Bradford City to the Spanish first division side Real Oviedo.

Ian Rush, the former Liverpool player, has joined Barnsley part-time as strikers' coach. The former Aston Villa defender Allan Evans has been sacked as Morton's manager after their 4-1 Scottish Cup defeat by Peterhead.

Joe Kinnear has left the Second Division's bottom side Oxford United after four months as director of football.

webTitle: Call for European inquiry on Atlantic league

fields.headline: Call for European inquiry on Atlantic league
fields.trailText: Uefa is to be investigated by the EC over its attempt to kill off the proposed "Atlantic league" of clubs from the continent's smaller countries
fields.body:
Uefa is to be investigated by the European Commission over its attempt to kill off the proposed "Atlantic league" of clubs such as Celtic and Rangers from the continent's smaller countries, after a complaint from a Dutch Euro MP.

Uefa is strongly opposed to plans to form such a weekend Euroleague of leading clubs from Scotland, the Netherlands, Portugal, Belgium, Sweden and Denmark, who claim that they are missing out on crucial revenue because of the lack of competition within their own domestic leagues.

The clubs also complain that they are lagging behind the continent's big clubs who play in more competitive leagues.

Now Toine Manders, a Liberal, Democratic and Reform MP, has asked the commission to step in, claiming that Uefa is acting as a monopoly by not allowing clubs to form their own competition and that this is in breach of European trust laws.

Peter Fossen, general manager of PSV Eindhoven, speaking here at Football Expo, revealed that several clubs had already signed a declaration signalling their intention to opt out of their domestic competitions to form the Atlantic league and that they would meet in Amsterdam tomorrow to chart the way forward, despite Uefa's opposition.

The clubs involved are Scotland's big two plus PSV, Feyenoord, Ajax, Benfica, Sporting Lisbon, Anderlecht, Bruges, the Swedish clubs AIK and Gothenburg plus the Danish clubs Brondby and FC Copenhagen.

Fossen declared: "A European league for us is a matter of survival. We cannot continue as we are within our domestic competitions. This is the only way forward for us.

"Uefa has been frustrating us and rather than engaging our clubs in constructive dialogue it has been laying down the law and saying that only it can organise competitions.

"We need a total change of mind-set because a European league is the only way we can survive. We cannot sit still.

"The problem with smaller clubs comes with matches at the weekend. They do not generate enough money or interest. Our fans want to see us playing the likes of Manchester United.

"Not only are the best players moving away from the smaller countries but the next best players are leaving as well."

Under plans being considered by Fossen and other club representatives, the new league would begin next year. The Champions League would still operate on a weekly basis but the Atlantic league would take the place of the clubs' regular weekend fixtures. Fossen refused to be drawn on claims that they would break away if Uefa refused to back them.

"We are meeting this Friday to discuss the way forward," he said. "We do not want confrontation, we want Uefa to listen to us. Times have changed, we now operate in a European market and work within a European environment, and Uefa has to understand this."

fields.headline: Three off as United roar on
fields.trailText:
Sunderland 0 - 1 Man Utd
Three off as United roar on.
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Three players were sent off here last night as Manchester United extended their lead at the top of the Premiership to 15 points, courtesy of a controversial goal from Andy Cole in the opening minute of the second half.

Sunderland argued, not without reason, that Cole had handled and Michael Gray was dismissed for dissent. Soon after this Cole and Alex Rae were sent off following an exchange of blows in the Sunderland goalmouth and ultimately only a frozen female streaker brightened Wearside's evening.

This time Sunderland's has been a longer haul to a position of high esteem. Whereas last season Peter Reid's side, newly promoted from the Nationwide League, rose like rockets only to fall like sticks they now look like maintaining their challenge for a Champions League place a little longer.

Not that the most optimistic Wearsider would have suspected as much last September, when after a 3-0 defeat at Old Trafford Sunderland lay in the bottom three.

Before last night, however, they had lost only twice in 19 league matches and another encounter with United offered them a chance to remind the champions of just how dramatic the improvement has been. For Sunderland there was also the practical necessity of victory to leapfrog back above Arsenal into second place.

Of course Reid's team had already knocked United out of the Worthington Cup this season but that night they were playing Sir Alex Ferguson's reserves. In fact the ease with which United's youngsters passed the ball around was a poor augury for Sunderland's hopes of holding the real thing.

As ever they looked to Niall Quinn's power in the air complementing the goalscoring instincts of Kevin Phillips. In the fourth minute a high ball from Jody Craddock skimmed Quinn's head and fell to Phillips at the far post. His shot was off target but the most likely threat to United's defence had quickly made itself apparent.

United's most recent conquerors, Liverpool in the league and West Ham in the FA Cup, had relied on outwitting them at their own passing game but Sunderland were always more likely to prefer the broadsword to the rapier.

After 10 minutes Gray's low cross might have seen Sunderland score had Quinn been a fraction further forward in the goalmouth. With Don Hutchison pushing up on the right and Gavin McCann and Stefan Schwarz pressing forward to support the front men, United's early attacking pressure soon gave way to containment punctuated by quick, economical breakaways. As Giggs steadily gnawed away at the Sunderland right so United began to take the heat and passion out of the evening.

The loss of Quinn with a shoulder injury on the half-hour did nothing for Sunderland's hopes of reimposing themselves. How they could have done with the suspended Danny Dichio, the usual alternative to Quinn, at that point.

By half-time, with Roy Keane and Paul Scholes dominant in midfield, United were controlling the tempo and pattern of the game. Half-chances fell to Keane and Teddy Sheringham (twice) which, while they failed to produce a goal, left little doubt about which team was the more likely to score.

Not that any such doubts lasted long into the second half, about half-a-minute in fact. A defensive muddle allowed Keane to send Cole clear with a short lob. Cole duly chipped the ball past Thomas Sorensen but appeared to handle it first.

When Graham Poll allowed the goal to stand Sunderland's fury erupted on and off the pitch. In the end Gray protested too much and got himself needlessly sent off when Sunderland more than ever needed to be up to strength.

In the event they were soon down to nine men. After 56 minutes Rae followed Gray, along with Cole, following a dust-up after the United striker had made a strong challenge on Sorensen.

Three dismissals is about par for the course for Poll, who had flourished a similar number of red cards in the Arsenal-Liverpool match last August. Undaunted, Sunderland would have drawn level had Jaap Stam not got back to block a shot from Kevin Kilbane which had beaten Fabien Barthez.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Tugay keeps Rangers in the hunt
fields.trailText:
Rangers 1 - 0 Aberdeen
Tugay keeps Rangers in the hunt.
fields.body:
Rangers took advantage of Celtic's night off to make some ground on the Premier League leaders last night. Third-placed Rangers are now nine points behind their great rivals, the Turk Tugay Kerimoglu scoring the winner for the understrength champions after 34 minutes on a raw night in Glasgow.

Rangers, though, made hard work of victory and both teams finished with 10 men, Neil McCann of Rangers and Aberdeen's Phil McGuire dismissed for each receiving two yellow cards in the second half.

In a quiet first half Bert Konterman, filling in a holding role in midfield for Rangers, tried an early shot from long range but it ended up as far away from goal as when it had arrived at the Dutchman's feet.

Thomas Solberg set the tone for the evening when he was booked for a body-check on McCann as the winger went past him down the line on the left. Derek Whyte was then penalised for bringing down Tore Andre Flo when beaten by a turn and when Tugay fired the free-kick against the wall it looked like the danger was gone.

But Tugay was first to the loose ball and fired a low shot past Dave Preece's outstretched right arm and into the net. It was the game's first shot on target.

The pressure was off the home side and Kenny Miller forced Preece into a save before Flo blasted over from a similar distance. Kevin McNaughton had to hack over his own bar under pressure from Flo but Preece punched away. It was a bad-tempered night and Rangers will have to improve to match Celtic step for step.

 Sky's pay-per-view Scottish Premier League venture last night got off to the worst possible start when St Johnstone's home game against the leaders Celtic was called off because of fog 15 minutes before the scheduled kick off.

fields.headline: Timely strike from Tal lifts the gloom at Goodison
fields.trailText:
Everton 2 - 2 Middlesbrough
Timely Tal lifts the Goodison gloom.
fields.body:
If Everton are to again move from gallows trap-door to saftey, rest assured it will be a tortuous journey and one completed, presumably, at the 11th hour.

As has been their way in recent seasons the Merseysiders are crawling, rather than sprinting, their way towards salvation. It is an agonising spectacle to behold.

They should have won this game but were ultimately grateful for a share of the spoils, the substitute Idan Tal driving home an uncleared corner with just 10 minutes remaining to square things up.

Seasoned Everton-watchers could be seen pinching themselves minutes before the kick-off for there, before their very eyes, were Kevin Campbell and Duncan Ferguson sharing the same pitch for the first time since Ferguson returned his battered frame to Merseyside six months ago. Everything comes to he who waits and, somewhat belatedly, the so-called dream pairing was finally up and running.

In the aftermath of the FA Cup debacle against Tranmere Rovers - a horror show in the Stephen King mould - Everton's manager Walter Smith shuffled a pack of few aces but many jokers. There were several casualties but, so poor was Saturday's performance, Smith would have enhanced his reputation had he dropped the lot.

At least Everton showed more spirit last night, but they still resembled a jigsaw puzzle in need of assembly. While their sustained early pressure was impressive, they remain unable to transform possession into goals. It is a wrong they must swiftly right.

Middlesbrough soak up attacks with no apparent discomfort these days; a defence which pre-Venables was both shoddy and sloppy now exudes a measure of authority. Everton dominated the early stages but it was the visitors who scored first in fine style, Hamilton Ricard turning home from no great distance after Alen Boksic had headed on Christian Karembeu's divine cross from the right.

Everton promptly threw everything in the general direction of the towering Ferguson - a predictable ploy but one that often yields high dividends. Last night, however, chances came but were carelessly squandered. Campbell and Steve Watson both found room inside a crowded penalty area but lacked the composure to inflict any damage.

Middlesbrough may not have deserved to be in front, but nor did they deserve to see Everton restore parity in the manner they did five minutes into an acrimonious second half. As the goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer moved out to collect Watson's orthodox cross he appeared to be nudged in the back by Campbell. But there was no whistle and, as the ball fell at the back post, Gary Naysmith arrived unannounced to score with a stooping header.

Having created a platform upon which to build something more meaningful, Everton promptly dismantled it when the goalkeeper Thomas Myhre punched a Curtis Fleming cross high into the air, allowing Colin Cooper to head the ball back over the line.

fields.headline: Tiatto throws City a lifeline
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 1 Liverpool
fields.body:
Among Joe Royle's mail this week was a small package containing a square print with a light-grey background and a red switch in the middle. Written at the top were the words "Panic Button".

The pessimist who designed it will doubtless be pleased to know it is now being used as a drinks coaster on Royle's desk. "I haven't pressed it yet," the Manchester City manager said on Tuesday, but after watching his side hold Liverpool to a creditable draw last night maybe his restraint should not be written off as blind faith after all.

Certainly Royle can feel mightily satisfied with the manner in which his side composed themselves after Emile Heskey had opened the scoring just before half-time. They concocted an equaliser through Danny Tiatto after the re-start and even threatened to snatch an improbable victory. For City, everything might not be lost.

Liverpool relegated City from the Premiership on their last visit here in May 1996, a game that will always be remembered for the infamous sight of the then City manager Alan Ball frantically ordering his players to run the clock down, wrongly believing the 2-2 scoreline would be enough to keep them up.

Such moments of tragi-comedy have by and large been expunged from their repertoire under Royle's tenure, but after plummeting from 10th position in October to the relegation places it has been threatening to reach the stage where, yet again, Maine Road is a place from where only the sadomasochistic go home happy.

While City were grubbing around for points after a traumatic sequence of only one win in their 11 previous league games, Liverpool journeyed down the M62 on the back of a run of 11 victories in 15 matches.

But until Heskey opened the scoring on 43 minutes, the gulf between the two sides was seldom evident throughout an opening period that flickered into life without truly igniting.

Liverpool's attacking threat was scarcely more potent, although Gérard Houllier could look back and sigh at two missed opportunities engineered from Gary McAllister corners but which were spurned by Markus Babbel and then, from an open goal, the woefully profligate Vladimir Smicer.

Given the height advantage that Liverpool were conceding it was surprising that they were causing such an aerial threat, and Heskey finally made City pay for their defensive creaks when he stole ahead of his marker to head in Smicer's precise left-wing delivery for his 17th goal of the season.

The lead was just about deserved, although the feeling persisted that Liverpool were somewhere below their best while City were just content to use a bit of rough and tumble and see how far it got them.

Royle introduced Andrei Kanchelskis for the hamstrung Andy Morrison at half-time, though the Ukrainian could not claim to have played a part in their equaliser.

Instead City's first attack of the half saw Darren Huckerby's misplaced pass take a kindly ricochet to leave Shaun Goater marauding to ward Sander Westerveld on the right of goal. Rather than shooting from a difficult angle the Bermudan chose wisely to drag the ball back from the byline and Danny Tiatto thumped the ball into the roof of the net from a position close to the penalty spot.

It was the first goal that Liverpool had conceded in 420 minutes and, all of a sudden, City started to play with some thing curiously reminiscent of self-belief.

Much of that was due to Kanchelskis, who did enough to suggest he can add some enterprise to the City attack while also consolidating the belief that Houllier's decision to play Steven Gerrard at left-back was a waste of the midfielder's talents.

Seldom one to conform to the predictable, Houllier had left Robbie Fowler on the bench and by the time he replaced the largely ineffective Litmanen Liverpool were looking decidedly ragged around the edges.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Poyet and Zola link up to lift resurgent Chelsea
fields.trailText: Chelsea 3 - 1 Newcastle
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri again rang the changes last night but there remains one constant in this resurgent Chelsea. Gianfranco Zola's continuing excellence, typified by his wonderful equaliser, constructed the platform for his side's domination of the second half, which was rounded off with eye-catching goals by Gustavo Poyet and Jesper Gronkjaer.

The Italian's goal - his tenth of the season - and Poyet's speak of renewed confidence at the Bridge, which was underlined by Gronkjaer's emphatic strike 11 minutes from time. Europe may yet welcome Chelsea again next season.

United had the best of the opening exchanges, though. The two-game suspension for Kieron Dyer, which happened to coincide with his shin injury, saw the spring-heeled midfielder back in vibrant health. His pace, deployed up front because of Newcastle's familiar shoal of strikers' injuries, troubled Chelsea even before he created the opener.

It came when Nol Solano dispossessed Celestine Babayaro and fired a canny pass up the right flank. Dyer took possession, ran on, took one look at the non-departing Frank Leboeuf and sped past him to the byline before crossing.

The towering Shola Ameobi missed but the hovering Christian Bassedas did not, firing low to Carlo Cudicini's left.

Ranieri, rarely slow to make a change, did so eight minutes later, his choice eased by the earlier sight of Graeme le Saux holding his thigh in discomfort. Gronkjaer took over the left wing-back role from the injury-plagued England man.

Amid Chelsea's largely unconvincing early attacks, Zola's talent shone brightly. After 10 minutes he served warning by driving just wide after a delicious back-heel from Gustavo Poyet. Then the Italian and Uruguayan combined quickly and cleverly again, this time for Zola to loft a shot that was deflected for a fruitless corner.

By now Zola was simmering and he came to the boil on 37 minutes when he received Babayaro's pass, cut inside and, despite facing four Newcastle shirts, half-turned and curled a superb shot from 22 yards past the hopelessly beaten Shay Given.

Gronkjaer's surging runs down the left featured in Chelsea's early second-half attacks but it was the more thoughtful touches of Zola and Poyet that threatened to unhinge United who, despite a fair share of possession, rarely threatened Cudicini's goal.

Chelsea pressure paid off on 62 minutes when Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink curled an inviting low cross into the area. Poyet reacted fractionally faster than the defenders, flicking the ball cleverly past Given.

 Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates last night slated Monaco over the French transfer deadline-day collapse of Frank Leboeuf's proposed move home, for which a £2.5m fee was agreed two weeks ago. "To put it bluntly, Monaco can't come up with the money," said Bates. "The situation is unresolved because their president has done a runner and is unavailable having interfered with and messed up the negotiations."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Petrescu makes winning start
fields.trailText:
Southampton 1 - 0 Leicester
Petrescu makes a winning start.
fields.body:
Having just signed Dan Petrescu for a second time, Glenn Hoddle is in no doubt as to the Romanian's virtues, though matchwinning feats have not hitherto been high among them. Nevertheless there was Petrescu in the 79th minute to decide an untidy game and launch his Southampton career with a flourish.

It was a strike the game had been in dire need of for some time, for it had become locked in midfield with few penalty-area thrills despite Southampton's early indications that they could at least match Saturday's three-goal haul in the FA Cup.

When these sides met in September a Gerry Taggart goal hoisted Leicester up to second in the table and suggested that Southampton, from a place one off the bottom, could contemplate another winter of struggle. In fact Hoddle's men never again wore such a bleak look as they did that day, and seven wins in nine home games have lent the Dell a fortress reputation in its final season.

Southampton began in robust fashion and within 30 seconds James Beattie had cruised past Matt Elliott and sent an early shudder through Leicester's confidence. Elliott was still groping for his bearings when Claus Lundekvam lofted a pass high and Beattie's instant control obliged Gary Rowett to intervene with a tidy challenge.

Leicester's unease may have had something to do with Taggart's absence through a thigh strain. Certainly no blame could be attached to Junior Lewis who, having figured only fitfully for Gillingham, found himself thrust into a Premiership debut at the start of a three-month loan; with his long legs and measured passing he won crucial tackles and gave his team a fair amount of possession, though Southampton remained the more likely to engineer a breakthrough.

Strong headers from Beattie and Dean Richards kept the level of expectancy high. Then on the half-hour Petrescu slid in to make contact with Beattie's nod across goal after a diagonal ball from Wayne Bridge and was only inches away from finishing off the move.

Leicester, unable to get bodies up in support of their strikers, did improve as half-time approached and Paul Jones was forced into the first urgent save of the night when Muzzy Izzet was left alone to direct a header down towards the near post.

Roberto Mancini's quality on the ball was self-evident though his influence had been peripheral at best. Early in the second half the veteran Italian found himself with two chances to score from close in, thwarted first by Jones's smothering plunge and then by the ubiquitous Beattie, now performing vital defensive duties as Leicester attacked dangerously.

Hopes of an end to the deadlock were fast disappearing when Bridge swung a free-kick into the area. Beattie made a move towards it but the crucial touch came from Petrescu.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst:
When a Canadian schoolboy was jailed after reading out his violent story in class, the country's best-known authors rallied to his defence. But with rumours of bullying and death threats surfacing, could there be more to this saga than just an essay? Aida Edemariam investigates
Read the schoolboy's story
fields.trailText: When a Canadian schoolboy was jailed after reading out his violent story in class, the country's best-known authors rallied to his defence. But with rumours of bullying and death threats surfacing, could there be more to this saga than just an essay?
fields.body:
It was all clearly unfair. A schoolboy had been asked to write a short monologue and present it to his drama class. Sixteen days later he was in jail. He would be there for 34 days, for his 16th birthday, for Christmas, for new year. The writing community was immediately up in arms. His right to freedom of expression had been violated, and they wanted to do something about it. Last Sunday they congregated in Ottawa, at a fundraising event called Artists for Freedom of Speech.

Michael Ondaatje, whose first novel Billy the Kid was about a young killer, spoke."It was full of violence, but somehow I learned to keep it there. I see myself as someone who was saved by writing."

Margaret Atwood spoke. "Childhood can be hell," she said, quoting The Untouched Key by Alice Miller. "One reason childhood can be hell is that as a child you can have no power, you can have no recourse and nobody who will actually believe you if you did go so far as to express, in one way or another, something that happened to you." She gave the boy a book, First Words, a collection of early writing by well known authors. Even Stephen King weighed in, telling the Toronto Globe and Mail: "I am in total solidarity with that young man and admire him because it shows again that the imagination is the most powerful force on earth."

Ondaatje and Atwood aren't commenting now, though. And there's a feeling that they, and the other 13 writers who read at the event, might have been a little rash. That the case might be more complicated than they initially thought. That it has less to do with free expression than they'd like, and that not enough people went to the school to find out what was actually going on. They would have discovered, among other things, that disciplinary action was taken because of an alleged series of death threats, rather than as a direct result of his monologue.

"Was he arrested for reading his monologue in class? In my view, no," says Frank MacEachern, the crime reporter for the local newspaper, the Cornwall Standard-Freeholder. He attended the boy's bail hearing. "If he hadn't allegedly made threats to three students in the school, I doubt the police would have been involved."

The boy, who cannot be named under Canadian law because of his age, had only been at Tagwi secondary school in Avonmore, Ontario, for a couple of months when this flared up. It's a small, rural school of about 500 students. In interviews with Canadian papers, and a written account of the event that he released to papers, the boy says that he was bullied soon after he arrived. (The family was not answering calls last night.)

"People would make fun of me, my family, my possessions and my actions/words. One thing I remember quite clearly is one boy saying 'Can you say "The rat ran over the river across the road?" ' If you notice there are seven Rs in that one sentence. I have difficulty saying one R (this is my shameful secret which until now I would deny impetuously) which turn out sounding like a W or an O (due to an inability of my mouth)."

Some of the writers in Ottawa, for instance novelist Elizabeth Harvor, did focus on the serious issue of bullying in schools, citing the fact that the boy claimed to have been, on one occasion, so severely beaten up that he went home bloody.

His classmates, however, have a slightly different story. They admit he was probably taunted, but Marty Partridge, a Grade 11 student who was in the drama class when the boy presented his monologue, says: "To start he was just some other kid. But then he started to make himself more noticeable ... He would go around making things up, saying that some kids were ugly and dirty and stuff like that. He walked around by himself a lot of the time."

November 22 was the last of four sessions in which students presented monologues they had written. Each session had been followed by a critique by students and class, and so far he had not done well. Once he had even plagiarised Stephen King, changing the names, but effectively passing off The Boogeyman from Night Shift as his own work. The youth has told the media that there were four assigned categories that he could choose from, fantasy, tragedy, comedy and horror. But Cory Lafave, another student in the drama class, says this is pure fabrication; students could write about anything they chose.

The youth, who has a black goatee and whispy hair, and is about 5ft3in and slightly stubby, stood up in front of the class and delivered the monologue with what Partridge describes as a smirk. And the script that has since been released, Partridge adds, isn't exactly what the class heard. "He ad-libbed a lot. Like he said that if anyone tried to get out they'd walk up to the front door and he'd shoot them between the eyes with a shotgun.

"The object of a monologue is to get people's attention and get them to hear what you want to say, at the edge of their seat wanting to hear the rest. And he did that. He had me. He totally wrote a good monologue. That was just a good piece of theatre." The drama teacher agreed, praising the effort, rather than censuring it.

It seems that after this there were more alleged death threats. People started talking about the monologue, asking if there was a hit list, allegedly learning that there was, and that there were three specific people inplicated. His defence counsel, Frank Horn, says that everything is rumour, that hysteria snowballed and the allegations of threats are unfounded, that nothing can be pinned down. That his client is being persecuted by students jealous of someone "who might make it". "My guy is innocent." Be that as it may, much of the school, with an eye to the "12:12" mentioned in the monologue, had decided not to attend on December 12.

The police were called in. He was arrested on Friday December 8, and would not be released until January 9. While he was in jail, his 14-year-old brother had charges laid against him for allegedly making death threats at a different school, and his two older sisters, who ran away from home, alleged to the Ottawa Citizen that it was their brother who was often the bully.

During that time, in the arts community and among civil rights activists, support for the boy was growing quickly. PEN (the Canadian branch of the writers' association) got involved. Clayton Ruby, one of the most famous criminal lawyers in Canada, asked to take over the case. The International Writers Festival organised Sunday's rally.

But by the time the rally occurred, writers were backtracking. Broadcaster Laurier Lapierre, who has suffered bona fide censorship, even said: "At the beginning of this great drama, it seemed so simple. Now it is no longer so clear." The boy, who attended in a Pink Panther tie, was meant to read his story to the 400-strong crowd, but didn't.

More measured, thoughtful voices are now beginning to be heard too. There are issues here that go beyond saving face, beyond misjudgments. The first is, of course, the very real issue of freedom of speech. If the case comes to trial (for four alleged threats) in September, and it's discovered that the boy was disciplined because of real threats to the safety of the school, then PEN Canada and the writers who ranged themselves for him risk trivialising censorship. Secondly, the writing in the monologue is OK - but, as award-winning children's author Tim Wynne-Jones puts it, anyone who's worked with young people has seen writing like it before.

Wynne-Jones was scheduled to speak in Ottawa, but dropped out because he was concerned about all these things, concerned that it wasn't really an issue of the freedom of speech."I was particularly concerned about the boy, that he would confuse notoriety with talent." The funds collected are to go towards getting him into a creative writing program. The rest will go to supporting programs that put artists in contract with students.

"I think he needs tutors; if he were to sit down and read the books of the people who stood up and spoke, he'd be a lot smarter than he was a month ago. I do feel sorry for what he's had to go through. I hope he's not left out in the cold now all this has blown over. I don't think any of the writers who were there on Sunday will be inviting him over for tea."

'Twisted': the story that landed its writer in jail

There's this boy who's been harassed and tortured all his life until he was at the brink of insanity and sanity. His entire life has been one test after another: testing his patience, his sanity, emotions and morals.

Without rest there was always someone on his back, teachers, principals, but most of all the other students. I could go on talking about their hatred for him for no specific reason other than they wanted to. His teachers cheated him, tricked him and despised him, and why not they had their pets.

Teachers always have their pets and their toys. No matter how much they preached about not having any. The toys were good for playing with then discarding, the pets you pampered looking mostly at their good points and getting attached. The principals well they didn't plain just like him. But it's the students I think that did it; yeah definitely, it was the students that warped him.

No matter how hard he tried there was always something wrong with him in their minds. He tried and tried he really did. He wanted to be just like them at first, well up until Grade 7 that is. Then he came to terms with his life and realised that he didn't fit in. In Grade 9 he began to like being different, being an outcast, he liked the dumb comments, because by then they weren't at him but rather at someone on the outside. Somehow during all this he had slowly and steadily retreated from the world, putting up barriers and shields, so many in fact that he saw the patterns of the fabric of life, saw all the little holes and tears, gimmicks and faults.

He discovered what life is: pain. When you live something else is in pain. When you eat something had to go through pain to be there for you to eat, even base feeling is little shocks being shot up the nerves. Every action, thought and creation is borne on pain. Any ways one day he went to class in a bad mood, he had been pushed really hard that day. This was supposedly his favourite class, but it had been the hardest on him, his projects were all considered pieces of crap, his classmates of course loved him as always. Apparently this class had been set-up that day. Oh what fun they had that day poking and prodding and pushing and pulling. And of course who said "Boo," no one that's who. I supposed they had no clue what he was thinking about because I'm sure that if they did they would have backed off really, really quickly.

The next day he came to school he was super happy, bouncing along in a hyper/jovial mood, he laughed at the stupid jokes pretending not knowing they were insults. He was buddy buddy with the teachers. Oh just the best of moods. I guess that no one knew that he had woken up at 5.00 in the morning and jimmied the lock on one of the back doors. In addition, that in his bag he was carrying 13 packages of C-4 and a detonater. I guess he had fun stashing them under the garbage bags in the pails, 4 packages under the tables in the cafeteria, mostly in high traffic areas.

Apparently he kept one strapped to his chest just in case the others were found. Luckily for him none were found. Everyone blissfully unaware that their lives were in very imminent danger. He went happily along waiting for the right moment. He decided to detonate at 12:12 exactly. Everyone would be having lunch and having fun.

The boy, who cannot be named under Canadian law because of his age, had only been at Tagwi secondary school in Avonmore, Ontario, for a couple of months when this flared up. It's a small, rural school of about 500 students. In interviews with Canadian papers, and a written account of the event that he released to papers, the boy says that he was bullied soon after he arrived. (The family was not answering calls last night.) "People would make fun of me, my family, my possessions and my actions/words. One thing I remember quite clearly is one boy saying 'Can you say "The rat ran over the river across the road?" ' If you notice there are seven Rs in that one sentence. I have difficulty saying one R (this is my shameful secret which until now I would deny impetuously) which turn out sounding like a W or an O (due to an inability of my mouth)." Some of the writers in Ottawa, for instance novelist Elizabeth Harvor, did focus on the serious issue of bullying in schools, citing the fact that the boy claimed to have been, on one occasion, so severely beaten up that he went home bloody. His classmates, however, have a slightly different story. They admit he was probably taunted, but Marty Partridge, a Grade 11 student who was in the drama class when the boy presented his monologue, says: "To start he was just some other kid. But then he started to make himself more noticeable ... He would go around making things up, saying that some kids were ugly and dirty and stuff like that. He walked around by himself a lot of the time." November 22 was the last of four sessions in which students presented monologues they had written. Each session had been followed by a critique by students and class, and so far he had not done well. Once he had even plagiarised Stephen King, changing the names, but effectively passing off The Boogeyman from Night Shift as his own work. The youth has told the media that there were four assigned categories that he could choose from, fantasy, tragedy, comedy and horror. But Cory Lafave, another student in the drama class, says this is pure fabrication; students could write about anything they chose. The youth, who has a black goatee and whispy hair, and is about 5ft3in and slightly stubby, stood up in front of the class and delivered the monologue with what Partridge describes as a smirk. And the script that has since been released, Partridge adds, isn't exactly what the class heard. "He ad-libbed a lot. Like he said that if anyone tried to get out they'd walk up to the front door and he'd shoot them between the eyes with a shotgun. "The object of a monologue is to get people's attention and get them to hear what you want to say, at the edge of their seat wanting to hear the rest. And he did that. He had me. He totally wrote a good monologue. That was just a good piece of theatre." The drama teacher agreed, praising the effort, rather than censuring it. It seems that after this there were more alleged death threats. People started talking about the monologue, asking if there was a hit list, allegedly learning that there was, and that there were three specific people inplicated. His defence counsel, Frank Horn, says that everything is rumour, that hysteria snowballed and the allegations of threats are unfounded, that nothing can be pinned down. That his client is being persecuted by students jealous of someone "who might make it". "My guy is innocent." Be that as it may, much of the school, with an eye to the "12:12" mentioned in the monologue, had decided not to attend on December 12. The police were called in. He was arrested on Friday December 8, and would not be released until January 9. While he was in jail, his 14-year-old brother had charges laid against him for allegedly making death threats at a different school, and his two older sisters, who ran away from home, alleged to the Ottawa Citizen that it was their brother who was often the bully. During that time, in the arts community and among civil rights activists, support for the boy was growing quickly. PEN (the Canadian branch of the writers' association) got involved. Clayton Ruby, one of the most famous criminal lawyers in Canada, asked to take over the case. The International Writers Festival organised Sunday's rally. But by the time the rally occurred, writers were backtracking. Broadcaster Laurier Lapierre, who has suffered bona fide censorship, even said: "At the beginning of this great drama, it seemed so simple. Now it is no longer so clear." The boy, who attended in a Pink Panther tie, was meant to read his story to the 400-strong crowd, but didn't. More measured, thoughtful voices are now beginning to be heard too. There are issues here that go beyond saving face, beyond misjudgments. The first is, of course, the very real issue of freedom of speech. If the case comes to trial (for four alleged threats) in September, and it's discovered that the boy was disciplined because of real threats to the safety of the school, then PEN Canada and the writers who ranged themselves for him risk trivialising censorship. Secondly, the writing in the monologue is OK - but, as award-winning children's author Tim Wynne-Jones puts it, anyone who's worked with young people has seen writing like it before. Wynne-Jones was scheduled to speak in Ottawa, but dropped out because he was concerned about all these things, concerned that it wasn't really an issue of the freedom of speech."I was particularly concerned about the boy, that he would confuse notoriety with talent." The funds collected are to go towards getting him into a creative writing program. The rest will go to supporting programs that put artists in contract with students. "I think he needs tutors; if he were to sit down and read the books of the people who stood up and spoke, he'd be a lot smarter than he was a month ago. I do feel sorry for what he's had to go through. I hope he's not left out in the cold now all this has blown over. I don't think any of the writers who were there on Sunday will be inviting him over for tea." 'Twisted': the story that landed its writer in jail There's this boy who's been harassed and tortured all his life until he was at the brink of insanity and sanity. His entire life has been one test after another: testing his patience, his sanity, emotions and morals. Without rest there was always someone on his back, teachers, principals, but most of all the other students. I could go on talking about their hatred for him for no specific reason other than they wanted to. His teachers cheated him, tricked him and despised him, and why not they had their pets. Teachers always have their pets and their toys. No matter how much they preached about not having any. The toys were good for playing with then discarding, the pets you pampered looking mostly at their good points and getting attached. The principals well they didn't plain just like him. But it's the students I think that did it; yeah definitely, it was the students that warped him. No matter how hard he tried there was always something wrong with him in their minds. He tried and tried he really did. He wanted to be just like them at first, well up until Grade 7 that is. Then he came to terms with his life and realised that he didn't fit in. In Grade 9 he began to like being different, being an outcast, he liked the dumb comments, because by then they weren't at him but rather at someone on the outside. Somehow during all this he had slowly and steadily retreated from the world, putting up barriers and shields, so many in fact that he saw the patterns of the fabric of life, saw all the little holes and tears, gimmicks and faults. He discovered what life is: pain. When you live something else is in pain. When you eat something had to go through pain to be there for you to eat, even base feeling is little shocks being shot up the nerves. Every action, thought and creation is borne on pain. Any ways one day he went to class in a bad mood, he had been pushed really hard that day. This was supposedly his favourite class, but it had been the hardest on him, his projects were all considered pieces of crap, his classmates of course loved him as always. Apparently this class had been set-up that day. Oh what fun they had that day poking and prodding and pushing and pulling. And of course who said "Boo," no one that's who. I supposed they had no clue what he was thinking about because I'm sure that if they did they would have backed off really, really quickly. The next day he came to school he was super happy, bouncing along in a hyper/jovial mood, he laughed at the stupid jokes pretending not knowing they were insults. He was buddy buddy with the teachers. Oh just the best of moods. I guess that no one knew that he had woken up at 5.00 in the morning and jimmied the lock on one of the back doors. In addition, that in his bag he was carrying 13 packages of C-4 and a detonater. I guess he had fun stashing them under the garbage bags in the pails, 4 packages under the tables in the cafeteria, mostly in high traffic areas. Apparently he kept one strapped to his chest just in case the others were found. Luckily for him none were found. Everyone blissfully unaware that their lives were in very imminent danger. He went happily along waiting for the right moment. He decided to detonate at 12:12 exactly. Everyone would be having lunch and having fun.

fields.headline: Fame and fortune
fields.standfirst: Milly gets her 15-minutes of fame on TV, celebrates Chinese New Year, glimpses the high life at a five-star hotel, but finds her own bedroom full of cockroaches
fields.trailText: Milly gets her 15-minutes of fame on TV, celebrates Chinese New Year, glimpses the high life at a five-star hotel, but finds her own bedroom full of cockroaches
fields.body:
I've just read through the others Netjetter's reports and somehow I don't think mine are quite as exciting as theirs - but hey ho, I guess the reality of an 19-year-old travelling is that they run out of money pretty quickly. This means that for me, cliff-jumping and the like is temporarily suspended which frustrates me a little, but makes me even more eager to work like crazy for a couple of months so I can spend the rest of the time racing round jungles with total abandon... sigh...

My week started with my second job trial, this time at the prestigious five-star hotel I'd already had an interview at. It must be the most entertaining procedure I've been through to get a waitressing job, but there was a fun crowd in the waiting room with me, all hoping to start together. Besides seeing another four or five people I was also given a full medical check, which seemed fantastically over the top. The nurse happily informed me that I had a "weak left wrist, not helped by being short!", but besides that all was in good working order apparently. At the end of a few hours of interviews I was finally told I'd got the job - yippee! As jobs go this one should be interesting - the prospect of meeting big businessmen, celebrities or even being at a Jewish wedding await.

Friday dawned sunny and bright, which fitted brilliantly with it being Australia Day, a public holiday commemorating the time when the First Fleet set up in circular quay, home of the Opera House. After a quick stroll around the beachside markets in Coogee, Brian and I headed to Darling Harbour which was more packed than ever this time with jet-ski performers, street theatre, countless stalls and holidayers in their thousands. That evening we had intended to return to watch the fireworks, but I realised I'd never been to a proper club in Sydney which, given the lively nature of the city, seemed a terrible omission. Besides, Australians are renowned for partying - my friends in Canada lived by the motto 'Go hard or go home'.

So, I took Brian to Home, probably the best known club in the city, with three stories of glass walls overlooking Darling Harbour. I'd determined to dance 'til dawn, or at least have a decent go at it! The atmosphere inside was incredibly relaxed and happy. A bouncer told me he'd rarely seen any kind of fights because of the vibe there. One nice touch for me was a wash-room attendant who insisted on massaging my arms every time I went to the bathroom!

I returned to my apartment at six the next morning, so I felt I'd pretty much fulfilled my aim, and had a great time with it. Saturday, although I made every attempt to wake early and achieve great things, by early evening the lack of sleep caught up with me. Kept in by a raging tropical storm that plunged the whole of Coogee into greyness I soon collapsed asleep, fully-clothed.

The next day my thoughts turned to my friends Sapphire, Dave and Gary who left England today to follow the same route as me. Good luck, and I'll see you in Sydney! And I'll get to see how travelling with friends compares to travelling alone. I headed to Chinatown, central Sydney to watch the parade celebrating Chinese New Year (of the snake). It was a colourful event with dancing dragons and elaborately dressed Chinese ladies, but for some reason the audience didn't seem too enthused - maybe it was just Sunday morning lethargy. Meanwhile I treated myself to Chinese dinner to keep in with the spirit of the day.

I met up with Brian and we made a snap decision to go to Fox studios. While we were there, a live MTV-style programme was being filmed for Australian TV so we sat to watch it being shot. It was then that an assistant came over and asked if we'd like to request a song - Brian asked for an obscure Australian band named Porkers, and the assistant then asked if we'd mind having a chat with the presenter before he played our choice!! We had about two minutes of interview, which went out live, and pretty much involved us discussing hostels and travelling. So, if anybody was watching Channel V at 5.30pm on Sunday, that girl in the pink top was me!

Later that night a group of us headed to the Clovelley hotel to watch a live band, and Brian and I got recognised from our TV appearance - the guy even seemed quite excited to see us! So there you have it, fame at last! But when I returned to my room later that night, I found it had been infested with enormous cockroaches. Michaela had sprayed the room, leaving it full of dying roaches. I was just glad I hadn't been the one to discover them! Not wanting to sleep in my room, the two of us squeezed in with the couple next door.

On Monday I felt the need to stretch my legs again, so decided to give the pleasant walk from Bondai to Coogee another try. I was quite surprised to find that doing it alone it took only half the time that it had with Josh, but then again I did stick to the path on this occasion! Stopping at the Coogee Bay Hotel, a man started asking about my interest in sailing as he was going to rent a boat. I like to think I've learnt something from my travels so I politely declined his invitation to join him and left - no more outings with random strangers!

At 8.30am the next morning I went to the hotel for my first day's work, and it felt eerily like going back to school. A group of 10 of us, all on working visas, were given our uniforms then sat in a circle in a room where we were given name-cards and made to play getting-to-know-you activities! Our first day didn't involve any actual work but it did include a tour of the hotel, including a peek into one of the bedrooms. This $800-a-night room had incredible harbour views and a walk in bathroom - we all noted that it was a little nicer than our own present accommodation! The quality of service - room service tables, 24-hour laundry, overnight shoe-shine - just reminded me of a movie and I found it fascinating. The only drawback was that at the end of the day, having watched videos and filled out handbooks, we were all informed there was no work for the next week. All of us hoping to work there are in exactly the same boat, so this was pretty distressing. Quick tip for anybody hoping to work in Sydney - jobs are easy enough to come by, but February is a much better month to start looking, so I'm told.

Wednesday saw torrential rain for the second day in a row which scuppered my plans. Still, I made it into Sydney to see if there was any other temporary work going only to hear repeatedly that things will be picking up in a couple of weeks. I hope so. I'm itching to continue my adventures again - in the mean-time if anyone has good suggestions for Sydney-based activities they'd be very much appreciated. Until next week, and who knows what can happen in a week?
Milly

webTitle: 5,000 jobs go in steel closure plan

fields.headline: 5,000 jobs go in steel closure plan
fields.trailText: 1 Februqry: Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, will today announce plans to axe more than 5,000 British jobs, despite government anger over the way the company has conducted itself.
fields.byline: David Gow, Michael White and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, will today announce plans to axe more than 5,000 British jobs, despite government anger over the way the company has conducted itself.

South Wales will bear the brunt of the two-year programme of cuts, through the mothballing of virtually the whole of the Llanwern plant and the closure of the Ebbw Vale tinplate business.

Sir Brian Moffat, the Corus chairman and acting chief executive, has summoned union leaders to his HQ in London's West End for a breakfast briefing.

But he will provoke a storm of protest at the scale of the cutbacks - which include the closure of a core mill on Teeside - despite an unprecedented lobbying campaign led by Tony Blair.

Downing Street yesterday expressed anger over the company's refusal to tell even the government details of its plans or exactly when it would make the announcement.

"It's a pretty extraordinary state of affairs where, as the government, if you were to ask us when is this decision going to be announced we would say we don't know," the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said.

He contrasted Corus' attitude with the constructive talks between Whitehall and other firms engaged in major restructuring such as Vauxhall at Luton and BMW/Rover during the crisis in Longbridge last year.

Industry sources said last night that Sir Brian had been rattled by the sheer intensity of the lobbying campaign but felt he had no alternative but to slash over-capacity brought about by shrinkage of the Britain's manufacturing base and a flood of cheap imports.

Corus's UK operations lost at least £350m last year.

The prime minister and senior colleagues, fearing that the thousands of job losses will damage Labour, have pulled out all the stops to convince Corus that the recent weakening of the pound against the euro and a decision by several car groups to increase output will ease the group's medium-term trading prospects. But Sir Brian is expected to press ahead with plans to shut virtually the entire Llanwern plant, keeping just some specialist units.

Llanwern, employed 3,300 last summer, but could now be reduced to just a 600-strong workforce.

The main steel union, the ISTC, will later today put flesh on plans for a consortium to take over the plant, despite Corus's initial rejection of its demand for talks on a buyout.

webTitle: Chief justice clashes with Straw on jail policy

fields.headline: Chief justice clashes with Straw on jail policy
fields.standfirst: Lord Woolf describes overcrowding as 'Aids virus of prison system' and urges shorter sentences after home secretary takes hard line
fields.trailText: Britain's most senior judge last night clashed with the home secretary over Jack Straw's plan for longer prison sentences for the 100,000 most persistent offenders, which is to form a centrepiece of Labour's election manifesto.
fields.body:
Britain's most senior judge last night clashed with the home secretary over Jack Straw's plan for longer prison sentences for the 100,000 most persistent offenders, which is to form a centrepiece of Labour's election manifesto.

Mr Straw yesterday made plain he was prepared to see prison numbers rise to tackle the hardcore of persistent criminals who, he claimed, were responsible for nearly half of all crime. He said there might come a time when fewer prison places were needed "but that is a long way off".

Within hours the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, marking the 10th anniversary of the day he handed his influential report on prison reform to the then home secretary, described jail overcrowding as the "Aids virus of the prison system" and called on courts to pass shorter sentences.

He said: "The judiciary must play their part in reducing the use of custody to what is the acceptable and appropriate minimum. When a custodial sentence is necessary the shortest sentence should be imposed.

"Frequently one month will achieve everything that can be achieved by three months and three months will achieve everything that can be by six months and so on."

Lord Woolf made clear last night in his Prison Reform Trust lecture that the best way of cutting crime was a higher detection rate rather than an increase in the prison population of 62,000, which is already forecast to rise to more than 78,000 by 2007.

"What has to be realised, and I include the government here, is that a short custodial sentence is a very poor alternative to a sentence to be served in the community. It is far more expensive. It will do nothing to tackle the offender's behavioural problems. It should be regarded as being no more than a necessary evil whose primary purpose is to obtain compliance with court orders."

His views were in sharp contrast to those of Mr Straw, who declared that community penalties did nothing for 80% of the 100,000 hardcore of the most persistent offenders.

"Almost without exception, every persistent offender sentenced to custody has been through the mill of community sentences and has still reoffended," Mr Straw said in a lecture to the Social Market Foundation.

"If we are to get on top of this problem of persistent criminality and are to process more through the system prison numbers may well have to rise. We have factored that into our spending plans. In time, and it will take time, once the system has got on top of this problem, then there may be a need for fewer places, but that is a long way off."

Mr Straw's decision to target the "100,000 most persistent offenders" is one of the first fruits of work by the former BBC director general, Lord Birt, as the home secretary's special adviser on crime. Initial findings of Home Office research commissioned by Lord Birt suggest that this hardcore accounts for about 10% of all active criminals and yet has a much greater impact on the crime rate than was previously thought.

"Half are under 21. Nearly two-thirds are hard drug users. More than a third were in care as children. Half have no qualifications at all. And three quarters have no work and little or no legal income," Mr Straw said.

He added that although they were convicted again and again by the courts there was little appreciable increase in the length of sentence they received each time.

Tony Blair told the cabinet this week that the "war on crime" would be a central part of Labour's election manifesto and at the heart of it would be a radical reform of sentencing to ensure that the persistent offenders received longer sentences each time they were convicted by the courts.

Mr Straw said he wanted to end the "just deserts" philosophy contained in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act - the piece of legislation that had incorporated most of the reforms Lord Woolf recom mended in his report. The 1991 act had ensured that the courts did not hand out prison sentences out of all proportion to the crime, and contained a "milk bottle clause" which was quietly dropped. This ensured that a judge did not sentence a thief to six months in prison for stealing a bottle of milk even if it was the 12th time he had been convicted of the offence.

Mr Straw said yesterday it was time to make the sentence fit the offender rather than the offence.

He acknowledged that the clause in question had been dropped, but said the courts still sentenced within its spirit and few persistent offenders got longer sentences every time they appeared in court.

"What has to be realised, and I include the government here, is that a short custodial sentence is a very poor alternative to a sentence to be served in the community. It is far more expensive. It will do nothing to tackle the offender's behavioural problems. It should be regarded as being no more than a necessary evil whose primary purpose is to obtain compliance with court orders." His views were in sharp contrast to those of Mr Straw, who declared that community penalties did nothing for 80% of the 100,000 hardcore of the most persistent offenders. "Almost without exception, every persistent offender sentenced to custody has been through the mill of community sentences and has still reoffended," Mr Straw said in a lecture to the Social Market Foundation. "If we are to get on top of this problem of persistent criminality and are to process more through the system prison numbers may well have to rise. We have factored that into our spending plans. In time, and it will take time, once the system has got on top of this problem, then there may be a need for fewer places, but that is a long way off." Mr Straw's decision to target the "100,000 most persistent offenders" is one of the first fruits of work by the former BBC director general, Lord Birt, as the home secretary's special adviser on crime. Initial findings of Home Office research commissioned by Lord Birt suggest that this hardcore accounts for about 10% of all active criminals and yet has a much greater impact on the crime rate than was previously thought. "Half are under 21. Nearly two-thirds are hard drug users. More than a third were in care as children. Half have no qualifications at all. And three quarters have no work and little or no legal income," Mr Straw said. He added that although they were convicted again and again by the courts there was little appreciable increase in the length of sentence they received each time. Tony Blair told the cabinet this week that the "war on crime" would be a central part of Labour's election manifesto and at the heart of it would be a radical reform of sentencing to ensure that the persistent offenders received longer sentences each time they were convicted by the courts. Mr Straw said he wanted to end the "just deserts" philosophy contained in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act - the piece of legislation that had incorporated most of the reforms Lord Woolf recom mended in his report. The 1991 act had ensured that the courts did not hand out prison sentences out of all proportion to the crime, and contained a "milk bottle clause" which was quietly dropped. This ensured that a judge did not sentence a thief to six months in prison for stealing a bottle of milk even if it was the 12th time he had been convicted of the offence. Mr Straw said yesterday it was time to make the sentence fit the offender rather than the offence. He acknowledged that the clause in question had been dropped, but said the courts still sentenced within its spirit and few persistent offenders got longer sentences every time they appeared in court.

fields.headline: BBC 'begged' for another series of Playing the Field
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
2pm update: The BBC 'begged' for another series of the football drama and wanted to turn it into a soap opera, writes Julia Day.
11.45am: Whistle blown on Playing the Field
fields.body:
The BBC "begged" for another series of the Kay Mellor-scripted drama Playing the Field and wanted to transform it into a half-hour long soap opera.

"The BBC asked us to turn Playing the Field into a soap - it was begging us," said Andrew Zein, commercial director of Tiger Aspect Productions.

The company decided the next series, due to air in the autumn, would be the last. It will mark the end of one of the BBC's most acclaimed long-running programmes.

"Some programmes - like Ally McBeal or The Bill - are designed to be endless shows and Playing the Field was also quite open-ended," said Tiger Aspect head of drama Greg Brenman.

"But this is a positive thing - we wanted to end with a bang and move on to new projects."

webTitle: Interviews: Prisoners on their life in jail

fields.headline: Interviews: Prisoners on their life in jail
fields.standfirst:
Steve Taylor, 24
Sentence: four months
Crime: deception
fields.trailText:
Steve Taylor, 24
Sentence: four months
Crime: deception
fields.body:
I spent some of my sentence in Armley jail in Leeds which is a hellhole. You spend 23 hours a day in your cell. You get books out of the library that have the last 20 pages missing. You get visits if the officers can be bothered. You get mail when they can be bothered. It's just a warehouse for people.

Fortunately I spent most of my sentence in HMP North Sea Camp which is an open prison. The buildings are a mess but the way it's run and the resources available are fantastic, and it's probably got the lowest re-conviction rates of all prisons. You've got to work because if you refuse they take you back to the local prison; there's a big farm which supplies the prison service with food and an excellent education department where I worked as a tutor, teaching basic skills to inmates who couldn't read or write.

I witnessed two ends of the spectrum when it came to drugs, too. I only saw drugs once at North Sea Camp and it was jumped on that hard that nobody would dare. At Leeds, you only have to look at the inmates to see there is a huge problem. There's almost a tacit approval of heroin because it isn't picked up easily in tests and the officers would rather just leave the addicts to it because that way they give less grief.

At night, I saw one syringe doing the whole side of a wing. They'd drop the needle into a tin, hang it outside the window on a piece of string and swing it round. The inmate in the next cell would catch it, use the needle and send it on.

The other problem is that the prison service doesn't recognise homosexuals exist. I'm gay and when I arrived at Leeds, I was asked by a senior officer: "Are you a raving queen or can you keep it to yourself?" If you did admit to being a "raving queen", you'd end up separated from the other prisoners for your own protection. The trouble is the separate wing is generally for sex offenders, so any gay man who goes there is seen as a sex offender which is a big problem. A chap I know of came out of a protected wing, was raped, then contracted HIV. There really needs to be some policy movement in that area.

webTitle: Five arrested in bomb factory swoop

fields.headline: Five arrested in bomb factory swoop
fields.trailText: Five Irishmen were arrested today when armed police stormed a suspected bomb factory in a quiet west London suburb, then swooped on another address nearby.
fields.body:
Five Irishmen were arrested today when armed police stormed a suspected bomb factory in a quiet west London suburb, then swooped on another address nearby.

Components thought to be necessary for making pipe bombs were seized in the dawn raid in Sutherland Road, Ealing. Later, about 20 armed police searched an address in Fosse Way, about half a mile away.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "This was a carefully planned armed operation and we believe we may have thwarted a pipe bomb attack."

The men were arrested on suspicion of conspiring to cause explosions and taken to a central London police station for questioning.

No shots were fired during the raid and no one was injured, but residents of a neighbouring flat were unable to get inside their home after being evacuated as a safety measure, police said.

Detectives are not linking today's arrests with three bomb attacks in the capital last year at this stage. A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said: "At this stage there is no evidence to suggest that today's arrest and seizures are linked to Irish Republican dissident terrorism."

The Real IRA was thought to be behind three major bomb attacks in London last year, bringing havoc to the capital. On June 1, a blast went off at Hammersmith Bridge, caused by a high-explosive bomb.

A second explosion disrupted services around Ealing Broadway station on July 19, affecting more than 150,000 commuters. The blast was set off in the midst of tight security surrounding the Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebrations.

The final bomb attack occurred on September 20 when the capital's MI6 building on the River Thames was rocked by two explosions.

fields.headline: My time behind bars
fields.standfirst:
Pete Sampson, 34
Former prison officer
fields.trailText:
Pete Sampson, 34
Former prison officer
fields.body:
Despite grave doubts, I joined the prison service as a graduate, intending to rise through the ranks as a radical mover and shaker. My career lasted just under a year.

Officer training then was largely at a residential centre, with a brief period at a local prison. I remember a visit to "Fraggle Rock", as the section for mentally disturbed prisoners was called. A senior officer proudly showed me his new copy of a Guide to Mental Illness. I also saw an inmate, in extreme distress, lying on his cell-floor, faeces covering the walls and flies circling.

During training, there was a heavy emphasis on fitness that almost disappeared once in the post, the average officer carrying a stone or three too many. Prison life is mundane and for much of the time, little happens, the consent of the prisoners making things work. But the physical training is ill-conceived and ineffective. Why spend so much time training people to physically restrain inmates, but none on how to anticipate or diffuse violent situations?

But my worst doubts about my career were confirmed by the equal opportunities training section. After a series of talks about legislation, the principal officer taking the session handed around a list of racist and sexist jokes to the all-white group. A sub-text was being conveyed - this is what being a prison officer is really all about.

While many prisoners are untroubled by being imprisoned, some are clearly traumatised. One inmate would languish on his bed, gazing up at nothing visible to anyone but himself. He became more and more distanced, muttering to himself, fingers clasped together. Referred to as a "loony-tune", he was transferred to Feltham.

Yet other inmates reacted with pure fury, hurling abuse at staff or throwing "shit parcels" out of their cells at passing officers.

But the prison service sets itself up to fail. The training, the culture, the nature of most new recruits, and the under-resourcing of prisons means that rehabilitation of prisoners is a virtual impossibility. Longstanding members of staff present newcomers with ways of doing things that are extremely difficult to break down. These old ways are not always aggressive, neglectful or abusive. However, they are nearly always obstacles to practice in prisons improving.

As ever, it is easier to say what is wrong than to suggest how to put it right. But firstly, we - because what happens in prisons happens in our names - have to decide what we want from the prison service. Once we make that decision, then things would have to change.

webTitle: Ofsted defence of LEAs is no comfort to Tories

fields.headline: Ofsted defence of LEAs is no comfort to Tories
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Ofsted
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of schools in England produced a report yesterday which he said offered no comfort to those, including William Hague, who wanted to abolish local education authorities.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools in England produced a report yesterday which he said offered no comfort to those, including William Hague, who wanted to abolish local education authorities.

Mike Tomlinson's first big report, summing up the results of 91 LEA inspections, criticised the unacceptably wide variation in services and said most councils had little effect on school standards.

But unlike his predecessor, Chris Woodhead, who questioned whether LEAs should exist at all, Mr Tomlinson defended the part they played in organising school admissions and transport.

"They do have important roles in strategic planning across an area which could never been taken by an individual school," Mr Tomlinson said.

"The report gives no comfort to those who believe that the existence of LEAs serves no purpose. It does not support the abolitionist argument. Nor does it support some of the more exaggerated claims made by LEAs."

The chief inspector's comments amounted to criticism of the Tory "free schools" policy, which would, in effect, abolish LEAs. But Mr Tomlinson denied he was being party political. Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, hailed the success of the inspections, introduced by the government in 1997.

Mr Tomlinson said 59 of the 91 authorities inspected were performing satisfactorily, of which 19 could be described as good. But 17 performed so badly they required intervention from government.

Mr Tomlinson sympathised with LEAs for suffering a decade of "something approaching turmoil" as governments chopped and changed their role. Provision of special educational needs was the most worrying area. The LEAs inspected had responded well to its recommendations on tackling racism.

Ofsted had searched for evidence of an "LEA effect" on school performance but found no strong link, although a well-run authority in a prosperous area could have an impact. Ms Morris said the worst authorities had been inspected first. She was unhappy but not surprised by the difference in standards of LEAs.

The government has "outsourced" - privatised - some or all services in 18 poor-performing education authorities.

Ms Morris said she would continue to encourage even "authorities in a position of relative strength" to outsource some services when required.

The best performing authorities were, according to the Ofsted report: the corporation of London, Coventry, Kensington and Chelsea, Warwickshire, Lewisham, Birmingham, Oxfordshire, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hartlepool, Newham, Wandsworth, Barking and Dagenham, York, North Yorkshire, Solihull, Hertfordshire, Camden and Bury.
