fields.headline: Wales reveals its 'radical' NHS plan
fields.trailText: The NHS in Wales is to get a "radical" overhaul with the publication of a programme of reforms designed to bring the health service under the direct control of the Welsh assembly.
fields.body:
The NHS in Wales is to get a "radical" overhaul with the publication of a programme of reforms designed to bring the health service under the direct control of the Welsh assembly.

Welsh first minister Rhodri Morgan is to launch the reforms, which include controversial proposals to retain community health councils, the local patient watchdog bodies that are to be abolished in England on the grounds that they are outdated.

Mr Morgan says in the introduction to the plan that it will continue the assembly's work on improving health in Wales and break "new ground in the necessary work of transforming our nation".

Assembly health minister Jane Hutt said: "We need to ensure that the national assembly itself provides a new sense of leadership, direction and oversight.

"The plan will involve a new assertion of the national assembly's direct democratic control of its health responsibilties."

The plan, Improving health in Wales, heralds the abolition of the principality's five health authorities in a bid to cut management costs and strip away bureaucracy.

The health authorities commissioning role will taken on by GP-led, local health groups - the Welsh equivalent of English primary care groups.

A health and well-being partnership council is to be created, chaired by Ms Hutt, with a brief to improve health services.

There will be a shake-up of the public health function, while the role of local government in health services will be "enhanced" through the creation of partnership boards.

webTitle: Charities cast the net wider in search for trustees

fields.headline: Charities cast the net wider in search for trustees
fields.standfirst: Voluntary organisations are resorting to advertising in order to attract a new ilk of board members, says Patrick McCurry
fields.trailText: Voluntary organisations are resorting to advertising in order to attract a new ilk of board members, says Patrick McCurry
fields.body:
Recruiting trustees with a mix of skills has become a growing challenge for voluntary organisations, which are increasingly seeking board members with particular expertise.

As the legislative environment becomes more complex and as pressure grows for charities to become more professional, finding trustees with skills in finance, fundraising, employment and other areas has climbed the agenda for many organisations.

There is also a growing recognition of the need to diversify trustee boards, many of which are still dominated by white, middle-aged and middle-class members.

Outside the traditional word-of-mouth recruitment method, advertising for trustees is becoming more common.

"Advertising can be useful but may be expensive, not just because of paying for ads but also in the work required to prepare and send out information on the charity and process responses," says Janet Cummins, chief executive of consultants Charity and Fundraising Appointments.

She points out that prospective trustees may be attracted to a particular cause but will want to know much more about the specific charity and what may be expected of them as trustees.

"Some charities are looking for trustees who will take an active, hands-on approach while others want people they can bounce ideas off and this all needs to be spelled out to prospective trustees," says Ms Cummins.

Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse has run advertisements seeking trustees for the past two years. Advertising is part of the charity's strategy of recruiting trustees with a mix of skills.

"The last time we advertised we were particularly interested in people with skills at a senior level in human resources, finance and brand marketing," says volunteer co-ordinator Stephanie Witts.

The decision to focus on specific skills when appointing trustees sprang from recognition that diverse expertise was needed on the board to ensure the charity was well run and managed, says Ms Witts.

Even if advertising does not lead to appointments the charity can benefit in other ways, she argues. "The advertisement in the Guardian this year generated between 30 and 40 responses and, while we didn't end up appointing anyone, two of the shortlisted candidates agreed to volunteer in other ways."

John Naylor, secretary and treasurer of the Carnegie UK Trust, says that the decision to advertise was part of a move to diversify the board, particularly by recruiting some younger members. He says that a side benefit of the decision to advertise is that it can concentrate the minds of charity bosses. "It forces the charity to look at the balance of its trustees and ask itself what it expects of trustees," he says.

While the Carnegie Trust has never found it difficult recruiting trustees, the decision was made to advertise in order to have a bigger pool to recruit from and in order to introduce more openness and transparency into the process.

"An open approach is particularly beneficial for trusts, which can sometimes seem to the outsider to be a bit inward looking," says Mr Naylor.

Advertisements in the Guardian and the Times last year attracted around 100 written applications from high-calibre individuals. The only drawback was that many of the applications were from middle-aged and older people, while the trust was keen to focus on younger trustees.

One trustee was appointed as a result and a handful of others are being held in reserve for when other trustee vacancies occur.

Mr Naylor argues strongly that, for older well-established trusts like Carnegie, it is important to recruit more widely.

Another advantage of advertising compared with approaching potential trustees directly, he believes, is that trustees may be more likely to participate fully.

"Sometimes trustees who have been approached to join the board may feel special," says Naylor. "While trustees must be welcomed and supported, they should not be seen as a privileged class."

 The Trustee Act comes into force on February 1, 2000

fields.headline: History of Britain's steel industry
fields.standfirst: Map: where are the Corus job losses?
fields.trailText: 1967: British Steel Corporation is formed when the ruling Labour government nationalises the 14 biggest steel producers in the UK.
fields.body:
1967: British Steel Corporation is formed when the ruling Labour government nationalises the 14 biggest steel producers in the UK.

1970s: Increased production despite falling world demand and a world recession cripples British Steel. The company slashes the workforce from 142,000 in 1980 to 52,000 in 1988.

1984: Norman Tebbit, then trade and industry secretary, warns that the miners' strike could result in closure of British Steel plants. Llanwern in south Wales is thought to be one of those at risk.

March 1988: Ahead of the planned floatation later in the year, the Economist Intelligence Unit reports 82m tonnes of steelmaking over-capacity in the western world.

1988: Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government privatises British Steel. The company is the first to be privatised after the stock market crash in 1987 and is priced at the bottom range of the market.

May 1990: More than 1,100 jobs are axed at the Brymbo steelworks in Wrexham part owned by British Steel.

May 1992: Despite promising to keep the Ravenscraig steel plant open until 1994, British Steel announces the plant's closure with the loss of 1,800 jobs. A further 608 jobs are shed in Shotton, Wales.

December 1993: The European Union offers £5bn in subsidies for state-owned steel companies in eastern Germany, Italy, Spain and Portugal in exchange for cuts in production capacity.

January 1995: British Steel announces plans to spend £22m on a second slab casting machine at its Llanwern works in south Wales and £65m on moving two direct reduced iron units from Hunterston in Scotland to the US gulf coast.

October 1999: British Steel and Koninklijke Hoogovens of the Netherlands merge to create the Corus Group, creating the biggest steelmaker in Europe and the third largest in the world.

June 2000: Corus says it plans to slash its workforce by 4,500 (leaving only 33,000 workers in the UK) after making losses to the tune of £20m a month.

January 2001: The Labour government criticises Corus for not informing ministers about restructuring plans that could cost up to 7,000 jobs in the UK.

February 1 2001: Corus, Britain's biggest steel-maker confirms that 6,050 jobs will be cut at plants across the country. Wales will be hardest hit, with 1,340 redundancies at the huge plant in Llanwern, near Newport. The company employs 3,500 workers at Port Talbot, 3,000 at Llanwern in Newport and 3,500 elsewhere in Britain.

fields.headline: Cafés,  Boutiques, and Theatres
fields.trailText: GROUNDS FOR COMPLAINT
fields.body:
GROUNDS FOR COMPLAINT

Birthday party coming up, but can't find a venue? Got a couple of relatives visiting for the weekend, but nowhere to put them up? Or maybe there's a work function on the horizon and all the local Café Rouges are booked? Well, why not take advantage of the luxurious combination of concrete and turf on offer at Wembley stadium? Yes, it looks like the historic old lunk is going to be hanging around for some time yet, so you might as well make use of it.

The demolition of Wembley has been put back by another six months, the FA announced today, with the spanking new stadium (if it hasn't become a big bingo hall by then) not expected to be completed before December 2004. The delay has been blamed on the recent change in design from the Ken Bates-inspired "chuck a hotel on the end of it" plans to the new streamlined "chuck a set of rugby posts in it" version. But whatever the reason, the ground will not be ready for the 2004 FA Cup final, as had been expected. As Adam Crozier put it today: "The start date has been moved back, so the end date has had to move back as well."

The new Ken Bates, Sir Rodney Walker, believes, like his predecessor, that plans for the new Wembley will prove popular enough with investors to raise the funding needed. Sir Rodders recently presented the new plans to the boards of the FA and Wembley National Stadium Limited (ie: the people who approved the old plans) and is ready to go to the city in April. "I am enormously encouraged by the reaction of the FA board. Everybody wants the project to succeed," said Sir Rodders, stating the obvious. "I am confident that with the new support package we have outlined today [the details of which have not been disclosed], the likelihood of City backing has been greatly enhanced." Well, let's flipping well hope so.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TOTALLY HAPPY

It was supposed to be the winter sale to end all sales. All old stock - yes, all of it - had to go! But today, the storerooms of swanky west London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea have a surprisingly familiar feel. Look, there's cheeky chap Dennis Wise cheeky-chapping away! And there's Ed de Goey moping around, because his move to Anderlecht fell through because of his wage demands. And after his £2.5m move to Monaco collapsed last night, even Frank Leboeuf is still in the shop window (although they have buffed his forehead something lovely).

There are many ways you could describe Leboeuf's strained relationship with Chelsea's in recent months. However, a "love affair" probably isn't one of them - unless your romantic evenings are regularly interrupted by the social services, that is. "It's been a very nice love affair and I'm very pleased I'm still a Chelsea player," Leboeuf said. And just to prove how happy and unbitter he is he then accused Monaco president Jean-Louis Campora of showing "total disrespect" to himself and Chelsea by pulling out of the deal at the last minute.

"Having seen the politics, I'm glad to be staying at Stamford Bridge," Frank insisted as the shadow of a large pig crossed his shiny pate. "I have nothing to be embarrassed about, but as a Frenchman, I feel ashamed of Monaco's behaviour, particularly the president. He has been so unprofessional." After bashing us over the head with his fake sincerity, Leboeuf then went for the jugular, lauding Claudio Ranieri as "great" and even claiming: "There is no problem at all with me staying. I might yet finish my career here." Is there no end to the man's cheek?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I think Lazio are better, and I'm not just saying that just because I'm here now. This team has a much higher technical level than the English side, they don't have such technically good players" - Former Manchester United substitute Karel Poborksy doesn't think much of the Red Devils. Funny that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

UNITED MAKE MORE NOTES

It's irritating when you have a great money-making idea but someone pips you to it. So having sat up all last night to knock off a few songs about popular football club Manchester United, we were well narked when we heard that some chancers called The Big Red Musical Company are staging a musical called The Theatre of Dreams. What the hell are we going to do with "Here comes Roy, his shirt is red / look at the veins pop out his head" now?

Producer Patrick Nally put paid to our plans this morning, as he revealed to the world his (so-called) original concept about United's rollercoaster ride under the stewardship of Matt Busby. "This is a musical about a magical man and it is a magical story," he luvvied. Nally plans to take his dangerously syrupy show - which boasts schmaltz like Up From The Ashes and Keep The Flags Flying Red - to Asia, Japan and Korea, as well as eastern Europe. "I have even had a call this morning from Poland which blew me away!" cooed the over-excited producer.

The whole farce will begin on April 9, when British tenor Russell Watson - "opportunity", "great honour", "incredible", "simper" - plays Busby in a charity performance in Manchester. The fun-loving Imperial Lord Ferg will share the stage: for one show only, he's playing himself. But while Ferg's presence will undoubtedly light up the whole arena, it's a shame that none of the current United stars are to appear in the production. When will we get the chance to guffaw loudly at, for example, Andy Cole as he hilariously tries to sing, rap and be street? Sorry, for a minute there we completely forgot about his number 187 hit single Outstanding.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Coventry have reportedly resurrected their interest in Wimbledon striker John Hartson. The London Evening Standard claims the Premiership strugglers have offered the Dons £5m in cash.

Spurs are lining up a bid for Brann's Norway international striker Thorstein Helstad, according to reports. However, they face competition from Sunderland and West Ham.

Ajax striker Shota Arveladze is Aston Villa's latest target. The Georgia international, who has scored 16 goals in 34 internationals, admitted to onefootball: "My agent Ivan Benesh called me up yesterday and told me that Aston Villa are seriously considering buying me."

Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic could move to Aston Villa, Everton or Blackburn on loan. Berkovic's agent Pinhas Zahavi said: "The fact is that Eyal has now agreed in principle to go on loan and we are now ready to do that. We will know in the next few days where he will go."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers are one of five new members of the G-14, the group of European football's elite clubs. Parma, Roma, Lazio and Hertha Berlin were also admitted. Arsenal, Valencia, Deportivo La Coruna and Galatasaray were denied membership.

Ladbrokes have agreed to pay out on all bets placed on Manchester United to win the Premiership and Fulham to win the First Division. "It's probably true to say that if either of these teams does get caught we'll be looking at the costliest cock-up in betting history," Sean Boyce, spokesman for Ladbrokes, said. "We normally wait until the fat lady sings before parting with the cash. But in the case of both Fulham and Manchester United the fat lady has been clearing her throat for weeks, so we're coughing up now."

Fifa have announced the twelve teams that will play in the second World Club Championship from July 29 to August 12 in Spain. They are Jubilo Iwata (Japan), Al-Hilal (Saudi Arabia), Accra Hearts of Oak (Ghana), Zamalek (Egypt), Los Angeles Galaxy (USA), CD Olimpia (Honduras), Palmeiras (Brazil), Boca Juniors (Argentina), Wollongong Wolves (Australia), Real Madrid (Spain), Galatasaray (Turkey) and Deportivo La Coruna (Spain). The format will be three groups of four teams, with the top team in each group and the best second-placed team qualifying for the semi-finals.

Sunderland midfielder Eric Roy has joined French First Division club Troyes until the end of the season. Roy made just one Premiership appearance for Sunderland this season, and the club have agreed to release him from his contract early.

Bolton manager Sam Allardyce has won the Nationwide First Division Manager of the Month award for January. The Second Division award went to Bournemouth's Sean O'Driscoll, with the Third Division prize going to Hartlepool manager Chris Turner.

Rangers have handed £2.2m defender Daniel Prodan a free transfer. The decision ends Prodan's two-and-a-half-year Ibrox career, during which he failed to kick a ball for the first team.

Hibs manager Alex McLeish and assistant Andy Watson have agreed contract extensions that will keep them at the club until at least the summer of 2003.

Arrigo Sacchi could resign as Parma coach tonight because of stress, according to reports from Italy. Sacchi took charge of the Gialloblu just three weeks ago.

Bari have denied selling their teenage forward Antonio Cassano to Serie A leaders AS Roma for £20m. "Talks are still underway with Roma and with other interested clubs," the club said in a statement. Cassano has also been linked with Juventus, AC Milan and Manchester United.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

fields.headline: Charities make TV earthquake appeal
fields.trailText: Fourteen charities will launch a television appeal tonight to raise money for survivors of the earthquake in Gujarat, India.
fields.body:
Fourteen charities will launch a television appeal tonight to raise money for survivors of the earthquake in Gujarat, India.

TV presenter, Nick Ross and author, Meera Syal will simultaneously launch the appeal on BBC and ITV at 6.55pm.

The Disasters Emergency Committee is a consortium of 14 overseas aid charities that coordinates responses to disasters and fundraising appeals. Key members include ActionAid, the British Red Cross and Help the Aged.

The aim of the appeal is to raise money to buy food, medical supplies and building materials for those left homeless by the earthquake. Chief executive of DEC, Brendan Gormley, said: "We know the British public will respond and respond quickly and generously."

One of the members of the consortium, Oxfam, has already raised £34,000 with £15,500 of this coming through donations to its website, including one donation of £3,000.

James Darcy, Oxfam's emergencies coordinator for Asia, said: "The priority is money, we need the cash to buy the blankets, the tents, the food and equipment to provide clean water. This is going to be a massive international relief effort if we're going to sustain the lives of the survivors. At times like this, there is no such thing as compassion fatigue."

Nikki Hill, of Help the Aged, is flying to India on Saturday to help with the relief effort and will send an exclusive diary to SocietyGuardian.co.uk next week.

The teams of aid workers already in Gujarat are now shifting their attention to caring for those who need medical attention and help with rebuilding homes.

&#149 Emergency appeal tel: 0870 6060900
£1 will buy enough rice to feed a family for a week.
£12 will provide one emergency kit - which includes a 10 gallon water carrier, water purification tablets, a ground mat, blanket, a lantern and matches.
£25 is the cost of running a medical unit for one day helping 280 people.
£50 provides temporary shelter with plastic sheeting for three families.

fields.headline: When service users enter the board room
fields.trailText: Involving service users in the decision making of charities can bring major benefits, but can also throw up challenges and often involves a significant cultural shift.
fields.body:
Involving service users in the decision making of charities can bring major benefits, but can also throw up challenges and often involves a significant cultural shift.

A growing number of voluntary organisations, particularly in health and disability, are seeking to recruit more of their service users as trustees or in other influential roles. The drivers include pressure from funders and the growing confidence of many users themselves.

But involving users can be a complex process and, if tokenism is to be avoided, one that must be carefully thought through and supported from the chair and chief executive to other trustees and staff.

"It is important that the charity have someone with responsibility for board development, who can guide the process when these kinds of changes are being put into practice," said Paul Robson, principal research fellow at the University of East London's Centre for Institutional Studies.

The challenges charities must tackle include possible confrontations between groups of users and other groups, such as medics, who may have different priorities for the charity's development.

It is also important that, as beneficiaries of existing services, user trustees are aware of their responsibility to future beneficiaries of the charity. This issue is highlighted in a charity commission guidance document, Users on board, published last year and available from the website.

Mr Robson, however, argues that this concern can be overplayed: "Potential conflicts of interest have always been applied to trustees and sometimes it seems this is played up when it comes to user trustees."

Mr Robson, who has advised many charities on user involvement in governance, believes changes can often be superficial: "There are cases where, even if users represent a third or a half of the trustee board, power remains concentrated in other hands and the users may feel they don't have enough influence."

He adds that a lot of the larger, national charities have made changes for PR reasons: "They feel they have to be seen to be doing something."

An increasing number of charities founded by carers are attempting to involve users more. At the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, for example, targets were introduced two-and-a-half years ago to ensure 30% of representatives on the trustee board and local committees were users.

"We've made progress but are not quite there yet," said public affairs director Paul Farmer, noting that three of the 15 trustees are users.

He said the changes have focused attention on the way the charity conducts its business. For example, to make discussions more accessible to users, frequent breaks in trustee meetings were introduced.

"We found out this was welcomed not just by users but also by other trustees," Mr Farmer said.

Mencap has gone further, with a range of changes to the way meetings are conducted, in order to involve people with learning difficulties. The charity, which was set up by parents of people with learning difficulties in the 1940s, changed its structure last year to a "one member, one vote" model.

"Half our 15,500 members are people with learning difficulties who are entitled to vote in elections to the national assembly, which in turn elects the board of trustees," said internal communications manager Moira McMillan.

Seventeen of the 45 assembly members and one of the seven trustees are people with learning disabilities.

They are helped in discussions by a system of "traffic light" cards. For example, a member will hold up a card with a question mark if they want to ask a question or a card with a red light if they want the meeting to pause or slow down.

Agenda items are written in plain English, avoid legalese and items are colour-coded to aid members, said Ms McMillan, adding that extra training and induction has been put in place for all committee members.

"We've a long way to go but we're making progress," she said.

fields.headline: Vivendi chief quits BSkyB board
fields.trailText:
5pm: Eric Licoys, chief operating officer of Vivendi Universal, has resigned from BSkyB's board, reports Dan Milmo. Jan 31: Murdoch to press ahead with flotation
Vivendi and Liberty: a cut-out-and-keep guide
fields.body:
Eric Licoys, chief operating officer of Vivendi Universal, has resigned from the BSkyB board as the French media giant prepares to sell its stake in the satellite broadcaster.

Vivendi said it was no hurry to sell its 22.7% holding but the resignation of Mr Licoys will make it easier to pursue negotiations.

The US cable company Liberty Media Group is expected to take the £4.4bn stake. It already owns 20% of BSkyB's parent company News Corporation.

French newspapers are reporting a cash deal is imminent.

Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier is keen to find a buyer who will be able to work with News Corp owner Rupert Murdoch.

Vivendi is expected to spend its £4.4bn windfall on a share buyback, which will boost its flagging share price.

Analysts have pointed to the vulnerability of Vivendi's stock ever since the company merged with Seagram of Canada in a blockbusting £50bn deal last year.

A quick sale of the BSkyB stake will also boost Mr Murdoch's plans to float his Sky Global Networks satellite TV company.

BSkyB will form a core part of the company and a flotation will be hampered if there are doubts about the company's shareholder structure.

Relevant stories
Jan 31: Murdoch to press ahead with flotation
Jan 29: News Corp in running for DirecTV stake

webTitle: Prince joins A-list celebs for PCC party

fields.headline: Prince joins A-list celebs for PCC party
fields.trailText: 5pm: Prince William will be joined by a host of celebrities and politicians who have clashed with the UK press when he attends the Press Complaints Commission's 10th birthday bash next week. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Prince William will be joined by a host of celebrities and politicians who have clashed with the UK press when he attends the Press Complaints Commission's 10th birthday bash next week.

The prince will attend the lavish reception at Somerset House with his father - who himself is a successful complainant to the PCC - and Camilla Parker Bowles, the first time the three will have been at an official function together, though they will arrive and leave separately.

Other guests include the Duke of York, TV presenter Selina Scott and home secretary Jack Straw, all of whom have had complaints upheld against the press.

Less successful complainants will be there too, including morning TV stars Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan, whose grievances were not upheld by the commission.

The host, PCC chairman Lord Wakeham, will introduce his guests to editors and journalists who are often seen as hostile by royals and stars alike.

Prince William is also set to come face to face with someone he once famously impersonated - Ali G.

Organisers of the party, which is being held to celebrate the success of self-regulation in the industry, have invited actor Sacha Baron Cohen, whose spoof DJ character was copied by the young prince during a stint at a local radio station on his gap year adventure in Chile.

The guest list also includes actors Ewan McGregor, Vinnie Jones, Joanna Lumley and Anna Friel, fashion designer Donatella Versace, TV presenters Sir David Frost and Carol Vorderman and Conservative leader William Hague.

A host of Coronation Street stars, including Kevin Kennedy who plays Curly Watts, have also confirmed they will be attending.

fields.headline: Skull cap used by 'race jokers'
fields.standfirst:
Angry broker traded insults with boss, tribunal told

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Brokers at the City firm which ordered a Jewish employee to put on an Adolf Hitler uniform used to place a skull cap on top of the office television whenever a Jewish person appeared on CNN, an employment tribunal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Brokers at the City firm which ordered a Jewish employee to put on an Adolf Hitler uniform used to place a skull cap on top of the office television whenever a Jewish person appeared on CNN, an employment tribunal heard yesterday.

Laurent Weinberger, 33, is suing Tullett & Tokyo Liberty for racial discrimination and unfair dismissal, claiming that he was subjected to a catalogue of anti-semitic abuse including the names "Yiddo" and "Jew boy", before being demoted.

A preliminary hearing yesterday heard how two of Mr Weinberger's colleagues and his line manager admitted name-calling, hiring a Nazi uniform and misusing the skull cap, but said it was part of the "idle banter and horseplay" on which their department thrived.

The term "Yiddo", they said, was not race-specific since it had been applied to non-Jewish members of staff as slang for Tottenham Hotspur supporters.

Makbool Javaid, Mr Weinberger's solicitor, said: "The intention behind calling someone "Yiddo" is irrelevant. Any objective third party will know that these are offensive terms.

"To hand someone who lost his grandmother at Auschwitz a Nazi uniform cannot be innocent. It is like handing a black person a Ku Klux Klan uniform."

Mr Javaid referred to an invoice from Mad World fancy dress hire for an Adolf Hitler costume taken out in the name of Mr Weinberger and paid for by the company, which he was asked to wear as a forfeit for arriving late.

Sinclair Cramsie, acting for the company, said: "It might appear in extremely poor taste, but brokers find it an outlet for stress in a high-pressure environment. Such banter was often prearranged to create an aggressive and productive atmosphere."

Mr Cramsie said that while "peculiar", this was a practice in which Mr Weinberger had himself engaged, calling his manager, Mike Roffey, a "big-nosed tosser" and a "fucking wanker", his colleague a "fat Scot", and non-Jews in the office as "Yoks", Yiddish slang for gentiles. Mr Weinberger disputes this.

The defence that he was treated no differently to other staff, was, Mr Javaid said, "extraordinary." "The argument that an employer can escape liability by saying that everyone was treated badly, not just the applicant, drives a coach and horses through race, sex and disability discrimination acts."

Mr Weinberger, who is married with two children and lives in Middlesex, said: "What really upsets me is that they are still not accepting that what they did was wrong. I have got to stick up for what I believe in."

After being transferred from his £125,000-a-year job to a less well paid position, Mr Weinberger left the company to join the GFI Group as a currency trader.

Mr Weinberger's father, Isi, 59, said: "Not only did my son's grandmother die in Auschwitz, but 60% of my family were murdered and burnt. People can't believe that this is treated as a joke. It's unbelievable, in 2001. This is England."

The full hearing is scheduled for June.

fields.headline: Unilever sponsors mykindaplace
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Unilever is to sponsor the main rival to its now-defunct teen girl portal Wowgo.com, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Unilever is to sponsor the website that was the main rival to its now-defunct teen girl portal, Wowgo.com.

Mykindaplace, which is backed by BSkyB, Freeserve and ThinkVentures, has acquired Wowgo.com's database of registered users and a redirection link to mykindaplace.com from the Wowgo site.

Under the deal, Unilever will sponsor one of mykindaplace's channels.

Other existing sponsors include Gillette, Woolworths, Orange and Superdrug.

The financial details of the acquisitions and commercial sponsorship deal have not been divulged.

"We see this acquisition as a further opportunity to consolidate and grow our business and tap this extremely large and buoyant market," said Charlie Redmayne, commercial and marketing director at Mykindplace.com.

"Teenagers represent 31% of the online population. This means there are about 2m teen girls online, and of this audience in just six months we have already captured 20%."

Earlier this week mykindaplace.com announced it was to sponsor the new series of Buffy the Vampire Slayer on Sky One in a £250,000 deal.

It is currently running a TV and press advertising campaign.

fields.headline: Anger after 6,000 steel jobs axed
fields.trailText: The government today responded angrily to the "appalling and unprecedented" loss of 6,050 jobs announced this morning by the country's biggest steel-maker.
fields.body:
The government today responded angrily to the "appalling and unprecedented" loss of 6,050 jobs announced this morning by the country's biggest steel-maker.

Anglo-Dutch steel firm Corus announced more than 6,000 job losses as part of a huge cut-back in capacity.

Corus ended weeks of speculation by confirming that 6,050 jobs would be cut during the next year at plants across the country.

Wales will be hardest hit, with 1,340 redundancies at the large plant in Llanwern, near Newport, south Wales.

The nearby factory at Ebbw Vale will close with the loss of 780 jobs, while redundancies will also hit factories at Shotton in north Wales and at Teesside.

In an emergency Commons statement, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, told the company to rethink its decision. Mr Byers voiced his anger over Corus's behaviour and was openly critical of the company for its "short term response" to trading problems.

"Today's announcement by Corus stands in stark contrast to other manufacturing companies who are prepared to take a long term view," he said.

Mr Byers promised that the government would not "walk away" from those who lost their jobs and held out the prospect of future aid.

But he said "it need not come to that" and Corus could adopt a different approach. "On behalf of 6,000 steelworkers, their families and the communities in which they live, I urge Corus to think again and work with us to identify a better way forward."

The job cuts will be made between 2001 and 2003, and when finished, Corus will have 22,000 staff in the UK.

Corus's chairman, Sir Brian Moffat, said: "Today's announcement is painful and clearly devastating for the workers and their families. I sympathise with these people as I fought for the region to regain competitiveness for a number of years."

But he added: "It is important to be aware that without taking these actions there would be no future for the 22,000 people [employed by Corus] in the UK."

Reacting to criticism that Corus failed to tell the government about the scale of the redundancies, Sir Brian said that they had a duty to inform their workers first.

He said: "We were not prepared to go into detail with the government before first talking to our employees.

"We think we have handled it properly, albeit we have frustrated the government. The government has been kept informed about the overall reasons and the regions where the jobs would be impacted."

Wales will be hit hardest by the job losses, and reaction there was swift and unforgiving.

Former Welsh secretary Ron Davies today said that Corus had been "high-handed, arrogant, duplicitous and secretive" in dealing both with its employees and with the government, and he described today's announcement as "not only appalling but unprecedented".

"Here we have a major company as a matter of policy refusing even to discuss with the government of the country its plans, knowing that those plans are going to have such a devastating effect," Mr Davies said.

"Today's decision is brutal. It's a short-term decision that's going to have a devastating impact on those communities ... and the impact will be much wider," he said.

Mr Davies praised the first minister, Rhodri Morgan, for having worked "tirelessly, doing everything he could have done" to prevent the job losses.

Former Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd Wigley said later the government was duty bound to move towards re-nationalisation of the steel industry. "If such an important industry cannot be safeguarded in the private sector then I believe there is a responsibility on government to take those steps that are necessary," he said. "The steel industry is too important to be left in the hands of a crumbling corporation like Corus."

Blaenau Gwent Welsh assembly member Peter Law, whose constituency has lost 780 jobs at Ebbw Vale, said Sir Brian would bear a heavy responsibility for the rest of his life.

"At the stroke of a pen my community has been plunged into bottomless poverty ... an era of soup kitchens and handouts," he said. "I can't ever forgive that." Mr Law said that when British Steel merged with Hoogovens to form Corus "we were sold a lemon".

"It was not a blank cheque to wipe out the Welsh steel industry," he said. "How can they do this to steel workers whose only offence has been high productivity and total loyalty? How can they do this to such a poor community as Ebbw Vale and Blaenau Gwent?" In a restrained speech, the Welsh Conservative leader, Nick Bourne - who has been highly critical of the assembly administration's handling of the job losses - said: "Corus has not behaved well, but it is no good wringing hands, we need to offer help to these communities."

Dennis Owens, chairman of the development committee of Blaenau Gwent county borough council, said: "I never thought I'd see the day when Ebbw Vale was to close. Only last summer we were told of a plan for survival that would give Ebbw Vale a fair chance of keeping 750 jobs. Now, in proportionate terms, it is bearing the brunt of the Corus cutbacks."

Complete breakdown of the 6,050 job cuts at Corus:
 Llanwern iron and steel operations, 1,340
 Ebbw Vale factory, 780
 Shotton factory, 319  Teesside coil plate mill, 234
 Bryngwyn plant, 127
 Newport and Port Talbot offices, 200
 Teesside, Scunthorpe, and Motherwell construction and industrial division, 1,086
 head offices of the Construction and Industrial and Engineering steels divisions, 400
 Engineering Steels (principally in Rotheram), 390
 Tubes division in Corby, Hartlepool and Stockton, 298
 European Market unit (spread around the UK), 292
 European Electrical Steels (principally in Newport), 276
 Special profiles and Rail units, Workington, 73
 Special strip unit, south Wales, 35
 corporate offices, London, the Midlands and south Wales, 200

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Hard disk heaven | JVC vision
fields.body:
Hard disk heaven
In the US, major hi-fi and PC manufacturers have adopted an "if you can't beat 'em join 'em" tactic in response to the growing number of hard disk-based audio recorders on sale from small companies.

Yamaha is expected to become the first mainstream hi-fi company to explore the solid state audio route when it ships a hard disk/CD combi to the US in February.

The CDR-HD1000 combines a CD-writer with a built-in 20 gigabyte hard disk. The unit can rip tracks from CDs to its hard drive at 10x speed and then copy them back on to a CD-R at 8x speed.

However, unlike some of its rivals, the unit has no internet connection for downloading tracks, CD information and so on.

The CDR-HD1000 is on sale in the US for $1,000 and is expected to retail for around £800 when it lands in the UK in August.

Meanwhile, Compaq is set to launch a $1,000 hard disk-based audio system in the US as part of its iPaq range.

The Music Center incorporates a CD player, 20 gigabyte hard disk and broadband internet connectivity. The unit, which hooks up to both a hi-fi system and a TV, guides users through their music choices via a display on the TV screen. There is no news on UK availability.

In the USA, Compaq has also announced that it intends to offer a Pioneer DVD-R/CD-RW drive (CD/DVD recorder) similar to the one recently displayed in Apple's G4 Power Mac, as part of its Presario desktop PC range. Again, there is no news on UK availability.

Designer Palms
Anyone for a celebrity approved PDA? Following the launch last year of a Claudia Schiffer Palm Vx (finished in a fashionable aqua blue and available via her website), Palm is reportedly on the verge of securing a similar deal with the basketball star Michael Jordan. The company is also keen to add further celebrities to its designer PDA range. What price on a Posh 'n' Becks version in leopard skin?

JVC vision
JVC is planning to launch a concerted attack on the UK digital camcorder market with seven new models due in the next two months. They range from high-end Pro Style cams to the latest in the company's budget RealVision range.

Due next month are a pair of top-end models, the £1,400 GR-DV1800 and £1,600 GR-DV2000, both of which can deliver up to 576 lines of vertical resolution of moving images and a 1.92 megapixel still image. Other facilities include compatibility with both the new SD (Secure Digital) and MultiMedia storage cards, a 3.5 inch LCD monitor, 300x digital zoom and an info-shoe accessory for housing lights, zoom microphones etc. The DV2000 features both a digital video (DV) input and output, while the DV1800 is limited to a DV output.

The company's quintet of RealVision models range in price from the GR-DVL150 at £650 to the GR-DVL557 at £900. All five camcorders feature JVC's new digital nightscope facility that delivers brighter, more colourful images of footage shot in darkness than rival systems.

The more expensive models, the £750 GR-DVL355, £800 GR-DVL357 and £900 GR-DVL557 also feature a digital snapshot facility, a USB output and compatibility with both SD and MultiMedia storage cards.

JVC also showed some of the products it may launch later in the year, including an SD-based MP3 player, a Windows CE-based laptop with a seven-inch screen, and a hard disk/S-VHS video recorder, the HM-HDS1.

Helpful Hippo
Tired of having to visit the post office to collect those goods you ordered online? You might want to find a place in your life for the e-commerce industry's unlikely new ally - the Hippo.

Available now is the £180 Hippo Box, a large safe-style holder that sits outside your home and acts as a receptacle for all online-ordered deliveries, from groceries to consumer electronics.

Your postie takes the crate you ordered from www.priceychardonnay.com and places it inside the Hippo. Once the goods are safely inside the box it locks and requires a key to open it. To prevent burglars from absconding with the unit, it comes with a pair of bolts so it can be attached to a wall. More information from www.giraffemarketing.co.uk

webTitle: Health: Is coffee the devil's brew?

fields.headline: Is coffee really the devil's brew?
fields.standfirst:
Many of us can't start the day without it, but new research says it stops us working well. Oliver Burkeman searches for the truth about caffeine

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Many of us can't start the day without it, but new research says it stops us working well. Oliver Burkeman searches for the truth about caffeine.
fields.body:
The coffee-drinker's last excuse seems finally to have vanished. For years beleaguered office workers, long-distance lorry drivers and students pulling all-nighters have been able to rebut fears about the health risks of caffeine consumption with a simple truth: drinking coffee helps you stay alert and get the job done.

Except that now, it seems, it does not. According to a study published this week, coffee-drinking in British workplaces is undermining concentration and damaging productivity. The survey found 76% of workers drinking three or more cups of coffee, tea or cola every day - enough caffeine to act, in the words of researcher Dr David Lewis, "as a powerful diuretic [causing] people to visit the toilet more frequently, which can lead to power-zapping dehydration."

You'd be entitled to feel confused: few substances in recent years have been subject to so many entirely contradictory clinical studies as caffeine - not even wine and beer, the other once frowned-upon stimulants now periodically presented as elixirs of good health.

Depending on whom you believe, coffee-drinking either raises blood pressure, increases the chances of miscarriage and the risk of developing Alzheimer's, arthritis and infertility - or is a powerful protection against the worst effects of bronchial asthma, colon cancer, bladder cancer, hayfever, Parkinson's, heart disease, depression, anxiety, gallstones, dermatitis, chronic angina and hypotension.

A web of sponsors on both sides of the debate means that few studies are entirely free of commercial interests: this week's study, in one of the more clunkingly obvious examples, was funded by Volvic, manufacturers of an ideal water-based alternative to latte-slurping.

Besides dehydration, coffee blocks the receptors of adenosine, a chemical in the brain that normally counters the effects of adrenaline - which explains why it does enhance the sense of alertness. But related effects of this process, some researchers believe, can be calamitous: "The daily blood pressure elevations caused by caffeine consumption," says Dr James Lane of Duke University in North Carolina, "could contribute to an increased risk of coronary heart disease in the general population that consumes caffeine."

A group of Swedish researchers reported in December that women who drank more than four cups of coffee per day in early pregnancy doubled the chances of spontaneous abortion, while caffeine intake is also thought to affect birthweight - though the precise mechanisms by which it contributes to any of these problems remain mysterious.

An unresolved argument rages, too, over its addictiveness: even a single cup of instant coffee daily is sufficient to induce withdrawal symptoms when it is taken away; on the other hand, studies into the parts of the brain which are most affected by cocaine, nicotine and morphine addictions have repeatedly failed to reveal any such effect from coffee drinking.

But the issue reaches far beyond coffee. Caffeine makes a regular appearance in the ingredients lists of numerous common painkillers. But since most researchers deny that it has any painkilling function, and argue that one of the key symptoms of caffeine withdrawal is headaches, it doesn't take a particularly paranoid conspiracy theorist to suggest that something vaguely suspicious might be going on. And non-coffee-drinkers are not, of course, immune: there is around 50mg in a cup of tea, and up to 20mg in a cup of hot chocolate.

And yet for every study demonstrating a health risk, there is another suggesting benefits. Take coffee and cancer: a year ago, a study published in the Journal of Epidemiology and Public Health found that smokers reduced by half the extra risk they run of contracting bladder cancer if they drink coffee as well.

"For centuries people have been investigating exactly the same thing. Around 2.5bn cups are drunk per day in the world, so if this was an issue, it would be a problem of epidemic proportions," says Dr Euan Paul, scientific adviser to the industry-backed coffee science information centre. "Recent papers are in complete contradiction to the Volvic findings."

The debate is complicated by the fact that coffee remains, relatively speaking, a drink of the wealthy (and, in the case of the high-end joints, the profligate). Since environmental and dietary factors are likely to mean they contract fewer serious illnesses in any case, epidemiological studies concluding that coffee enhances health are at risk of drawing unsubstantiable conclusions.

"It's also hard to separate out the effect of coffee from caffeine," says Dr Mary Berrington of the cancer research campaign. "Something else in the coffee may be protective, such as flavinoids. But in the case of cancer, most of the epidemiology studies suggest there is no great association with coffee, either positive or negative."

The only point of agreement among these studies is that the most serious negative effects of coffee-drinking, if they exist at all, only begin to kick in after at least three cups and possibly more, while few would dispute that enough coffee drunk all at once would kill. Everything in moderation: it's a boring motto to live by, admittedly, but in this case, very probably true.

webTitle: Health: The diary of a junior doctor

fields.headline: Bedside stories
fields.standfirst: The junior doctor catches Aids from a wayward needle - well, almost
fields.trailText: The junior doctor catches Aids from a wayward needle - well, almost.
fields.body:
I've gone and got bloody Aids. I'll be dead in 10 years. I shall devote myself to working in a lab, desperately struggling to find a cure, which will tragically be developed just weeks after my painful, lingering demise. They will read out at my funeral my last wish, that the fruits of my work should be donated free to an African workers' HIV cooperative, so that others may live on after my pain is over. I've got bloody Aids.

By which I mean, of course, I've had a needlestick injury. Not just any old needlestick injury of course. The kind of needlestick injury where the donor (and what a sweet turn of phrase) is a drug-using alcoholic with psychiatric problems. The kind of donor who is stacked to the gills with every risk factor you can bloody think of, the bastard bastard bastard.

Deep breath. First let me tell you what a good boy I was. I was wearing my rubber gloves. I mean, I may as well have been wearing black satin ballgloves up to my elbows for all the difference they made, but I was wearing them when that idiot flinched his arm, which moved his hand, which pushed my elbow against the cotsides, which stopped me lifting my hand clear, which held the hollow needle filled with poisonous blood, which eased its way gently into my glove.

And when I pulled it off there was a needle-shaped hole in it and when I looked at the side of my thumb there it was! The teeniest little miniscule pinprick, quite possibly even the smallest dot of nothing at all that I have ever seen. I beheld it in awe: should I chop my hand off?

"I know I should be sensitive about this, doctor. But that's the crappiest littlest needlestick injury I've ever seen. In fact, that's not a needlestick injury. It didn't even go into your hand. That's not even where it hit." She held up the glove for comparison. What a cow. I had just contracted bloody Aids and still I was getting bullied by nurses.

Clearly I needed to see a doctor. Top-notch medical cover is a perk in this job, and on this occasion it came in the form of a rather famous A&E consultant. "The drugs only really work if you take them within an hour," he said. Fabulous, I replied: it only happened 10 minutes ago. "Why don't you register at the front desk?" he said. Sounds time-consuming, I thought. What does he think I am: some kind of patient? "How about we just chop my hand off right away and then I can start on some intravenous Aids drugs?"

Neither of us were laughing, so I wasted 10 minutes trying to register in my own A&E department, desperately fighting off visions of lurid computer animations depicting hundreds of little HIV viruses, all busily replicating in my bloodstream. A&E consultants are the hardest people in the world.

So we filled out the forms and he told me the risks and he took some blood for storage and finally I was allowed to get my hands on some ridiculously potent anti-retroviral drugs: three brown tubs of huge yellow horse-medicine tablets. And then I had to wait 36 hours for my senior house officer to nobly but gently convince our acutely delirious (and actually rather sweet) patient that we needed a confidential HIV test on him. The rules on things like consent are made by Guardian-reading do-gooders with cultural studies degrees on committees where everyone wears black polo-neck sweaters, and for a day and a half I was seriously considering switching teams and becoming a reactionary old bigot.

So let me tell you about the drug side-effects. I thought it was bad enough when I took too much aspirin for an earache and it made my haemorrhoids bleed. These HIV drugs are monstrous: my heart heavy with the knowledge that I was over-reacting outrageously, and that the drugs were almost certainly unnecessary, I struggled zombie-like to the toilet every half hour to release another payload of loose, green stool, post on-call with 23 new patients on four hours' sleep, feeling like I was indulging in some morbid kind of disease tourism to the land of HIV positivity. At least it kept my mind off thoughts of my own mortality.

So obviously he was negative. It took me days to recover. And this is what I am thinking right now: it's not too late to get out of acute hospital medicine. Maybe I should bite the bullet, apply for some NHS-issue family doctor sideburns, buy some corduroy trousers, and become a GP.

webTitle: Health: The diary of a marathon runner

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: I've unconsciously started sowing the seeds of my running downfall. I'm eating anything I can lay my hands on. I'm drinking more than I should. I'm now smoking with both hands.
fields.body:
There has to be something that Freud wrote about people who insist on running for long periods. But apparently not. He had nothing to say about marathons. Flicking through indices of his works leads me to lots of talk of human form and nothing on carbohydrate deficiencies, optimum sugar intake or isotonic drinks.

The only reason to mention this is that I've unconsciously started sowing the seeds of my running downfall. I'm eating anything I can lay my hands on. I'm drinking more than I should. I'm now smoking with both hands.

This is all new. What's the point? I run to get fit, to prepare myself for what is going to be - so they say - the worst and best day of my post-21-year-old life. But seemingly without a thought I'm intent on destroying all my good work with the indulgences and weaknesses I thought I'd seen off years before.

This is therapy territory. I'm throwing it all away and I can only think that there is a latent desire to ruin it all. A month into my schedule and I'm up to 22 miles a week but only beery cigarette breath to show for it. So, I've decided to see a personal trainer. I want him to be strict, to run my life while I run my run.

When he's not changing people's bodies James Nash climbs mountains for fun. He lost a stone on his last holiday. My first meeting with him is promising. He tells me I can eat anything I want - within reason. I can even perk up my running with a shot of coffee before the outset. He knows that's not conventional but then neither is he.

But James has certain rules which I must stick to. The most important is all about carbohydrates. Under no circumstances go out on a low-carb diet. Cutting down on the carbs - de rigueur in 2001 I'm told - may help me lose weight but will ensure an early exit from the marathon.

There is also an undesirable side effect. Low-carb diets mixed with exercise make you smell - like pear drops. It's all a bit scientific but James simplifies it. Low carb supplies leads to a higher level of "ketone bodies" in your blood and a distinct pong all round. James promises to tell me more.

fields.headline: 'Most women would not like their baby in a jar'
fields.standfirst:
As an NHS insider Meg Henderson saw some shocking things involving organ removal. They were, she says, an affront to human dignity. But former mortuary attendant Charles Burgess finds the outcry over Alder Hey mawkish

Special report: Alder Hey
fields.trailText: As an NHS insider Meg Henderson saw some shocking things involving organ removal. They were, she says, an affront to human dignity. But former mortuary attendant Charles Burgess finds the outcry over Alder Hey mawkish.
fields.body:
There is public horror at the stories of children's heads in jars, of shelves of babies' body parts. And all over the country, doctors stare at their newspapers and TV screens, bemused and unable to comprehend what all the fuss is about. The hospitals talk about "outdated bad practice in one or two pockets", which is intended to convey the impression that it used to happen and perhaps still does in some isolated areas, but of course, it isn't the norm.

The truth is that snipping out bits and pieces at postmortems has always been standard practice, one that is so entrenched that no one sees anything wrong with it. The reason relatives have never been told is that what they don't know won't hurt them.

This excuse is part of what the medical profession likes to see as its paternal role - thought for others. Those of us who have seen the profession at close quarters have always known that this is a lie, a cover-up for sheer arrogance andinsensitivity. Doctors remain unable to tell the difference between empathy and sympathy yet still try to convince us that they are kindly, golden-hearted, caring Dr Camerons.

I was once a cardiac technician; all you needed to come within my remit was a pulse or the absence of one. I worked in heart surgery, heart disease, resuscitation, and research in various hospitals here and abroad, rising to chief tech before I changed careers. So I know that patients belong to the medical profession from the moment doctors lay stethoscopes on them. We're not talking about the removal and retention of organs from a few babies and children, or a few hundred even; we are talking about patients of all ages and sizes. That is what that desperate smokescreen is intended to cover, that the situation is across the board, adults as well as children.

Organs are retained for a variety of reasons. For instance, there is great rivalry between medics and surgeons, and if something goes wrong in a case they share, one lot will try to blame the other. I often collected someone's heart from pathology and took it back to my medic colleagues for examination, in the hope that a badly sutured plastic valve could be identified, or maybe a leaking vein or artery, so that the pointed finger could be diverted back to the surgeons. No one ever thought to ask the relatives; medicine just doesn't work like that, and anyway, what they don't know won't hurt them.

And medical research needs supplies of organs, and there are papers to be written to enhance and further medical careers. There is always someone looking for some little piece and another someone perfectly willing to supply it - and who will ever know?

Sometimes pathology technicians have been known to make extra money selling items to drug companies who do their own research, and however hotly denied this may be, it is true all the same. After all, the patient no longer needs it, so where's the harm? I have yet to meet anyone who was asked to donate a piece of a loved one, let alone their unborn or stillborn child. Most women would not react well to a request that their lost baby should be kept in a glass jar for the foreseeable future, or dissected, with bits sent to various interested parties so that they can submit a paper to one of the journals or get more letters after their names. So no one asks.

I lost five babies and, knowing what I knew, the first thing on my mind each time was what would be done with them; however incomplete they were, they were still human, still my children. It's a sad indictment of the medical profession that what became of my child was uppermost in my mind each time, when I should have been coming to terms with my loss. Other women in similar situations were spared that knowledge. Until now, of course; all over the country women today must be wondering if their lost baby is part of that collection at Alder Hey, and how can they ever be sure?

Most of these cases are outside the retention of organs for teaching purposes, to be kept in medical museums, where there might be some justification; though even when I was in medicine I used to look at those preserved oddities and grotesques, but human beings for all that, and feel guilty to be staring at them, the babies with two heads, and other little bodies at different stages of normal development floating in jars for ever. I often wondered if their mothers were aware that their children were here on our dusty shelves and I had an almost irresistible urge to cover them up to stop idle eyes gazing at them. Indeed, I once shared an office with a brain in a jar that had been used as a paperweight for so long that it wasn't questioned. I used to look at it occasionally and wonder if this was the use the owner had envisaged for it, even if he or she had given written consent, which I doubted.

When my mother died some years ago an over-zealous official decided that she should have a postmortem and I vainly tried to stop it happening. Before it went ahead, I vowed dreadful vengeance if any part of her should be removed. Of course, as those conducting the postmortem knew perfectly well, unless I'd been standing beside them throughout I could and would never be certain. Somewhere in the dark recesses of my mind it still bothers me occasionally, though that won't change whatever did happen. But she was my mother, she deserved respect in death, just like all those other mothers I know didn't get it, and the same applies to the babies I lost.

You try not to think that they too might be on shelves somewhere or used for some experiment, but the thought is there, because I saw it happening to other babies, and now that even those emotional creatures outside know too it has all turned into a nightmare for the medical profession, though some of us see it as chickens rightly coming home to roost.

'All that's there is the shell - nothing more'

When I worked in a mortuary as a transporter and cleaner nearly 30 years ago bodies used to be stuffed with rolled-up copies of the local newspaper when the autopsies were finished and the next stop was the undertaker.

And I did not - and still do not - see anything wrong with that.

It was the end of a precise process which may seem appalling to those who have never thought about it before but which I came to realise was absolutely necessary. All the internal organs were taken out and looked at; some were kept and some were thrown away into black plastic bags which one of us then took to the incinerator. I remember once an amputated foot looking rather odd, sticking up as if someone was stuffed whole in the bag. And I remember too what looked like a fully formed baby making that functional final journey.

The noise of an electric saw (or the smell of formaldehyde, for that matter) still takes me back to that autopsy room where the saw was used to cut the skull so that the brain could be taken out. And then paper would go into the head and the skin would be flipped back and sometimes you had to hit the forehead to get the skull into line so that the body would not look like Frankenstein's monster. And sometimes when an intestine had been rolled into a concentric circle on a plate we would put one end into the bin and watch it unwind, until the final plop.

Then we would comb the hair, put a white shroud over the body and wheel it into a room off the chapel. And relatives would come and you could hear them crying for their dead loved ones. And we knew that all that was there was the shell - nothing more.

It taught me, as an 18-year-old, was that once you are dead that's it with the body you have been carrying around all your life. If there is a spirit then it took a hike straight away.

That is why I find the reaction to this week's Alder Hey story mawkish. I appreciate that people are upset that they never knew what was happening to their children's bodies. If they had read the above they probably would not want to know anyway. At Alder Hey theorgans are kept in tubs in a room, which some seem to think an outrage. But how else should they be kept? It seems that we care more about the dead than the living - or certainly the elderly. How can we talk about "dignity in death" when we allow our elderly to die in conditions stripped of dignity?

And is it any better to bury the remains of a human being, to let it rot in the earth, than to have it used to try to help someone else's life?

Pathologists are not murderers, although it seems some have not been playing by the rules. Society can't have it both ways and say we want to find a cure for a plethora of diseases but then get squeamish when we know what is involved. Pathologists use dead people's organs for research. The process involves some butchery. But it is worth it.

And don't forget to carry a donor card.

The Paediatric Pathology Society

fields.headline: Within these walls
fields.standfirst:
Amid the endless debate about what jails are for, whether they work, who should be in and who should be out, does anyone spare a thought for the buildings themselves? Jonathan Glancey on the philosophy of prison architecture
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Amid the endless debate about what jails are for, whether they work, who should be in and who should be out, does anyone spare a thought for the buildings themselves? Jonathan Glancey on the philosophy of prison architecture.
fields.body:
"Norman Stanley Fletcher, you are a habitual criminal ..." It's not so odd that our common impression of prisons is that of clanking steel doors and long, echoing galleries lined with crowded cells watched over by blue-uniformed "screws".

But Porridge, in which Ronnie Barker's TV lag served his time, isn't so far off the mark in terms of prison architecture, with even the latest following a tradition of monumental Victoriana. Only last year, the prison service opened a new wing at Hunterscombe young offenders institution in Oxfordshire, a thing of cell-lined galleries and corridors.

Throughout Britain, Gormenghast-like prisons such as Pentonville, Dartmoor and Strangeways stand as monuments to an age in which they existed both to deter the rising urban proletariat from crime and as models of muscular Christian punishment. As these leviathans towered into mostly industrial skies, smaller jails closed. In 1877, the number of prisons fell from 113 to 56; after 1918, 29 more were closed. Until 1952, only two new prisons were built; those that emerged with the consumer boom of the 50s and the consequent rise in crime were, with the exception of Everthorpe, North Humberside (1958), wings added to existing buildings or conversions of country houses and various institutions.

By the late 50s, Britain's prisons were an architectural ragbag. Attitudes to treatment of prisoners, however, had been moving from detention and repentance towards retraining and rehabilitation. The first new prison to emerge from this thinking was Blundeston, Suffolk, in 1963. Looking like a public school, it had four, four-storey T-shaped cell blocks, each housing 75 prisoners, rather than the hundreds held in the wings of Pentonville, the first and archetypal British radial prison, gathered around a nucleus of communal facilities.

For all its inherent decency, Blundeston proved to be no model for future prison design. Over the next 40 years, government policy was to change with the speed and dexterity of a cat burglar. The escape of the spy George Blake from Wormwood Scrubs in 1966 led to the draconian Mountbatten report, calling for maximum security. Industrial relations problems in the 70s and 80s brought a lapse in staff morale and greater separation between jailers and jailed, and though a new liberalism began to take hold in the 80s, public building programmes were so slow that new prisons were 10 years out of date by the time they opened.

Most prisons dating from the 60s tend to be little more than regimented rows of corridors lined with cells. Offering prisoners little or no "defensible" space, they were dangerous and difficult to monitor. Badly constructed buildings shared the problems common to contemporary housing estates: flat roofs, leaks, condensation, ill-ventilated bathrooms.

The one real breakthrough in prison design came in the late 80s, with the setting up of the Prison Building Board. Its fresh look at design was framed by the prison service's new statement of purpose: "Our duty is to look after them [prisoners] with humanity and help them lead law-abiding lives in custody and after release." This sentiment was reinforced by the Woolf and Tumim reports which followed the prison riots that ended in three weeks of violent unrest at Strangeways in April 1990. The aim of the experts - including architects, who were to be given more say in prison planning - was to reduce overcrowding and foster a humane atmosphere in jails.

Famous last words. In 1993, Michael Howard, Margaret Thatcher's rightwing home secretary, promoted a policy of increasing the prison population. Before him, numbers had been falling (from 51,000 in 1988 to a low of 40,600 in 1992); it was widely thought this trend would continue and that prison building should therefore be given low priority.

Instead, the prison population rose by 50% between 1993 and 1998, and could hit 92,000 by 2005, according to Sir Richard Tilt, former head of prison services, if the government persists with its Howard-style policies on crime. His "reforms" have resulted in the growth of private prisons and PFI (private finance initiative) designs - as many cells as possible for the least possible cost.

There has been a spate of pre-fab prisons (designed for lives of 15-17 years) and even the mooring at Weymouth of the Weare, a former floating barracks used in the Falklands conflict and one-time rehab centre for drug crime in New York. The optimism and humanity that flourished in the late 80s have given way to a strange brew of fast-buck, fast-track construction. Prisons now exist as much to make money for investors (who are these people?) as to make politicians look tough.

Now the treadmill has turned full circle and it's back to Victorian architectural and penal values. The politicians' need to win cheap votes by appealing to our basest instincts means prison design has lagged behind that of architecture generally. In the 60s new prisons were pretty much indistinguishable from certain housing estates, hospitals and chain hotels; now, in the 21st century, British architecture is riding high, yet our prisons are, for the most part, pathetic things.

Of course, they are designed to deter and no one expects them to be beautiful (though architectural historians will argue that George Dance's 18th-century Newgate possessed a terrible beauty), but much more effort should go into their design.

Solid construction aside, the prime reason Victorian prisons are considered among the best of Britain's penal institutions is that they are fairly easy to oversee. Major General Sir Joshua Webb, military engineer and the first surveyor general of prisons, designed Pentonville, inspired by the Eastern Penitentiary, Philadelphia. Charles Barry, joint-architect of the Palace of Westminster, added the facades. The interior remains much as it was, with long galleries of cells leading off in three directions from a central observation core. It looks like a shopping arcade without the frills.

The only credible alternative to date is the small wave of property services agency prisons designed and built in the late 80s and early 90s. These include Doncaster, Lancaster Farms and Woodhill prison in Milton Keynes. Like Pentonville, they are based on US precedent (some of the best and equally some of the most degrading prisons are to be found there).

Here, at last, there is some meeting between contemporary architecture and prison design. Woodhill has something of the look of the kind of corporate HQ you expect to find in an 80s business park. A central triangular atrium is flanked by three tiers of cells leading on to walkways. These are easy to supervise. Incidents of violence, in particular sexual assault, are notably low and prisoners and staff meet more often than in radial prisons like Pentonville or postwar corridor or "hotel" designs.

Yet no matter how humane, Woodhill was not to be the way forward. Too decent for macho politicians, according to Leslie Fairweather, architect and co-editor of Prison Architecture, Policy, Design and Experience, (Architectural Press). "What we need," he says, "is a sane, rational and humane policy towards prisons, carried through by successive governments. We won't get that as long as criminal policy is used as a crude vote-catcher. Current hardline policy means we may need 20 new prisons in the next few years and who knows how the balance between the private and public sector will work out. It's a complex situation we're facing and not a very nice one."

webTitle: Tesco tops the internet food chain

fields.headline: Tesco tops the internet food chain
fields.standfirst: All the latest internet news is at Net news
fields.trailText: British shoppers are using the internet for their weekly food shop more than consumers in any other country - including the US, where the concept was pioneered.
fields.body:
British shoppers are using the internet for their weekly food shop more than consumers in any other country - including the US, where the concept was pioneered.

A new survey shows some $580m (£398m) of groceries were sold online in the UK last year - and Tesco has more than half of that market. The survey also shows that the rapid growth of the supermarket chain's Tesco.com offshoot has made it the world's biggest online grocer.

The report, by market research specialist Datamonitor, shows that the penetration of online sales into the overall grocery market remains small. In Britain, internet grocery shopping accounts for just 0.4% of the market for food. In the US the rate is 0.33%, and in Germany and Italy it is 0.1% and 0.02% respectively. But web food shopping is forecast to grow rapidly.

According to Datamonitor, the online grocery market is worth $3.5bn and set to become the biggest business-to-consumer sector.

In mainland Europe the most developed market is the Netherlands, but the Datamonitor report says the highest rate of growth in the coming 12 months will be in France, where national store chains such as Carrefour, Auchan, Cora, Casino and Galeries Lafayette are all rolling out on line services. Web shopping is also developing fast in Spain.

In Germany, however, the market for groceries is so dominated by tough price competition that retailers do not have the margins to invest in new sales channels.

In the US, online retailing has been driven by "pure plays" - companies set up specially to service stay-at-home web shoppers. They had a tough time last year as dot.coms fell out of favour. Many exhausted their funding and had to be rescued by existing store chains. Netherlands-based Ahold, for instance, bought out Peapod, while Safeway bought a 50% stake in Groceryworks.

Webvan, the US market leader, has scaled back expansion plans and traditional supermarkets such as Albertsons and Kroger are moving into the online sector.

fields.bodyText: British shoppers are using the internet for their weekly food shop more than consumers in any other country - including the US, where the concept was pioneered. A new survey shows some $580m (£398m) of groceries were sold online in the UK last year - and Tesco has more than half of that market. The survey also shows that the rapid growth of the supermarket chain's Tesco.com offshoot has made it the world's biggest online grocer. The report, by market research specialist Datamonitor, shows that the penetration of online sales into the overall grocery market remains small. In Britain, internet grocery shopping accounts for just 0.4% of the market for food. In the US the rate is 0.33%, and in Germany and Italy it is 0.1% and 0.02% respectively. But web food shopping is forecast to grow rapidly. According to Datamonitor, the online grocery market is worth $3.5bn and set to become the biggest business-to-consumer sector. In mainland Europe the most developed market is the Netherlands, but the Datamonitor report says the highest rate of growth in the coming 12 months will be in France, where national store chains such as Carrefour, Auchan, Cora, Casino and Galeries Lafayette are all rolling out on line services. Web shopping is also developing fast in Spain. In Germany, however, the market for groceries is so dominated by tough price competition that retailers do not have the margins to invest in new sales channels. In the US, online retailing has been driven by "pure plays" - companies set up specially to service stay-at-home web shoppers. They had a tough time last year as dot.coms fell out of favour. Many exhausted their funding and had to be rescued by existing store chains. Netherlands-based Ahold, for instance, bought out Peapod, while Safeway bought a 50% stake in Groceryworks. Webvan, the US market leader, has scaled back expansion plans and traditional supermarkets such as Albertsons and Kroger are moving into the online sector. fields.headline: Radio 2 goes neck-and-neck with Radio 1
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
4pm update: Radio 2 is neck-and-neck with trendy rival Radio 1 in the battle for UK listeners, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 1: TalkSport loses women listeners
Special report: The BBC
fields.body:
Radio 2 is neck-and-neck with trendy rival Radio 1 in the battle for UK listeners.

The latest Rajar figures show both stations on 10.7m listeners, although Radio 2 edges ahead with a listening share of 13.6% compared with 10% for Radio 1.

But the standout success was for Terry Wogan's morning show, which added 520,000 listeners between September and December last year, giving him a total of 6.29m.

"I owe it to all the togs, or Terry's old geezers and Terry's old girls who listened in and who stuck with me through thick and thin - mostly thick," said Mr Wogan.

Former Radio 1 star Steven Wright, who quit the station in protest over the Matthew Bannister purges of the mid-90s, added 420,000 people to his Radio 2 show.

Radio 2 has dominated listening share of the UK radio market for some time, but this is the first time it has equalled Radio 1's listening reach.

"Radio 2 have always been the most listened to station, because they go for a wider age range than us. We aim for 15 to 24-year-olds and they go for everyone else," said a Radio 1 spokesman.

Overall, BBC Radio continues to dominate the UK market, widening its total audience share to 51.7%, ahead of 46% for commercial radio.
