webTitle: Promoting a new culture of giving

fields.headline: Promoting a new culture of giving
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's new tax incentives are thoroughly welcome but they need to be promoted if they are to successfully affect public behaviour, says Michael Brophy
fields.trailText: The chancellor's new tax incentives are thoroughly welcome but they need to be promoted if they are to successfully affect public behaviour, says Michael Brophy
fields.body:
A national campaign will be launched in April to undertake the difficult but achievable task of publicising new tax incentives designed to encourage charitable donations. The government has agreed to provide funds, and charities themselves are dipping into their pockets to help resource the campaign. The Charities Aid Foundation and the National Council for Voluntary Organisations fully support these efforts and are helping to steer the campaign, which is headed up by Lord Joel Joffe, the chair of Oxfam.

It is vital to stress that the campaign team and steering committee are not interested in simply flinging lots of money towards a blitz of press and radio advertising - methods of influence which might be approaching their sell-by date, especially in relation to the wider task of altering the culture of giving for the long term. Instead, the campaign is committed to a segmented approach, identifying specific constituencies of potential supporters who might be persuaded to do more.

For example, how can we engage young people these days? Probably not through the auspices of fusty charities and certainly not through general advertising campaigns. On the other hand, the brand products which young people identify with might be more productive avenues of support.

In the same way, high flyers in the City are more likely to be influenced by their peers and other successful entrepreneurs than by the stalwarts of the charity sector. Identifying such "champions", and enthusing them to join in our efforts, could be an early task for the campaign.

It is also important to assert that the campaign is dedicated to helping to increase the total size of the pot and is, therefore, aiming to work in a complementary way with charities' existing fundraising initiatives. The campaign is not raising money itself - it is simply encouraging people to give more. If it succeeds, the whole charity sector will benefit.

The measures introduced by the chancellor in April last year present huge new opportunities to significantly increase the flow of tax-effective funds to the voluntary sector.

For example, there is no longer a £1,200 annual limit on donations made through the payroll deduction scheme. Now high earners can make gifts in this way, involving sums as large as £100,000 or £200,000, as well as those with more modest means. Tax relief and the extra 10% given by the government to encourage take up make it an even more attractive option.

For example, shares can now be donated, attracting tax benefits, and Gift Aid limits have been dropped, enabling people to give small amounts and still see the Treasury contributing more.

The challenge is to make the most of these incentives, helping to engineer a real change in the way people give and the amounts they contribute. It is quite simple really. We want to see a major increase in the number of donors and the amount of donations. Who can disagree with that?

 Michael Brophy is chief executive of the Charities Aid Foundation

fields.headline: At the right hand of Dod
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson is someone whom everyone knows about; but what about Keith Vaz - the second government victim, perhaps, of the Hinduja virus?
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson is someone whom everyone knows about; but what about Keith Vaz - the second government victim, perhaps, of the Hinduja virus?

You can find his basic details in the standard reference books - the parliamentary guides, Dod and Vacher; the Times Guide to the House of Commons; Who's Who. A good many people are vaguely aware that he's minister for Europe (which he is) and the first Asian government minister (which he isn't); and that all has not been harmonious back in his Leicester constituency.

But all of that is perfunctory. To get a meatier picture, you must turn to an 81-year-old New Yorker who came to Britain in 1950 as a refugee from McCarthyism, got hooked on our politics and has stayed here ever since. Volume four (S to Z) of Andrew Roth's Parliamentary Profiles for the 1997 House of Commons comes hot off the presses just in time to answer the strangled cry last week in newspaper offices everywhere: this fellow Vaz - knock us off a quick profile, would you?

Over the years Roth's profiles have established a pattern. First, something about the constituency (for which he now has a co-author in Byron Criddle). Then, a section mainly drawn from newspaper judgments, though often prefaced by a snappy summary of Roth's own. "Fast-maturing ambitious lawyer", says his entry for Vaz, "rising fast in the government after a slow start as one of a dozen frontbenchers denied ministerial posts in 1997, retarded by controversial reports of involvement in local Leicester politics."

Then, in each case, what is often a long and mercilessly comprehensive section called History, running in eminent cases to many pages. Jack Straw rates 10 and a half, Keith Vaz five. Roth seems to work on the basis that it's better to give too much than too little, and you can't be sure that some minor occasion won't take on a greater significance later.

So they're all here: the achievements, promotions, escapades, the articles for the Guardian expressing opinions of which their authors may one day repent. Here are maidens and ministerial speeches, but also Jimmy Wray's divorce, and Tim Yeo's love children, and Charles Wardle's links with Mohamed Al Fayed, and the views which got Bob Wareing into trouble over Serbia.

There are also offbeat facts which even close observers of parliament may not have known. The veteran Labour leftie Brian Sedgemore had a policeman brother whose duties included protecting the Princess Royal. Labour backbencher David Winnick did not speak until he was four (he's made up for that since). Tory grandee Sir Peter Tapsell was conceived in the Raffles hotel, Singapore. And the 1997 Labour entrant Derek Wyatt, a former rugby international, has published a book called Wisecracks from the Movies.

So what light does the entry on Vaz shed on his present predicament? There's a sense that people had seen trouble coming. Before he gained ministerial office, says Roth, he was getting a reputation for "fickle flexibility", as "a preening weather vane mainly interested in his admirers", for deft footwork touching every useful base, "not necessarily with consistency or for long". "The most incredible networker I have ever met," Lord Irvine is quoted as saying, whether in praise or blame is not clear. He also has a weakness for chocolate. But mixed with all that are tributes to his dedicated work for the Asian community and even his self-deprecation. Accused by the Tory MP for Market Harborough of being a "pompous barrister", Vaz agreed, adding that he'd rather be spending his life "wandering around Market Harborough, bitterly trying to be recognised".

These four books add up to a rich and varied and sometimes even poignant pageant of parliamentary life. Here are all those eager young 70s lefties - Milburn, Byers, Denham, Stringer - now transformed into equally eager Blairites. Here are the coming men and women who in the end never made it. Here too are all those bright-eyed 1997 arrivals who somehow blend into each other, so that you need Roth beside you to sort out your Michael Fosters and Gareth Thomases (there are two of each) and disentangle your Debra Shipleys from your Rachel Squires.

And if sometimes a judgment or two sounds familiar, that is because the 2,500 pages of Roth's quadrology are so often ruthlessly pillaged by reporters with a profile to write and with too little space, it seems, to acknowledge their source. An election in May will bring in a host of new MPs who will need to be profiled too. Work has already started.

 Parliamentary Profiles, 1997-2002, by Andrew Roth and Byron Criddle, Parliamentary Profile Services, 020 7222 5884 (£150 for set of four).

fields.headline: TalkSport sheds female listeners
fields.trailText: 3.30pm:Three-quarters of TalkSport's listeners are now male, according to new listener figures, report Lisa O'Carroll and Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport has finally shed the female listeners it didn't want.

According to new listener figures, up to 75% of the station's fan base is now male - a proportion it claims is "unique in commercial radio".

TalkSport was founded as shock-jock station Talk Radio.

It was transformed a year ago from a round-the-clock news and phone-in network to a sports station.

Before the original schedule was ripped up and replaced with a diet of cricket and football, the station had what it called a "mish-mash" of listeners.

"Our typical listener was a woman in her 40s in the lower end of the demographic scale," said a spokesman.

"Now our biggest listenership is young men aged 25 to 34."

Over the past two years, Mr MacKenzie has crusaded against the BBC's Radio 5 Live in a bid to become the nation's number one sports station.

However, its listenership still hovers around the 2m mark - 2.16m listeners in the three months to December 17 - a fraction of Radio 5's 5.52m audience.

The gap between BBC Radio and the commercial sector widened further in the closing months of 2000, according to Rajar figures.

The combined share for the BBC's national and local radio networks was up slightly - 51.7% in the final quarter of last year.

That compares favourably with 51.4% in the previous quarter and 51.3% in the same period for 1999.

Commercial radio's share of listening between October and December 2000 was 46%.

This was down by 0.7 of a percentage point on the preceding quarter and the same three months of 1999.

But the commercial sector crept ahead of BBC Radio in terms of weekly reach in the final quarter of last year.

Commercial radio reached 30.871m listeners each week, just 49,000 more than BBC Radio.

In the previous quarter, the BBC had inched ahead by a mere 20,000 listeners.

But the headline figures hide some contrasting fortunes for the BBC's stations.

BBC local radio was the biggest winner, increasing its collective share of listening from 11.1% to 12% quarter on quarter.

And Radio 1 was the biggest loser, dropping 1 percentage point to 10%. In the final quarter of 1999 the BBC pop station had 10.9%.

Radio 2 continued to grow its listener share, claiming 13.6% of the UK market. In the previous quarter Radio 2 notched up 13%.

"The figures are testimony to the enduring power of radio in an increasingly competitive and fragmented media marketplace," said BBC director of radio Jenny Abramsky.

"It's good news across the board and I'm thrilled that Radio 2 and BBC local and national services have done so well."

In the commercial radio sector, the combined share of listening for the four national stations - Atlantic 252, Classic FM, TalkSport and Virgin Radio - stayed the same at 8%.

But Classic FM was up from 4.2% to 4.7%, quarter on quarter; while Virgin Radio was down by 0.3 percentage points to 1.4%.

Local commercial radio saw its share drop by 38.7% in the summer months to 37.9% in the final quarter of 2000. That was also half a percentage point down on the same period in 1999.

fields.headline: BBC racing veteran retires
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Peter Bromley, the BBC's horseracing correspondent of the past 41 years, is to retire after this year's Epsom Derby, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Peter Bromley, the BBC's horseracing correspondent of the past 41 years, is to retire after this year's Epsom Derby.

Mr Bromley, 71, is one of the best-known figures of British horseracing. He gave his first BBC commentary at Newmarket in 1959 and has been racing correspondent for BBC Radio ever since.

Among his most memorable commentaries were Shergar's victory in the 1981 Derby and the emotional victory of Aldaniti and Bob Champion in the same year, which reduced him to tears.

"I have worked with so many people around the microphone, most of whom have become friends," said Mr Bromley.

"I've thoroughly enjoyed thousands of races, but all good things must come to an end."

BBC Sport director Peter Salmon added: "Peter is an iconic figure in the racing world and his brilliant reading of races and his fantastic grasp of his sport have been legendary. We wish him all the best for his retirement."

Bromley will bow out on June 9 after this year's Derby.

fields.headline: HIT Entertainment suspends shares
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: The creator of Bob the Builder has suspended its shares ahead of a 'significant' acquisition, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
HIT Entertainment, the creator of children's favourite Bob the Builder, has suspended its shares ahead of a "significant" acquisition.

The company is set to complete a reverse takeover of a much larger, unnamed company.

It has asked for its shares to be suspended while it ties up the deal.

HIT, which refused to comment on any deal, has transformed itself from a distributor of children's TV programmes into a leading producer of cult characters.

This has been achieved on the back of the success of Bob the Builder, who had the Christmas number one pop record last year.

Bob the Builder launched recently on US TV networks and other characters, such as Kipper and Angelina Ballerina, are tipped for success.

Thanks to massive hits such as the Tweenies and the Teletubbies, children's TV series have become big business.

fields.headline: Viewpoint: Beverly Malone
fields.standfirst: Rookie RCN member Alan Simpson has high hopes for the college's new general secretary
fields.trailText: Rookie RCN member Alan Simpson has high hopes for the college's new general secretary
fields.body:
There are many differences between Beverly Malone and me. Ms Malone is a black woman, I am a white man. She is short, I am tall. While she comes from America, I was born and bred in England.

But there are a couple of similarities, too. Both she and I are psychiatric nurses and we are both new to the Royal College of Nursing. With my RCN membership barely three months old, I'm not, perhaps, the best-placed nurse to pass comment on the choice of the RCN's new leader. Yet, paradoxically, maybe I am. I have worked in nursing since the early 1980s, but only recently seen fit to join the RCN.

Why? The RCN has many good points. It clearly values nursing highly and it recognised the major contributions that nurses could and should make to the health of the nation long before this government woke up to the idea. It promotes and nurtures professional development and clinical excellence for nurses at all levels of their careers and supports a flourishing nursing research community.

But it suffers from an image problem. For many, the RCN is seen as an organisation out of touch with the reality of its members' working lives. However unfairly, the name conjures up a picture of grey-haired dames with double-barrelled surnames, wearing twinsets and pearls.

The expensive refurbishment of its London offices, while probably sound and necessary, provided an easy target for those struggling daily to maintain their professional dignity. Whether on hospital wards or out in the community, nurses are being forced to compromise and skimp in order to meet ever-increasing workload demands.

The UK is experiencing its largest shortage of nurses ever, with tens of thousands of vacancies. Plane loads of nurses are flown in from all corners of the world in a desperate attempt to prevent the collapse of the NHS. Thousands more nurses are approaching retirement age and members of the minority ethnic groups, who in the past propped up many of our public services, no longer see nursing or the NHS as a path to undiscriminating success.

Yet, somehow, the recent 0.5% pay rise after inflation was heralded by the nursing representatives as a generous response to the financial needs of a skilled, energetic and flexible profession.

In choosing Beverly Malone as their new general secretary, the RCN has made a brave and exciting decision that belies their traditional image.

Yet, rather than the revolutionary move that this appointment has been hailed as by some commentators, I see it as another wise step by the RCN, as they strive to become an inclusive professional nursing union rather than the distant, conservative and aloof organisation they have often appeared to be. It began with the scrapping of the "no-strike" policy and has continued with the recent vote to admit health care assistants.

So, I welcome Beverly Malone. When this new ambassador speaks up for nurses and patients, people are going to take notice. Beverly Malone is a formidable black American woman and, in British society, she is going to stand out. People will notice Beverly Malone and they will notice nurses. New faces will be attracted to nursing. She brings a fresh eye and a keen mind to the challenges we face.

The RCN has cast off caution and chosen a person who will act as a towering icon for the nursing profession. And they have chosen someone who will not mind stepping on a few toes along the way. Ms Malone's appointment shows the RCN means business.

While she comes from America, I was born and bred in England. But there are a couple of similarities, too. Both she and I are psychiatric nurses and we are both new to the Royal College of Nursing. With my RCN membership barely three months old, I'm not, perhaps, the best-placed nurse to pass comment on the choice of the RCN's new leader. Yet, paradoxically, maybe I am. I have worked in nursing since the early 1980s, but only recently seen fit to join the RCN. Why? The RCN has many good points. It clearly values nursing highly and it recognised the major contributions that nurses could and should make to the health of the nation long before this government woke up to the idea. It promotes and nurtures professional development and clinical excellence for nurses at all levels of their careers and supports a flourishing nursing research community. But it suffers from an image problem. For many, the RCN is seen as an organisation out of touch with the reality of its members' working lives. webTitle: Sorry the hardest word for Putin's Russia

fields.headline: Sorry the hardest word for Putin's Russia
fields.standfirst: The Russian president seems more interested in celebrating the Soviet Union's past than apologising for it, writes Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: The Russian president seems more interested in celebrating the Soviet Union's past than apologising for it, writes Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
Ten years after the Soviet collapse, the small Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia have been commemorating over the past few weeks the bloody events of early 1991 that were the midwives of their rebirth as independent nations.

They have been bittersweet events marked by sadness at the deaths of a score of people when Moscow's crack troops bloodily sought to stifle the recovery of sovereignty and liberty in the Baltic; and by satisfaction at their escape from the Kremlin's grip, their growing ties with Germany and the Scandinavian democracies, and their ultimate prospects of being integrated into the European Union.

In Riga, the capital of Latvia, crowds of people turned out on a frosty evening to build bonfires and remember the five people, including one little boy, who died when Soviet troops attacked the Latvian interior ministry in January 1991.

A week earlier, in neighbouring Lithuania, 14 people were killed in a bloody crackdown ordered by Moscow against the independence-seekers. Such were the dying gasps of the Soviet regime, and six months later the Baltic republics regained the independence crushed by Stalin in 1940 when he annexed the region as part of his diabolical deal with Hitler to carve up eastern Europe between them.

If the break-up of the Soviet Union was surprisingly unbloody generally, the bitterness lingers in the Baltic at these needless deaths and on the anniversary the calls have been ringing out for Moscow to apologise for the killings, most loudly in Estonia where no one was killed.

''We see that the crimes of the past are not regretted, but in fact glorified [in Russia],'' the Estonian foreign minister, Toomas Ilves, complained. ''The past is not a supermarket where you can pick and choose what to praise and what to deny.''

But in President Vladimir Putin's Moscow, immersed in a wave of Soviet nostalgia, stubbornly proprietorial about its lost imperial possessions, and aggrieved that it is no longer the superpower that held the satellite states captive, sorry is the hardest word.

There is a contemporary vogue among western statesmen for the S-word. Bill Clinton can say sorry to Africa for the slave trade. Tony Blair can voice his regret to the Irish about Britain's behaviour in the 19th century famine. The Vatican of Pope John Paul II can issue wordy apologies for Roman Catholicism's persecutions of other religions in centuries past.

Germany, of course, has long been issuing mea culpas to the victims of the Third Reich, most spectacularly with Willy Brandt prostrating himself in Warsaw, though these days Gerhard Schröder's Berlin Republic wants to put the breast-beating behind it and be a ''normal'' country.

Even France may in the end be brought to the point where it apologises for the atrocities it perpetrated in Algeria. But Moscow never utters the s-word.

A few weeks ago, Sweden and Russia ended nine years of research into the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from the Nazi gas chambers before disappearing into Stalin's Gulag.

For the first time officially, the Swedish government apologised to the Wallenberg family for the negligence it showed in the 40s and 50s on Wallenberg's fate. But Russia, while insisting that Stalin's secret police executed Wallenberg at its Lubyanka headquarters, still could not say sorry to the relatives for the murder.

Opposite the Lubyanka in central Moscow there is a small piece of granite from Solovetsky Island in the far north, one of the first prison camps in the Gulag.

The boulder is a modest and eloquent gesture in memory of the countless millions who perished in the Gulag.

But the stone was not laid by the Russian state or government which have erected no national monument to the millions of innocent victims of the Soviet regime. A bunch of human rights activists who campaign against national amnesia were responsible - though, of course, they could not have laid the stone without official blessing.

Continuity is a leitmotif of Putin's Russia, whereas Boris Yeltsin was more about caesuras, breaking with the past.

Whether talking about the national anthem or the KGB's successors or the material legacy, the Kremlin stresses that Russia is the inheritor of the Soviet Union. The positive aspects are stressed, the nasty bits ignored. The inheritance and the memory are partial.

Rather than saying sorry to the former captive peoples of the Soviet Union, Moscow is now able to impose a bizarre and symbolic reminder of the bad old days on the ex-Soviet republics, as occurred in Kiev a couple of weeks ago.

When the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, touched down at Kiev airport, he was welcomed by a guard of honour and brass band blasting out, in independent Ukraine, the old Soviet national anthem.

Putin has just had the old communist anthem reintroduced as Russia's new national tune, though minus the communist lyrics. It's a popular choice in Russia. But every time a Russian VIP visits Tallin, Prague, or Warsaw, the locals are likely to reach for the ear plugs as they are subjected to the theme tune of their former oppressors.

fields.headline: No 3. Coventry City
fields.standfirst: Neville Hadsley, editor of Coventry fanzine Gary Mabbutt's Knee, waxes lyrical
fields.trailText: What makes Coventry so special
fields.body:
What makes Coventry so special

We've gone 34 years uninterrupted in the top flight. We're the only team never to have been relegated from the top flight. We've suffered no relegation of any kind since 1958. (All these could change soon if our legendary talent for escapology fails us this season, though.)

We won the FA Cup in 1987, which makes us the only midlands club to do so in the last 30 years. We're unbeaten in Wembley finals. And at home in Europe.

We're the only team to spend more than 30 years in the top flight without actually winning the championship. Our highest finish, believe it or not, is sixth and I don't think we are going to change that this year!

We're the only club in the world whose fans sing a song with lyrics written by Jimmy Hill.

The high points

The smile on John Sillett's face as we won the FA Cup in 1987 with a team - that's right, a team, not a collection of highly-paid individuals. Qualifying for Europe in only our third season in the top flight - our last match in Europe saw us beat Bayern Munich.

The low points

Losing 6-1 to Bayern in the first leg! Having Bobby Gould as manager - twice. Don Howe's 1982 side - the most boring team on the planet who managed four 0-0 draws in a row at one point.

How we're doing at the moment

Don't ask.

Come on

Well, I'm writing this on the way to the match against Leeds at Elland Road. If we get a pasting - likely - then we need super-human form to save us from the drop. If we win - not very likely - it's Houdini time again. Our problem is we can't score. Solve that and we are safe.

Our last game

Losing to Manchester City in the FA Cup after dominating the game and missing 8 or 9 good chances. Even Joe Royle said his side were lucky.

Our next game

After tonight, it's home to Arsenal. A must win. They're all must wins at home now.

This is irritating

Missing chances that most season-ticket holders and their elderly relatives could stick away. At Newcastle, David Thompson scored direct from a corner but couldn't score from ten yards out with only the goalie to beat.

The chairman

Bryan Richardson is big on promises, short on delivery. He has grandiose plans for a new £72m stadium but cannot find the extra £2.5m to buy John Hartson. He's fanatically loyal to Gordon Strachan, though. Our president (and the man with the cash) is Geoffrey Robinson, the MP who was Paymaster General until he hit a little political turbulence.

Our traditional rivals

Aston Villa - it goes back to the 1930s and beyond. I couldn't care less about them, though - apart from their comedy value.

How we're turned out

Please don't mention kit, I'll be here all night. OK, we have a split personality. God, that is JH, decreed we should be in solid sky blue, but the regime now running the club have a heretical love of stripes. At present we look like the Argentine national side which, with the Hand of God still fresh in my memory, hurts like hell. No doubt it will change soon, though - it does every year. Best kit? The solid sky blue with white vertical tramlines circa 1978. The worst kit has to be the giant T kit of 1982. Still makes me shudder.

Mascots

Our best performer this season is Sky Blue Sam, a nine-foot tall blue elephant that walks on his hind legs and has ears as big as Gary Lineker.

The ground

Highfield Road has been sold to builders by our marvellous chairman even though our new promised land is still a gas works.

The crowd

Unhappy, depressed.

Links

www.GMKonline.com, a site that grew out of the fanzine Gary Mabbutt's Knee (the title celebrates the winning goal in our 1987 FA Cup Final victory).

It's got news, features and a history section which is still under construction but is a lot further ahead than our new stadium. It's also a good place for Sky Blues fans to sound off as there is also a message board.

webTitle: Charities will bring pressure to bear on business

fields.headline: Charities will bring pressure to bear on business
fields.trailText: Charities will challenge the business sector to be more generous when they gather at the annual National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) conference on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Charities will challenge the business sector to be more generous when they gather at the annual National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) conference on Wednesday.

The charity umbrella body is launching a 10-point plan calling for radical government measures to make companies donate more money to the voluntary sector. The plan will include cabinet-level pressure on the business sector and the naming and shaming of companies that do not give enough.

Currently, corporate donations account for a mere 5% of the voluntary sector's income, representing £315m a year, and 97% of the money comes from just 400 companies. Charities are asking the government to help secure an extra £1.25m.

Deputy director-general of the Confederation of British Industry John Cridland hit back at the campaign: "Companies do give money to charity, they also give time and expertise to their local communities as a contribution to socially inclusive wealth creation. There is no way that charitable giving for companies can be compulsory, any more than it is for members of the public".

However, NCVO will also release a survey showing that the public thinks businesses should give more to charities.

The aim of the campaign, led by NCVO, is to increase levels of giving to match those achieved by the business sector in the US. Between 1998 and 1999, corporate donations in the US rose by 14.2%, totalling $11.02bn and representing 1.3% of pre-tax profit.

Key speakers at the conference are David Blunkett, secretary of state for education and employment, and leader of the Conservative party, William Hague.

There will be a panel debate in the style of BBC's Question Time, sponsored by the Guardian. Panellists include MPs from the main political parties with responsibility for the voluntary sector: Paul Boateng, Simon Hughes and David Lidington. It will be chaired by Christina Odone, deputy editor of the New Statesman.

NCVO is launching its own manifesto at the event in the run-up to the election. For up-to-date coverage, log on to SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

webTitle: 5,000 jobs go in steel closure plan

fields.headline: 5,000 jobs go in steel closure plan
fields.standfirst: Analysis: Meltdown for British industry
fields.trailText: Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, will today announce plans to axe more than 5,000 British jobs, despite government anger over the way the company has conducted itself.
fields.byline: David Gow, Michael White and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, will today announce plans to axe more than 5,000 British jobs, despite government anger over the way the company has conducted itself.

South Wales will bear the brunt of the two-year programme of cuts, through the mothballing of virtually the whole of the Llanwern plant and the closure of the Ebbw Vale tinplate business.

Sir Brian Moffat, the Corus chairman and acting chief executive, has summoned union leaders to his HQ in London's West End for a breakfast briefing.

But he will provoke a storm of protest at the scale of the cutbacks - which include the closure of a core mill on Teeside - despite an unprecedented lobbying campaign led by Tony Blair.

Downing Street yesterday expressed anger over the company's refusal to tell even the government details of its plans or exactly when it would make the announcement.

"It's a pretty extraordinary state of affairs where, as the government, if you were to ask us when is this decision going to be announced we would say we don't know," the Downing Street spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said.

He contrasted Corus' attitude with the constructive talks between Whitehall and other firms engaged in major restructuring such as Vauxhall at Luton and BMW/Rover during the crisis in Longbridge last year.

Industry sources said last night that Sir Brian had been rattled by the sheer intensity of the lobbying campaign but felt he had no alternative but to slash over-capacity brought about by shrinkage of the Britain's manufacturing base and a flood of cheap imports.

Corus's UK operations lost at least £350m last year.

The prime minister and senior colleagues, fearing that the thousands of job losses will damage Labour, have pulled out all the stops to convince Corus that the recent weakening of the pound against the euro and a decision by several car groups to increase output will ease the group's medium- term trading prospects. But Sir Brian is expected to press ahead with plans to shut virtually the entire Llanwern plant, keeping just some specialist units.

Llanwern, employed 3,300 last summer, but could now be reduced to just a 600-strong workforce.

The main steel union, the ISTC, will later today put flesh on plans for a consortium to take over the plant, despite Corus's initial rejection of its demand for talks on a buyout.

fields.headline: Libya may compensate Lockerbie families
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.body:
The Libyan government is today considering compensation payments to the families of victims of the Lockerbie bombing, as a group representing the British families of those who died in the tragedy gathered in London to press for an independent public inquiry.

The Libyan ambassador to London, Mohammed al-Zwai, said today that his government will consider both compensation payments and agreements reached with the UN security council if Abdel Baset al-Megrahi's appeal against his conviction for the bombing fails. The security council agreements include the requirement that Libya offer compensation and accept responsibility for the bombing.

Megrahi, a Libyan citizen, was sentenced yesterday to life imprisonment for the murder of 270 people in the 1988 bomb attack on Pan Am flight 103. Scottish judges accepted that he was a special agent for the Libyan government, thereby implicating Tripoli in the attack. According to Libyan television reports, Megrahi will lodge an appeal against his conviction within 14 days.

Mr Zwai's comments seem to contradict statements out of Tripoli that the Libyan government bears no responsibility for the bombing. Libyan foreign minister Abdel Rahman Shalgam has insisted that Tripoli will never accept responsibility for the attack.

Colonel Muammar Gadafy's government has not been indicted in the bombing, but the Lockerbie blast was alleged to have been committed to "further the purposes" of Libyan intelligence. The prosecution has charged that the attack was carried out to avenge the US bombing of Tripoli and Benghazi in 1986.

Following the verdict, Libya called for an end to the UN sanctions imposed after the Lockerbie bombing.

"The sanctions imposed on Libya must be lifted completely because the Lockerbie case was used as a pretext to delay their lifting," foreign ministry spokesman Hassouna Chiouch told a news conference. "Now that the court has ended the case, the sanctions must be lifted completely."

"We extend our hand to the United States to build relations based on mutual respect and benefit for the two parties," Chiouch said. "Now that the Lockerbie case is behind, we look forward with interest to improving our relations with the United States in the interests of both countries and of peace worldwide."

Foreign secretary Robin Cook said Britain and the United States both agreed Libya "must" fulfil the UN security council resolutions before the sanctions will be lifted. Mr Cook stressed that Libya is barred from offering "no fault" compensation.

"Libya has in the past said it would pay compensation if there was a guilty verdict. There has been a guilty verdict, and a guilty verdict against a very senior official of Libyan intelligence," said Mr Cook.

"Libya can't walk away from their responsibility for the act of their official," he added.

In Washington, President George Bush praised the conviction and said the Libyan government must take responsibility for the attack. After less than two weeks in office, the Bush administration faces a major foreign policy decision on how hard to squeeze Libya.

State department spokesman Richard Boucher laid down four demands with which the United States said Libya must comply.

"That means revealing everything they know about the Lockerbie bombing, paying reparations, a clear declaration acknowledging responsibility for the actions of the Libyan officials and clear unambiguous actions which demonstrate the Libyan government understands its responsibilities," Mr Boucher said.

Meanwhile, the British families of those who died in the Lockerbie bombing are gathering in London today to press for further inquiries into the disaster. The group, which includes high profile campaigners Dr Jim Swire and the Rev John Mosey, will call for an independent public inquiry into unanswered questions surrounding the circumstances of the bombing.

The families have always maintained they want a public inquiry into issues not fully explored in the Fatal Accident Inquiry which was completed in 1991 or in the criminal trial which ended yesterday.

Most crucially, they want the failure of the intelligence services and the aviation authorities to stop the bomb getting on board to come under the spotlight.

Several bomb warnings were circulating at the time of the disaster including the so-called 'Toshiba warning' which advised that a bomb hidden inside a radio cassette recorder could be smuggled on to a plane. The bomb which blew up the Pan Am flight was hidden inside a Toshiba radio cassette recorder.

Previous calls for a public inquiry have been rejected on the grounds that such a move would prejudice the long-awaited criminal trial. Now that the trial is finally over, the families will argue that there are no grounds for rejecting a public inquiry.

Scotland's top law officer said today that insufficient evidence exists at this time for more prosecutions over the Lockerbie bombing. Colin Boyd QC, the Lord Advocate, added that it is clear that the man convicted yesterday for the outrage was not acting alone.

Following the announcement of the verdict yesterday, Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, Megrahi's co-accused who was acquitted, left the court at Camp Zeist, a former US military base in the Netherlands, a free man.

Taken to a safe house last night, he was expected to leave the Netherlands for home today. The time and place of his departure are closely guarded secrets. Megrahi remained in the specially built prison where he and Fhimah had been held since Tripoli handed them over in April 1999.

An official source said Megrahi's mother had been taken to a Tripoli hospital after collapsing, overwhelmed by news that her son had been jailed for life.

An appeal would be heard at Camp Zeist, except in the highly unlikely event Megrahi chose not to be present - in which case it would be held in the Scottish capital, Edinburgh.

And under the terms of the groundbreaking deal under which the Libyans were brought for trial, Megrahi stays at the camp until the entire legal process is complete.

Any appeal would take months to get under way, legal experts say. There is no automatic right of appeal in Scottish law, and that alone complicates and delays the process significantly.

fields.headline: Whistle blown on Playing the Field
fields.trailText: 11.15am: BBC1's Kay Mellor-scripted women's football drama Playing the Field is being killed off after five years, writes <BJulia Day.
fields.body:
BBC1's Kay Mellor-scripted women's football team drama Playing the Field is being killed off after five years.

The fifth series of the drama, whose stars have included Cold Feet and Fast Show favourite John Thomspon and Bad Girl Debra Stephenson, will be its last.

Tiger Aspect Productions confirmed the demise of Playing the Field, which centred on the lives and loves of a Yorkshire ladies football team.

The show was one of the highlights of the BBC's weekday drama with up to 7m viewers when it was last screened last summer.

And it was hailed as one of the few dramas the BBC developed that could compete with ITV for the hearts and minds of viewers.

"Five years is a good innings, but it is a question of if we can do more with the characters and the situation," said a BBC spokesman.

"Playing the Field has done a terrific job but you never know how long a series is going to run."

The final series of Playing the Field will air in the autumn. It will consist of 3 x 120-minute episodes instead of the usual 6 x 60-minute formats.

Tiger Aspect Productions has sold Playing the Field to Whoopi Goldberg's US production company, One Ho Productions.

fields.headline: Popstars breaks 10m-viewer barrier
fields.trailText: 12.15pm TV overnights: ITV's peaktime instalment of Popstars pulled in 10m viewers for the first time last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's decision to schedule an extra peaktime instalment of Popstars paid dividends last night - the show pulled in 10m viewers for the first time.

The final episode before the identities of the five band members are revealed was screened between 8pm and 9pm.

It had a 10m audience - up from 8.6m on Saturday evening - and a 42% share.

Crashing through the 10m barrier is a significant breakthrough for the show, which is gearing up to launch a pop band.

When the series kicked off three weeks ago, it had just 7.6m viewers.

BBC1 opposition Celebrity Ready Steady Cook gained 5.5m viewers from 8pm.

From 8.30pm, the Midweek National Lottery Draw and docu-soap Escape to the Sun drew just 4.5m.

A repeat of One Foot in the Grave followed between 9.10pm and 10pm on BBC1, attracting 6.3m viewers and a 29% share.

Between 9pm and 10.30pm, ITV scheduled police drama The Vice, starring Ken Stott, which pulled in 8m and a 37% share.

The second 10.30pm News at Ten did better than the first last Wednesday. Last night's ITV bulletin had 4.8m viewers, compared with 4.5m at the same time last week.

BBC1's Ten O'Clock News drew 5.4m - 200,000 less than last Wednesday, when the Peter Mandelson resignation story was unfolding.

The audience for flagship BBC2 winter season drama In a Land of Plenty appears to have bottomed out, falling from 2.2m to 1.3m between the first and third episodes.

Last night's fourth instalment of the 10-part series drew 1.4m and a 6% share.

webTitle: Indian government under fire for quake handling

fields.headline: Indian government under fire for quake handling
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Indian prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said today that relief was reaching Gujarat as criticism grew over his administration's handling of last week's devastating earthquake in the western state.
fields.body:
Indian prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said today that relief was reaching Gujarat as criticism grew over his administration's handling of last week's devastating earthquake in the western state.

Tens of thousands of survivors in once-prosperous Gujarat sought food and shelter and an official warned of disease, six days after the 7.9 quake struck, killing an estimated 25,000 people. "There was some lag in making arrangements and providing immediate relief, but that was made good in 24 hours," Mr Vajpayee said in the southern city of Madras, on his way to the inauguration of a new port on the eastern coast. Mr Vajpayee, who has called a meeting of the federal cabinet today to discuss measures to rehabilitate the devastated state, said enough relief material had reached Gujarat.

"We are getting relief material from other states, from abroad, there is no dearth," he said.

But survivors in Bhuj, the largest town nearest to the epicentre of the quake, said they had spent a sixth night in the open in falling temperatures. One former state lawmaker said people were desperately looking for shelter and tents were in short supply.

"The tragedy is not that there is no one to help, it is the opposite," the Times of India said in an editorial. "Relief is coming in a tidal wave, rescue missions have arrived from across the globe but there is no direction to these efforts."

Prime Minister Vajpayee said law and order in Gujarat was under control amidst persistent local media reports that armed gangs had threatened survivors with knives and were stealing jewellery.

One newspaper said nomads had landed in the quake zone from the neighbouring state of Rajasthan to take foodstuff meant for the survivors.

Most Indian political groups, including the main opposition Congress party which is bitterly opposed to the ruling coalition, have held back on criticism, saying this is not the time to play politics.

But at least one former federal minister said the Gujarat government had completely failed to deal with the calamity and must be sent packing. "The state government has failed to protect the rights of the people for speedy relief," Subramaniam Swamy said.

The earthquake has brought key commercial activities in the region to a halt. India's largest port suffered severe damage to its jetties and normal operations are unlikely to resume for another six to eight months.

Kandla port in the western state of Gujarat hasn't operated since last Friday's earthquake, losing about $2m (£1.4m) in revenue, said Vipul Mitra, deputy chairman of Kandla Port Trust.

The port is central to India's economy, handling one third of its imports, or an average of 46m tons per year, including 20m tons of crude oil. It has 10 jetties of which six are used for offloading crude while four are used for loading and unloading dry cargo. Two of the dry cargo jetties are badly damaged, mainly because of cracks in the concrete support piles, Mitra said.

"The cracks in the jetties is a major concern for us," he said. "The complete rectification will take at least six to eight months on the dry cargo jetties."

India's diamond trade has also been badly hit as 80% of the country's lucrative polishing and cutting business takes place in Gujarat.

Traders in Ahmedabad, Gujarat's main city which has about 5,000 cutting and polishing factories, said today that even though their buildings were undamaged by the quake, most units were shut because panic stricken workers had fled the city.

Only about 10-15% of the diamond units are working and the diamond trade in Ahmedabad is losing some 20m rupees (about £300,000) a day because of the shutdown, traders added.

"I expect that it will take another week to 10 days before things normalise," said Ramesh Naidu, a member of the Ahmedabad Diamond Association.

webTitle: Brown signs New York mayor in £5m-plus deal

fields.headline: Brown signs New York mayor in £5m-plus deal
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Former New Yorker editor Tina Brown has signed up New York mayor Rudy Giuliani in a £5m-plus book and TV deal. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Former New Yorker editor Tina Brown has beaten her more established rivals by signing up New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani in a deal reputed to be worth more than £5m.

The mayor's deal with Ms Brown's Talk Miramax Books includes a memoir and a leadership and management guide and is expected to lead to a TV show and potentially a film about the Guiliani's colourful life.

Ms Brown said she had been "spellbound" by the mayor's triumphs and his family history.

"In the light of the discovery of his father's past, the mayor's long fight against crime is an even more intriguing human interest story that will appeal to men and women alike," she said.

Sources in the US are already speculating that the deal is worth more than the £5m paid to Hillary Clinton by Simon & Schuster last month.

Mayor Giuliani would have been a challenger for Mrs Clinton in the New York senate last year but for his health and personal problems, which caused him to drop out of the race.

Talk Miramax Books is a subsidiary of Talk Media, the multimedia company set up by Disney's Miramax Films and Tina Brown in 1998 to publish books, produce films and TV shows, as well as publishing the monthly magazine Talk.

The books division has already gained a reputation for being hard-nosed.

Last year it killed a book project that planned to reveal the homosexuality of six members of "Sexgate" investigator Kenneth Starr's team, despite paying the author, John Connolly, an estimated $100,000 advance.

webTitle: Q & A: Junior doctors' pay deal explained

fields.headline: Q & A: Junior doctors' pay deal explained
fields.trailText:
What is a junior doctor?
The term "junior" is somewhat misleading, as it refers to all doctors in training who are working under the supervision of consultants. That includes everyone from the most junior doctors, who are straight out of medical school, to pre-registration house officers, senior house officers and specialist registrars. It typically takes between 10 and 16 years to become a consultant, although this time period varies between specialties.
fields.body:
What is a junior doctor?
The term "junior" is somewhat misleading, as it refers to all doctors in training who are working under the supervision of consultants. That includes everyone from the most junior doctors, who are straight out of medical school, to pre-registration house officers, senior house officers and specialist registrars. It typically takes between 10 and 16 years to become a consultant, although this time period varies between specialties.

How many junior doctors are there?
There are some 39,000 junior doctors across the UK, with more than 30,000 working in the English health service.

Why have they got a new pay deal?
Junior doctors had long complained about their previous overtime system, which saw rates drop as low as 50% of the normal hourly rate for any hours worked over the contracted 40-hour week. Things came to a head during 1999, when junior doctors threatened strike action if improvements were not introduced.

So is it just about money?
No. There are major concerns about patients being treated by extremely tired doctors. Changes were needed to ensure patient safety was not compromised, as well as to treat junior doctors fairly.

Why now?
In fact, a so-called "new deal" was introduced nearly a decade ago, in 1991, to put an end to the ridiculous hours worked by some doctors. But, despite major progress, many junior doctors continue to work unacceptably long hours with inadequate rest periods.

How long are junior doctors expected to work now?
The new contract for junior doctors sets out a maximum 56-hour week, although the ultimate aim is to reduce this to 48 hours, in line with the phasing in of the European working time directive. The directive must be implemented in full for junior doctors by 2009, although there is an interim deadline, in 2004, to ensure no doctor is on duty for more than 58 hours.

How will the new working hours limits be enforced?
The new pay deal, which came into force on December 1 2000, provides hospitals with clear financial and contractual incentives to reduce hours and work intensity.

Explain?
Any junior doctor whose working pattern is "not compliant" with the new deal - ie those working more than 56 hours or with insufficient rest periods - will now be paid a "band 3" supplement worth 62% of their salary. Those who are compliant, but who work between 48 hours and 56 hours will receive a 50% "band 2" supplement. These supplements will rise in December 2001 and again in December 2002, so that a junior doctor who is still working more than 56 hours in two years' time will receive a supplement worth 100% of the basic salary.

The increases sound enormous?
Remember, these supplements are replacing the previous overtime or out-of-hours payments. But there is no doubt junior doctors will be better off. According to the Department of Health, a new junior doctor will typically be £1,700 better off under the new system, earning nearly £26,000, while a senior house officer will see an extra £2,800, earning between £32,305 and £43,140.

How many doctors are currently working more than 56 hours?
Departmental figures from September suggest nearly 25% of the 30,000 junior doctors in England are working over the stipulated maximum. Taking into account the requirements for rest periods, some 38% of junior doctors were thought to be "non-compliant". But managers claim the new questionnaires filled in by junior doctors, on which the new pay system is based, have led to massive increases in the numbers of non-compliant doctors. Some trusts have seen non-compliance levels rise from 20% to more than 80%. The British Medical Association puts this down to "under-reporting" of work levels under the old system.

What is the cost to the NHS?
Hospitals are reporting a 10% increase in their junior doctors' paybill, with the big teaching hospitals being the worst hit. A survey of hospitals in the Northern and Yorkshire region found, on average, that acute trusts face increased costs of £771,031 - or £5,281 per junior doctor. For community and mental health trusts, which employ far fewer junior doctors, the average increased cost is £46,186 - or £3,299 per junior.

What would it take to comply with the 56-hour working week ceiling?
Hospital managers are currently examining this. The survey suggests that, on average, an acute trust would need an extra 17 junior doctors to reach compliance, although teaching hospitals will have to recruit far higher numbers. Also, given that juniors have to be supervised by consultants, an average of four additional consultants would be needed in each trust. In total, reaching compliance in the Northern and Yorkshire region would cost an estimated £17m in new salary costs. This comes on top of the £21m cost of the new pay deal, making a total of some £38m.

If junior doctors' hours are reduced, won't it take longer to train them?
Views are split on this. The BMA claims that junior doctors' time could be used more appropriately, with routine tests performed before a junior doctor is involved and reducing administrative duties. This could lead to reduced working times without impacting on training.

webTitle: Suspended council chief executive offers to resign

fields.headline: Suspended council chief executive offers to resign
fields.trailText: A council chief executive suspended from her £70,000-a-year job following allegations of bullying today offered to resign - just hours before a meeting to discuss her future.
fields.body:
A council chief executive suspended from her £70,000-a-year job following allegations of bullying today offered to resign - just hours before a meeting to discuss her future.

Sari Conway could still face the sack if Eastbourne borough council refuses to accept her resignation. Council leaders are to meet at 6pm to discuss an independent report into allegations that Mrs Conway bullied and harassed council officers. She is still entitled to attend the meeting to put forward her case.

Mrs Conway, a former home economics teacher, was suspended a year ago on full pay following complaints from four senior council officers about her aggressive management style.

The council has refused to comment on recommendations made in the 54-page report, produced by independent inquiry head and former National Electricity Consumer Council chairman Rodney Brooke.

It is understood, however, that the report will note that working relationships between Mrs Conway, of Wish Hill, Eastbourne, and the council's chief officers had broken down.

A council spokesman said: "We have received a letter tendering an offer of resignation from chief executive Sari Conway with the request that it takes immediate effect. The council will consider this offer when it meets as planned tonight."

Mrs Conway became the council's first woman chief executive in 1995, and rapidly became well known in the town.

She appeared on the BBC series Changing Rooms in 1999, swapping homes with Conservative councillor Mark Roberts, owner of the Belle Tout lighthouse at Beachy Head.

Few details about exactly why Mrs Conway was suspended have so far been released.

fields.headline: Britain's diplomatic dilemma
fields.standfirst: With NMD and Europe's rapid reaction force raising the heat between the US and the EU, Britain risks being caught between two stools, writes Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: With NMD and Europe's rapid reaction force raising the heat between the US and the EU, Britain risks being caught between two stools, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
The extent to which Britain may increasingly be caught between the devil and the deep blue sea - that is to say, between Europe and America - began to become clear this week.

The immediate issue was US President George Bush's plan for a new missile defence system. But several other policy areas provide potential conflicts of interest for Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, and his centre-left government.

National missile defence (NMD) was on the agenda at a discreet dinner given for Mr Blair by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, at his private villa in Berlin last Monday night. Germany, like most EU member states, has expressed serious misgivings about the American plan that it believes will undermine existing arms control agreements and trigger a new international arms race.

The Russian government has also been bending Germany's ear, hoping to strengthen its opposition to NMD. Mr Schröder is understood to have made his views plain to his dinner guest.

Nobody knows exactly what Mr Blair said in reply. But there is no doubt that he is in a tight spot. On the one hand, the very last thing Mr Blair needs is another point of conflict with his EU partners. Despite a news blackout on the Berlin meeting, for example, his spokesman was subsequently forced to deny that the prime minister agreed in principle to tax harmonisation within the EU.

EU control over taxation, along with Britain's possible future membership of the euro, are issues that Mr Blair does not want highlighted in advance of a British general election expected this spring. But if Britain takes a different position on NMD to that of its EU partners and another "Euro-row" erupts, that can only help Britain's Eurosceptic Conservative opposition while further weakening Britain's influence over the future development of the community.

On the other hand, Mr Blair is likely to come under increasing pressure from Washington to endorse the US missile plan and further still, to allow the US to upgrade early warning and radar tracking facilities in Britain. Many within the Labour party, including some senior ministers, may oppose such a decision. But they, like Mr Blair, recognise the overriding need of the Labour government to build a working relationship with the people who now run the government of Britain's closest and most important ally.

Mr Blair and Mr Bush have never met - and worryingly for Downing Street, the Republican president seems to be in no particular hurry to arrange a meeting with a man seen as a close friend of former president Bill Clinton.

They will meet, of course. The difficulty for Mr Blair is that at that key moment, he may be asked to give his blessing to NMD. A refusal would get relations with Dubya off to a very bad start.

The chances are that Britain will go along with the US missile plan while stressing the need for international consultation and agreement, in particular with Russia. The issue may become a little clearer next week, when Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, travels to Washington to meet General Colin Powell, the new US secretary of state, and Pentagon chiefs. NMD cooperation will certainly be discussed.

Any decision by Britain to side with America on this issue is certain to have a knock-on effect on other EU policy areas - including defence, principally the EU's plan for a Rapid Reaction Force (RRF). Britain and France, the two largest contributors to the still notional 60,000-strong force, fell out last month over the question of the RRF's relationship with Nato.

Britain says the force will not compete with, but rather will complement Nato's existing (and pre-eminent) role in European defence. France's President Jacques Chirac, who makes no bones about his view of Nato as an American tool for the continuing US domination of western Europe, said last month that the RRF he envisaged would be independent of Nato - with the implication that it might one day supplant the Atlantic alliance.

Speaking in Brussels this week, Maj-Gen Graham Messervy-Whiting, head of the EU's newly-formed military staff, seemed to agree with Mr Chirac's prognostications. Once an EU army was established, he reportedly suggested, "there will have to be a critical conversation between the EU and Nato over who takes on what".

When these problems over NMD, the RRF, and the future of the Nato alliance are set side by side, the nightmare prospect for Mr Blair of being pulled one way, then another by Europe and America becomes plain.

Even worse, there are other big, potentially divisive issues coming down the pipeline, in particular the German-backed plane for a legally binding European constitution - what Eurosceptics see as a fundamental building block in the construction of a federal European superstate.

Mr Blair knows full well, that, in logic, the more Europe integrates into one economic, trade, military and political bloc, the harder it will be to maintain Britain's traditionally close links with the US. He also knows (or should know) that the Bush administration is probably less interested in Europe than any US government since the second world war. Its emerging priorities are in East Asia, the Middle East, and the Americas.

Up until now, British leaders have managed to avoid having to choose between America and Europe. They have sometimes positioned themselves as "honest brokers" between the two. They may not be able to carry on doing this much longer. To mangle metaphors, Britain, caught between the devil and the deep blue sea, risks falling between two stools - and ending up feeling unloved by all.

fields.headline: New Media Age
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 1
fields.trailText: February 1: Banners and email marketing targeting children could be banned under the new Swedish presidency of the EU.
fields.body:
Banners and email marketing targeting children could be banned under the new Swedish presidency of the European Union.

Leading UK web agency AKQA is moving into offline advertising for the first time.

The National Pharmaceutical Association has today launched a website, AskYourPharmacist.co.uk, which enables its members to build their own transactional websites.

Zefer, which made its name in the UK by poaching VirginNet's entire creative team last April, has imploded, shedding 35 of its 43 London staff.

Sega-Pace deal to pave the way for similar tie-ups.

The British Internet Publishers' Alliance has warned a cross-party group of MPs that the BBC is strangling commercial competition online.

AltaVista Europe's core strategy seemed to be teetering on the brink of collapse following two more top-level management departures.

Sharedetec, launched today, claims to be the first service monitoring bulletin boards to protect against online share abuse.

Homes4u launched today, is promoting itself as the first next-generation multi-channel business model.

Site of the week www.clubinlondon.co.uk scored a total of 77 out of 100: "The comprehensive dance guide to London is back and looking better than ever".

fields.headline: World interest rates
fields.standfirst: As the American economy falters the US central bank has cut interest rates for the second time in a month. What does this mean - and what effect will it have on Britain? Julian Glover explains
fields.trailText: As the American economy falters the US central bank has cut interest rates for the second time in a month. What does this mean - and what effect will it have on Britain?
fields.body:
What has happened?
The Federal Reserve, the world's most powerful bank, decided to reduce its key interest rate from 6% to 5.5% yesterday.

This doesn't sound like much of a change. Why does it matter?
Actually it is quite a big change. Interest rates rarely shift by a larger amount. And it is important for two reasons. Firstly, the cut comes on the back of a similar one earlier this month. This sends a clear signal around the globe that Alan Greenspan, head of the Federal Reserve and the most powerful financial chief in the world, believes interest rates should be lower. Secondly, this rapid rate cut increases the chance that the US economy will not fall into recession. That is good news for everyone, since the US economy is by far the largest in the world. When it falters, other economies, too, stop growing.

But why do interest rates affect the economy?
Because when interest rates are high, companies and people have to pay more to borrow money. As a result they are less likely to do so, and spend less, causing the economy to shrink. When interest rates are low, the reverse happens and economies begin to expand.

So why do interest rates ever rise?
To ensure that economies do not grow out of control. When this happens, inflation takes off - and that, too, causes economic problems.

Sounds like an exact science
But really it is nothing of the sort. In recent years central governments and banks have begun to use interest rates as their chief tool for managing the economy. They raise and lower rates in the same way as a pilot uses flaps on an aeroplane. In both cases the aim is the same, to keep a level course. This doesn't always happen.

So will it work this time?
Probably. The US economy is showing signs of faltering, but it is a long way from a real recession. This recent rate cut may be enough to level things out. On top of that the European economy is still growing, as is Britain's.

What effect will the US rate cut have on Britain?
It makes it more likely that our interest rates will fall - already British rates have reached their likely high point. That means cheaper mortgages and ought to have the side benefit of causing the pound to drop in value against the euro, helping exporters. We'll know on February 8, when the Bank of England's monetary policy committee next meets.

fields.trailText: 11.45am: The news agency has committed itself to the internet by taking a 25% share in Citywire, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Reuters has underlined its commitment to the internet by investing in rival news service Citywire.

The news group is transforming into an internet-based company and has taken a 25% stake in Citywire, which runs the highly rated citywire.co.uk.

"Citywire will complement and reinforce Reuters's evolving products for private investors via the internet," said Mark Wood, managing director of Reuters Content Partners.

"Citywire has one of the strongest and most innovative teams in online financial commentary and we look forward to using its coverage on our planned UK personal finance portal."

The deal is a coup for former Independent on Sunday business news editor Richard Lander and former Mail on Sunday deputy financial editor Lawrence Lever, who founded Citywire two years ago.

Mr Wood, a leading Reuters executive and chairman of ITN, will sit on the board of Citywire.

"We went through the period when we started about 16 months ago when people told us we were worth strange sums of money. But we didn't believe them and what we tried to do was offer something different and not compete head on with everyone else," said Mr Lander who met Mr Wood when he worked at Reuters during the 1980s.

The company now employs 18 financial journalists and provides commentary, analysis and opinion to for private investors.

Under City regulations Reuters cannot provide financial commentary.

Citywire also sells its content to financial institutions such as Old Mutual and Fimatex.

"The relationship with Reuters provides a tremendous platform for the wider distribution of our content," said Mr Lever.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: LONGEST GAP BETWEEN TROPHIES
fields.body:
LONGEST GAP BETWEEN TROPHIES

"My team in Norway, Odd BK, won the Cup last season - their first trophy since 1931. What is the longest gap between two domestic trophies for a European club?" asks Arild Andersen.

Harry Georgiadis and Paul Joyce both point out that Swiss club St Gallen won their league last year - the first time they had been Swiss champions since 1904. That's 96 years. However, they did win the Swiss Cup in 1969, making the gap between pots a mere 65 years.

We reckon Blackburn are the closest English challenger. After winning the FA Cup in 1928, Rovers didn't get their hands on another trophy until 1987, the year they beat Charlton 1-0 with a Colin Hendry goal to win the Full Members Cup - a gap of 59 years.

And if you're talking league titles alone, Blackburn still cut the mustard in this field: their stumble over the Premiership finishing line in 1995 came 81 years after their previous championship in 1914.

MOST PLAYED

What is the most-played fixture in top-flight football in England? asks Simon Conway.

The most-played fixture in top-flight English football involves two of the Football League's founding members, Everton and Aston Villa.

The Goodison giants have only spent four seasons out of the top division since the league was founded in 1888, while Villa have slummed it in the lower leagues for a meagre total of 12 years.

Neither side plumbed the depths at the same time. Therefore, with 98 and 90 top-flight campaigns behind them by the end of last season, this fixture - played 173 times so far - is the one you're after.

FROM GOOD TO BAD

What is the fastest decline of a football club? Has any club ever gone from top-flight to basement in consecutive seasons? asks John Lee

In the Eighties, Bristol City and Wolves both managed to travel from the First to the Fourth Division in consecutive seasons (via the picturesque route of the official receiver's office).

City had enjoyed top-flight footer for four seasons between 1976 and 1980, but upon finally succumbing to relegation went into a sorry tailspin that saw them reach the very bottom of the pile (ie: 92nd place) within two years.

The decline of Wolves was slightly less abject: they didn't actually hit the bottom as they plummeted from the First to the Fourth between seasons 1983-4 and 1985-6. Mind you, having won the League Cup as recently as 1980, you could argue that their slump was even more embarrassing.

STOP IN THE NAME OF SPORT

I have vague memories of a match played, on a wet and dismal night sometime in the early 1960s, between Scotland and Austria at Hampden Park. Am I right in recalling that the game was eventually abandoned because so many Austrians had been sent off? asks Dave Baxter.

Nearly. On May 8 1963, Rangers outside-left Davie Wilson and Manchester United striker Denis Law established a 4-1 lead for Scotland against Austria in front of 95,000 spectators at Hampden.

But after 79 minutes, the massive crowd - and the Scottish team - watched in amazement as the referee stopped play. The reason? Austria were reduced to eight men after two dismissals and an injury and, in the days without subs, it wasn't considered sporting or fair to continue.

CAN YOU HELP?

"What was the highest ever drawn game in terms of goals scored?" asks Gary Ross.

"Who was the first footballer to be sent off for a professional foul?" asks Stuart Baxter.

"Has any player ever scored an FA Cup final goal against the club that sold him?" asks Lee Cafferkey.
