Closer attention, for example, to Marion Kingston Stocking's superb edition of The Clairmont Correspondence (1995) would have allowed Seymour to pinpoint more precisely than she does both Mary's first meeting with Byron, and the actual date (Saturday, 20 April 1816) Claire Clairmont finally manoeuvred him into bed. Seymour's statement that Thomas Moore "had never bothered to read the memoirs which Byron gave him when he visited Venice in the autumn of 1819", and so was entirely dependent in 1827, after they had been destroyed, on Mary Shelley's own account when writing his biography of Byron, is untrue. Unlikely in itself, it is contradicted by a letter of Moore's to Lord Holland in November 1821, in which he specifies the material he believes would need to be censored when the memoirs were eventually published. Her reference to Trelawny's dissolution of his "brief marriage to a maid of Greece", because she tried to abandon native dress for French fashions, rather glosses over the peculiarities - not to say, enormity - of the union itself. One wonders how much Mary Wollstonecraft's daughter ever learned about Trelawny's unfortunate child bride. And the 'Pisan affray' of 1822, of which Mary was a terrified witness - that very ugly skirmish with the dragoon Masi, probably instigated by the authorities in the hope of dislodging the Gamba family and their radical English associates from that part of Italy - could have done with more and sharper attention. In some ways, the second half of Seymour's biography, dealing with Mary Shelley's life between her husband's death in 1822 and her own in 1851, is the fresher and more arresting. This is a comparatively untrodden area. Understandably, the later years have always attracted far less attention than those during which the 16-year-old Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin eloped spectacularly with Shelley from Godwin's London house to the continent, came back to confront debt and estrangement from her father, then - established once more in Switzerland with Shelley - began Frankenstein during the famous ghost-story session with Byron, confronted the suicides of her own half-sister Fanny Imlay and of Shelley's wife Harriet after another return to England, and subsequently (now as Mary Shelley) took up that peripatetic existence in Italy which was to claim the lives of two of their three small children, and ended only when Shelley was drowned. It has sometimes been hard to remember that Mary Shelley's life continued for almost thirty years after that final catastrophe, extending well into the Victorian age. Her widowhood has never haunted biographers or moved them to long for admission to its various supper tables. Yet, as Seymour's book ably demonstrates, this period is in its way quite as extraordinary as the better known earlier one, and equally riddling. Seymour is excellent on the vexed subject of Mary's increasing conservatism: her eventual attempts to conceal something about which she had once been unabashed - that she lived with Shelley before they were actually married - her retreat from the atheism and the radical politics she had once shared with him, and her suppression or alteration, when editing his poetry and prose, of certain passages she came to regard as politically or sexually too outspoken. This was not simply a matter either of youthful unorthodoxy repudiated in age, or of response to the changing social climate in England. Compounded with those factors, at least for a time, was real fear lest she lose possession of her surviving child, Percy Florence, and of the meagre allowance granted the two of them by Shelley's appalling father. (Sir Timothy refused to the end of his days ever to meet her, and did his best to prevent publication of his son's work.) Seymour's respect and affection for Mary Shelley, attractively evident throughout, are especially conspicuous in these final sections of her book, as she sets out to chart Mary's struggle to earn badly needed money for herself, her stolid and disappointing son, and her distinguished but perpetually indigent father in the only way available to her: through her writing. As heroic in its way as Walter Scott's determination to pay off his creditors with the proceeds from yet another novel, it was further complicated by what became her crying - and unsatisfied - need once more to love and be loved in return. Mary Shelley's journals after Shelley's death make painful reading. By September 1824, an undeniable deep grief for the partner she had lost, rendered worse by her own sense of having failed him during his last years, was merging with cries that "now I am not loved - I never never shall be loved more - never o never more shall I love . . . - never more shall I be happy - never more feel life sit triumphant in my frame - I am a wreck." She had already made the first of what were to prove many attempts to find "Another Companion!": not of course another Shelley - he was irreplaceable and unique - but someone with less transcendent qualities to whom, nevertheless, she could devote herself during what remained of her life. (She was then only 27.) "I cannot live," she moaned in September 1826, "without loving & being loved." The various men on whom in the course of time she seems to have placed her hopes (Bryan Proctor, Aubrey Beauclerk, John Howard Payne, Washington Irving, Prosper Mझrimझe) tended to want too much from her, remain elusive or abruptly marry someone else. Most depressing of all was her late romantic fixation on the Italian adventurer Ferdinando Gatteschi, to whom she gave sums of money she could ill afford, and from whom she was eventually obliged to extract compromising personal letters of her own under a threat of blackmail. The most excruciating disappointment, however, stemmed from a woman not a man. Jane Williams had shared those last months in Italy and, whatever Mary Shelley may have felt at the time about her husband's attentions to this attractive musician to whom he addressed some of the most yearningly exquisite of his late lyrics, once back in England she herself became "excessively", as she admitted, attached to her. Jane was her "sole delight", and although aware from the start that her own affection was stronger than Jane's, she nonetheless felt for a time that she lived "to all good & pleasure only thro' her". Their relationship foundered when Mary learned, first that without confiding in her at all, Jane had married Thomas Jefferson Hogg, by whom she was pregnant, and then that she had spread ugly tales about the unhappy marriage of Percy and Mary Shelley, and how greatly Mary's coldness had been to blame. That, given her own remorseful feelings about their last years together, was to inflict a particularly grievous wound. Seymour tells this story of betrayal well. She is also able, largely thanks to Betty Bennett's painstaking and brilliant recovery of the history of Walter Sholto Douglas, as set out in her book Mary Diana Dods: A Gentleman and a Scholar (1991), to illuminate Mary Shelley's proud assertion, in her journal for October 1828, that although she may never have written as her mother did, "to vindicate the Rights of women, I have ever befriended women when oppressed - at every risk I have defended and supported victims to the social system". The story of Mary Diana Dods, the illegitimate and, in conventional terms, unattractive daughter of a Scottish earl, who assumed both a male identity and masculine dress, and passed herself off successfully for some time in Parisian society as the husband of Isabel Robinson, and father of 'their' child, is remarkable in itself. But it is also remarkable that the Mary Shelley who increasingly tried to bury her own irregular past, and declared in 1838 that "since I lost Shelley I have no wish to ally myself to the Radicals - they are full of repulsion to me" should nevertheless have gone far beyond any radical brief by supporting Mary Diana, of whose lesbian orientation she must have been entirely aware, to the extent of welcoming her transvestism and even being instrumental in negotiating a forged passport in 1827 for 'Walter' and his 'wife'. Mary Shelley was inclined, following Shelley's death, to become a bit 'tousy-mousy' (as she enigmatically put it) for women. Although her own fiction after Frankenstein and Matilda carries a somewhat dispiriting freight of gentle and inevitably golden-haired charmers, their self-sacrificing attentions entirely focused on men, she did once tentatively suggest, in her novel Lodore (1835), a very different scenario. Fanny Derham in that book, a young woman of superior intellect and learning, is described as "more made to be loved by her own sex than by the opposite one". But she hovers on the outskirts of the plot, never fully integrated into it, and Mary Shelley interestingly refuses to tell her story: "What the events are that have already diversified her existence, cannot now be recounted; and it would require the gift of prophecy to foretell the conclusion. In after times these may be told." One would certainly rather hear more about Fanny than about Lodore's daughter, the saintly and unconvincing Ethel, but as Caroline Gonda has wittily remarked (in the special Mary Shelley issue of Women's Writing, 1999), "like Sherlock Holmes's encounter with the Giant Rat of Sumatra, it seems, the tale of Fanny Derham is a story for which the world is not yet prepared." Miranda Seymour says about Fanny Derham only that "she declares with Mary's own passion the importance of championing oppressed women." With Lodore, as elsewhere in writing about Mary Shelley's fiction, she is primarily concerned to sketch plots, then identify various autobiographical elements: Lodore himself as a portrait of Byron, Ethel's intense relationship with her father as a reflection of Mary's with Godwin, Ethel and Edward Villiers's attempts to evade the London bailiffs as mirroring Shelley's financial predicament in 1814, Lady Santerre as a portrait of Lady Shelley, even the reformed Cornelia Lodore, in the second half of the book, as a projection of Mary. Although Seymour briefly suggests that Lodore should not be dismissed as just another 'silverfork' novel, she never really addresses herself to its peculiarities or to the question of its artistic merits. A similar shying away from engagement with Mary Shelley's work, except as it comments on her life, is evident throughout this (again) not-very-literary biography. Seymour has, of course, a particular excuse for writing (in Barrell's terms) yet another 'new novel': the compulsively self-reflexive nature of Mary Shelley's fictions - a tendency increasingly marked after the early Frankenstein. Her novels might indeed be classified as a form of very literary biography. How good are they, when viewed in detachment from their author's life? A hint of what might be Seymour's actual opinion surfaces when she observes of the short critical-biographical notes on Italian, Spanish and French literature that Mary Shelley wrote over a period of some five years in the 1830s that she may well have felt "this kind of work suited her as well as, and possibly better than 'romancing'," adding, significantly, that "few readers today would disagree, if they were able to sample her contributions to the Lardner Cyclopaedia, long out of print." (The Lardner Lives are not represented in the fine 1996 Pickering and Chatto edition of Mary Shelley's works, under the general editorship of Nora Crook.) Seymour's reservations here were anticipated by Muriel Spark in her own crisply excellent Mary Shelley (revised edition, 1988), a book neatly divided between biography and literary criticism, which praises the Lives while finding only Frankenstein, The Last Man and isolated passages in Perkin Warbeck worth serious attention among the fictions. That, however, is not at present a fashionable view. The bicentenary of Mary Shelley's birth, 1997, generated a number of conferences and publications in her honour. Academic journals produced special Mary Shelley issues, and two other collections have now appeared, one edited by Betty Bennett and Stuart Curran, the other by Michael Eberle-Sinatra. Much recent Mary Shelley criticism, as might be expected, is specifically feminist in orientation, some though not all of it concerned with the way her fictions shadow her own life and that of various people she knew. Other writers address her editing, travel books and reviews, or else explore her novels as comments on current affairs. A certain amount, perhaps less persuasively, is psychoanalytic. (Do we gain much by being told that Frankenstein's Creature - looked at closely - is a daughter, that the shudder which convulses its limbs as it awakens into life is an orgasm, or that what Matilda beholds when she discovers her drowned father's body in the cottage on the beach, 'something stiff and straight' covered by a sheet, is undeniably a phallus?) There is some excellent and fresh new work in the various anthologies - the Gonda piece, for instance, William St Clair on The Impact of Frankenstein, Michael O'Neill on Mary Shelley as an editor, Charles Robinson on Mathilda as Dramatic Actress (the last three in the Bennett/Curran collection) or Nora Crook intelligently defending the revised 1831 Frankenstein in Eberle-Sinatra. But, for some readers, nagging doubts are likely to remain about the stature of Mary Shelley's work as a whole. There is a case for adding Matilda to Frankenstein and The Last Man as a major achievement. A novella that remained unpublished until 1959 (Godwin, to whom Mary sent the manuscript from Italy, suppressed it, understandably horrified by the implications of its incestuous father/daughter relationship), it is powerful in some of the same visionary ways that Frankenstein and The Last Man - especially Book Three of the latter - are powerful. Part of the trouble with the others stems from Mary Shelley's clumsiness with dialogue. Her characters tend to speak in long, stilted paragraphs and, however impressive her historical research (as in Valperga and Perkin Warbeck), she is rarely convincing in her portrayal of human relationships other than those of a most extreme and unusual kind. Hence her success with Frankenstein and the Creature, or Matilda and her father, but failure with the happy de Lacey family in Frankenstein, or with the love of Perdita and Raymond in The Last Man. Where all her novels shine is in the evocation of place, whether the rigours of the frozen north, or, more usually, the varied landscape of Italy. She is at her finest when Lionel Verney, in The Last Man, is left as the sole human survivor of the plague, and wanders through noiseless and unpopulated cities, particularly Rome at the end, where the grass grows between the stones of the streets, and only the colossal wreck of a civilisation is to be seen. The other problem is Mary Shelley's lack of a sense of humour. This deficiency is one her admirers have indignantly denied as "a canard", pointing to her acceptance of such nicknames as 'Pecksie' or 'Maie', her unchaperoned excursion to the opera in London with Jane Williams, when the two of them pretended to be Italian ladies, and giggled a lot, or to those rather ponderously 'light' short stories Roger Dodsworth: The Reanimated Englishman or The Bride of Modern Italy. Not all readers will be convinced. That Mary Shelley was capable of sharply turned and acerbic comment is incontrovertible. Laughter is another matter. To have christened one of her two heroines in Valperga 'Euthanasia' is indicative enough. It was like her also to believe that the fifth act of The Cenci was Shelley's finest work, and to take so strongly against his scintillating jeu d'esprit The Witch of Atlas, apparently because it contained "no human interest", that her husband was moved to address a reproachful poem to her on the subject. One sometimes wonders whether, as she made all those fair copies for Byron of cantos of Don Juan, a smile ever crossed her lips. Certainly she manages, in her note on Shelley's Peter Bell the Third, to avoid any suggestion that the poem might be funny, not simply designed for the "instruction and benefit" of the world. Having registered this, however, one is likely at once to feel churlish. There wasn't, after all, a great deal in Mary Shelley's eventful but tormented life for her to laugh about: from Mary Wollstonecraft's death (caused by complications resulting from her own birth), her problematic relations with Godwin and with her stepmother and stepsister, the suicides of her half-sister and of Shelley's first wife, the deaths of three of her small children, followed by the uneven years with Shelley, his drowning, and the long, dreary aftermath in England in which she was left to live with her remorse and, finally, only a devoted daughter-in-law for support. As Miranda Seymour says, in the final pages of this long biography, although "hounded, persecuted and vilified", Mary Shelley nonetheless never surrendered, remaining to the end generous, forgiving and hopeful. That, under the circumstances, was no mean achievement.  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. webTitle: Coke admits failures in key markets

fields.headline: Coke admits failures in key markets
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The world's best-known brand, Coca-Cola, has admitted its marketing efforts have failed in key markets, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The world's best-known brand, Coca-Cola, has admitted its marketing efforts have failed in two of its key markets.

Coca-Cola president and chief operating officer Jack Stahl said the company was disappointed with its marketing efforts in the US and Germany, which he said have failed to communicate "brand Coke".

As a remedy, Coke is planning to put into action aggressive marketing plans. Sales in Germany and the US, two of the firm's largest markets, have been flat over the fourth quarter.

Coke, which spends £80m a year on global advertising, has been struggling to reorganise its marketing and advertising arrangements over the past year.

It aims to make its marketing more responsive to local conditions and has put in place a "Think local, act local" mandate.

Douglas Daft, Coke worldwide president, last year declared his intent to devolve marketing control out of the company's Atlanta headquarters and allow local managers greater autonomy.

"When you are the world's biggest brand you must guard not only against complacency, but also narcissism - the temptation to stare into the mirror when you should be looking out of the window," he said.

"Our business is not about understanding our brand, it's about understanding people."

As part of the revamp, Coke disbanded its in-house advertising agency Edge Creative and launched a global advertising review of all its brands.

In November 2000, Publicis picked up Coke's pan-European branding assignment, to develop the brand's "Enjoy" theme for European markets.

It was the first time Coke had appointed a network to produce work on a regional basis. In 1999 the agency was hired to spearhead a crisis communications programme after tainted Coke cans were found in Belgium.

webTitle: Dispatch from Florida: Tampa rocks the Gaspar

fields.headline: Tampa rocks the Gaspar
fields.standfirst: Three centuries ago Spanish pirate Jose Gaspar invaded Tampa. In celebration of 'Gasparilla' the town is still besieged each year by beer-swilling blokes heading for the nearest lap-dancing club, reports Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: Three centuries ago Spanish pirate Jose Gaspar invaded Tampa. In celebration of 'Gasparilla' the town is still besieged each year by beer-swilling blokes heading for the nearest lap-dancing club, reports Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
This could almost be the end of time. Helicopters buzz overhead while people below dart in all directions through streets ankle deep in trash.

Explosions sound from below the bridges and the three-card monte scam merchants try to squeeze a last couple of hundred dollars from any dupe rash enough to approach their makeshift tables. A pair of gents dressed as ancient Christians haul crosses on their shoulders, their burdens eased only by the wheels at the bottom of the wooden shafts.

In fact, it is only a party. Specifically, this is Gasparilla, the annual celebration of the invasion of what is now Tampa, Florida, by an 18th century Spanish pirate, one Jose Gaspar. This is a big deal here, the nearest the city can get to Mardi Gras in New Orleans.

More than 750,000 people made it to Tampa for this year's rather thin excuse for an extravaganza, all of them sporting strings of cheap beads, some in such numbers that it seemed as though they were wearing chain-mail armour.

Certainly, more sensitive souls needed some defence against the American genius for staging a big event (How else could the United States have run a soccer World Cup in 1994 in honour of a sport that barely registers in an environment dominated by baseball, basketball and football played by the indigenous code?)

It is not unlike Twickenham on a rugby day, though with more people, more choreographed pizzazz and more sunshine though there is much anguish locally that the temperature in January was down to a daytime average of just above 17C (63F).

Hundreds, perhaps thousands of boats bob about just off the waterfront, the most ostentatious gin palaces sharing the surface with the most modest beer punts, all just inches apart. Perhaps this is as close as they get to operating a successful democracy in Florida.

Horns blow, canon blast, voices howl and beads are thrown from craft to craft as a B-52 bomber performs tentative stunts. Some boats have inflatable sofas and chairs on deck, holes strategically placed in the armrests to offer a handy refuge for beverages.

Señor Gaspar's invasion would hardly have been noticed had it happened in the middle of this lot. Next came a parade of floats through streets stocked with retail opportunities, stalls selling plastic cutlasses, blow-up jolly jack tars and all the other must-have piratical accessories of the season.

Do not kid yourself that it is the prerogative of the English to misbehave in public on the high days of the calendar. A short walk over a bridge from the centre of activities takes you to Four Green Fields, a pub where only the recently signed photographs of Gerry Adams serve to remind that the Easter Rising did not happen the day before yesterday.

The six foot wire fence enclosing the establishment and its grounds charges the air further with republican nostalgia even if its true purpose is to create a social system that divides those who are prepared to pay a cover charge of $10 from those who are not.

Mostly, these two groups observe each other in a good-natured fashion. After all, this is a social occasion. "There's a Belfast man and a Cork man playing at 5 o'clock," says the barman. The two open up at the appointed hour with Van Morrison's Brown-Eyed Girl.

But before that there is an even more discordant racket. "Go, you losers," a tall, well-built man in his 20s and with a square jaw is chanting from beyond the wire at a group from New Jersey inside. This goes on until a bottle of Amstel Light hits the fence in front of Square-Jaw's face. "OK, I'm gonna get you," he promises, pointing a finger and making his way to the entrance, where he is stopped by two boyish policemen who do not look up to the challenge despite the guns on their hips. "The cops are asking me who it is but don't worry, I'm not telling," he shouts. "It's cool, but later Pretty Boy, it's you and me. Believe it." Pretty Boy, with his tortoiseshell shades propped up in his carefully fashioned blond hair, has the look of David Beckham without the brains.

This exchange goes on for more than an hour. Square-Jaw keeps returning, always with the girlfriend who remains steadfast in her support for his vendetta, while Pretty Boy starts to look a little sheepish, even from the safety of his bellowing group.

If nothing else, this is a useful warm-up for the evening's events in Ybor City. This is the neighbourhood east of downtown that was once the centre of the nation's cigar-making industry and now, at least at night, likes to take on what it fancies to be some of the atmosphere of Bourbon Street in New Orleans (there's no escaping the place).

Here, girls dance on almost every bartop in a ritualistic facsimile of sexuality and the five blocks cordoned off for the pursuit of fun are close to impassable, or impossible, due to the crush of people. A horde of young men wielding beers is braying up at a group of women lined up along an ornate metal balcony, teasing the testosterone below by toying with their tops. The ensemble cry goes up: "Show us your tits, show us your tits."

Gaspar the pragmatic pirate might at this point have hailed a cab, had he been able to find one, and headed for Mons Venus, the establishment most closely associated with Tampa's reputation as the home of lap-dancing.

fields.headline: Britain's holocaust shame
fields.trailText: Nunca mas - never again! - is the only possible response to contemplation of the last century's crimes against humanity. The first Holocaust Memorial Day last weekend rightly recalled Britain's sacrifices to stop Nazism, but paid less attention to failures in combating other genocides, in particular its role in the worst modern holocaust denial: Rwanda, 1994.
fields.body:
Nunca mas - never again! - is the only possible response to contemplation of the last century's crimes against humanity. The first Holocaust Memorial Day last weekend rightly recalled Britain's sacrifices to stop Nazism, but paid less attention to failures in combating other genocides, in particular its role in the worst modern holocaust denial: Rwanda, 1994.

There is, in British foreign policy, a persistent strain of reluctance to punish the authors of genocide, from 1920 when it urged abandonment of trials of Turkish leaders guilty of directing the Armenian massacres, to encouraging the absurd 1999 amnesty for Foday Sankoh in Sierra Leone. The Nuremberg trial after the second world war and its associated proceedings produced a rule of international law that states have a duty to prevent and punish crimes against humanity. That legal obligation was soon spelled out, in respect of the most wicked of all such crimes, by article one of the 1948 Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide. By this treaty, states pledged themselves to act immediately to stop any systematic attempts to destroy an ethnic or racial group by mass murder, starvation and the like. The UK was not alone in ignoring the implications of the convention (it supported the Nigerian war against the Ibo people of Biafra and the rehabilitation of the Khmer Rouge by permitting it to share Cambodia's seat at the United Nations).

But there is no example of British acquiescence in genocide so inexplicable, and so unexplained, as the behaviour of John Major's government during the racial slaughter which began in Rwanda on April 6, 1994. This continued for 12 weeks, and some 900,000 non-combatant civilians were killed. The daily death rate is estimated to have been more than five times that of the Nazi concentration camps at their murderous peak. Why did the UK, holding a permanent seat at the UN security council, turn its back on legal obligations under the genocide convention?

The security council members took care to meet over the crisis in secret session. But evidence has emerged indicating that the UK led the opposition to intervention, on the pretence that what was happening in Rwanda was not genocide. Its central role was first exposed by the independent UN inquiry, chaired by Ingvar Carissen. His report reveals that the UK actually urged a pull-out of the existing but inadequate Unamir force, and even rejected a United States proposal to send a fact-finding mission to the region once the death toll reached six figures. Worst of all, in Carissen's view, was the refusal of the permanent members (led by Britain) "to acknowledge that the mass murder being pursued in front of the global media was a genocide". The consequence of the failure to strengthen Unamir may be judged by the fact that the UN commander on the ground, General Dallaire, estimated (when the death toll was still in five figures) that he could curb it with 5,500 more crack troops.

The case for an inquiry into the decision-making behind government policy on Rwanda is further strengthened by revelations in a new book, A People Betrayed - The Role Of The West In Rwanda's Genocide, by journalist Linda Melvern. She uses leaked security council minutes to demonstrate the UK's leading role in rejecting Western intervention when Human Rights Watch reminded security council members of their obligations under the genocide convention. She suggests that Parliament was misled by ministers when Labour forced a debate on Rwanda.

The memorial day's motto was "Remembering genocides. Lessons for the future". Lessons will not be learnt until we have a full inquiry into whether, and if so why, our foreign policy abandoned obligations to the people of Rwanda. Some explanations are easier than others: the Clinton administration, obsessed by the Mogadishu disaster, refused to contemplate another African intervention.

Did the US dictate the British response? Was there some subconsciously skewed perception which could recognise ethnic cleansing in Yugoslavia as genocide but not black-on-black violence in Africa?

There is another reason for a British inquiry. President Clinton in 1998 apologised for the Anglo-American position: "We did not act quickly enough after the killing began . . . we did not immediately call those crimes by their rightful name, genocide. Never again must we be shy in the face of the evidence." But there was a chilling exchange in the second presidential debate when George Bush disagreed with Al Gore's admission of this mistake: Bush thought the Rwandan genocide really was beneath US notice. Unless he changes his mind, there may be more holocausts to remember on the Holocaust memorial days to come.

the author of Crimes Against

Humanity (Penguin)

webTitle: Clunes stars in latest Nescafe ad

fields.headline: Clunes stars in latest Nescafe ad
fields.trailText: 12pm: Martin Clunes is the new face of Nescafe coffee in the latest of a series of celebrity ads, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Martin Clunes is to be the new face of Nescafe coffee in the latest of a series of celebrity-fronted adverts for the brand.

But the ad, called "noisy neighbours", shows the former Men Behaving Badly star in an entirely new light - as the sensible and deeply uncool neighbour of hell-raising youngsters.

The £8.5m national TV, poster and radio drive, which breaks on February 5, is the latest in a two-year celebrity-driven campaign that has featured Ian Wright, Chris Eubank, Denise Van Outen and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen.

The ad shows an angry Martin Clunes knocking on the door of his young neighbours, who are energetically rehearsing a song.

"Do you know what time it is?" he asks, to which the reply comes, "No, is it by the Stones?".

The lead singer of the band then brings out mugs of Nescafe to calm things down, as the hapless Mr Clunes returns clutching a recorder in the hope of accompanying the band.

"Realign your MoJo with Nescafe Original," advises the voiceover.

"Martin Clunes has universal appeal - both with the young and older consumer, and so was a perfect choice for Nescafe Original," said Brett Grebert, category marketing manager at Nestle.

"This is the next stage of development in our celebrity campaign, driving the appeal of Nescafe to a more youthful audience."

fields.headline: Mandelson resigns over passport deception
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's glittering political career collapsed for the second and final time over an unnecessary act of deception - his fatal refusal to be frank with the Prime Minister about his role in brokering a British passport for a £1m donor to the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's glittering political career collapsed for the second and final time over an unnecessary act of deception - his fatal refusal to be frank with the Prime Minister about his role in brokering a British passport for a £1m donor to the Millennium Dome.

On Wednesday of last week, in a day of high drama not equalled at Westminster since Mr Mandelson's previous resignation, over his secret home loan in 1998, the man who helped to craft New Labour's modernising image for 15 years stepped down as the Northern Ireland Secretary and renounced all strategic responsibility for the coming general election.

In an hour-long meeting Tony Blair and the man who had been his most trusted aide discussed why the media, the Prime Minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, and ministers were misled for 48 hours about Mr Mandelson's single phone call to Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister, in June 1998.

Mr Mandelson, the MP for Hartlepool, insisted that he had done nothing improper, but accepted that he had not told the whole truth about his intervention in the application for naturalisation by Srichand Hinduja, a wealthy Indian businessman, known as S P.

After revelations in the Observer, Mr Mandelson insisted that he had merely asked his private office to pass on a request for information regarding a possible application from Mr Hinduja to the Home Office in June 1998. In fact he made the crucial two-minute phone call in person.

In the same month S P and his brother Gopichand, who was granted British citizenship in 1997, offered to sponsor the faith zone at the Millennium Dome. Mr Mandelson, as the Cabinet Office minister, was in charge of the project. The coincidence prompted opposition MPs to accuse the minister of selling a passport in return for what turned out be a £1m contribution, which was formally announced in October 1998.

In his resignation statement Mr Mandelson denied acting improperly, but admitted: "I do accept that when my office spoke to a Sunday newspaper at the weekend I should have been clear that it was me personally, not my officials, who spoke to a Home Office minister."

He also attacked the media for its relentless vilification of his political role as a pro-European, pro-Lib-Lab moderate, and for its interest in his private life.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP whose Commons questions prompted Mr Mandelson's evasive answer to the Observer, established that both brothers were turned down for UK passports in 1990, apparently because they had not spent enough time in Britain.

The newspapers were united in not mourning Mr Mandelson's passing, but they all felt that in European terms the winners were the Eurosceptics, and in this context the Chancellor, Gordon Brown.

"The Cabinet has lost its most passionate pro-European," said the euro-supportive Financial Times, "and Mr Blair has been left more vulnerable." Some of Mr Blair's friends had said they feared it would make Mr Brown over-powerful, especially in decisions such as whether Labour would call a referendum on the euro if re-elected.

In the Commons William Hague gleefully denounced Mr Blair's "monumental error of judgment" in giving his old friend a second chance in 1999.

Mr Blair quickly appointed a leading QC, the former Treasury counsel Sir Anthony Hammond, to examine the way S P's passport was granted - although the Prime Minister told MPs that he and the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, were satisfied that it was properly done. The inquiry should be completed by early March.

It was widely known at the time S P applied for a British passport that he and his brother could face charges in India over the acceptance of an alleged £7m kickback from the Bofors sale of guns to the Indian army. Last week they were granted bail by an Indian court while the allegations are investigated, but were refused permission to leave the country.

Later Keith Vaz, the Europe minister and Britain's most prominent Asian MP, became embroiled in the controversy when the Conservatives tabled a clutch of parliamentary questions about his involvement with the Hindujas.

Sir Anthony's inquiry will now include letters written by Mr Vaz to the Home Office asking about progress on the Hindujas' applications for UK passports.

Extensive contacts between the billionaire brothers and ministers were then detailed by a meeting-by-meeting account released by the Department of Trade and Industry.

The Trade and Industry Secretary, Stephen Byers, authorised publication of the list as officials, mindful of how Mr Mandelson's evasiveness cost him his career, insisted that the department wanted to be open.

But when the Guardian applied for a copy of the official record of the key conversation between Mr Mandelson and Mr O'Brien over the passport application, the Home Office refused to publish it.

A former adviser to the brothers explained their attitude to politicians, both Labour and Conservative, revealing that the Hindujas see them "as a commodity to trade with".

Events deteriorated last weekend when Mr Straw spearheaded a Cabinet assault on Mr Mandelson in the wake of his decision to launch a fightback to clear his name. "There is no doubt by his own admission that he told an untruth," Mr Straw said.

His criticism was echoed by the International Development Secretary, Clare Short. "Peter Mandelson went last Wednesday because he has got problems telling the truth," Ms Short said. "Peter Mandelson is over."

In an article in the Sunday Times Mr Mandelson said he had been forced to resign after a "summary exploration of limited available evidence" about his role in the affair.

Downing Street's attempts to distance itself from Mr Mandelson played a hand in persuading him to put his side of the saga on the record.

He highlighted the end of his political alliance with Mr Blair when he wrote of how he lost the will to fight for the first time in his life during their fateful meeting.

"I felt isolated," he wrote. "I knew I hadn't done anything wrong, but I had no time to prove it. I agreed to resign and the Prime Minister - understandably, given the presentation of the facts - did not try to dissuade me. I should have fought for time to allow a fuller examination of the facts."

However, Mr Mandelson's lengthy article only served to tarnish his reputation further after he admitted that a week before his resignation Mr Straw had reminded him of the telephone conversation with Mr O'Brien. His failure to recall this conversation was the "killer fact" that prompted Mr Blair to dispense with his ally.

Mr Mandelson also admitted that his initial instinct was to ask the Home Office to keep his name out of the parliamentary written reply about the passport application that led to his downfall.

Such an elaborate defence is said to have appalled Downing Street. Beyond Mr Mandelson's attempts to justify his actions, there is a final factor that guarantees his exile. He has claimed his memory may have been hazy because of the burden of the peace process.

"Part of the problem, and Peter would accept this, I think, is that there were things that Peter cannot explain and cannot explain to himself," Mr Campbell said. "I think he has been slightly detached."

webTitle: In brief: Love's Labours flop turns Branagh off Shakespeare

fields.headline: Love's Labours flop turns Branagh off Shakespeare
fields.standfirst: Plus: DreamWorks snaps up remake rights to Japanese horror film, Ring
fields.trailText: Plus: DreamWorks snaps up remake rights to Japanese horror film, Ring
fields.body:
 One of history's great movie romances could well be nearing an end with the news that William Shakespeare and blushing Kenneth Branagh (pictured) are kaput at least for now. Apparently hurt by the poor critical and commercial response to his last Shakespeare adaptation, Love's Labours Lost, Branagh has decided to put the Bard on the back burner and mothball two other putative projects. A spokesman for the actor-director yesterday told the Independent newspaper that: "Love's Labours Lost was a brave attempt to do something different and the audience just didn't get it. I think probably he is not hurrying to make the other two Shakespeare movies because he is concentrating on other things." Love's Labours Lost re-framed the Bard's romance as a musical in jolly-hockeysticks pre-war Britain. According to insiders Branagh had (no joke) been planning a Macbeth set on Wall Street and As You Like It in a Japanese tea garden. Both are now languishing on the pending pile.

 DreamWorks has inked a deal costing a reported $1m (£681,000) to obtain the distribution and remake rights to cult Japanese horror yarn, Ring. A breakthrough hit, Hideo Nakata's film tells the story of a mysterious video cassette that apparently causes death in the viewer a week after watching it. The film, which was such a hit in Japan that it spawned a sequel, enjoyed decent reviews and a highly successful limited run on British screens last autumn.

webTitle: Hasselhoff withdraws from Dundee's rector election

fields.headline: Hasselhoff withdraws from Dundee's rector election
fields.trailText: The Baywatch star David Hasselhoff has withdrawn from the race to become rector at Dundee University, the university announced today.
fields.body:
The Baywatch star David Hasselhoff has withdrawn from the race to become rector at Dundee University, the university announced today.

Mr Hasselhoff said he was flattered by the nomination to represent the students at Dundee but found himself unable to fulfil the duties because of a hectic work schedule.

If voted in, Mr Hasselhoff would have added to a long tradition of famous Scottish rectors, whose job is to represent student interests and concerns. Richard Wilson, alias Victor Meldrew from the series One Foot In The Grave, was rector at Glasgow, while the chancellor Gordon Brown was rector at Edinburgh University.

But Mr Hasselhoff, who first rose to fame in the UK as the star of the TV series Knightrider, faxed university officials to say he would only be able to visit Dundee once a year which was not enough to honour the duties of rector. He may come to speak to the students at some point in the future.

Students' association president Dave Cunningham said: "This race will see the election of a committed rector who will visit the campus often and represent the needs and views of the students. David Hasselhoff's decision to withdraw because he could not honour the substantial commitment is an encouragement to all the students to elect a rector who can effectively represent them."

The election for University of Dundee Rector will take place on Friday 9 February. The official list of candidates now consists of Dr Abd-al-Fattah El-Awaisi, Nick Johnston MSP, comedian Fred MacAulay and Richard Whiteley, host of the Countdown TV programme.

Hustings will take place on 7 February at the Dundee University students'association.

fields.headline: Feeling Sky Blue
fields.standfirst: Neville Hadsley, editor of fanzine Gary Mabbutt's Knee, on why Coventry fans have had enough
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan is a great guy. I'll say that from the start. As a person, I think he is fantastic. Honest, passionate, dedicated, loyal. I think the vast majority of Sky Blues fans, even his fiercest critics, would agree with me on that.
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan is a great guy. I'll say that from the start. As a person, I think he is fantastic. Honest, passionate, dedicated, loyal. I think the vast majority of Sky Blues fans, even his fiercest critics, would agree with me on that.

But he has not been good for Coventry City.

Some fans of other clubs crave for stability. Manchester City fans swear by it. We at Coventry have been cursed by it. We have had our most stable period of management at Highfield Road since another Gordon - Milne - was in charge in the 1970s. But all it has brought us is mediocrity and the real prospect of relegation for the first time in over 40 years.

A national newspaper recently calculated that we were the ninth-highest net spenders in the Premiership over the last five years - a period that roughly corresponds to Strachan's reign

That reign has brought us finishes of 17th, 11th, 15th and 16th. Hardly the sort of stuff to get Sky Blues supporters dancing in the streets. Only Middlesbrough have seen a greater underperformance on the cash-to-success meter - and they've been to three finals.

The problem is, well, everything. Gordon's judgement on players is poor. He paid £6.5m for Craig Bellamy when he is hardly worth a third of that. Bellamy was bought as a striker but it took the manager three months to realise that he works best in midfield.

Gordon plays players out of position - until recently we had a right-footed midfielder at left-back. He doesn't know what his best team is and cannot change the course of a game when he sees it going wrong. Tactically he is poor, his talent-spotting is unsound and his legendary motivational powers are waning. In every department he is found wanting.

But the fans would not mind so much if he got in some help. When Alex Ferguson loses his number two he goes out and gets another. When Gordon lost his two years ago he concluded he did not need a replacement. We have been in decline ever since.

If relegation happens, Strachan will still have a job at Highfield Road, partly because the chairman is fanatically loyal to him, partly because the cost of sacking him is something we cannot afford.

People ask Coventry fans: "You enjoy a good relegation scrap don't you?" Well, no. It's a nice feeling when we survive, but to be constantly scrabbling around at the bottom of the league is an embarrassment. That's why the demonstrations against the manager and the board that supports him was so passionate after the defeat against Everton.

We're fed up, not just with the manager, but a board that takes all the advantages of Premiership status and converts them into ashes. We are not a well-run club. And that explains why we struggle.

The problem is, well, everything. Gordon's judgement on players is poor. He paid £6.5m for Craig Bellamy when he is hardly worth a third of that. Bellamy was bought as a striker but it took the manager three months to realise that he works best in midfield. Gordon plays players out of position - until recently we had a right-footed midfielder at left-back. He doesn't know what his best team is and cannot change the course of a game when he sees it going wrong. Tactically he is poor, his talent-spotting is unsound and his legendary motivational powers are waning. In every department he is found wanting. But the fans would not mind so much if he got in some help. When Alex Ferguson loses his number two he goes out and gets another. When Gordon lost his two years ago he concluded he did not need a replacement. We have been in decline ever since. If relegation happens, Strachan will still have a job at Highfield Road, partly because the chairman is fanatically loyal to him, partly because the cost of sacking him is something we cannot afford. People ask Coventry fans: "You enjoy a good relegation scrap don't you?" Well, no. It's a nice feeling when we survive, but to be constantly scrabbling around at the bottom of the league is an embarrassment. That's why the demonstrations against the manager and the board that supports him was so passionate after the defeat against Everton. We're fed up, not just with the manager, but a board that takes all the advantages of Premiership status and converts them into ashes. We are not a well-run club. And that explains why we struggle.

webTitle: An exchange of knowledge, World Bank style

fields.headline: An exchange of knowledge, World Bank style
fields.trailText: Yesterday, the Guardian published a leaked World Bank memo, which criticized the Bank's President, James Wolfensohn, for being "isolated from reality" and fostering "an atmosphere of fear" in the Bank.  Wolfensohn has been busy for the last few years trying to re-create the Bank as a disinterested participant in global debates around development.  Yet, the memo says, he has failed to "practice the values and behaviours he espouses for the rest of us".
fields.body:
Yesterday, the Guardian published a leaked World Bank memo, which criticized the Bank's President, James Wolfensohn, for being "isolated from reality" and fostering "an atmosphere of fear" in the Bank. Wolfensohn has been busy for the last few years trying to re-create the Bank as a disinterested participant in global debates around development. Yet, the memo says, he has failed to "practice the values and behaviours he espouses for the rest of us".

A similar lapse between rhetoric and reality appears to have been the order of the day at the second Conference of Parliamentarians with the World Bank last weekend. Parliamentarians from 35 countries including the UK, the Netherlands, Denmark, Finland, Norway, Uganda convened at the House of Commons to debate a series of key development concerns. Clare Short topped the bill, but less internationally conspicuous power-mongers were also in force: Bowen Wells, MP (also Chairman of the International Development Select Committee), Mats Karlsson, Vice President, External Affairs, World Bank, Daniel Kaufmann, Director of the World Bank Institute, as well as a host of leaders of NGOs such as the Bretton Woods Project and academics from institutions such as the LSE.

Topics under discussion included: "Responding to Globalisation: What Role Can Parliamentarians and Civil Society Play?"; "The structure of Foreign Aid and International Development"; "Beyond Debt Relief: Fighting Poverty"; "After Seattle: Where are we going in Trade and Development"; "High Noon: The Urgent Need for New Global Governance". The conference also established a new Parliamentarians network.

The Bank presented its motives for the conference in the sort of terms it likes to use: "to inform parliamentarians about the Bank's role in poverty reduction and convey its readiness to share its knowledge resources". The World Bank, as it has told us, is keen to recreate itself as the "Knowledge Bank", a disinterested participant in global debates on development. This enterprise has already been criticized in a recent report by Yves Tavernier, Rapporteur to the French parliament's Commission des Finances.

Tavernier emphasised that "the idea of transforming the World Bank into a Knowledge Bank should be opposed". He proposed a series of reforms, including that the World Bank and the IMF should limit their missions and be made to respect international law and the roles of UN organization, and that other ministries, parliamentarians and civil society groups should be involved with the Ministry of Finance in dealings with the institutions.

Most importantly, a "Knowledge Bank" cannot be truly knowledgeable without listening to its critics, internally and externally. Alan Simpson, a Labour MP, says he was never told about the two day conference, an oversight he finds "quite bemusing. I don't know how they approached parliamentarians, but I knew nothing about it." Simpson's absence from the invite list might perhaps be explained by his belief that Britain should be "leading a serious international debate about how we cease to fund the World Bank". The World Bank, he suggests, is failing because it has not yet acknowledged the crucial necessity of a "non-polluting development agenda", an agenda which allows country to develop their economies without committing to fossil fuel rich industries. It has, he adds,"been evident for a long time that the World Bank has lost its way and its meaning. Setting up discussions with politicians who have also lost their way and meaning begins to resemble a session at Relate."

This exclusion of anti-World Bank parliamentarians from the conference makes it look precisely the sort of reality-deficient debate Wolfensohn has been accused of favouring. Just as the leaked memo suggests that Wolfensohn quashes internal dissent, so ostensibly "open" discussions seem to have been stage-managed to remove discordant voices. Only certain types of opinion may be presented to the Knowledge Bank, that is, only "Knowledge" the Bank wants to hear. This is hardly the sort of "sharing of knowledge resources" the Bank needs.

Useful links
Yves Tavernier report to Commission des Finances

fields.headline: Gonna film a classic?
fields.standfirst: Just don't lose sight of the original book, begs John Sutherland
fields.trailText: Just don't lose sight of the original book, begs John Sutherland.
fields.body:
Imitation is the sincerest form of artistic flattery. The great age of literary imitation in this country was the 18th century - the "Augustan" period. Poets such as Pope, Dryden and Johnson took it on themselves to "English" and modernise the ancient classics: Virgil, Homer, Juvenal, Horace.

It would overstate things to say we are living through something equivalent in film. It's more a flavour of the month thing. None the less, over the past few years, movie-makers have exerted themselves to "cinema" a corpus of classic literary texts. It goes beyond mere adaptation. Ang Lee's Sense and Sensibility (1995) takes liberties with Jane Austen's text, but remains faithful to Regency period, costume, dramatis personae and the novel's dialogue. Clueless (1995), by contrast, is transparently derived from Austen's Emma, but transposed to a Valley-girl, Beverly High setting.

Emma was still there in Amy Heckerling's script, but as a kind of floating essence. One smelled it on the film, like some expensive fragrance. It was a new and rather flattering experience for 1990s audiences. Once you caught on, you felt exceptionally sophisticated - a literate film-goer, capable of relishing sly in-jokes that the director was directing in your direction. Clueless was also, in its own right, a witty comedy of southern California manners (in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer class, I would say, and a cut or two above Prom Night).

The runaway success of Clueless has been one trigger for the current vogue for "versioning" (as literary critics like to call it). Another was the successful 1988 versioning of Dickens's A Christmas Carol as Scrooged (starring Bill Murray as the old skinflint in modern TV producer clothes). The bandwagon rolled on with Great Expectations (frosty Gwyneth Paltrow, lusty Ethan Hawke, grizzled De Niro as an improbable Magwitch) and 10 Things I Hate About You, the 1999 update of Shakespeare's Taming of the Shrew, transposed, like Clueless, to the scatty world of the American high school.

The most complex of these recent versionings is A Thousand Acres (1997). Jocelyn Moorhouse's film is an adaptation (fairly faithful) of Jane Smiley's novel, itself a modern recasting of Shakespeare's King Lear. Old man, three daughters, time to split up the estate, trouble.

There must have been an elite in the audience who both knew the play and had read the 1992 novel. Watching the film was, in fact, something of a critical ordeal because, if you were really hip to this kind of thing, you would also be running Kurosawa's versioning of Lear, Ran (1985), through your head. One staggered out of the cinema after watching A Thousand Acres aesthetically knackered. Movies really shouldn't be such hard work.

My own preference is for versionings that make the audience work a bit for the payoff. Films, that is, whose core literary in spiration is not released as part of the advertising package. The Coen brothers' O Brother, Where Art Thou?, was, one gradually apprehended, based on the Odyssey. But so delicate were the Homeric allusions (as in John Goodman's cyclopean eye, or the slag-sirens in the river) that one was never quite sure. Perhaps those naughty Coens were pulling our leg? Surely this belly-laugh Grapes of Wrath burlesque couldn't be a homage to the noblest of literary epics? Could it?

My favourite versioning film just about makes it into the third division of cult classics. Marco Brambilla's Demolition Man (1993), starring Wesley Snipes and Sylvester Stallone, transposes Aldous Huxley's Brave New World to southern California ("San Angeles"), 30 years hence, after the Big One. As in Huxley's dystopia, it's a world without conflict or friction.

The Stallone character, John Spartan (John Savage in the book), is thawed out of his cryo-penitentiary to perform his usual bull-in-a-china-shop act. Conflict and friction up the kazoo. It's very funny, not least because Stallone seems to be laughing at his own Rambo excesses. But since Huxley's novel is still in copyright (unlike King Lear) the film-makers were careful to keep any parallels at the level of subtext. The effect was delicious: Demolition Man was Die Hard crude and Citizen Kane subtle at the same time.

All of which brings us to The Claim, a versioning of Thomas Hardy's The Mayor of Casterbridge. There's no question where this movie is coming from. Pre-release publicity has hammered home the point. The novel, published in 1886, is one of Hardy's "satires of circumstance" ("life's a bitch, and then you die").

A vagrant farm labourer, Michael Henchard, gets drunk at a fair in early 19th-century Wessex and sells his wife and child to a passing sailor. Hardy picked the story up from old newspapers. When he sobers up, Henchard swears off drink for 21 years and goes to a distant part of the west country. By way of hard work and ruthlessness he monopolises the corn wholesaling trade in the town of Casterbridge and becomes its mayor. It is the early 1840s, and Wessex - protected by the Corn Laws - is the bread basket of England.

Enter a new man, Donald Farfrae, a Scot on his way to Canada's prairies (the world's bread basket, as they will be). Fatally, Henchard befriends Farfrae. Hardy's is a Darwinian universe. The new man must destroy the old. It's the law of life. Farfrae usurps Henchard's business and succeeds him as mayor.

Fate - as remorseless as in Greek tragedy - plays its part. The sold wife, now a widow, returns. The great circle turns, Henchard dies what he was 21 years before: a drunk and a day-labourer. It being Hardy, there is a further irony. In 1846, a couple of years on, the Corn Laws will be repealed. Farfrae too will be destroyed and with him, Wessex prosperity. Life sucks.

The British director of The Claim, Michael Winterbottom, and his British script writer, Frank Cottrell Boyce, have transposed Hardy's story to a later period, the 1860s (the time of the great transcontinental American railroad) and another west country - Sierra Nevada. The lineaments of the plot are the same, although names have been changed. Daniel Dillon, a "forty-niner", sells his wife. He strikes it rich and rules over the town he has made, Kingdom Come. Enter the New Man, Dalglish, a surveyor laying the railway. Enter the sold wife. So it goes.

The makers of the film have retained Hardy's Darwinism, but give it - perversely - a final upbeat spin. Producers hate unhappy endings. The achievement of Winterbottom's film is essentially visual. It is a photographer's movie. What the audience takes away from the film is a series of vivid snapshots - many (as in Gladiator) the product of computer-generated imagery.

The narrative is dominated by panoramic snowscapes (there's more ankle-deep trudging in this movie than in Scott of the Antarctic). There's a pièce de résistance sequence in which Dillon's house is physically moved, like a gigantic wedding cake, to its new location. Old towns are burned down, new towns spring up in stunning montage. At times, one can't believe one's eyes. A price is paid. The story, Hardy's story, is buried in all the visual effect, like a flower in a snowdrift.

The Claim is a ponderous, self-important film, which is glorious to look at. Myself, I prefer Demolition Man. What do we go to the movies for? Literature?

 The Claim is released tomorrow. John Sutherland's edition of The Mayor of Casterbridge is published by Signet Classics.

webTitle: NHS managers will struggle to meet targets

fields.headline: NHS managers will struggle to meet targets
fields.trailText: The NHS faces "serious" financial difficulties, less than a year after the government announced a £19bn increase in NHS funding, with managers warning that they will struggle to find the resources needed to meet key government targets in areas such as cancer and waiting times.
fields.body:
The NHS faces "serious" financial difficulties, less than a year after the government announced a £19bn increase in NHS funding, with managers warning that they will struggle to find the resources needed to meet key government targets in areas such as cancer and waiting times.

Budget problems, which have arisen just months after ministers triumphantly declared the debate over NHS funding was dead, threaten to re-ignite a potentially explosive debate over the financing of health care in the run-up to a general election.

Managers say they are labouring to agree budgets for the next financial year and blame higher than expected costs of implementing the welter of initiatives and instructions handed down from ministers, who are anxious to push ahead with NHS modernisation plans announced last summer.

They have warned ministers that health authorities and trusts can only meet the cost of national performance targets, drug costs, staff pay awards and the NHS reform programme over the coming months at the expense of running up huge deficits.

One chief executive of a major trust told the Guardian: "The sums simply don't add up. This is a serious national problem."

The Healthcare Financial Management Association, which represents NHS finance directors, said that it was "difficult to see how the targets would be met."

A Department of Health (DoH) spokesman said: "We have made a historic commitment to the NHS to increase funding by one third over five years and we expect health authorities to meet spending out of this."

Last March, chancellor Gordon Brown announced a 6.1% average annual real terms increase for the NHS worth around £19bn over four years, a move dubbed the biggest ever increase in health service history. Ministers claimed they had moved the debate away from finance and onto reform - reform that was subsequently spelled out in last summer's NHS Plan.

But managers are privately describing negotiations for 2001-02 as the "toughest ever".

The NHS confederation said that despite the extra billions ploughed into the service by the government, the coming year looked "as tight as ever financially".

Andrew Foster, a confederation policy director, said: "There are pressures and it will not be easy to meet all the objectives. There are a lot of must dos - 4% on pay, 2% on pensions (meeting the) junior doctors' (pay deal) - and there is a set of very ambitious targets.'

The settlement for the coming year will see all health authorities receive cash increases of at least 7.8%, with the average rise being 8.5%. But managers say ministers and their officials have underestimated unavoidable cost pressures, leaving insufficient growth funds to implement everything on ministers' NHS Plan wish list.

According to the DoH, the basic increase of 7.8% breaks down into 4.9% for the increased costs of pay, pensions, general inflation and the costs of implementing recommendations on new drug treatments from the National Institute for Clinical Excellence. The remaining 2.9%, equivalent to around £1bn, was to implement the NHS Plan.

But trusts and health authorities claim that real terms inflation for the NHS is closer to 6%, fuelled by high pay rises for staff, including a new deal for junior doctors, and increased pension costs - an overshoot on core, unavoidable costs that has eaten deep into money intended to implement the NHS Plan.

The DoH has also ring-fenced about £1bn within health authority allocations, reflecting the sums it estimates will have to be spent nationally to deliver key targets and milestones on cancer and coronary heart disease (£450m), waiting times and access (£423m), intermediate care (£188m) and information technology (£113m).

Many health authoritities say that even delivering on their share of these spending requirements leaves them in a deficit position.

The NHS faces a plethora of management targets, including the introduction of 24-hour catering facilities, setting up ward budgets, making progress on the mental health national service framework, and investing in improving hospital cleanliness - all of which carry significant costs.

In the meantime, the NHS Executive's regional offices are reminding health bodies that they must break even in 2001-02, a feat that is expected to be achieved in the current year for the first time in many years.

Mark Millar, chairman of the Healthcare Financial Management Association, said: "The government has acknowledged that 2.9% is the real purchasing power. The feedback from the service is that the true purchasing power is less than 2.9% and it is difficult to see how all the targets can be hit. But it is still a work in progress."

In the meantime, the NHS Executive's regional offices are reminding health bodies that they must break even in 2001-02, a feat that is expected to be achieved in the current year for the first time in many years. Mark Millar, chairman of the Healthcare Financial Management Association, said: "The government has acknowledged that 2.9% is the real purchasing power. The feedback from the service is that the true purchasing power is less than 2.9% and it is difficult to see how all the targets can be hit. But it is still a work in progress."

fields.headline: John Hutton online chat
fields.standfirst: Health minister John Hutton took part in a live online chat on SocietyGuardian.co.uk's talkboards on January 30, answering your questions on a range of health and social care issues
fields.trailText:
Tamsin Walker
I would like to know if you think the Department of Health is better placed than the social exclusion unit to tackle the social exclusion of people with mental illness. If you think it is, I would like to know why, and, if you think not, then I would like to know why the none of the policy action teams are focusing on this group.
fields.body:
Tamsin Walker
I would like to know if you think the Department of Health is better placed than the social exclusion unit to tackle the social exclusion of people with mental illness. If you think it is, I would like to know why, and, if you think not, then I would like to know why the none of the policy action teams are focusing on this group.

John Hutton
Tackling social exclusion for people with a mental health problem is something we take seriously both in the Department of Health and across government as a whole. DoH is taking two initiatives that you might be interested in. Firstly we are launching this week a new campaign to tackle discrimination and stigma associated with mental illness and we are working closely with employers on this campaign. Secondly we are later this year developing a new service for people with a mental illness to provide better support for them in the workplace. There is a lot still to do but I think we are making moves in the right direction.

gooded
The guidelines on local authority charging for care services have just been released for consultation. There seems to be a number of contradictions and policy changes.

I am disabled, I use personal assistants to provide my care and I'm lucky enough to have a full-time job.

In paragraph 52 it states that any charging policy should not be a disincentive to work. However, the document goes on to say that up to 55% of your income can be assessed for charging. The document seems to follow the charging policy of the Independent Living Fund (ILF) rather than the current policies of the majority of local authorities. Under this policy there are disabled people working full-time for only part-time wages with the rest going on care costs. This is contra to equal opportunities policy in employment.

In paragraphs 48 & 49 this covers joint incomes. Currently guidelines on the HASSASSA act 1983 states that only the service users income is taken into account when calculating care costs and not the spouse or partners. Again however, the new guidelines seem to follow the ILF policy of allowing spouse/partners income to be assessed for charges. Under this policy there are disabled people working full-time for nothing as all of their income is being spent on their care costs.

Can the minister give an undertaking that working disabled people on average salaries should be allowed to retain all of their salary? As do non-disabled people.

Can the minister give an undertaking that the current guideline on service user only charging will be retained and not to include the spouse or partner.

Finally, it's the ILF and its charging policy that is out of step with the majority of local authority charging policies, and the ILF should change to meet these standards rather than the local authorities taking on the ILF policy.

John Hutton
Hi. The document you refer to is a consultation document and obviously we want to hear what people have to say about these changes. We are trying to make the system fairer particularly for those on low or fixed incomes.

The present situation is not acceptable and I think our proposals represent a positive step in the right direction but we haven't made any final decisions. On income levels it's worth bearing in mind that many authorities take all of a person's earned income into account in setting charges so therefore our proposals that only 55% should be taken into account would help remove the disincentive for disabled people to remain in employment.

But once again we haven't made any final decisions about any of these important issues. Thanks for your views.

Adoptionnet
The government has said it wants to increase the number of adoptions by 1,000 in the next 4-5 years.

Mr Hutton, how are local authorities expected to achieve this given that: a. most of the children available for adoption are older children (some of whom attract no inquiries at all from potential adopters despite extensive advertising) and many adoptive families only want to adopt babies - and go abroad if they can't do it in this country; b. There is a shortage of social workers to process applications from people interested in adopting and assess the children in the care system who may be best served by adoption?

Are local authorities going to be expected to permanently remove children earlier and younger from their parents so that there is a greater supply of younger - and thereby less damaged - children who are more likely to be successfully adopted?

How are local authorities expected to make the adoption of older children or those with special needs a more attractive proposition for families?

Critics have said that the targets set in the adoption white paper on increases and speed of adoptions will be difficult to achieve and could work against the interests of children because of hurried and therefore badly matched placements. What do you say to those critics?

JohnHutton
I believe our target for increasing the number of adoptions is a very realisable objective given that last year alone adoption increased by nearly 20% and when you consider that some local authorities are placing between 10 and 15% of looked-after children for adoption but others are only managing 1-2%, there is obviously scope for significant improvement.

The white paper has announced additional resources for adoption services which will help. But no we will not require local authorities to remove children earlier and younger from their parents. This would be quite wrong because any decision to take a child into care has to be based on the facts and the circumstances of each case.

And finally it is worth bearing in mind that there are nearly 2,500 parents waiting to adopt and nearly 1,400 children waiting for a new family. The new national adoption register should help speed up the matching process.

taffimak
Anna Climbie tragedy/child abuse
The problems started in the late 1970's when social work departments ditched common sense and experience for qualifications.

As an Oxford don (ex-social worker) friend said to me about a notorious child abuse case some years ago, 'The trouble is that the social workers concerned were over qualified'.

I wonder what Mr Hutton thinks?

JohnHutton
No I don't think social workers are over qualified. I think in particular social workers who work with children need better qualifications in future and we will be making some announcements soon about this. In all professions however there can never be a substitute for common sense.

dogstar23
John, are you able to confirm whether or not the national service framework for older people will be published before the election? It has now exceeded the expected original publication date by almost one year. Is ageism rife in the DoH in spite of the statements made in the NHS plan?

JohnHutton
The NSF will be published in the next few weeks. And by the way it is not a year late. We have always said that it would be publised by the end of the year 2000, but it will be worth the wait as it will tackle age discrimination head on.

Harvey Gallagher
Does the minister think the requirements of children and young people are adequately protected under the proposed changes to the Mental Health Act and will the final version mention the interface with the Children Act and how/when the two legal instruments might be best used?

John Hutton
I think for the first time the recently-published white paper has attempted to set out how we can improve the safeguards for young people who might be faced with compulsory treatment for a mental health problem.

Previous legislation has never made any specific provision for young people. I think the measures we are proposing will certainly benefit young people and represent a real improvement on the present position.

We made it clear in the white paper that we will continue to look at how we can improve these safeguards into the future so there is more work to be done. Young Minds is welcome to contribute to this work. Warm regards.

rb497
Hello Mr Hutton,

You described the Alder Hey report as "absolutely shocking". What is the DoH doing to ensure these events never happen again?

John Hutton
Good afternoon. I didn't describe the Alder Hey report as "absolutely shocking" as it hasn't been published yet. I described as absolutely horrifying the practise of removing without parental consent tissues from children and giving them to drug companies for research purposes.

Alan Milburn [health secretary] will be setting out later this afternoon how we can make sure these practices can never happen again.

John Hutton
Sorry I did not get a chance to answer all your questions. I have to rush back to the House of Commons for the Alder Hey announcement. Thank you for your questions.

webTitle: Chronic miscalculation over junior doctors' pay

fields.headline: Chronic miscalculation over junior doctors' pay
fields.trailText: NHS hospitals face massive increased costs after health officials appear to have underestimated the cost of the new pay deal for junior doctors aimed at reducing their working hours.
fields.body:
NHS hospitals face massive increased costs after health officials appear to have underestimated the cost of the new pay deal for junior doctors aimed at reducing their working hours.

A survey of hospitals in the NHS Northern and Yorkshire region, seen exclusively by SocietyGuardian.co.uk, puts the cost of the new deal at more than £5,000 per junior doctor - far higher than was anticipated when the deal was introduced in December 2000.

The survey suggests the total cost to the NHS in England - which employs 30,000 junior doctors - could reach as much as £150m in the first year.

The findings, undertaken by consultants Pay and Workforce Research on behalf of human resources directors, were presented to the NHS HR director Hugh Taylor yesterday.

Mr Taylor was told that the trusts surveyed in the region expect the pay system to cost an average of £771,031 or an average cost per junior doctor of £5,281.

Head of Pay and Workforce Research John Northrop said: "On the findings of this survey it appears that the costs are far higher than expected and the numbers going into the top band have been grossly underestimated."

But the Department of Health questioned the validity of the figures saying that only 17 out of 40 trusts were surveyed. It said it estimated the cost to the NHS of meeting the junior doctors' deal would be £150m over three years.

Mr Northrop estimates the total cost of implementing the new pay system and increasing the number of staff in Northern and Yorkshire alone will reach a staggering £38m.

Much of the extra costs relate to trusts' estimates that they will each need an average of 17 additional junior doctors and four extra consultants to bring all juniors' hours below the 56-hour maximum, and become fully compliant with the new requirements.

This could add a further £17m to the £21m cost of implementing the system in Northern and Yorkshire.

Andrew Foster, HR policy director of the NHS confederation, said it was clear the increase in non-compliance was stumping up costs. "This creates an affordability problem for organisations because there hasn't been that level of funding put in."

The new junior doctors' pay deal came into effect in December 2000 and is expected to force NHS hospitals to start the process of reducing doctors' working hours to comply with European working time regulations.

It spells the end of junior doctors' infamous payment system, which saw some doctors paid as little as half the normal hourly rate for overtime. Doctors now working more than 56 hours a week or without sufficient rest periods will receive a "band 3" 62% supplement to their basic pay.

This will rise to 70% in December this year and 100% at the end of 2002. Doctors working between 48 and 56 hours a week (known as band 2) will initially receive a 50% boost to their pay.

In November the Department of Health predicted a new junior doctor could earn £25,890 or an extra £1,700 as a result of the deal. A senior house officer could be paid £43,140 or an extra £2,800 compared with the old overtime system.

But these estimates were based on doctors not exceeding the 56-hour maximum and so receiving the 50% supplement. As soon as the 56-hour maximum is breached those same doctors would see earnings rise to £27,961 and £46,591 respectively.

Following a new assessment of doctors' working patterns, it is believed that more than 70% of junior doctors could be eligible for the top 62% supplement - twice as many as were deemed "non-compliant" before the deal was introduced.

According to Dr Trevor Pickersgill, chairman of the British Medical Association's junior doctors' committee: "We feel we are seeing the true number of doctors working outside the recommendations."
