fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours are not attending Narcotics Anonymous meetings in a courageous bid to beat their addiction to drink and drugs
fields.trailText: "She wore an itsy-bitsy, teeny-weeny, yellow polka-dot rumour."
fields.body:
Brazilian full-back Cafu has revealed that an English club - believed to be Chelsea - have made a £10m bid for him. "It's true, I have received a big offer from a London club," he told onefootball.com. "I am staying in Rome until June, then we will see," he added. "My top priority remains Roma. I like it a lot here. But obviously if another club offers me a good deal and, more importantly, a longer contract, I'd seriously think about it."

Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic could move to Aston Villa, Everton or Blackburn on loan, according to Planet Football. Berkovic's agent Pinhas Zahavi said: "The fact is that Eyal has now agreed in principle to go on loan and we are now ready to do that. We will know in the next few days where he will go."

Arsenal are close to completing a £1m transfer for 19-year-old Danish centre-half Per Kroldurp, reports the Sun. The paper claims that Arsene Wenger has already met with Kroldurp, who plays for B-93, to discuss personal terms.

Ajax striker Shota Arveladze is John Gregory's latest target. The Georgia international - who has scored 16 goals in 34 internationals - admitted to onefootball: "My agent Ivan Benesh called me up yesterday and told me that Aston Villa are seriously considering buying me. Benesh said coach John Gregory is very keen."

Manchester City striker Gareth Taylor will sign for Sheffield Wednesday today, reports Teamtalk.

onefootball.com also reports that Anderlecht have pulled out of move for Ed de Goey after the Chelsea keeper refused to lower his £16,000-a-week wage demands.

webTitle: Badly performing councils get help from the experts

fields.headline: Badly performing councils get help from the experts
fields.standfirst: The local government Improvement and Development Agency has launched a new project to help ailing councils. Project head Patricia Coleman describes how it will work
fields.trailText: The local government Improvement and Development Agency has launched a new project to help ailing councils. Project head Patricia Coleman describes how it will work.
fields.body:
A new performance support project launched by the local government Improvement and Development Agency (IDeA) will throw a lifeline to seriously under performing councils.

The project is a pioneering new concept. It will use teams of experienced councillors and local government officers to provide in-depth help to other authorities.

The new initiative will help provide councils with the extra staff, time and ideas they need to create real improvements and build a basis for lasting change. This process could last between six months and two years, depending on the nature of each case.

By mobilising local politicians and officers to form these support teams, troubled councils will receive advice from those with relevant experience, expertise and practice. Chief executives from other authorities will head the teams, which should be formed by March.

The IDeA is already supporting councils through its successful local government improvement programme, which uses teams of council professionals to assess the work of other authorities. The agency's consulting arm offers performance improvement help to a large number of individual councils.

The new project builds on this to provide intensive help to those authorities facing the most complex challenges of political and managerial leadership. By doing this, the IDeA will be able to help close the gap between local government's best and worst performers.

The idea of calling in a performance support team should not send shivers down the spines of chief executives. Instead, it should provide them with the reassurance that help is at hand. It is a purely voluntary programme and is conducted in partnership with individual councils. The team will identify where problems exist and then begin to work with the authority, adding to existing management structures and finding and implementing best practice. But this will take time.

John O'Brien, director of improvement and consultancy at the IDeA, believes that real change requires real commitment: "Spending up to two years adding capacity to existing structures is an indication of how seriously we take the challenge of helping these councils to drive their own real and sustainable improvements," he said.

Struggling local authorities are not the only ones who stand to benefit from the performance support process. Team members will be able to add to their own experience and inject new, innovative ideas back into their own councils.

Membership of the support teams is designed to suit both the individual and the releasing authority and placements of varying length, both part and full time, will be available. The teams may also include specialists from outside local government, with some likely to come from the private sector.

The project has the backing of a range of organisations, including the Local Government Association, the Audit Commission and the government. Local government minister Beverley Hughes spoke at the project's launch.

Mr O'Brien believes this shows that there is a shared recognition of the contribution the performance support project can make to improvement: "We do not believe that the local government community automatically has the capacity, or spare resources, to address every problem that a council faces," he said. "But it is very clear that there are a range of skills and experience within the sector that can make a real difference where it is needed most."

 Patricia Coleman is head of IDeA performance support

webTitle: Nightmare on Pennsylvania Avenue as Craven shoots Clinton

fields.headline: Nightmare on Pennsylvania Avenue as Craven shoots Clinton
fields.trailText: Wes Craven, best known for the Scream and Nightmare on Elm Street films, is making a documentary about Bill Clinton's final days as the American president
fields.body:
Angry Republicans would doubtless claim that there is no more fitting Hollywood director to shoot a movie about Bill Clinton than Wes Craven - the creator of such horror-fests as Scream, Nightmare on Elm Street and Last House on the Left. For them, the past eight years have indeed been the nightmare on Pennsylvania Avenue.

But Craven was presumably in a more respectful mode when he trailed Bill Clinton around the White House during the former president's last week in office just over a fortnight ago. The resulting documentary will become a centrepiece at the Clinton presidential library currently under construction in Little Rock, Arkansas. The picture is being produced by Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein and Jane Rosenthal of Tribeca Films.

The notion of a Clinton documentary was apparently raised when Craven visited the White House to screen his decidedly non-horrific Music of the Heart starring Meryl Streep. During the course of three hours filming, Clinton led Craven through the Oval Office, the Cabinet Room and into the private quarters he shared with wife Hillary and daughter Chelsea.

Afterwards, Craven admitted he was a little dazed by the experience. "I was thinking, here I am. I've made some of the most horrific films and here I am in the White House," the director told Fox News. "Someone said I should have brought a Scream mask and have someone jump out in it, but that would have been the last time we'd have been invited over."

webTitle: Casting news: Del Toro tracked down for thriller

fields.headline: Del Toro tracked down for thriller
fields.standfirst: Plus: Denise Richards in line for live-action version of cartoon web short; and will Marilyn Manson play Willy Wonka for Tim Burton?
fields.trailText: Plus: Denise Richards in line for live-action version of cartoon web short; and will Marilyn Manson play Willy Wonka for Tim Burton?
fields.body:
 Fresh from his triumph at last week's Golden Globes, where he won Best Supporting Actor for his role in Traffic, Benicio Del Toro is in talks to join Tommy Lee Jones in William Friedkin's killer thriller The Hunted. Del Toro will play the role of a psychotic, media-fixated wannabe who embarks on a spate of murders in order to become the subject of a manhunt. Jones, reprising his Oscar-winning role in The Fugitive, will be the cop on his trail.

 Denise Richards is in negotiations to take the female lead opposite Eddie Griffin in the offbeat comedy Undercover Brother. Based on a series of animated web shorts, the film focuses on a member of an anarchic brotherhood who infiltrates the WASP establishment. The star of Drop Dead Gorgeous and The World is Not Enough (in which she made an unlikely nuclear physicist) recently completed work on the indie film,You Stupid Man, with Milla Jovovich.

 Rumours are still swirling over singer Marilyn Manson's involvement in a remake of the 1971 picture Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory to be directed by Tim Burton. Yesterday's Sun quoted Manson as describing the film as: "One of my favourite movies and I think I can play that role like no-one else." The wacky one added that: "I really see the movie as a metaphor. I see Willy Wonka as Satan because he presents people with the temptation of picking good and evil, and they all pick evil." Prompted by such revelations the Sun and numerous websites appear to have concluded that Manson had officially signed on to play the part of Roald Dahl's anti-hero. Not so, however. Q online learned from a Manson spokesman that the singer: "Has not been approached to appear in the film and was unaware that a remake had even been planned." With Manson's busy workload of spooking middle-America with his albums and tours, the spokesman concluded: "I can't see when he would have the time to do a film."

webTitle: Answers to organ questions 'could take months'

fields.headline: Answers to organ questions 'could take months'
fields.trailText: The parents and relatives of people whose organs may have been stored in hospitals around the country face a wait of several months to have their questions answered.
fields.body:
The parents and relatives of people whose organs may have been stored in hospitals around the country face a wait of several months to have their questions answered.

Thousands phoned hospitals that were listed by the chief medical officer yesterday as having collections of organs, while others sought information from NHS Direct. The helpline took more than 3,000 calls between midnight and 2pm yesterday.

Hospitals have been instructed by the NHS executive to take the details of people who phone but not to try to tell them whether they hold any organs belonging to their relatives.

Even hospitals that have comprehensive catalogues of what has been retained, and from whom, are not permitted to put relatives out of their misery until a national catalogue is compiled, which will take months.

Yesterday Margaret Brazier, chairwoman of the retained organs commission - announced yesterday by the health secretary, Alan Milburn - said the moratorium not only on disposal but also on return of organs was needed to ensure that nobody else went through the trauma suffered by Alder Hey parents, some of whom endured several funerals as body parts were returned to them.

"I recognise that, for some parents, this will be a further, disappointing delay in what has already been a harrowing process for those involved," she said.

"But equally the risks of multiple burials and of setting off a drawn-out and highly distressing repeat of the problems experienced in Liverpool make it important that nothing should be released until the commission is satisfied that a comprehensive and secure cataloguing process has been completed."

The edict will not go down well with some trusts, which are sure that they have full and proper records and could relieve the anxiety of some relatives promptly, but a Department of Health spokesman pointed out that Alder Hey, too, thought it had complete records when it was first approached.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, revealed yesterday that hospitals and medical schools are holding some 105,000 organs, of which around 54,000 date from 1970 and will be returned, if families want that.

Many hospitals set up telephone helplines to deal with inquiries. Derriford hospital in Plymouth, which has 268 adult organs, mostly brains, had 60 calls.

Great Ormond Street in London, which holds one of the biggest collections - 3,800 children's organs - had 50 calls, while its child death helpline had 200.

Oxford Radcliffe hospitals NHS trust, which has a store of 4,400 organs - the second biggest collection after Alder Hey - said it had received more than 150 calls yesterday morning.

Southampton general hospi tal said it had 1,300 brains and 220 hearts retained for research on diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Alzheimers and congenital heart conditions.

At a press conference, the director of nursing and patient services, Katherine Fenton, said the hospital was "not an Alder Hey". All the organs had been used for research and had been catalogued.

The hospital said the brains kept were mostly those of adults and the hearts of children. These had been removed only for clinical reasons and never just removed and stored.

Jim Lowe, of the University of Nottingham medical school, yesterday warned that medical research was already being seriously damaged by a new reluctance not only by families, but also coroners and the medical profession, to agree to the removal and retention of organs at postmortem examination.

He said he feared that society would be the loser.

A study in the Lancet last year indicated that 10% of death certificates were wrong.

If pathologists are not able to remove and study organs, which may take some time, many more people will be buried or cremated with the wrong cause of death on the certificate, and many more relatives will not discover earlier that they are at risk of genetically inherited disease.

Dr Lowe said that "a loss of confidence in the postmortem" began over a year ago, when it was revealed at the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry that hospitals had not returned children's hearts for burial.

It was not the histopathologists who carried out the postmortem examinations who asked for permission from families for organs to be retained, but the doctor who cared for the person who had died and who had established a relationship of trust with the families.

Now those doctors were less willing to ask, because "they feel at this time it will be too intrusive and too painful", Dr Lowe said.

webTitle: Zapata to live again in Banderas biopic

fields.headline: Zapata to live again in Banderas biopic
fields.trailText: Antonio Banderas is to follow in the footsteps of Marlon Brando and star in a film about the legendary Mexican hero
fields.body:
Antonio Banderas is to play the famed Mexican revolutionary hero Emiliano Zapata in a Disney biopic written and directed by Gregory Nava. The flamboyantly moustached folk hero has already been immortalised by Hollywood in Elia Kazan's 1952 picture Viva Zapata starring Marlon Brando.

Production on the as yet untitled project is likely to commence after Hispanic film-maker Nava has completed his current picture Bordertown for New Line studios. Banderas is currently preparing for his role in Julia Taymor's biopic of painter Frida Kahlo, a long-term labour of love for Salma Hayek. He will soon be seen in the steamy noir thriller Original Sin opposite Angelina Jolie.

A key figure in the Mexican revolution of 1911-1917, Zapata, a Marxist, was a champion of agrarian reform who aggressively redistributed farmland among the working poor in the style of Robin Hood and coined the slogan: "Land and liberty". Zapata's fiery insistence that "it is better to die on your feet than live on your knees" became a reality when he was assassinated in April 1919.

"This project is the dream of a lifetime for me," Nava told Variety yesterday. "This is one of the great heroic dramas of our time. He was a warrior who was also a man of peace."

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 2
fields.trailText: February 2: Lion Television has won best independent production company at the Broadcast Awards.
fields.body:
Castaway 2000 producer, Lion Television, won the best independent production company award at the Broadcast 2001 Awards last night.

The BBC is ditching its quarterly commissioning rounds and will commission on a rolling basis. It will put 25 per cent of production in each genre up for competition between independents and in-house producers, according to BBC director of television Mark Thomspson.

ITV is considering launching its own-branded news channel.

Gerald Kaufman has suggested the government's communications white paper will be dead before it is translated into legislation.

Disney Channel UK has joined other commercial broadcasters in voicing concern over the BBC's proposed new digital channels.

Channel 4 is poised to strike a deal with US personal video recorder company Tivo to provide highlights channels. C4 is expected to offer highlights of programming on its terrestrial service, E4 and FilmFour. The BBC and BSkyB launched four hightlights channels each when Tivo became available in the UK last October.

The fifth series of BBC 1's Playing the Field will be its last, according to Tiger Aspect Productions' head of drama, Greg Brenman.

fields.headline: IPC to rethink men's title
fields.trailText: 8.30am: IPC is reviewing its men's title Later as part of a rebranding of its Music & Sport portfolio, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC has admitted it is reviewing its older man's magazine Later as part of a rebranding of its Music & Sport portfolio.

The portfolio is to be rebranded IPC ignite! in a move that managing director Mike Soutar says more accurately reflects the magazines within it.

Mr Soutar admitted IPC had failed to come up with the "killer application" in the title, which was launched last year under editor Phil Hilton to provide a magazine for the ageing Loaded reader.

"We are committed to the magazine, but we don't think we've got it yet. We don't think we've got the killer application," he said.

The long-predicted move follows the a series of developments at IPC, including the appointment of a new senior management team over the past year, the divestment of a clutch of sports titles and the closure of Melody Maker.

Last week new Loaded editor Keith Kendrick said he planned to take Loaded to a more "savvy" marketplace, and wanted to appeal to more "grown-up" men.

Mr Soutar confirmed that IPC was reassessing Later, which sold only 77,000 copies at the last ABCs.

He said he would continue to "revisit the editorial blueprints of all the products in IPC ignite!."

fields.headline: Working IT out: novel ideas
fields.standfirst: Paul McAuley is one of the UK's leading SF writers. His new book, The Secret of Life, is out now
fields.trailText: Paul McAuley, one of the UK's leading SF writers, on how he uses technology
fields.body:
How did you first encounter computers? My first experience was in 1978 when a friend let me play an early, text-based, role-playing game on his firm's mainframe. Then I did some work on a mainframe at University College Los Angeles using APL (A Programming Language), which was like hieroglyphics! My research supervisor also had a Tandy desktop, which had no disk drive and I had to program it in Basic.

Information superhighway or world wide wait? I think it's half and half. I can squirt whole novels to the USA in under a minute but then spend ages downloading a page that has one Flash thing on it! There's a lot of information-poor and feature-rich stuff out there.

Is it time for an overhaul of the net's infrastructure? Given that it's grown up in such an ad hoc way, and that it's so central to many people's lives, it's difficult to see how it could be overhauled. It's like trying to overhaul transport in London in one day without interfering with commuters! Itdoes need changes though.

Are people warming to e-commerce? I have used it, but warily. I'm in favour of the French system, where you have a pin number when you use your card. People have found that the thrill of buying over the net is not so different from the thrill of buying in a shop. It comes into its own when you're searching for something rare.

Can you envisage computers replacing the printed word? It's a contentious issue! People are saying "even Stephen King couldn't make it work", but that's unfair. It can work but only in a supplementary way. I put stories on my website (www.omegacom.demon.co.uk) that I've had my money out of. As for novels, that is another issue.

Where do you see technology going? Everything will become more invisible and more ubiquitous. The advent of "intelligent agents" in your computer or on the web will lead to a far more personalised relationship with technology.

Will there ever be a sentient computer? It's very difficult to replicate human consciousness. Computers work differently from the human brain. They are wired differently and our brains also work with chemicals. Theoretically, one could replicate a human being, but why on earth you would want to, I don't know!

How would you like to see the net utilised best? Always on and always there! What I really want is one of those wireless tablets that always work, never crash, and always get to the site first time. It would be lovely to have something the size of a magazine that could get you on to the web without messing around with phone connections and ghastly wires.

Then I did some work on a mainframe at University College Los Angeles using APL (A Programming Language), which was like hieroglyphics! I can squirt whole novels to the USA in under a minute but then spend ages downloading a page that has one Flash thing on it! There's a lot of information-poor and feature-rich stuff out there. Is it time for an overhaul of the net's infrastructure? Given that it's grown up in such an ad hoc way, and that it's so central to many people's lives, it's difficult to see how it could be overhauled. It's like trying to overhaul transport in London in one day without interfering with commuters! Itdoes need changes though. Are people warming to e-commerce? I have used it, but warily. I'm in favour of the French system, where you have a pin number when you use your card. fields.headline: Travel writing
fields.standfirst: Guidebooks must lead readers not only through the city but also the cyber world, finds  Mick Sinclair
fields.trailText: Guidebooks must lead readers not only through the city but also the cyber world, finds Mick Sinclair
fields.body:
With flights, hotels and package holidays available online, along with webcam views of beaches, local restaurant menus and transport timetables, is there any future for that traditional source of destination information, the guide book?

If anybody wants to know the answer, it is me. I have written 15 guide books over 14 years, and researching them has seldom been a holiday. The first involved four months of underpaid slogging through some of Europe's most expensive regions, while the latest took just a few weeks of on-the-spot touring coupled with several days of mouse-led travel from the comfort of my desk.

So if I can find a lot of the information I need online, why can't the reader? And why do guide publishers who have put their text online claim dramatically increased sales?

Partly, perhaps, because the more far-sighted guide publishers have developed an online presence to heighten brand loyalty and provide an interactive element that books cannot. Besides offering twice-yearly online updates to their print guides and some lovely icons, www.lonelyplanet.com also includes the Thorn Tree message board on which travellers can email their recommendations and where older travellers find encouragement: "Spend the kids' inheritance and hit the road."

No such frivolity from the American travel giant Fodors http://micksinclair.com. Its Rants and Raves section carries readers' views on food and accommodation, while Travel Talk allows travellers to swap tips and experiences. It is less fun and less intuitive than Lonely Planet, but what backpacker would dare ask "where can I find high tea in Chicago as a break from shopping?"

Other publishers are following suit, although inviting Joe Public's comments can have its drawbacks, as I know from too many ill-informed letters from my readers. The unbiased, first-hand reports can easily be poorly informed moans or even rival local businesses trying to rubbish each other.

In a more ingenious departure, the California-based publisher Moon http://moon.com has converted an online version of its Roadtrip USA guide into a self-contained site at www.roadtripusa.com combining map, text and page-linking in a rare example of a book page translated effectively to web page.

Print publishing schedules can mean a guide book being out of date even before it is on sale: a wired world brings the prospect of instant information for the traveller. This is something that Lonely Planet's CitySync www.citysync.com, Frommer's, City to Go and Citykey all aim to provide, offering restaurant, hotel and attraction listings downloadable on handheld devices.

This is all well and good if up-to-the-minute information is really necessary. Perhaps it is for the high-flyer unaware of what city they will be in for lunch, but surely not for most travellers, who only want to visit the main sights and would benefit more from considered text on a printed page than a bulleted list? Handheld devices have drawbracks, too: use is restricted on planes, batteries die, and who would want to be reading from a Palm or Handspring in a place where the device might be worth more than the annual wage?

Internet info can be as out-of-date as any book. Time Out's online version of its Miami guide (See www.timeout.com/miami) was recently plugging an art deco street festival from January 1998. Other sites lack the expertise of a travel author and simply get it wrong: could the demise of www.utravel.co.uk have anything to do with the fact that its recommendations included using "official taxi ranks" in Bangkok (where none exist) and train travel in Phuket (an island with no railway)? And what use is the knowledge that "Denmark is a difficult country to pin down" to someone thinking of booking a Danish trip at www.thomascook.com?

Sadly, few web-based sources provide consistent, well-informed and well-written text that is frequently updated. The American citysearch series is one exception, as is the Stockholm Information Service, whose many nuggets of intelligence include the location of every public toilet in the Swedish capital.

For the guide writer, it is often not publishers or travel-related sites that bring out the best information but newspapers and radio stations. From the South China Morning Post to the LA Times, they can provide a steady stream of local news and insights, all current but likely to leave the uninitiated, would-be visitor bemused.

Which means that today's guide author needs to be as knowledgeable about the web as about local history or food, able to lead readers not only through neighbourhoods, museums, shops and along bus routes, but also through a cyber world as potentially beguiling as the real one.

What is it that bookshop-goers look for when flicking through a guide book to check whether it has its finger on the pulse? Right, a long list of recommended websites.

 Mick Sinclair has written travel guides for AA Publishing, Thomas Cook, New Holland, Rough Guides and others. Details at http://micksinclair.com

fields.headline: Techies offer protection for emailers
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Geneva techies have developed the 'RumorBot' to protect emailers from internet scandal, writes Amy Vickers .
fields.body:
Living in dread of your private email messages ending up in millions of in-boxes? Fear not, for help is at hand.

Clever techies in Geneva have developed a new piece of technology called RumorBot that they say will protect victims from scandalising internet distribution.

While the RumorBot won't be able to stop cases of internet rumour-mongering, such as the infamous Claire Swire email that found its way into millions of in-boxes, it will add a big brother element to the internet.

The programme claims it can root out the rumour-mongers who use email and chat rooms to spread idle or malicious gossip, by trawling through search engines and databases to find the source.

Companies will also find the programme useful to track down saboteurs who start chatroom rumours that can go on to affect share prices.

It could also be used by detectives working on cases of paedophile photographs being traded via the internet.

Stephane Perino, founder of RumorBot creator Agence Virtuelle in Geneva, said the potential was enormous.

"More than 8m new web pages and internet postings appear each day, so it's impossible to manually check every possible source," she said.

webTitle: Councils conned out of £1m in asylum seeker scam

fields.headline: Councils conned out of £1m in asylum seeker scam
fields.trailText: Unscrupulous landlords have made over £1m by charging local authorities for housing non-existent asylum seekers, it emerged today.
fields.body:
Unscrupulous landlords have made over £1m by charging local authorities for housing non-existent asylum seekers, it emerged today.

A report released by the Audit Commission reveals that in one case, a property company tried to con its local council out of more than £400,000.

The landlord made duplicate claims for the same people, claimed for refugees who did not exist, and asked for money for housing people in non-existent properties.

The money is part of the full £100.7m value of detected council fraud in 1999-2000. This cuts the total fraud in England and Wales by more than £3.5m on the previous year - the first decrease since the Audit Commission began collecting fraud information in 1990.

The number of cases of detected fraud fell more dramatically, dropping by nearly a third to 145,000.

These have, however, had little effect on the total amount of money lost to fraud because councils are detecting more long-running, high value scams. In fact, the average value of each detected fraud has risen by more than £150 to £644.

The Controller of the Audit Commission, Andrew Foster, said: "Where money goes, fraud will follow, and criminals have shown themselves to be very adaptable. There is no substitute for proper fraud prevention strategies, meaningful deterrents and the development of a strong anti-fraud culture."

Housing benefit makes up more than 90% of the fraud, with a range of crimes, including cheque fraud, making up the rest.

In one case, criminals intercepted a council tax refund cheque made out for £32.50, changed its magnetic number, its value and the payee's name, and cashed it for £9635.20.

The decrease in fraud is almost entirely due to the efforts of London boroughs. Most other regions registered increases.

The commission partly attributes this to the boroughs' position at the forefront of anti-fraud initiatives, and to the work of the capital-wide intelligence agency, the London Team Against Fraud.

The Association of London Government chairman, Sir Robin Wales, said: "This report highlights a major success story by our councils and shows just how effective our initiatives have been in tackling fraud."

The Audit Commission has, however, warned councils not to become complacent. One in six authorities does not have an anti-fraud strategy, and one in eight does not have whistleblowing policies in place.

Less than half have adopted the Department of Social Security's verification framework for checking the identity of benefit claimants.

"The threat is constant, and authorities cannot afford to drop their guard," said Mr Foster.

 The Audit Commission's research is based on a survey of over 95% of councils in England and Wales

fields.headline: BBC3 seeks 'screwy' programme ideas
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC3's Stuart Murphy has called for producers to come up with 'screwy' proposals to liven up the schedules. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC3 controller-in-waiting Stuart Murphy has called for producers to come up with "screwy" proposals in his bid to liven up the schedules.

More than half the £313m the BBC has allocated to new digital TV and radio services over the next two years will go to BBC3.

The channel will be aimed at 16 to 34-year-olds and will focus on music, comedy, entertainment and contemporary drama programming.

It is expected to showcase new talent, but also make use of established BBC1 and BBC2 stars.

Mr Murphy, speaking yesterdat at a BBC presentation to independent TV producers, also revealed that BBC3 programme budgets would be between £120-140,000 an hour.

What he was looking for, he said, was "screwy and fucked up TV" proposals.

But he was also keen to stress that the plans for BBC3 still had to secure government approval.

News that the BBC has held such a meeting is sure to further anger the corporation's commercial rivals, who have argued that the BBC is not waiting for culture secretary Chris Smith's official approval before going ahead with preparations for the new digital services.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey, speaking at the same gathering, stressed that "there is no hiding place" for programmes to establish themselves, given the ever increasing competition from ITV and other channels.

Ms Heggessey told producers that when they came to her with a new programme idea they had to be confident it would be able to survive against the likes of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?.

She also called for more drama ideas, emphasising the lighter side of life. "I'm not saying it's always raining in BBC drama, but we need to stress that there's a light side."

fields.headline: Extra security for William
fields.standfirst:
University of St Andrews
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Police in the Scottish university town where Prince William will study for his degree have asked for more money to help meet the cost of his protection, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Police in the Scottish university town where Prince William will study for his degree have asked for more money to help meet the cost of his protection, it emerged yesterday.

Fife police asked the Scottish executive for £114,000 to meet the costs of providing 12 to 14 extra officers to provide round-the-clock security for the young royal after he starts his four-year history of art course at St Andrews, in October.

The application has been submitted to the Scottish executive and was discussed yesterday at Fife council's public protection and regulation committee. The money would be extra to the force's budget.

This week students and staff at the university were warned they faced disciplinary action if they leaked stories about Prince William to the press. In an interview with the student newspaper the Saint, Brian Lang, principal of the university, said he was determined to protect the 19-year-old's privacy. Dr Lang said he would take a "very dim view" of any member of the university passing on information of "an inappropriate nature".

But it is feared some impoverished students may find it hard to resist the prospect of earning cash from the tabloids for photographs or gossip about the prince.

Last night Andrew Keddie, chairman of Fife council's public protection committee, said: "We don't want to deprive other parts of Fife of police officers, that's why additional funds are needed. Prince William will be treated as one of the local residents, just the way the rest of the students are."

Marcus Booth, student union president at St Andrews, said: "I want Prince William to live as normal a life as possible, but of course we're concerned about intrusive media. The prospect of his university life being dissected, or his academic grades leaked, would be awful."

fields.headline: £60bn wipeout for Europe's dot.coms
fields.standfirst: All the latest internet news is at Net news
fields.trailText: More than £60bn was wiped off the combined value of Europe's leading internet companies during the final three months of last year as dot.com firms burnt through their cash resources faster than ever before, new figures show.
fields.body:
More than £60bn was wiped off the combined value of Europe's leading internet companies during the final three months of last year as dot.com firms burnt through their cash resources faster than ever before, new figures show.

At least 23 unnamed listed internet firms in Europe face the prospect of going out of business within the next year unless they raise more money, with the average business to consumer (B2C) company running out of cash 16 months after securing funding, PricewaterhouseCoopers researchers claim.

Kevin Ellis, partner at PwC's business recovery practice, said dot.com firms should brace themselves for a further wave of company collapses and forced sales now that the stock market has turned its back on the sector.

"The market is dead set against dot.coms and that cynicism is presenting start-ups with a big problem because they simply can't raise the money they need to get themselves to profitability," he said.

In the second quarter of last year internet companies managed to raise €7bn (£4.5bn) on the stock markets but between October and December they mustered just €1bn.

Business to business (B2B) internet stocks, once seen as a relatively safe haven for investors in the sector, were particularly badly hit, losing 51% of their value in the fourth quarter. B2C firms lost a third of their combined worth. Only 28% of firms in the sector are profitable, compared with 41% in the second quarter.

"Given some of the high-profile dot.com insolvencies last year, we might have expected some belt-tightening from companies in the sector," Mr Ellis said. "Instead, the typical internet company increased spending on marketing and overheads by 11% in the third quarter, bringing the total spend to more than 150% of gross profits."

The contrasting way in which companies control advertising, marketing and associated overhead costs is leading to a polarisation between the best and worst performing stocks. The most conservatively run companies - those that keep the ratio of such costs to sales to around 64% of their revenues - are still attracting investor support and some even saw their share prices triple during the quarter.

But those that let costs exceed revenues - in some instances firms were spending £1.25p to make £1 - saw their stock prices lose as much as 75% of their value in the quarter.

The shake-out among dot.coms has long been predicted. Merrill Lynch analysts believe that only one in four of the internet firms around at the start of last year will still be trading five years from now. Letsbuyit, Breathe and Boo have been the highest-profile failures but Mr Ellis said dozens of smaller, less well known dot.com start-ups around the country were going in search of financial salvation every month.

"We've seen about 20-25 people over the last three months and that is just our firm," he said. "Many of the start-ups that commanded huge valuations six months ago are now being mopped up by bricks-and-mortar firms that are looking to increase their online trading presence."

Survival of the fittest

Survivors

Spend less to achieve sales by keeping control of costs

Have high gross margins (of around 82%)

Sustain business without needing to consume cash

Boast a long track record and experienced management

Operate in specialist areas where rivals have difficulty competing

Strugglers

Spend heavily with £1 of revenue costing £1.25p to generate

Gross margins 65% or less

Likely to be burning cash at a level where a turnaround is essential to avoid bankruptcy

Have a short track record and inexperienced managers

Operate in areas where it is easier to compete and little expertise is needed

Kevin Ellis, partner at PwC's business recovery practice, said dot.com firms should brace themselves for a further wave of company collapses and forced sales now that the stock market has turned its back on the sector. In the second quarter of last year internet companies managed to raise €7bn (£4.5bn) on the stock markets but between October and December they mustered just €1bn. Business to business (B2B) internet stocks, once seen as a relatively safe haven for investors in the sector, were particularly badly hit, losing 51% of their value in the fourth quarter. B2C firms lost a third of their combined worth. Only 28% of firms in the sector are profitable, compared with 41% in the second quarter. "Given some of the high-profile dot.com insolvencies last year, we might have expected some belt-tightening from companies in the sector," Mr Ellis said. "Instead, the typical internet company increased spending on marketing and overheads by 11% in the third quarter, bringing the total spend to more than 150% of gross profits." The contrasting way in which companies control advertising, marketing and associated overhead costs is leading to a polarisation between the best and worst performing stocks. The most conservatively run companies - those that keep the ratio of such costs to sales to around 64% of their revenues - are still attracting investor support and some even saw their share prices triple during the quarter. But those that let costs exceed revenues - in some instances firms were spending £1.25p to make £1 - saw their stock prices lose as much as 75% of their value in the quarter. The shake-out among dot.coms has long been predicted. Merrill Lynch analysts believe that only one in four of the internet firms around at the start of last year will still be trading five years from now. Letsbuyit, Breathe and Boo have been the highest-profile failures but Mr Ellis said dozens of smaller, less well known dot.com start-ups around the country were going in search of financial salvation every month. "We've seen about 20-25 people over the last three months and that is just our firm," he said. "Many of the start-ups that commanded huge valuations six months ago are now being mopped up by bricks-and-mortar firms that are looking to increase their online trading presence." Survival of the fittest Survivors Spend less to achieve sales by keeping control of costs Have high gross margins (of around 82%) Sustain business without needing to consume cash Boast a long track record and experienced management Operate in specialist areas where rivals have difficulty competing Strugglers Spend heavily with £1 of revenue costing £1.25p to generate Gross margins 65% or less Likely to be burning cash at a level where a turnaround is essential to avoid bankruptcy Have a short track record and inexperienced managers Operate in areas where it is easier to compete and little expertise is needed

webTitle: The Audit Commission's five-point fraud busting guide

fields.headline: The Audit Commission's five-point fraud busting guide
fields.trailText: 1. Put an anti-fraud and corruption strategy in place
fields.body:
1. Put an anti-fraud and corruption strategy in place

It may sound obvious, but more than 15% of councils have yet to do it. The commission describes these strategies as "a basic component" of an overall anti-fraud framework. One in five councils does not have a named police liaison contact with whom to raise fraud issues.

2. Make life easier for whistleblowers

More than one in ten councils still does not have formal arrangements to comply with the whistleblower-protecting Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998.

This means council employees can be reluctant to uncover problems because they lack confidence in their authority's ability to handle the complaint.

Today's report calls on councils to improve this situation, and says they need to designate a senior officer to receive disclosures and protect the confidentiality of complainants.

If whistleblowers suffer as a result of their disclosure, the council could face an industrial tribunal and payouts running into hundreds of thousands of pounds.

3. Use more technology

The total number of staff employed in anti-fraud work has been rising for most of the last decade, but the number of internal audit staff - accountants who scan an authority's books - is in decline. The average number employed by councils in 1993 was 8.8. It was 7.9 last year.

The commission says: "It remains important that the reduced level of staff resources is compensated for by the increased use of technology." Techniques such as data-matching - comparing lists of benefit claimants with private sector pension data, for instance - are already having a huge impact in cutting down on fraud.

4 Sort out standards committees

Under the Local Government Act 2000, every council will have to set up its own watchdog to set and monitor codes of conduct for politicians and local authority staff.

More than 200 councils have done so in advance of the legislation coming into force, but many of them will have to review the composition and remit of their standards committees if they want to comply with the law. The act defines six roles for the committees, and no single council has yet met all of them.

5. Create an anti-fraud culture among councillors

New Westminster-style council cabinets or directly elected city mayors will mean power is concentrated in the hands of fewer councillors than ever before. The commission says this could add new risks for councils in their fight against the fraudsters.

It calls on authorities to make sure these new structures are open and transparent, and to demonstrate a clear commitment to fighting fraud.

webTitle: Freeserve adds short films to website

fields.headline: Freeserve adds short films to website
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Freeserve has signed a deal with an American internet broadcaster to add animated short films to its website, writes Amy Vickers.
www.brilliantdigital.com
fields.body:
Freeserve has signed a deal with an American internet broadcaster to add animated short films to its website.

An interactive version of Xena: Warrior Princess where visitors can choose what happens next has been added to the entertainment section of Freeserve.com, along with Kiss Immortals, an adventure-based interactive series following the rock band Kiss.

More animated shorts, or "webisodes", from Brilliant Digital Entertainment, which also produces series based on Superman and Ace Ventura, are expected to be added to Freeserve.com in the coming months.

To view the 5 to 10-minute shows, users must spend two minutes downloading a desktop TV viewer, called a digital projector, which looks like a TV screen.

"These latest additions to the ever expanding Freeserve portal further demonstrate our commitment to providing the best entertainment content on the web," said Frank Keeling, chief operating officer at Freeserve.

Freeserve's experiments in the past with broadcasting have been limited.

Last year it ran an interactive diary-oriented webshow called Online Caroline, which picked up a BAFTA award for best online drama.

Online Caroline became an instant hit and proved to be so compelling for its audience that thousands emailed her, phoned her, sent photographs, and, in a few cases, even phoned the police when they were worried about her boyfriend's behaviour.

fields.headline: How fraudsters swindled councils
fields.trailText: Cheque alterations:
fields.body:
Cheque alterations:

Fraudsters made nearly £10,000 by intercepting and altering a council tax refund cheque for just £32.50.

Using sophisticated equipment, they altered the magnetic number on the cheque, and changed its value to £9,635.20. They apparently reined in the amount of money they stole because they knew council cheques of above £10,000 needed a second signature.

Pensions:

A woman claimed over £22,000 of her father's pension by failing to tell the council that he was dead. As part of the four-year scam, the daughter forged her father's signature on two life certificates.

Housing benefit:

A claimant made £19,000 in extra housing benefit by keeping his occupational pension secret. The council is recouping the money by reducing the claimant's future payments.

Corruption:

A council worker helped his extended family buy six council houses by falsely claiming they were homeless.

The family members eventually became council tenants and bought their homes under the right to buy, and the council may now not be able to recover them. The employee has been prosecuted.

Asylum seekers:

An unscrupulous property company claimed nearly half a million pounds from its local council for housing non-existent asylum seekers.

The landlord made duplicate claims for the same people and claimed money both for properties not being used by asylum seekers, and for housing refugees in non-existent homes.

webTitle: McDonald's plans text message marketing blitz

fields.headline: McDonald's plans text message marketing blitz
fields.trailText: 8.30am: McDonald's is planning to send text messages to customers' mobile phones in a bid to keep youngsters hooked, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Yesterday McDonald's shocked upmarket sandwich-eaters across the UK by buying into the snack chain Pret a Manger.

Now the king of junk food is jumping on the text message bandwagon in a bid to keep youngsters hooked on its diet of burgers and milk shakes.

The year-long marketing initiative will launch in Germany next month and could be extended to the UK.

In a joint venture with a mobile phone service firm, McDonald's will bombard consumers with text and voice messages.

The fast-food chain is not planning to alert customers to discounts on its latest burgers but will use a more subtle marketing approach involving music and games for mobile phones, which will be branded by McDonald's and the Munich-based firm 12snap.

The move follows on from its hugely successful in-store toy giveaways - a children's favourite.

A spokeswoman for 12snap said it will consider rolling the initiative out to the UK and Italy, the other territories where the company operates.

"We are opening up completely new roads in marketing. We want to reach our customers through the most direct means - namely their mobile phones," added McDonald's Germany senior director of marketing Jeffrey Wahl.

'We are convinced the mobile phone will become an integrated component of the marketing mix in the future."

If it takes off McDonald's could become the biggest text messager in Europe with millions of customers receiving free games.

American Express has signed a similar deal with 12snap to advertise the financial giant's Blue credit card, which is aimed at young, affluent consumers.

It is also the first time American Express has used text messaging for promotion.

The explosion of text messaging for commercial purposes comes just days after figures showed 750m messages were tapped out over Christmas in the UK with more than 1m sent every hour in December.

The phenonemon is already causing concern with a wireless marketing body, the Wireless Marketing Association (WMA), creating a charter for good practice in mobile marketing.

The association is considering developing sanctions for companies that "spam" consumers with unsolicited messages.

"Because messages are "pushed" to a user, they can be intrusive, especially when users start to get bombarded with them," said Steve Wunker, CEO of Saverfone and chairman of the WMA. "Mobiles are seen as a very personal space, and unwanted messages are often viewed as a real privacy violation. The key is for users to choose relevant services and request that they receive messages from them."

webTitle: Agonising wait for organ scandal relatives

fields.headline: Agonising wait for organ scandal relatives
fields.standfirst:
Thousands phone helplines but record of body parts held is months away

Special report: Alder Hey
fields.trailText: The parents and relatives of people whose organs may have been stored in hospitals around the country face a wait of several months to have their questions answered.
fields.body:
The parents and relatives of people whose organs may have been stored in hospitals around the country face a wait of several months to have their questions answered.

Thousands phoned hospitals that were listed by the chief medical officer yesterday as having collections of organs, while others sought information from NHS Direct. The helpline took more than 3,000 calls between midnight and 2pm yesterday.

Hospitals have been instructed by the NHS executive to take the details of people who phone but not to try to tell them whether they hold any organs belonging to their relatives.

Even hospitals that have comprehensive catalogues of what has been retained, and from whom, are not permitted to put relatives out of their misery until a national catalogue is compiled, which will take months.

Yesterday Margaret Brazier, chairwoman of the retained organs commission - announced yesterday by the health secretary, Alan Milburn - said the moratorium not only on disposal but also on return of organs was needed to ensure that nobody else went through the trauma suffered by Alder Hey parents, some of whom endured several funerals as body parts were returned to them.

"I recognise that, for some parents, this will be a further, disappointing delay in what has already been a harrowing process for those involved," she said.

"But equally the risks of multiple burials and of setting off a drawn-out and highly distressing repeat of the problems experienced in Liverpool make it important that nothing should be released until the commission is satisfied that a comprehensive and secure cataloguing process has been completed."

The edict will not go down well with some trusts, which are sure that they have full and proper records and could relieve the anxiety of some relatives promptly, but a Department of Health spokesman pointed out that Alder Hey, too, thought it had complete records when it was first approached.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, revealed yesterday that hospitals and medical schools are holding some 105,000 organs, of which around 54,000 date from 1970 and will be returned, if families want that.

Many hospitals set up telephone helplines to deal with inquiries. Derriford hospital in Plymouth, which has 268 adult organs, mostly brains, had 60 calls.

Great Ormond Street in London, which holds one of the biggest collections - 3,800 children's organs - had 50 calls, while its child death helpline had 200.

Oxford Radcliffe hospitals NHS trust, which has a store of 4,400 organs - the second biggest collection after Alder Hey - said it had received more than 150 calls yesterday morning.

Southampton general hospi tal said it had 1,300 brains and 220 hearts retained for research on diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Alzheimers and congenital heart conditions.

At a press conference, the director of nursing and patient services, Katherine Fenton, said the hospital was "not an Alder Hey". All the organs had been used for research and had been catalogued.

The hospital said the brains kept were mostly those of adults and the hearts of children. These had been removed only for clinical reasons and never just removed and stored.

Jim Lowe, of the University of Nottingham medical school, yesterday warned that medical research was already being seriously damaged by a new reluctance not only by families, but also coroners and the medical profession, to agree to the removal and retention of organs at postmortem examination.

He said he feared that society would be the loser.

A study in the Lancet last year indicated that 10% of death certificates were wrong.

If pathologists are not able to remove and study organs, which may take some time, many more people will be buried or cremated with the wrong cause of death on the certificate, and many more relatives will not discover earlier that they are at risk of genetically inherited disease.

Dr Lowe said that "a loss of confidence in the postmortem" began over a year ago, when it was revealed at the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry that hospitals had not returned children's hearts for burial.

It was not the histopathologists who carried out the postmortem examinations who asked for permission from families for organs to be retained, but the doctor who cared for the person who had died and who had established a relationship of trust with the families.

Now those doctors were less willing to ask, because "they feel at this time it will be too intrusive and too painful", Dr Lowe said.

Oxford Radcliffe hospitals NHS trust, which has a store of 4,400 organs - the second biggest collection after Alder Hey - said it had received more than 150 calls yesterday morning. Southampton general hospi tal said it had 1,300 brains and 220 hearts retained for research on diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, Alzheimers and congenital heart conditions. At a press conference, the director of nursing and patient services, Katherine Fenton, said the hospital was "not an Alder Hey". All the organs had been used for research and had been catalogued. The hospital said the brains kept were mostly those of adults and the hearts of children. These had been removed only for clinical reasons and never just removed and stored. Jim Lowe, of the University of Nottingham medical school, yesterday warned that medical research was already being seriously damaged by a new reluctance not only by families, but also coroners and the medical profession, to agree to the removal and retention of organs at postmortem examination. He said he feared that society would be the loser. A study in the Lancet last year indicated that 10% of death certificates were wrong. If pathologists are not able to remove and study organs, which may take some time, many more people will be buried or cremated with the wrong cause of death on the certificate, and many more relatives will not discover earlier that they are at risk of genetically inherited disease. Dr Lowe said that "a loss of confidence in the postmortem" began over a year ago, when it was revealed at the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry that hospitals had not returned children's hearts for burial. It was not the histopathologists who carried out the postmortem examinations who asked for permission from families for organs to be retained, but the doctor who cared for the person who had died and who had established a relationship of trust with the families. Now those doctors were less willing to ask, because "they feel at this time it will be too intrusive and too painful", Dr Lowe said. webTitle: Q & A: Social services performance indicators

fields.headline: Q & A: Social services performance indicators
fields.trailText:
How do I know if my local council is providing good social care?
Performance indicators are published for all 150 council-run social services departments in England. The indicators are known collectively as the personal social services performance assessment framework (PAF).
fields.body:
How do I know if my local council is providing good social care?
Performance indicators are published for all 150 council-run social services departments in England. The indicators are known collectively as the personal social services performance assessment framework (PAF).

How many indicators are there and what do they cover?
Currently, 37 indicators are published, although there are plans to introduce a further 13 during the next two years. Individual indicators measure quality, cost, effectiveness and whether access to services is fair, as well as indicating performance against nationally set priorities.

What do they tell us?
The idea is to give a statistical overview of social services performance. Ministers claim the second year of indicators, which were published in October 2000 covering the year 1999-2000, show services are improving and that standards are on the way up. Some 122 out of 150 councils showed improvements against 50%, or more, of the indicators.

Who are they aimed at?
Everyone with an interest in social services - councillors, users, carers, managers and the public. In an attempt to make them easier to understand, a banding system has been introduced. Councils are rated from band one ("investigate urgently") to band five ("very good").

So is there a league table of performance?
Not as such. The Department of Health insists that indicators "only indicate" and that other performance information needs to be taken into account to assess a department's performance. But in unveiling the latest indicators to journalists, health minister John Hutton couldn't help naming the top three performing councils - Derbyshire, Derby and the London borough of Redbridge - and those causing most concern. These included Calderdale, Islington, Kingston upon Hull, Knowsley, West Berkshire, and Windsor and Maidenhead.

So much for taking other information into account.
That's right. And not all the information sources paint the same picture. For a number of councils, the overall message from the PAF is at odds with the findings of their joint review, conducted by the Social Services Inspectorate and the Audit Commission.

What do councils think of the indicators?
Objecting to performance indicators - a pastime councils used to excel in - is pointless these days. The government is indicator-mad. The PAF is just the tip of the iceberg on social care indicators. Data is collected on some 300 indicators. And there are specific indicators as part of government initiatives, for instance to help monitor children's services as part of the Quality Protects initiative.

Is it just social services under such close scrutiny?
Far from it. The NHS has its own performance assessment framework. (Three "interface" indicators are common to both the NHS and social services frameworks, marking an attempt to measure partnership working). And in local government generally, the numbers of indicators and targets, both national and local, are mushrooming as the government's best value initiative forces councils to measure and report on performance levels compared with other service providers.

So social services departments back the initiative?
Broadly, yes. The Association of Directors of Social Services supports the principle of a "sensible" assessment framework that can help managers to ask questions about areas where they appear to score badly. But it believes that the framework is still evolving and that extreme care needs to be taken in interpreting individual indicators.

Such as?
Well, for example, one indicator looks at the number of re-registrations on the child protection register. To gain a good score councils need to keep this number low. But while this might indicate good performance, it could also mean the council is leaving children on the register for too long. The point is that the indicators are there to raise questions, not to make absolute assessments of performance.

Doesn't the banding system invite people to make simplistic judgements of performance?
Yes. It's a tough one. The threat of being publicly shamed as the worst performer is a great motivator to improve. So public understanding of the indicators is important. But such a simple scoring system can never take account of local context. Although the banding system is probably here to stay, the Guardian understands that its operation is being reviewed.

fields.headline: Hospital waiting times 'distorted'
fields.trailText: Health watchdogs yesterday accused the government of hiding the misery of lengthy trolley waits in hospitals by failing to count the time patients were "warehoused" in accident and emergency departments before a doctor decided whether to admit them.
fields.body:
Health watchdogs yesterday accused the government of hiding the misery of lengthy trolley waits in hospitals by failing to count the time patients were "warehoused" in accident and emergency departments before a doctor decided whether to admit them.

A spot check by community health councils at 52 hospitals in London and the south-east on Monday found a 71-year-old woman who had waited for 23 hours 55 minutes at Whipps Cross hospital in Leytonstone, east London. But according to the Department of Health's records, she had waited only three hours 20 minutes; she was counted as a successful case handled within the official target time of four hours.

The discrepancy rests with the department's calculation of waiting times. In this case, the wait began at 1.10pm on Monday when a doctor admitted the woman, who had a fractured tibia. But she had started waiting at 4.35pm the previous day in A&E.

Elizabeth Manero, chair of London Health Link, an association of CHCs, said: "It is an affront to the patient, who is in pain and anxious to know what is to happen to them, to be told that their trolley wait does not count because they have not yet seen the doctor.

"The NHS will only really improve if the real experience of patients improves, not just the management figures which only tell half the story."

The survey found that 27 of the 50 patients who had been waiting more than six hours in A&E were over the age of 65.

"We need a fundamental redesign of the way elderly people in particular are treated - the current system is clearly failing them."

The spot check also found a man aged 76 with abdominal pain who waited 12 hours 55 minutes on a trolley at Lewisham hospital, south London, but the official record put his wait at two hours 30 minutes.

Nigel Crisp, chief executive of the NHS, challenged the accuracy of some of the CHCs' complaints. Some patients had been sent home and so could not be counted as waiting, and others needed care in a resuscitation unit or assessment in A&E. These patients were not delayed because a bed could not be found for them.

Mr Crisp said 90% of patients went into beds within four hours of a decision to admit them. Over the past week, 30 people waited on trolleys for more than 12 hours, compared with 230 over the same period last year. "We are getting better but we have still got work to do," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"We are not saying the Department of Health has deliberately distorted the figures," Ms Manero said. "They are following a system introduced in 1995 to cut death rates of people waiting after doctors decide to admit them. But they're nervous about changing to a system showing the true wait."

The department said that from next year it would start calculating waiting times from arrival in A&E.

Malcolm Alexander, chief officer of Southwark Community Health Council, who drew up the report, said: "These figures are disgusting - what we are finding is a warehousing of patients in A&E."

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, said: "We get a regular casualty watch produced by the CHCs and ... this is absolutely par for the course. [But] the CHCs are being abolished - the government is making sure that any independent monitoring of the health service is wiped out."

Paul Burstow, Liberal Democrat spokesman for older people, said the patients' charter was not being honoured, and added: "The abolition of CHCs means that this is the last winter we will have accurate records of trolley waits."

webTitle: Scientists list mental risks from smoking cannabis

fields.headline: Scientists list mental risks from smoking cannabis
fields.trailText: Cannabis smoking - besides causing harm to heart, lungs and the immune system - can lead to temporary bouts of mental illness.
fields.body:
Cannabis smoking - besides causing harm to heart, lungs and the immune system - can lead to temporary bouts of mental illness.

Scientists report today in the British Journal of Psychiatry that regular use may make things worse for people who have mental health problems, and lead to panic attacks and anxiety in those who do not.

Andrew Johns of the Institute of Psychiatry at the Maudsley hospital in south London surveyed a number of recent studies. One found that 15% of users identified psychotic symptoms or irrational feelings of persecution. Other reports suggested the drug could induce psychosis in people with no history of severe mental illness.

Those with mental illness - living in the community, and as likely as anybody else to get hold of the drug - were even more at risk. "People with major mental illnesses such as schizophrenia are especially vulnerable, in that cannabis generally provokes relapses and aggravates existing symptoms," Dr Johns said.

"Health workers need to recognise, and respond to, the adverse effects of cannabis on mental health."

Researchers are testing cannabis as a potential medicinal drug - there are claims that it can quell nausea during chemotherapy, relieve glaucoma and stifle the pain of multiple sclerosis - but smoking marijuana also imposes a price.

Last year US researchers showed that squirrel monkeys found the drug addictive, and a Boston team reported that, an hour after inhaling, the risk of heart attack increased fivefold.

Heather Ashton, of the University of Newcastle, reports in the same journal that besides producing severe anxiety, panic, paranoia and psychosis in high doses, cannabis impaired memory and concentration.

There could be heart problems for people with pre-existing cardiac disease, and the drug also suppressed the immune system. Cannabis cigarettes could be as addictive as nicotine, and the tars from cannabis cigarettes contained higher levels of some cancer-causing chemicals than tobacco.

Smoking three or four reefers a day produced the same risk of bronchitis or emphysema as 20 or more cigarettes.

Chronic use might also cause complications in pregnancy and childbirth.

webTitle: Opening the door to promoting mental health

fields.headline: Opening the door to promoting mental health
fields.standfirst: Lynne Friedli, chief executive of mentality, examines the implications of the Department of Health performance targets for delivering standard one of the national service framework.
fields.trailText: Comment: After years of under-funding and neglect, mental health promotion has achieved new status as a strategic priority. Lynne Friedli examines the implications of the Department of Health performance targets for delivering standard one of the national service framework.
fields.body:
The inclusion of a mental health promotion standard in the national service framework for mental health represents an important milestone. For the first time, health and social services have a clear remit to promote mental health for all, and to reduce the discrimination experienced by people with mental health problems. But until recently, mental health promotion was very much on the margins, constantly side-tracked by the need to improve mental health services.

But this week's publication of national guidance to support standard one, together with specific performance management targets, means mental health promotion is no longer optional.

The targets focus on local strategies, which must demonstrate specific action to reduce discrimination; for example, through the employment of people with mental health problems in health and social services. Written care plans for those on the care programme approach will need to address employment, housing and entitlement to welfare benefits. And local strategies must include mental health in specific settings, for example in schools, prisons, workplaces and neighbourhoods.

The problem is, many people have yet to be convinced of the value of mental health promotion. There is a pressing need for a shared understanding of what mental health promotion actually is, and what it can deliver. To achieve this, there are four immediate priorities:

&#149 To look beyond prevention;
&#149 To challenge the belief that mental health services and mental health promotion are discrete tasks in competition for scarce resources;
&#149 To publicise research on the links between mental well-being and physical health;
&#149 To ensure major employers are aware of the relationship between mental well-being, profitability and productivity.

Mental health promotion is essentially concerned with how people think and feel, the factors that influence how we think and feel, and the impact this has on overall health and well-being.

Beyond prevention
Mental health promotion does have a role in preventing mental health problems, notably anxiety, depression, substance misuse and behavioural disorders. But mental health promotion has a wider range of health and social benefits. Action to reduce stress in the workplace, tackle bullying in schools, increase access to green, open spaces and reduce fear of crime all contribute to health through improving mental well-being, in addition to any impact they may have on preventing mental disorders.

Mental well-being and physical health
There is a growing body of research that demonstrates the impact of mental health on physical health. What has been called "stress biology" looks at the relationship between chronic stress and the nervous system, the cardiovascular and the immune systems, influencing cholesterol levels, blood pressure, blood clotting, immunity and growth in childhood.

These findings call into question the effectiveness of public health strategies that focus on physical health and highlight the importance of developing policies that include mental health.

Mental health promotion and mental health services
The belief that mental health promotion is not relevant to people with long-term mental health problems means promotion and services are often seen as separate tasks, in competition for scarce resources. But just as a diagnosis is only one part of a person's life, so medical treatment is only one part of the support they need - to cope, recover and avoid relapse. The other support - by far the largest part - will come from family, friends, schools, employers, faith communities, neighbourhoods - and from opportunities to enjoy the same range of services and facilities within the community as everyone else.

The importance of engaging with issues such as friendship, social networks and employment has been central to the success of early intervention programmes, which aim to reach young people experiencing a first episode of psychosis. These and other initiatives provide an opportunity for mental health promotion and mental health services to identify shared goals and work towards a common agenda.

Mental health and employment
The emphasis on reducing discrimination in employment through local strategies should be warmly welcomed. This will need to be matched by some major changes in the way health at work is addressed, with a move away from individual stress solutions towards a radical overhaul of organisational management and culture.

Local strategies
Developing a mental health promotion strategy is complex. It will need to include action to support individuals and communities, as well as addressing structural barriers to mental health in areas such as education, employment, housing and income policy.

A key challenge will be to ensure that commitment to mental health promotion is embedded in policy across all sectors. For this to happen, many more stakeholders will need to be convinced of the benefits of mental health promotion, and it is this the national guidance hopes to achieve.

&#149 Making it happen: a guide to delivering mental health promotion will be published by the Department of Health in a pilot edition, week commencing February 12 2001

webTitle: Tories retreat from abortion ban demand

fields.headline: Tories retreat from abortion ban demand
fields.standfirst: The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, sought to backtrack on his controversial call for the abolition of Britain's abortion laws yesterday by denying he was in favour of making terminations illegal.
fields.trailText: The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, sought to backtrack on his controversial call for the abolition of Britain's abortion laws yesterday by denying he was in favour of making terminations illegal.
fields.body:
The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, sought to backtrack on his controversial call for the abolition of Britain's abortion laws yesterday by denying he was in favour of making terminations illegal.

The outspoken frontbencher insisted he would not support the outlawing of abortions but wanted a restriction on the 24-week limit for conducting the operation.

But Dr Fox then revealed a more fundamentalist streak by suggesting the reason he had tempered his previous call was because it was unrealistic. "I said I would like to see restriction, if not abolition," he explained. "Because I don't think it would be abolished, I would like to see it restricted."

The shadow minister's explanation, on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, came a week after he called for the party "to pray that there would be a huge restriction, if not abolition, of our pro-abortion laws."

The comment, in the Conservative Christian Fellowship Prayerbook, was attacked by family planning charities as "an affront to women" and led to Tory central office seeking to play down fears it would become an election issue.

Even his leader, William Hague, distanced himself by saying there would be "no statement" on the issue in the party's manifesto. Dr Fox, a Roman Catholic, refused to respond at the time.

Yesterday, however, Dr Fox, who spearheaded the attack on stem cell research and is known for his pro-life views, sought to remain true to his views while toeing the party line.

"I would like to see some reduction in the time abortion is allowed in this country. It's a personal view" he told the programme. But he stressed any change in the law would be decided by a free vote.

He insisted that even those who supported the 1991 act permitting abortion up to 24 weeks would now support a change in the law since "science has changed and our ability to diagnose things has dramatically increased."

But family planning groups remained unimpressed. "Whether he wants abortion to be completely abolished or limited is to an extent irrelevant: it's still trying to limit women's rights and access to abortion and that is unacceptable," said Juliet Hillier, of the Family Planning Association.

No stranger to controversy, Dr Fox has recently come under fire for telling a joke - "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird? The Spice Girls" - that succeeded in being both racist and sexist.

Last August, he caused the Tories to be accused of propagating "fear and prejudice" by suggesting foreign doctors should undergo stricter tests in English.
