"I would like to see some reduction in the time abortion is allowed in this country. It's a personal view" he told the programme. But he stressed any change in the law would be decided by a free vote. He insisted that even those who supported the 1991 act permitting abortion up to 24 weeks would now support a change in the law since "science has changed and our ability to diagnose things has dramatically increased." But family planning groups remained unimpressed. "Whether he wants abortion to be completely abolished or limited is to an extent irrelevant: it's still trying to limit women's rights and access to abortion and that is unacceptable," said Juliet Hillier, of the Family Planning Association. No stranger to controversy, Dr Fox has recently come under fire for telling a joke - "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird? The Spice Girls" - that succeeded in being both racist and sexist. Last August, he caused the Tories to be accused of propagating "fear and prejudice" by suggesting foreign doctors should undergo stricter tests in English.

fields.headline: Ofsted defends council education role
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of schools in England produced a report yesterday which he said offered no comfort to those, including William Hague, who wanted to abolish local education authorities.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools in England produced a report yesterday which he said offered no comfort to those, including William Hague, who wanted to abolish local education authorities.

Mike Tomlinson's first big report, summing up the results of 91 LEA inspections, criticised the unacceptably wide variation in services and said most councils had little effect on school standards.

But unlike his predecessor, Chris Woodhead, who questioned whether LEAs should exist at all, Mr Tomlinson defended the part they played in organising school admissions and transport.

"They do have important roles in strategic planning across an area which could never been taken by an individual school," Mr Tomlinson said.

"The report gives no comfort to those who believe that the existence of LEAs serves no purpose. It does not support the abolitionist argument. Nor does it support some of the more exaggerated claims made by LEAs."

The chief inspector's comments amounted to criticism of the Tory "free schools" policy, which would, in effect, abolish LEAs. But Mr Tomlinson denied he was being being party political. Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, hailed the success of the inspections, introduced by the government in 1997.

Mr Tomlinson said 59 of the 91 authorities inspected were performing satisfactorily, of which 19 could be described as good. But 17 performed so badly they required intervention from government.

Mr Tomlinson sympathised with LEAs for suffering a decade of "something approaching turmoil" as governments chopped and changed their role. Provision of special educational needs was the most worrying area. The LEAs inspected had responded well to its recommendations on tackling racism.

Ofsted had searched for evidence of an "LEA effect" on school performance but found no strong link, although a well-run authority in a prosperous area could have an impact. Ms Morris said the worst authorities had been inspected first. She was unhappy but not surprised by the difference in standards of LEAs.

The government has "outsourced" - privatised - some or all services in 18 poor-performing education authorities.

Ms Morris said she would continue to encourage even "authorities in a position of relative strength" to outsource some services when required.

The best performing authorities were, according to the Ofsted report: the corporation of London, Coventry, Kensington and Chelsea, Warwickshire, Lewisham, Birmingham, Oxfordshire, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hartlepool, Newham, Wandsworth, Barking and Dagenham, York, North Yorkshire, Solihull, Hertfordshire, Camden and Bury.

webTitle: Animal rights activists target charity shops

fields.headline: Animal rights activists target charity shops
fields.trailText: A parcel bomb packed with nails which exploded yesterday morning in a charity shop is believed to be the latest in a series of attacks by animal rights activists.
fields.body:
A parcel bomb packed with nails which exploded yesterday morning in a charity shop is believed to be the latest in a series of attacks by animal rights activists.

The device went off as a volunteer at the British Heart Foundation shop in Penrith, Cumbria, opened the morning post. The woman was shocked but uninjured, police said.

It is the tenth device sent to premises in northern England and Wales and comes amid warnings from the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the government intends to crack down on intimidation from animal rights protesters.

The incident comes as a judge at Peterborough crown court jailed an animal rights activist for six months after she admitted sending threatening letters to employees of the animal research company Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Charlotte Lewis, 28, of Thornton Heath, Surrey, admitted four charges of harassment against current and former employees of HLS. The court heard how unemployed Lewis was arrested after forensic scientists matched her DNA to saliva on the back of stamps she had placed on envelopes.

Christopher Morgan, for the prosecution, said that Lewis had written two letters which began with the words "Dear Animal Abusing Scum" and "Dear Scum".

One letter warned: "If you don't quit HLS then your life will not be worth living. You will always have to be looking over your shoulder."

The other said: "This is a warning. Your life is in grave danger if you don't stop working at HLS. You will find yourself having a gun aimed at your stupid ugly head."

In mitigation, David Heraghgy, defending, said the animal rights campaigner did not have "a violent bone in her body" and had no intention of carrying out the threats.

But Judge Pollard said Lewis's crimes were so serious and the letters had had such an effect on the recipients that a jail sentence was necessary. He said Lewis would serve three months in prison and then be released on licence.

A spokesman for Cumbria police said of yesterday's nail bomb that no one had claimed responsibility for the incident but they believed it, and other recent attacks, to be the work of animal rights extremists.

The police spokesman said: "What we can say is we are aware, because of our liaison with other forces, that previous incidents were perpetrated against people with connections to the agricultural animal industry."

The tactics employed by animal rights activists have changed since the early 1990s, moving away from isolated incidents towards targeted campaigns of direct action.

A number of small separate cells are believed to use the internet to coordinate their activities. It is not known if these cells are involved in the recent nail bomb attacks.

Robin Webb, spokesman for the Animal Liberation Front, has consistently denied that his organisation has had any role in the recent parcel bomb incidents.

Police are taking the attacks so seriously they are coordinating efforts by linking incident rooms across the country - only the third investigation of its kind in history. Nine forces are now involved in the investigation. The inquiry, called Operation Package is being coordinated by North Yorkshire police and led by the deputy chief constable, Peter Walker.

Yesterday's explosion came just one day after the discovery of two nail bombs which were safely defused by the army.

One of the packages was sent through the post to agricultural suppliers on the outskirts of Sheffield. The second was sent to a Cancer Research Campaign shop in Lancashire.

In December last year a six-year-old girl was injured when she opened a package at her father's pest control business in Congleton, Cheshire.

In another incident earlier this month a woman received severe facial injuries when a device sent to an estate agents in Patrington, East Yorkshire, exploded as she opened the envelope it was concealed in.

Letter bombs have also been sent to other businesses including a chip shop, a pet shop and a farmer in Ripon, North Yorkshire, at the beginning of this year.

fields.headline: McCann picks up £6m Railtrack account
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Railtrack has hired McCann-Erickson to create the £6m launch campaign for its new travel website totaljourney.com. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Railtrack has taken on McCann-Erickson to create the £6m launch campaign for its new travel website, totaljourney.com.

Totaljourney is a joint venture between Railtrack and Firstgroup, the UK's biggest bus driver.

It will enable travellers to plan and book everything from trains and flights to hire cars and hotels. It is scheduled to launch this summer backed by a £6m marketing campaign.

Both Railtrack and Firstgroup will rebrand their existing websites as totaljourney. Railtrack.co.uk, which provides information about train times, was the second most popular travel site in the UK in a recent survey.

"McCann demonstrated knowledge and understanding of the totaljourney vision and presented a unique awareness of the market," said Elaine Holt, managing director of totaljourney.

"Theirs was a holistic approach, supported by the strong integration of their UK communications network."

McCann pitched against TBWA/Tequila and WWAV RAPP Collins to win the account.

fields.headline: Emap unveils 'mature' heavy metal title
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Emap Performance is launching a magazine aimed at the more discerning heavy metal fan, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap Performance is launching a magazine aimed at the older and more discerning heavy metal fan.

Kingsize, launched initially as a test issue, aims to tap into the new market for rap/rock and nu-metal.

These genres have not been catered for by the traditional heavy metal press.

It will feature acts such as the Offspring, Limp Bizkit and Wu Tang Klan.

The magazine comes from the same stable as heavy metal bible Kerrang!, headed by managing director Dave Henderson.

Kingsize will be edited by Ben Mitchel while Kerrang!'s editor Phil Alexander will be editor-in-chief.

The magazine will be aimed at 16 to 34-year-olds "who no longer feel they have to know absolutely everything about the heavy metal market".

The magazine will have an initial print run of 70,000 in the UK and will make its debut in March.

webTitle: Boxing: BBC punches its weight again

fields.headline: Seconds out as the BBC punches its weight again
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lennox Lewis was paraded as the BBC's latest sporting signing at the Television Centre in London yesterday. It was confirmed that his world heavyweight title defence against Hasim Rahman will be shown live on BBC1, and it was soon clear that the corporation is determined this will not be a one-off guest appearance.
fields.body:
Lennox Lewis was paraded as the BBC's latest sporting signing at the Television Centre in London yesterday. It was confirmed that his world heavyweight title defence against Hasim Rahman will be shown live on BBC1, and it was soon clear that the corporation is determined this will not be a one-off guest appearance.

The fight, on April 21, now seems more likely to be staged in Monaco than Las Vegas, and the BBC is trying to reach agreement with the American TV company HBO for a live showing in Britain, after Match of the Day, with a screening on tape delay in the United States.

Assuming the viewing figures are as healthy as the BBC management expects, it is reasonable to suggest that the BBC will try to make the most of options built into the contract for Lewis to have further fights on the network, possibly two before the end of the year.

Sky TV, which has covered all Lewis's title fights to date, would be favourite to outbid all competitors if he is finally able to entice the former champion Mike Tyson into the same ring, but the BBC director of sport Peter Salmon was keen to emphasise that the corporation is serious about challenging Sky's market dominance.

"It is not always the greatest amount of money which secures the deal," said Salmon. "There is a whole range of other issues to consider, and the BBC is able to offer a magnificent sportsman such as Lennox an unrivalled profile."

Salmon suggested, with justification, that Lewis might be watched on April 21 by a television audience 10 times the size of that he would expect on Sky, and the champion himself seemed genuinely excited by the prospect.

"It will give everybody the chance to see me, and see for themselves just how much I have improved. For all the people who have never been able to go to fights and haven't been able to watch TV, now they will be able to see Lennox Lewis before it's too late."

For all his success, and an immense fortune approaching $100m (£69m) from his ring career, it clearly rankles with Lewis that his standing in Britain is not as high as he might expect, with less gifted and long-retired fighters such as Frank Bruno and even Henry Cooper retaining a position of pre-eminence within public esteem.

Now, even at this late stage in his career - Lewis is 35 - that could all change and the BBC is sure to explore the possibility of working jointly with pay-per-view operators, which would enable it to compete with Sky for the rights to major fights, with recorded action to be shown on BBC terrestrial channels.

Pay-per-view sales on Sky of recent Lewis contests against Michael Grant and David Tua were disappointing, and even his two meetings with Evander Holyfield failed to match the 600,000 audience the satellite broadcasters achieved for Frank Bruno's 1996 world title defence against Mike Tyson.

Naseem Hamed, who fights against Mexico's Marco Antonio Barrera in Las Vegas on April 7, will be watching developments closely. Sky will show the fight, but only one date remains on the contract thereafter and Hamed's brother and manager Riath has already spoken of his interest in bringing Hamed back to the BBC.

After the disappointment of losing Match of the Day to ITV, morale within BBC sport has been given a timely boost. Plans for its other boxing star, Audley Harrison, are expected to be announced by the end of the week, with the Olympic champion likely to make his pro debut on April 28 or May 5.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Dial-up despair | Safer email
fields.body:
Dial-up despair
Every time I switch my computer on, it puts up the Connect box. If I don't get to the machine within a few minutes it will not cancel or connect but just hangs. The only way out is to switch off and start again. How can I stop it doing this? It isdriving me potty. Chris Rogers
crogers@redhotant.com

Jack Schofield replies: Do you feel lucky? Run Internet Explorer, select Tools|Internet Options and click on the Connections tab. If the middle radio button is selected (Dial whenever a network connection is not present) then select the top button instead (Never dial a connection). Click OK.

Another possibility is that one of your programs - a virus checker or perhaps even Windows 98 - wants to check for a software update. Go to Start|Settings|Control Panel, double-click Add/Remove Programs and see if you can spot any auto-update programs. Also, go through the programs in your Systray (bottom right-hand corner, by the clock) and see if one of those is set to check for updates, or something similar.

One way to narrow the field is to install a firewall to monitor incoming and outgoing traffic. I suggest you download Zone Alarm because it works and it is free for personal use. Set it to load automatically on start-up. Zone Alarm will tell you which program is trying to dial out.

Do you feel unlucky? There are now some unpleasant virus/worm programs that may try to connect to the net to download files. You could, for example, have the MTX virus, which is circulated as a blank message with an attachment. If you can find a hidden file called mtx_.exe or wsock.mtx then your PC is infected. (Twain00*.mtx and Twunk00*.mtx files are OK.) Either way, it would be a good idea to run an up-to-date virus scanner.

Safer email
I was sent an email by MonkeyMail. When I highlighted it to open it, Outlook Express shut down. This happened on numerous occasions and the last three times it caused my computer to crash as well. Given I can't highlight it, I can't delete it. Can you help me to get rid of this email, please? Danka Gordon
drg1@drg1.screaming.net

JS: Short answer: go to the View menu, select Layout and uncheck the box for Preview Pane. You should be able to highlight and delete the message now. (And this time, it worked.)

Long answer: set up Outlook Express to prevent email from trying to pull nasty tricks, which may include dialling out. First, select Tools|Options and click on the Security tab. In Security Zones, select the radio button that says: Restricted sites zone (More secure). Click OK and close Outlook Express.

Now run Internet Explorer, select Tools|Internet Options and click on the Security tab. Click on the Restricted sites icon, and then on the Custom Level button. Scroll down the Security Settings until you come to the Scripting area, near the bottom. Where it says Active Scripting, click Disable. Finally click OK, Yes and OK to exit.

Outlook Express 5 users should also have installed the security patch from www.microsoft.com/windows/ie/download/critical/patch9.htm and all OE users should read the Microsoft Security Bulletin article at www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/fq00-045.asp.

In order
I have a problem with the way that Windows 98 orders files. I "name" the files in a folder numerically, but they are then jum bled up because ordering appears to be based on the first and then second digit - as if it was alphabetic. Reg Jameson
RJdundee@aol.com

JS: In Windows Explorer, files can be sorted in alphabetical order, by size, by type and by date modified. If you have selected View|Details, go to the right-hand pane of Windows Explorer and sort them by clicking the buttons at the top of the list either once or twice.

If you are viewing files as large or small icons, you can sort them by selecting View|Arrange icons and then choosing "by Name" or whatever. (The keystrokes are Alt-V I N.)

If you want files to sort in numerical order, as well as alphabetically, give them names with a fixed length. For example, if you call the first file 0001.txt then it will appear above 0010.txt and 0173.txt and so on. Otherwise 10.txt will appear between 1.txt and 2.txt, as you found.

A useful file naming convention is to use dates in reverse order (year, month, day). For example, this file could be called aj010201.txt, to ensure it appears between aj010118.txt and aj010215.txt etc. This will work until the end of the millennium.

More fax to check out
I have just switched to BT's ADSL from Demon, but I have lost my capability of receiving incoming fax messages. Demon offered a Dfax service which, for a one-off payment of £20, routed faxes to my email account. Can you suggest a similar service? Bob Dixon
bobd.sherwd12@btinternet.com

JS: YAC (You're Always Connected) will accept both voice mail and faxes, like Demon's Inbox, and it is free. Go to www.yac.co.uk

Mouse-free and easy
Where can I find a list of all these key-stroke alternatives to mouse operations (Ask Jack, January 18)? Dudley Ward
jandud@jdward.fsnet.co.uk

JS: For Keyboard Shortcuts for Windows, see article ID: Q126449 in the Microsoft Knowledge Base at http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/q126/4/49.asp

For Apple Macintosh keyboard shortcuts, go to www.apple.com/macos/start/stKB.htm

Also, Paul Fletcher (PFle701745@aol.com) says it is possible to use the numeric keypad as a mouse. To enable this, go to Start| Settings|Control Panel and double-click the icon for Accessibility Options. Click the tab labelled Mouse and tick the box for MouseKeys. Also use the Settings button to set speed and acceleration to high, "otherwise it's extremely slow", he says.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Carer died in sea helping boy
fields.body:
Carer died in sea helping boy

A care worker with Brighton and Hove council died trying to save an autistic boy who was swept into the sea near Brighton marina in November, an inquest heard yesterday.

Marks on 10-year-old Timmy Barry's neck showed Janette Moss tried to pull him to safety.

A verdict of accidental death was recorded for both.

'Asylum' fraud hits councils

The audit commission last night warned councils of landlords fraudulently claiming for non-existent asylum seekers. Housing benefit accounted for 92% of detected fraud cases for councils.

Smog warning

Ozone smogs will cover the northern hemisphere by 2100, exceeding existing safety standards, warns the UN's climate change panel. By 2060, ozone levels will probably have risen from current levels of about 25 parts per billion to 60 ppb. Above 30 ppb, the gas damages trees and wilts crops.

Rights act halts trial

A judge halted criminal proceedings at Newcastle crown court yesterday, as the delay in bringing the men to court had breached the Human Rights Act.

Seven inmates were charged with violent disorder at Full Sutton jail in the East Ridings, Yorkshire, on April 26 1998. Yesterday all but one had to return to jail.

Upmarket move for Barbican

The Barbican, the arts and residential complex built between 1963 and 1982 in London, could get a grade II listing. Variously labelled a design classic or monstrosity, its future will be decided after public consultation.

Fruit to keep arteries clear

Scientists in Israel recommend persimmons for health. The fibrous fruit, rich in antioxidants, helps ward off atherosclerosis, they say.

webTitle: Animal rights bomb sent to charity shop

fields.headline: Animal rights bomb sent to charity shop
fields.trailText: A parcel bomb packed with nails which exploded yesterday morning in a charity shop is believed to be the latest in a series of attacks by animal rights activists.
fields.body:
A parcel bomb packed with nails which exploded yesterday morning in a charity shop is believed to be the latest in a series of attacks by animal rights activists.

The device went off as a volunteer at the British Heart Foundation shop in Penrith, Cumbria, opened the morning post. The woman was shocked but uninjured, police said.

It is the tenth device sent to premises in northern England and Wales and comes amid warnings from the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the government intends to crack down on intimidation from animal rights protesters.

The incident comes as a judge at Peterborough crown court jailed an animal rights activist for six months after she admitted sending threatening letters to employees of the animal research company Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Charlotte Lewis, 28, of Thornton Heath, Surrey, admitted four charges of harassment against current and former employees of HLS. The court heard how unemployed Lewis was arrested after forensic scientists matched her DNA to saliva on the back of stamps she had placed on envelopes.

Christopher Morgan, for the prosecution, said that Lewis had written two letters which began with the words "Dear Animal Abusing Scum" and "Dear Scum".

One letter warned: "If you don't quit HLS then your life will not be worth living. You will always have to be looking over your shoulder."

The other said: "This is a warning. Your life is in grave danger if you don't stop working at HLS. You will find yourself having a gun aimed at your stupid ugly head."

In mitigation, David Heraghgy, defending, said the animal rights campaigner did not have "a violent bone in her body" and had no intention of carrying out the threats.

But Judge Pollard said Lewis's crimes were so serious and the letters had had such an effect on the recipients that a jail sentence was necessary. He said Lewis would serve three months in prison and then be released on licence.

A spokesman for Cumbria police said of yesterday's nail bomb that no one had claimed responsibility for the incident but they believed it, and other recent attacks, to be the work of animal rights extremists.

The police spokesman said: "What we can say is we are aware, because of our liaison with other forces, that previous incidents were perpetrated against people with connections to the agricultural animal industry."

The tactics employed by animal rights activists have changed since the early 1990s, moving away from isolated incidents towards targeted campaigns of direct action.

A number of small separate cells are believed to use the internet to coordinate their activities. It is not known if these cells are involved in the recent nail bomb attacks.

Robin Webb, spokesman for the Animal Liberation Front, has consistently denied that his organisation has had any role in the recent parcel bomb incidents.

Police are taking the attacks so seriously they are coordinating efforts by linking incident rooms across the country - only the third investigation of its kind in history. Nine forces are now involved in the investigation. The inquiry, called Operation Package is being coordinated by North Yorkshire police and led by the deputy chief constable, Peter Walker.

Yesterday's explosion came just one day after the discovery of two nail bombs which were safely defused by the army.

One of the packages was sent through the post to agricultural suppliers on the outskirts of Sheffield. The second was sent to a Cancer Research Campaign shop in Lancashire.

In December last year a six-year-old girl was injured when she opened a package at her father's pest control business in Congleton, Cheshire.

In another incident earlier this month a woman received severe facial injuries when a device sent to an estate agents in Patrington, East Yorkshire, exploded as she opened the envelope it was concealed in.

Letter bombs have also been sent to other businesses including a chip shop, a pet shop and a farmer in Ripon, North Yorkshire, at the beginning of this year.

fields.headline: Church's illuminated cross proves costly
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: God said let there be light, and Stockport council said: "That will be fifty quid, please."
fields.body:
God said let there be light, and Stockport council said: "That will be fifty quid, please."

A Methodist minister has been charged for hanging an illuminated cross on his church because it is considered to be an advertisement.

The back-lit wooden cross hangs above the entrance to Ridge Methodist church in Marple, Greater Manchester. Stockport council said that because the church was on a hill and the 3ft cross was visible for two miles and "draws people towards it" it was classed as an advert - and therefore subject to a £50 administration fee for renewal of planning permission every five years.

The Rev Rob Wilson, minister at the church, said: "The cross was funded by a donation from one of our older members in memory of her mother. When the light isn't on, the daughter often phones up and asks: 'Where's my cross?' And other people will ask: 'Why wasn't the cross on last night?' So in that sense I suppose it is effective as an advertisement. But this is amusing and quite bizarre."

The church had always had a visible cross, he said. "In fact, the old building next door had a huge cross which I've been told was visible from Liverpool."

One parishioner said of the council: "They are treating the church like a pub or a curry house."

Steve Lamb, head of development and control at Stockport council, said: "The planning definition for an advertisement is wide. Anything deemed to draw attention or direct people to it in the smallest sense of advertising a location is deemed an advertisement.

"In the past there have been applications for planning permission for all sorts of devices on churches. This is a minor and quite trivial event in planning terms."

According to the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, "advertisement" means any word, letter, placard or board which is used to "announce" a site or "direct" passers-by.

Alan Pimlott, property director of the Methodist church, said any illuminated cross more than 4.6 metres above ground level was classed as an advert.

Geraldine Ranson, spokeswoman for the Methodist church, said: "It's a load of nonsense. Think of all the cathedrals across the country that are illuminated. There are a lot of small country churches lit up to celebrate the millennium. Are they all to be classed as adverts?"

fields.headline: Lockerbie: the final verdict
fields.standfirst:
 Libyan intelligence agent gets 20 years for mass murder
 Second defendant freed to fly home

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText:
 Libyan intelligence agent gets 20 years for mass murder
 Second defendant freed to fly home.
fields.byline: Gerard Seenan and Ian Black at Camp Zeist
fields.body:
Britain's most extensive criminal investigation ended yesterday with the conviction of a senior Libyan intelligence agent of the biggest act of mass murder in British history: the killing of 270 people in the Lockerbie bombing 12 years ago.

A panel of three judges, sitting in the Scottish court in the Netherlands, unanimously found Abdel Baset al-Megrahi guilty and jailed him for life; his co-defendant Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, another Libyan, was acquitted and immediately freed.

The verdict ended months of tension in the heavily guarded court at Camp Zeist and was seen as a vindication of 12 years of joint US and British investigation. It also served as an embarrassing reminder of Colonel Muammar Gadafy's role in state-sponsored terrorism and fuelled demands for compensation.

There were gasps from Libyan observers as the verdicts were read out, but there was indignation that Megrahi's minimum 20-year sentence was inadequate. His lawyers are almost certain to appeal, a process which must begin within two weeks.

"Twenty years is outrageous," said Peter Lowenstein of New Jersey, who lost his son when Pan Am Flight 103 was blown apart over Lockerbie on December 21 1988. "It works out at less than one month per life."

Jim Swire, the leading British campaigner, whose daughter Flora was killed, fainted and was carried from the court. Today, in London, Mr Swire will lead calls for a full public inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the atrocity.

Early yesterday evening Camp Zeist was sealed off as a Dutch aircraft arrived to take Mr Fhimah home to Tripoli. After spending the afternoon gathering his belongings in the company of his family, he left his cell to return to Libya under UN protection.

In an 82-page written judgment at the end of an eight-month trial which cost £60m, the court said it accepted evidence that Megrahi "was a member of the JSO [the Libyan intelligence service], occupying posts of fairly high rank".

The judges flatly rejected defence claims that two Palestinian terror groups had carried out the bombing, saying there was no evidence that anyone other than Libyans was involved. They were convinced by the prosecution theory that a suitcase containing the bomb began its journey on an Air Malta flight at Malta's Luqa airport. It was tagged for onward transfer to Pan Am 103, travelling from Frankfurt to New York via Heathrow.

The judgment said: "The clear inference which we draw from this evidence is that the conception from a planning and execution of the plot which led to the planting of the explosive device was of Libyan origin."

They said identification evidence from Tony Gauci, owner of a shop in Malta where the clothing found in the bomb suitcase was bought, was a key factor in Megrahi's conviction.

Relatives of the victims said the verdict made it clear the bombing was a case of state-sponsored terrorism. The American relatives of those who died have launched an action in the US civil courts demanding that Libya pay compensation. Although the Scottish court did not rule on the state's involvement - Libya has denied it sanctioned Megrahi - the conviction will clearly add credence to their claim.

Megrahi was found guilty of planting the bomb aboard the jet in Malta which connected with Flight 103. The judges were unanimous in acquitting Mr Fhimah.

The two Libyans sat side by side in the dock yesterday, as they have done for the past 85 sessions, and were dressed in traditional white robes.

They did not look at each other. Megrahi slumped deeper in his chair as Lord Sutherland, who led the judges, pronounced the word "guilty". Mr Fhimah wiped his face when hisverdict came.

Before the judges retired to consider the recommendation for a minimum sentence, chief prosecutor Colin Boyd reminded the court of the enormity of the crime. "Four hundred parents lost a child, 46 parents lost their only child, 65 women were widowed, 11 men lost their wives, 140 lost a parent, seven lost both parents," he said. "They, together with the other friends and their relatives left behind, are also victims of the Lockerbie bombing."

Although Col Gadafy's government was not indicted for the crimes, the Lockerbie blast was alleged to have been committed to "further the purposes" of Libyan intelligence. The attack was believed to be in revenge for the US bombing of Tripoli and Benghazi in 1986.

The US relatives' spokesman, Bert Ammerman, said the verdict led to the doorstep of Gadafy: "Gadafy is a coward. He is a rogue leader and Libya is a rogue nation."

Tony Blair was "glad that justice has been done", his spokesman said. Britain now expected Libya to take responsibility for the actions of its official and pay at least the $700m (£479m) compensation already awarded by the courts.

fields.headline: Dome deal could miss deadline
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Ministers could be forced to extend negotiations with the consortium seeking to buy the millennium dome after Legacy yesterday admitted it could miss the St Valentine's Day deadline.
fields.body:
Ministers could be forced to extend negotiations with the consortium seeking to buy the millennium dome after Legacy yesterday admitted it could miss the St Valentine's Day deadline.

The potentially embarrassing delay follows protracted discussions with the government over plans to tighten clauses guaranteeing the public purse a share of any profits.

Dome minister Lord Falconer yesterday met Legacy executives Robert Bourne and Richard Barrett with the government competition team handling the negotiations.

Afterwards, Legacy conceded the talks may not be concluded by February 14, the deadline set last month by both sides.

But the consortium insisted the deal was still on track and predicted the sale would go ahead before the election.

"We're not going to get hung up on the date," said a Legacy spokesman. "Things are progressing well."

The company has opened an exhibition in Greenwich, south-east London, to secure planning permission to change the dome from an entertainment complex into a business park, and this week released a 3D disc of its proposals.

Lord Falconer's department refused to comment last night but Downing Street is known to be anxious to conclude ne gotiations with Legacy before the election in an attempt to stop the dome becoming a campaign issue.

Deputy PM John Prescott, who will ultimately decide if the deal goes ahead, is expected to meet Lord Falconer to review progress.

Ministers are understood to have tried to raise the £125m price by an estimated £15m after offering to increase the site involved from 48 to 63 acres.

The negotiations are also advancing slowly over the "clawback clauses" with ministers wanting to share in any money made if Legacy sells the dome on or wins planning permission for hundreds of homes.

Appointed "preferred bidder" after Japanese bank Nomura dropped out last year, Legacy's plans to turn the dome into a hi-tech knowledge city have been questioned by rivals.

The consortium has yet to sign up any tenants and has been caught out talking up the interest of firms, suggesting they were committed to renting space when they had only suggested they might.

Legacy is fronted by Labour donor Mr Bourne but is 80% Irish-owned, Mr Barrett's Dublin-based Treasury Holdings emerging recently as the major shareholder.

Waiting in the wings if the Legacy bid collapses are property firms and PY Gerbeau who wants to turn the dome into a venue for concerts.

Lord Falconer's department refused to comment last night but Downing Street is known to be anxious to conclude ne gotiations with Legacy before the election in an attempt to stop the dome becoming a campaign issue. Deputy PM John Prescott, who will ultimately decide if the deal goes ahead, is expected to meet Lord Falconer to review progress. Ministers are understood to have tried to raise the £125m price by an estimated £15m after offering to increase the site involved from 48 to 63 acres. The negotiations are also advancing slowly over the "clawback clauses" with ministers wanting to share in any money made if Legacy sells the dome on or wins planning permission for hundreds of homes. Appointed "preferred bidder" after Japanese bank Nomura dropped out last year, Legacy's plans to turn the dome into a hi-tech knowledge city have been questioned by rivals. The consortium has yet to sign up any tenants and has been caught out talking up the interest of firms, suggesting they were committed to renting space when they had only suggested they might. Legacy is fronted by Labour donor Mr Bourne but is 80% Irish-owned, Mr Barrett's Dublin-based Treasury Holdings emerging recently as the major shareholder. Waiting in the wings if the Legacy bid collapses are property firms and PY Gerbeau who wants to turn the dome into a venue for concerts.

fields.headline: 'I've never been happier to be proved wrong'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Bruce Smith looked elated but still combative after the Lockerbie judgment, vowing that Colonel Gadafy and his regime would be next to face justice for the bombing of Pan Am 103 and for the murder of his wife.
fields.body:
Bruce Smith looked elated but still combative after the Lockerbie judgment, vowing that Colonel Gadafy and his regime would be next to face justice for the bombing of Pan Am 103 and for the murder of his wife.

Mr Smith, himself a former Pan Am pilot and a US citizen, signalled a determined effort to keep up the pressure on Tripoli after the conviction of Megrahi. "We would like to see Col Gadafy held responsible but the best we can hope for is that his government is held responsible," he said. "I would like to see a trial of the Libyan government or an acknowledgement that they did it."

Ingrid Smith, Mr Smith's Berkshire-born wife, then aged 31, was one of the 270 victims of Lockerbie, sitting in first class seat 4H on the Maid of the Seas.

Like many other relatives on both sides of the Atlantic, Mr Smith had been deeply pessimistic about the outcome, fearing two verdicts of not guilty or not proven.

"I've never been happier to be proved wrong," he said outside the court just minutes after the verdict.

"I am enormously gratified that it will make continuing action against the Libyan government much simpler. It will also keep the UN sanctions in place. That is small consolation, but most relatives are immensely gratified."

fields.headline: Stand against terror, Libya told
fields.standfirst:
Britain offers up olive branch to Gadafy

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Britain offers up olive branch to Gadafy.
fields.body:
Libya's leaders need to take every opportunity to prove that they have "definitively renounced" terrorism and will abide by international law, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, told MPs after the verdict.

"The Lockerbie bombing stands among the most brutal acts of mass murder," he said. Nothing could repair the loss of those who were murdered that night or remove the grief of their relatives. But today, at last, those relatives know that in a fair trial before an open court, justice has been done."

Mr Cook said three senior figures in the Libyan government had stated that they would accept and respect the judgment of the Scottish court at Camp Zeist.

He said he had agreed - in a phone conversation with the US secretary of state, Colin Powell - that there would be "close cooperation" between Britain and the US after the verdict - but he has made it clear that Britain wants to encourage Libya to return to the international fold as quickly as possible.

This was reflected in the comment of a senior FO official this week. In an indication of a desire to cement relations with Libya, he said: "If the verdict is guilty, that is saying something about the Libya of 1988. The Libya of 2000 and 2001 is different. We are judging them on their present behaviour."

A criminal law expert at Glasgow University, Clare Connelly, said of Mr Fhimah's acquittal: "There just was not enough evidence. The judges think that Fhimah assisted Megrahi but he did not know why."

The Labour MP Tam Dalyell, who has followed the case closely, said: "It stretches the imagination that Megrahi alone devised a scheme which led to the biggest murder of western civilians since 1945." He added: "There has to be a judicial public inquiry."

The man who led the Lockerbie trial prosecution team said he hoped the verdict would help to heal the wounds of the victims' relatives.

The Scottish lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, said: "They have waited 12 years for this trial. Many said it would not happen. But we have shown that when the international community stands together those accused of international terrorism can be brought to justice. I am proud that the Scottish criminal justice system has risen to the challenge."

Dumfries and Galloway chief constable Willie Rae also paid tribute to the police work involved in bringing the trial. He said the response to the disaster by the people of Lockerbie had touched the hearts of the grieving families.

webTitle: Lockerbie: Britain at odds with US over sanctions

fields.headline: Britain at odds with US on lifting sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: A split between Britain and the US emerged yesterday over the lifting of United Nations sanctions imposed on Libya after the Lockerbie bombing.
fields.body:
A split between Britain and the US emerged yesterday over the lifting of United Nations sanctions imposed on Libya after the Lockerbie bombing.

The Foreign Office, which believes in engagement with countries once regarded as "rogue" states, is keen to end the economic measures as soon as possible. The Bush administration, however, is in no hurry to do this, especially as it is under pressure from families of US victims.

President George Bush said yesterday: "I want to assure the families, the government will continue to pressure Libya to accept responsibility for this act and to compensate the families."

Libya insisted yesterday that it was not to blame. Its UN envoy, Abuzed Omar Dorda, stressed that no link had been established with the government and "Libya is not responsible".

A new UN resolution will be needed to end the sanctions and the US will be able to use its veto as a member of the security council to block this.

Mr Bush faces twin pressures: on one side the Lockerbie families and on the other US oil companies anxious to get back into Libya. A British official said: "There are some differences with the US over nuances. The US is less inclined to be pinned down on what is to be done."

The 1992 UN resolution which imposed the sanctions said Libya had to cease terrorism, hand over the two suspects for trial, disclose all it knew about the bombing, accept responsibility for the actions of its officials, pay compensation and cooperate with a French inquiry into the 1989 bombing of a UTA airliner over Niger.

fields.headline: Curbs to stay, says Bush
fields.standfirst:
Tripoli must satisfy terms of UN resolution

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Tripoli must satisfy terms of UN resolution.
fields.body:
George Bush, facing the first foreign policy test of his presidency, welcomed yesterday's verdict but vowed the US would maintain sanctions against Libya until it accepted responsibility for the bombing and agreed to compensate the bereaved families.

"The United States and the United Kingdom have made clear to the government of Libya that the delivery of a verdict against the suspects in the Pan Am 103 trial does not in itself signify an end to UN sanctions against Libya," the White House said in a statement.

"UN security council resolutions call on Libya to satisfy certain requirements, including compensation to the victims' families and the acceptance of responsibility for this act of terrorism, before UN sanctions will be removed."

Talking to journalists yesterday, the president said: "Nothing can change the suffering and loss of this terrible act, but I hope the families do find some solace that a guilty verdict was rendered.

"I want to assure the families and victims, the United States government will continue to pressure Libya to accept responsibility for this act and to compensate the families."

Following the verdict, the US and Britain were expected to come under pressure from other members of the UN security council to relax sanctions.

Abuzed Dorda, the Libyan ambassador to the UN, said after the verdict yesterday: "Even now, we can appreciate that Libya as a state is not accused in this incident, and was not accused by the prosecutors in the Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands."

Distancing Tripoli from the convicted Libyan intelligence agent, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, Mr Dorda said: "It was a case concerning two individuals and today one was shown innocent, and unfortunately the other one was convicted. The Libyan government has nothing to do at all with this."

But the White House said it would maintain the momentum created by the verdict to impose direct pressure on Tripoli. Yesterday's written statement said: "The United States and the United Kingdom will consult closely and then approach the government of Libya in the near future to discuss the remaining steps Libya must take under the UN resolutions."

fields.headline: Guilty, beyond reasonable doubt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: In their 82-page written judgment, the judges said there was no evidence that anyone other than Libyans was involved in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.
fields.body:
In their 82-page written judgment, the judges said there was no evidence that anyone other than Libyans was involved in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing.

They said they were convinced that the suitcase containing the bomb began its journey at Luqa airport in Malta.

"While no doubt organisations such as the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command and the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front were also engaged in terrorist activities during the same period, we are satisfied that there was no evidence from which we could infer that they were involved in this particular act of terrorism."

The judges said they were convinced the crown had proved that the suitcase containing the bomb was despatched from Malta airport, passed through Frankfurt and was loaded on to Pan Am flight 103 at Heathrow.

They said it was clear that, with one exception, the clothing packed in the suitcase was bought in Tony Gauci's shop in Malta on December 7 1988.

Regarding Mr Fhimah, who was cleared of the bombing, the judges said the main evidence against him came from entries in his 1988 diaries about collecting Air Malta luggage tags.

The prosecution maintained that Mr Fhimah had obtained the tags for Megrahi so that an unaccompanied bag could be placed on an aircraft.

The judges said they did not accept witness evidence, from double agent Abdul Majid Giaka, that both accused men were seen arriving at Luqa airport with a suitcase on the day before the bombing.

There was no evidence at all, said the judges, that Mr Fhimah was at Luqa airport on the day of the bombing.

The judges said that in the case of Megrahi, a major factor against him was identification evidence by Mr Gauci, owner of Mary's House, the shop where clothing found in the bomb suitcase had been bought.

The judgment said Mr Gauci was a reliable witness adding: "From his evidence it could be inferred that the first accused (Megrahi) was the person who bought the clothing which surrounded the explosive device."

They said the clothing had been bought on December 7 - the day Megrahi had arrived in Malta staying at a hotel close to Mary's House.

"If he was the purchaser of this miscellaneous collection of garments, it is not difficult to infer that he must have been aware of the purpose for which they were being bought." The judges accepted that Megrahi was a member of the Libyan Intelligence Services (JSO) - "occupying posts of fairly high rank". He was head of airline security for Libyan Arab Airlines, giving him knowledge of security precautions at airports.

The judgment said Megrahi appeared to have been involved in military procurement.

The day before the bombing, he arrived in Malta using a false passport, with no apparent reason for the visit. He left Malta for Tripoli the following day. The judgment said: "It is possible to infer that this visit, under a false name, the night before the explosive device was planted at Luqa, followed by his departure for Tripoli the following morning at or about the time the device must have been planted, was a visit connected with the planting of the device."

The judgment concluded: "Having considered the whole evidence in the case... we are satisfied that the evidence as to the purchase of clothing in Malta, the presence of that clothing in the primary suitcase, the transmission of an item of baggage from Malta to London, the identification of the first accused (albeit not absolute), his movements under a false name at or around the material time, and the other background circumstances ... does fit together to form a real and convincing pattern.

"There is nothing in the evidence which leaves us with any reasonable doubt as to the guilt of the first accused."

They said it was clear that, with one exception, the clothing packed in the suitcase was bought in Tony Gauci's shop in Malta on December 7 1988. Regarding Mr Fhimah, who was cleared of the bombing, the judges said the main evidence against him came from entries in his 1988 diaries about collecting Air Malta luggage tags. The prosecution maintained that Mr Fhimah had obtained the tags for Megrahi so that an unaccompanied bag could be placed on an aircraft. The judges said they did not accept witness evidence, from double agent Abdul Majid Giaka, that both accused men were seen arriving at Luqa airport with a suitcase on the day before the bombing. There was no evidence at all, said the judges, that Mr Fhimah was at Luqa airport on the day of the bombing. The judges said that in the case of Megrahi, a major factor against him was identification evidence by Mr Gauci, owner of Mary's House, the shop where clothing found in the bomb suitcase had been bought. The judgment said Mr Gauci was a reliable witness adding: "From his evidence it could be inferred that the first accused (Megrahi) was the person who bought the clothing which surrounded the explosive device." They said the clothing had been bought on December 7 - the day Megrahi had arrived in Malta staying at a hotel close to Mary's House. "If he was the purchaser of this miscellaneous collection of garments, it is not difficult to infer that he must have been aware of the purpose for which they were being bought." The judges accepted that Megrahi was a member of the Libyan Intelligence Services (JSO) - "occupying posts of fairly high rank". He was head of airline security for Libyan Arab Airlines, giving him knowledge of security precautions at airports. The judgment said Megrahi appeared to have been involved in military procurement. The day before the bombing, he arrived in Malta using a false passport, with no apparent reason for the visit. He left Malta for Tripoli the following day. The judgment said: "It is possible to infer that this visit, under a false name, the night before the explosive device was planted at Luqa, followed by his departure for Tripoli the following morning at or about the time the device must have been planted, was a visit connected with the planting of the device." The judgment concluded: "Having considered the whole evidence in the case... we are satisfied that the evidence as to the purchase of clothing in Malta, the presence of that clothing in the primary suitcase, the transmission of an item of baggage from Malta to London, the identification of the first accused (albeit not absolute), his movements under a false name at or around the material time, and the other background circumstances ... does fit together to form a real and convincing pattern. "There is nothing in the evidence which leaves us with any reasonable doubt as to the guilt of the first accused." fields.headline: Convicted bomber will try to overturn verdict
fields.standfirst:
Megrahi maintains innocence as Fhimah leaves for Libya

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Appeal: Megrahi maintains innocence as Fhimah leaves for Libya.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Abdel Baset al-Megrahi were yesterday preparing the grounds for his appeal as his former cellmate Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah was gathering his belongings to fly back to Libya.

William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi, has two weeks to give notice to the court that he intends to lodge an appeal. As yet he has not done so, but when the guilty verdict was read out, Mr Taylor gave a clear indication that he would.

"My client maintains his innocence," he said. The presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, offered the barrister a chance to make a plea in mitigation for his client, but he refused to do so. An appeal is therefore sure to follow.

Once Mr Taylor has given notice of his appeal, a judge must decide within six weeks if it is being made on competent grounds. If the judge does, the courts then must find five judges to hear the appeal.

That will be no easy business: Scotland already has a backlog of appeals, and a shortage of judges competent to hear them. Finding five judges with the time and experience to hear Megrahi's appeal may prove difficult.

The best guesstimate is that any appeal would go ahead in Camp Zeist in May. (It could, in theory, be held in Edinburgh, but only in the unlikely event that Megrahi waived his right to be present.)

Any appeal is likely to be hugely technical and, even before the new judges hear submissions, they must study more than 10,000 pages of court transcripts. The appeal is almost certain to hinge on a legal ruling.

"The appeal has to be on a miscarriage of justice or on fresh evidence," said Martin Kerr, of Glasgow University's Lockerbie trial briefing unit. "It can only be based on questions of legal reasoning or on new evidence - and 12 years down the line it will be difficult to find fresh evidence."

In the meantime, Megrahi will remain in his specially constructed cell in the £12m compound at Zeist. He will still have unlimited access to his family and security will remain as tight: 200 police officers and prison guards will stay on round-the-clock guard.

If the appeal is unsuccessful, Megrahi will spend at least the next 20 years in a Scottish prison. Although no decision has been made, the most likely choice is Glasgow's Barlinnie. Prison officers have already dubbed two specially constructed cells "Gadafy's cafe".

But as Megrahi returned to his cell yesterday, Mr Fhimah was preparing for his return home to Tripoli. He spent the afternoon with his wife and children, gathering his belongings from his cell.

Under Dutch law he had 24 hours to leave the country and, at 5.30pm, Camp Zeist was closed to allow him to begin his journey. Under armed guard, he was taken to a Dutch plane. That plane, accompanied by a UN guard, was to take him home for the first time in almost a year.

Without Megrahi, however, Mr Fhimah's return to Tripoli is likely to be a muted affair.

fields.headline: Palestinian links remain unexplained
fields.standfirst:
Intelligence reports rejected as unreliable

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Intelligence reports rejected as unreliable
fields.body:
Two months before the Lockerbie disaster, German police arrested a group of people in Frankfurt, where the bag containing the bomb was placed on the Pan Am airliner.

Among those seized in the operation was Hafez Dalkamoni, a prominent member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command (PFLP-GC), led by Ahmed Jibril and based in Syria's capital, Damascus.

They also included Marwan Kreeshat, a Jordanian who was found with a Toshiba cassette player in his car. It was similar to the one containing the bomb which destroyed the Pan Am airliner.

Kreeshat was released within days by the German police on grounds of lack of evidence. The decision astonished British intelligence agencies, who with their counterparts throughout the west, pointed the finger for the Lockerbie bombing squarely at the PFLP-GC.

They believed the bombing was funded by Iran in retaliation for the mistaken shooting down of an Iranian airliner by an American warship, the USS Vincennes, over the Persian Gulf in July 1988. Had not Tehran radio declared that the incident would be avenged "in blood-spattered skies"?

In the 1980s the PFLP-GC had close ties with Syria, then the only Arab country allied to Ayatollah Khomeini's Iran. Iran appeared to be further implicated in the bombing when a US national security agency report referred to Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former Iranian interior minister who supervised Iranian funding of Middle East terror groups, as paying out "10m in dollars in cash and gold to bomb Pan Am Flight 103 in retaliation for the US shootdown of the Iranian Airbus".

The existence of the report, which was given to lawyers representing Pan Am, became known in 1995. This was after the two Libyans had been indicted and officials in Washington and London played down its significance.

Yet this was not the only intelligence report implicating extremist Palestinian groups. A declassified counter-intelligence assessment produced by the US state department's diplomatic security section, dated December 2 1988, stated: "According to [source blacked out] team of Palestinians not assoc with Palestinian Liberation Organisation (PLO) intends to atk [sic] US tgts in Europe. Timeframe is present. Tgts specified are Pan Am Airlines and US mil bases".

The previous month, US security personnel were told to be on the lookout for an improvised explosive device (IED) concealed in a Toshiba radio recorder. "Recently, an IED was found by a terror group search in Germany," said an internal memo dated November 1 1988. "It was made into a Toshiba radio-recorder. During the security check of such devices that may be suspect, SPOs [security patrol officers] are warned not to switch these radios on or interfere in such a manner as to cause an electrical contact." A handwritten note on the memo added: "Stay clear of Frankfurt airport until further notice. US-bound aircraft."

US officials dismissed these reports of warnings as hoaxes, inaccurate intelligence, attempts by Pan Am to build up a case for their lawyers to sue the US authorities, or propaganda spread by Libya.

Whatever the truth, evidence heard at the trial raised questions about what the members of group who were arrested and released in Germany two months before the Lockerbie bombing were up to. It emerged that Kreeshat had been jailed for 18 years in his absence for his part in placing a bomb in a record player on an El Al flight from Rome to Tel Aviv in 1972.

During the trial, Edward Marshman, an FBI agent, told the court about an interview he had with Kreeshat. The Jordanian confessed to supplying five explosive devices to the PLFP-GC similar to the one used to bring down Flight 103. Kreeshat also told Marshman he had met Jibril and other Palestinian extremists while working in Germany for Jordanian intelligence.

Many commentators have argued that attention turned to Libya when the west wanted to improve relations with Iran and Syria after the Gulf war against Iraq. Washington and London have dismissed this as a conspiracy theory.

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial in statistics
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The trial in figures
fields.body:
The trial in figures

£ 60m Total cost of trial

£ 12m Capital costs of providing facilities - courtroom, prison, media centre and other facilities - at Camp Zeist

£ 44m Running costs of the trial, including staff, translation and transcription

 All capital costs and UK's share of running costs will be 80% - met from UK reserves - and 20% from the Scottish executive

 The US government has so far paid only £4.77m. It has agreed to contribute to the extra costs of holding the trial outside the UK but payment has been delayed. The US government also paid for two members of each victim's family to attend the trial

Other statistics

 229 prosecution witnesses and three defence witnesses gave evidence. The witnesses came from Libya, the US, Japan, Germany, Malta, Sweden, India, France and Britain

 The court was shown 2,488 pieces of evidence, including photographs, clothing and wreckage

 The judges considered their verdicts for 13 days

 The trial amassed 10,232 pages of evidence amounting to more than 3m words

 200 prison and police officers worked at Camp Zeist on a shift basis

 Eight UN observers monitored the proceedings

 The court was built to house up to 250 people

fields.headline: Old brutality catches up with 'new' Gadafy
fields.standfirst:
Jolt to Libyan hopes of acceptance by rest of world

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Jolt to Libyan hopes of acceptance by rest of world.
fields.body:
Abdel Baset al-Megrahi's conviction for murder is a spectre that is returning to haunt Libya - of the bad old days when it was a brutal exponent of state-sponsored terrorism.

Colonel Muammar Gadafy's return to the civilised world is unlikely to be significantly impaired by yesterday's dramatic outcome at Camp Zeist, despite disagreements between the US and Britain over international sanctions.

But the unanimous verdict - against a man described as a high-ranking member of Libyan intelligence - nevertheless throws an unwelcome spotlight on a government which, both before and after Lockerbie, did not hesitate to kill.

In the 1970s and 1980s, Libya was synonymous with the concept of state-sponsored terrorism.

Col Gadafy, who came to power in a military coup in 1969, regularly ordered the killing of opponents - "stray dogs" at home and abroad were eliminated.

Britain experienced directly Libya's willingness to kill when, in 1984, PC Yvonne Fletcher was shot dead by Libyan security men firing at demonstrators outside the People's Bureau in London.

The Libyan leader also supported an array of radical liberation movements, from the IRA through the Basque Eta movement to Palestinian extremists fighting Israel, especially the notorious Abu Nidal group.

But if Libyan involvement was exaggerated, especially by a US always looking to score propaganda points against an opponent, it was none the less real.

Libyan intelligence worked closely with the East German Stasi and received timers and bomb-making equipment from the same suppliers. In the mid-1980s some of it was found in West Africa.

In 1986 it was the alleged bombing by Libyan agents of the La Belle discotheque in Berlin, targeting US military personnel, that brought the retaliatory bombing of Tripoli - most probably the reason for the Pan Am attack.

And in 1991, when the Lockerbie indictments were issued, they included a wealth of information about the personnel and modus operandi of Libyan intelligence, some of whom had been involved in previous incidents.

But perhaps the most striking continuities were with the bombing of a French UTA airliner over Niger in September 1989, in which 170 people died.

Six Libyan secret service agents, including Abdullah Senussi, Gadafy's brother-in-law and intelligence chief, were eventually tried and convicted in absentia in a French court, with Tripoli paying millions of dollars in damages.

But in the early 1990s Col Gadafy cleaned up his act.

First came a cautious process of giving Britain information about the weapons Libya had supplied to the IRA, enabling the security forces to track down arms caches.

After that the Libyan leader began to lessen his support for Palestinians, closing down their training camps and forcing Abu Nidal to flee first to Egypt and then Iraq. Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, initially suspected of the Pan Am bombing, also became an unwelcome guest.

Col Gadafy also responded to the threat from Islamic fundamentalists at home, seeing them as a far greater threat to his secular regime than his old western enemies, most of whom were queueing to do business with him.

Allegations made by the MI5 renegade David Shayler involved clandestine British support for an underground Islamic group.

The Libyan leader's decision to hand over the Lockerbie suspects was seen as an important milestone in this process, as was his agreement to pay compensation in both the PC Fletcher and UTA cases.

Analysts say Col Gadafy has largely given up on his fellow Arabs, whom he has accused of cutting deals with Israel, and has turned instead to Africa as a stage on which he can wield influence and play a larger role.

"Gadafy is paranoid about Islamic extremists and now sees them as the real threat," one well-placed diplomat said last night.

"In some ways he now has common cause with the people who used to be his enemies."

But yesterday's verdict is an unpleasant reminder that, at least for the relatives of the Lockerbie victims, if not for the governments and companies anxious for business as usual, the terrorist slate has not yet been wiped clean.

"This was not just an indictment of Megrahi," insisted Brian Flynn, whose brother died in the 1988 bombing. "It was made quite clear that he was acting as an agent for Libyan intelligence. That means we have to go after Libya as a state sponsor of terrorism."

Col Gadafy will not be the first leader given a clean bill of health after being directly associated with acts of terrorism. fields.bodyText: Abdel Baset al-Megrahi's conviction for murder is a spectre that is returning to haunt Libya - of the bad old days when it was a brutal exponent of state-sponsored terrorism. Colonel Muammar Gadafy's return to the civilised world is unlikely to be significantly impaired by yesterday's dramatic outcome at Camp Zeist, despite disagreements between the US and Britain over international sanctions. But the unanimous verdict - against a man described as a high-ranking member of Libyan intelligence - nevertheless throws an unwelcome spotlight on a government which, both before and after Lockerbie, did not hesitate to kill. In the 1970s and 1980s, Libya was synonymous with the concept of state-sponsored terrorism. Col Gadafy, who came to power in a military coup in 1969, regularly ordered the killing of opponents - "stray dogs" at home and abroad were eliminated. Britain experienced directly Libya's willingness to kill when, in 1984, PC Yvonne Fletcher was shot dead by Libyan security men firing at demonstrators outside the People's Bureau in London. The Libyan leader also supported an array of radical liberation movements, from the IRA through the Basque Eta movement to Palestinian extremists fighting Israel, especially the notorious Abu Nidal group. But if Libyan involvement was exaggerated, especially by a US always looking to score propaganda points against an opponent, it was none the less real. Libyan intelligence worked closely with the East German Stasi and received timers and bomb-making equipment from the same suppliers. In the mid-1980s some of it was found in West Africa. In 1986 it was the alleged bombing by Libyan agents of the La Belle discotheque in Berlin, targeting US military personnel, that brought the retaliatory bombing of Tripoli - most probably the reason for the Pan Am attack. And in 1991, when the Lockerbie indictments were issued, they included a wealth of information about the personnel and modus operandi of Libyan intelligence, some of whom had been involved in previous incidents. But perhaps the most striking continuities were with the bombing of a French UTA airliner over Niger in September 1989, in which 170 people died. Six Libyan secret service agents, including Abdullah Senussi, Gadafy's brother-in-law and intelligence chief, were eventually tried and convicted in absentia in a French court, with Tripoli paying millions of dollars in damages. But in the early 1990s Col Gadafy cleaned up his act. First came a cautious process of giving Britain information about the weapons Libya had supplied to the IRA, enabling the security forces to track down arms caches. After that the Libyan leader began to lessen his support for Palestinians, closing down their training camps and forcing Abu Nidal to flee first to Egypt and then Iraq. Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, initially suspected of the Pan Am bombing, also became an unwelcome guest. Col Gadafy also responded to the threat from Islamic fundamentalists at home, seeing them as a far greater threat to his secular regime than his old western enemies, most of whom were queueing to do business with him. Allegations made by the MI5 renegade David Shayler involved clandestine British support for an underground Islamic group. The Libyan leader's decision to hand over the Lockerbie suspects was seen as an important milestone in this process, as was his agreement to pay compensation in both the PC Fletcher and UTA cases. Analysts say Col Gadafy has largely given up on his fellow Arabs, whom he has accused of cutting deals with Israel, and has turned instead to Africa as a stage on which he can wield influence and play a larger role. "Gadafy is paranoid about Islamic extremists and now sees them as the real threat," one well-placed diplomat said last night. "In some ways he now has common cause with the people who used to be his enemies." But yesterday's verdict is an unpleasant reminder that, at least for the relatives of the Lockerbie victims, if not for the governments and companies anxious for business as usual, the terrorist slate has not yet been wiped clean. fields.headline: The 12-year road to justice
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: December 21 1988
fields.body:
December 21 1988

Pan Am Flight 103 from London to New York explodes over Lockerbie in southern Scotland. All 259 people on board and 11 people on the ground are killed

November 1991

Two Libyans, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, are charged with the bombing in the US and in Scotland

December 1991

Libya insists it will try the men in its own courts

March 1992

After a United Nations order to surrender the suspects goes unheeded, the UN bans air travel and arms sales to Libya

December 1993

UN sanctions are tightened. Libyan assets in foreign banks are frozen and the import of spare parts for the Libyan oil industry is banned

January 1995

MPs demand a new Lockerbie inquiry after US intelligence documents suggest it was not Libya but Iran behind the bombing. US officials later play down the report

February 1998

The international court of justice in the Hague rules that it has the right to decide where the suspects should be tried

April 1998

Libyan government officials, lawyers and British representatives of the bombing victims meet in Tripoli. The Libyans confirm that they would accept a trial in a neutral country, operating under Scottish law

July 21 1998

The Guardian reveals a decision by Britain and the United States that the two Libyan suspects can be tried in the Hague under Scottish law. The plan follows months of discussions between Britain, the US and the Netherlands

August 28 1998

Colonel Gadafy says he has no objections to handing over two Lockerbie bombing suspects for trial in the Netherlands, but demands assurances that there are no "tricks"

December 5 1998

Kofi Annan meets Libyan officials in an attempt to persuade them to hand over the suspects

February 14 1999

After mediation by Saudi Arabia and South Africa, diplomats suggest that Libya will, after all, accept that the two suspects serve sentences in Scotland if convicted

February 26 1999

The UN security council extends sanctions against Libya for four months. Meanwhile, the US demands that Libya surrender the suspects within a month

March 19 1999

Nelson Mandela flies to Tripoli to speak with Col Gadafy with special UN permission. He says the Lockerbie suspects will be surrendered on or before April 6

April 5 1999

The suspects are taken into Dutch custody after flying from Tripoli to an airbase near the Hague and are formally charged with the bombing. UN sanctions against Libya are suspended as agreed

June 7 1999

A Scottish judge agrees to delay the trial for six months

December 7 1999

The suspects appear for the first time at a pre-trial hearing. Their lawyers apply for the charges against them to be reduced

February 2000

The suspects formally plead not guilty to the charges

May 3 2000

The trial begins at Camp Zeist, the Netherlands

January 9 2001

Defence lawyers unexpectedly announce that they will present no further evidence

January 10 2001

Prosecution counsel in their turn surprise the court by dropping conspiracy charges, leaving the two Libyan defendants to face only murder charges. The trial, effectively, is over after 78 days
