fields.headline: How trap closed on Libyan bomber
fields.standfirst:
Mass of evidence convinced judges that agent caused tragedy

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Mass of evidence convinced judges that agent caused tragedy.
fields.body:
The trail from the moment Pan Am flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie on December 21 1988 to yesterday's conviction of Libyan secret agent Abdel Baset al-Megrahi was complicated, circumstantial and occasionally uncertain - but undoubtedly true, according to the three judges in the case.

"There is nothing in the evidence which leaves us with any reasonable doubt as to the guilt of the first accused," they said.

In their 82-page judgment, they said they were convinced that the suitcase containing the bomb began its journey at Luqa airport in Malta, where Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, who was acquitted, worked for Libyan Arab Airlines. Megrahi was also a member of the Libyan intelligence services "of fairly high rank", concluded the judges.

"The clear inference which we draw from this evidence is that the conception from a planning and execution of the plot which led to the planting of the explosive device was of Libyan origin," they said.

The explosion that blew Pan Am flight 103 out of the sky marked Megrahi's involvement in the biggest mass murder in British history: all 259 passengers and crew on board died; 11 others were killed on the ground.

Almost immediately, the suspicion that a bomb had brought down the jumbo was confirmed. The CIA and the FBI joined Britain's smallest police force and the secret services to mount the biggest criminal inquiry ever launched.

Investigators discovered that the bomb was contained in a baggage container which was loaded at Frankfurt airport. Another clue came with the discovery of clothing and the charred remains of a Samsonite suitcase.

Their next discovery was even more remarkable. A thumbnail-sized piece of circuit board stained with the residue of RDX and PTN - the chemicals left behind after a Semtex explosion - was found. The piece of circuit board came from an RTSF15 Toshiba radiocassette recorder. Eighty per cent of sales of this Toshiba model were in Libya.

Forensic scientists came to the conclusion - a conclusion which the judges yesterday said was without doubt - that the bomb was housed in the Toshiba cassette recorder, packed inside the Samsonite suitcase. This in itself was remarkable, but what came next - a combination of forensic science and serendipity - was truly the stuff of detective fiction.

More than 11,000 pieces of fabric were recovered from the wreckage of the plane, but among that wreckage forensic scientists were drawn to clothing stained with Semtex residue.

One item bore the label Malta Trading Company. When German investigators checked through computer records, they discovered that baggage could have been transferred at Frankfurt on to flight 103A (the feeder for flight 103) from an incoming Air Malta plane. The search moved to the Mediterranean island.

When they traced the manufacturer of the piece of clothing, investigators discovered that one of its outlets was Tony Gauci's tiny Mary's House store in the port of Sliema. Remarkably, Mr Gauci remembered selling the clothing to an Arabic man a few weeks before Christmas 1988.

The man stuck in Mr Gauci's mind because he appeared to buy the clothing indiscriminately and paid little attention to either sizing or price. Mr Gauci had many dealings with customers from the Arab world and he could offer one further piece of information: the man's accent appeared to be Libyan. Airline receipts would later show that Megrahi was in Malta on December 7.

Breakthrough

Mr Gauci's evidence was a crucial factor in the case, the judges said. "From his evidence it could be inferred that the first accused (Megrahi) was the person who bought the clothing which surrounded the explosive device."

The next breakthrough was again the product of forensic detection. Among the rubble, the air accident investigation branch discovered another piece of circuit board. Detailed analysis showed it formed part of the timer used in the bomb. In time, detectives would discover it was an MST-13 timer manufactured by the Swiss firm MeBo - and testimony from the owner of this company, Edwin Bollier, gave the court a glimpse of the shadowy world of Megrahi's links to the international arms trade.

At this point of the investigation, however, the trail began to go cold. It was not until 1991, in a US warship off the coast of Malta, that it would suddenly heat up again.

In the summer of 1988, a Libyan named Abdul Majid Giaka presented himself at the American embassy in Malta claiming to be a disaffected member of the Libyan intelligence services, the JSO or joint security organisation. The CIA was immediately called and Giaka was recruited as a double agent. In exchange for payment of at least $1000 a month, Giaka - who worked alongside Megrahi and Fhimah at Malta's Luqa airport - gave information to the Americans.

The information, however, was often not convincing. Under cross-examination at the trial, it became clear that Giaka had exaggerated his status within the JSO and had lied about his relationships with senior members of the service. The judges made it clear in their ruling that they did not find him to be a wholly reliable witness.

The CIA were also uncertain of Giaka's worth: in cables released to the court the first time such sensitive material had been produced in a foreign court it be came apparent that the CIA had threatened to drop Giaka unless he came up with better intelligence.

In the summer of 1991 the patience of Giaka's handlers finally snapped: they threatened to ditch him unless he agreed to a complete debriefing from US marshals. Giaka, by now desperate, agreed.

The Libyan was taken to a US warship off the coast of Malta and it was there that he came up with his most damning evidence against Megrahi. Giaka told US officials that in 1986 he had been asked by the JSO to prepare a report on the possibility of planting a bomb on a British plane leaving Luqa.

False passport

The request was a response to Margaret Thatcher's decision to allow American bombers to use British airbases to launch a bombing raid on Tripoli and Benghazi. When Giaka told Megrahi - who was also a senior member of the JSO - about the report he replied: "Don't rush things."

But there was more damning evidence to come. On the day before the Lockerbie bombing, Giaka told investigators, he had watched Megrahi fly to Malta from Tripoli. He was travelling under a false passport in the name of Abdusamad. It was a pseudonym he used regularly on the trips he made to Malta on JSO business.

When he arrived in Malta, Megrahi carried a brown Samsonite suitcase which had been stored in the cockpit of the plane. He took this suitcase unchecked through customs. He stayed only one night in Malta.

Shortly after the Air Malta KM 180 plane carrying the Lockerbie bomb on its fateful journey left on the 21st, Megrahi boarded a Libyan Arab Airlines plane back to Tripoli.

"It is possible to infer that this visit under a false name the night before the explosive device was planted at Luqa, followed by his departure for Tripoli the following morning at or about the time the device must have been planted, was a visit connected with the planting of the device," said the judges.

The judges were certain Megrahi carried the suitcase which housed the Lockerbie bomb, but no one could explain how it found its way on to the Air Malta flight before being transferred on to flight 103. But the crown did point out the overwhelming circumstantial evidence which had stacked up against Megrahi. It was enough to satisfy the judges.

Tony Gauci, the Maltese shopkeeper who had sold the clothing found in the case which housed the bomb, was asked to look through a series of mugshots to see if he could identify the Arabic customer. He picked out a photograph of Megrahi. In court, however, Gauci would say only that the customer "resembled a lot" Megrahi. For the judges this was sufficient identification.

In the end, though the judges found flaws in the evidence, they saw that it fitted together "to form a real and convincing pattern". It was enough to bring the Libyan who planted the Lockerbie bomb to justice, but not enough to tell the full story of the atrocity. Questions remain. Who ordered the planting of the bomb? Did Britain and the US know it was going to happen? Those are questions for which we will probably never find answers.

fields.headline: Profile of the defendants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Nine aliases of 'quiet' man: Abdel Baset al-Megrahi
fields.body:
Nine aliases of 'quiet' man: Abdel Baset al-Megrahi

Born in Tripoli, Megrahi, 48, speaks English as well as Arabic.

He claims to have visited Britain four or five times during the 1970s , including nine months as a student in Cardiff. Also studied in US.

Married, to Aisha, and lived in father's modest house in Tripoli suburbs.

Thought to possess at least four Libyan passports, and used up to nine aliases.

"You judge me falsely. I'm a quiet man. I never had any problem with anybody. My life is clean," he said in an interview in 1991.

fields.headline: Case against Fhimah fatally flawed
fields.standfirst:
Crown relied on claims by double agent

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Crown relied on claims by double agent.
fields.body:
The prosecution's route from Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah to the Lockerbie bomb was fatally flawed. His alleged involvement hinged on the testimony of double agent Abdul Majid Giaka, and an entry in his diary.

Mr Fhimah's name came into the frame late in 1988. He worked with Mr Giaka at Libyan Arab Airlines in Malta. By this time, Mr Giaka was also working as a double agent, betraying his masters at the JSO, Libya's intelligence organisation, to the CIA.

Evidence was given that early on in their relationship Mr Giaka's handlers had threatened to ditch him unless he came up with better quality information. Late in 1988 Mr Giaka claimed that in the summer of 1986, when the pair shared an office, Mr Fhimah had shown him a quantity of orange-coloured explosive. This was an allegation that could not be checked. It also did little to advance the crown's case.

Mr Giaka claimed the explosive was TNT; Flight 103 was destroyed by Semtex. The crown claimed Mr Giaka's evidence showed Mr Fhimah had ready access to explosives. The trouble was, even assuming his evidence was accepted, it was the wrong sort of explosive.

Mr Giaka's testimony was, at times, doubtful and he had made fanciful claims to interrogators - not least that Colonel Gadafy was a freemason. Crucially, the crown had factual evidence to back up Mr Giaka's testimony against Megrahi; with Mr Fhimah, this was notable by its absence.

More crucial evidence was Mr Fhimah's diary. In an entry dated six days before the Lockerbie bombing, he reminds himself to get Air Malta tags for Megrahi. The bomb which blew up Flight 103 was planted on an Air Malta plane from Luqa, before being transferred to the Pan Am jumbo at Frankfurt.

Here the crown asked the judges to infer that this proved Mr Fhimah had helped Megrahi get the bomb on board. But, as the judges made clear in their written judgment, even if Mr Fhimah had helped Megrahi, there was no evidence that he had done so wittingly.

In an attempt to prove that Mr Fhimah knew of the plot to blow up the aircraft, the crown revealed that although, at the time of the bombing, Mr Fhimah was no longer working for LAA, he had kept his security pass. This would have allowed him to get airside.

Mr Fhimah made no secret of keeping the pass: he used it for identification when he hired a car.

Not only that, there was no evidence he had gone airside. After this, Mr Fhimah's connection relied again on the testimony of Mr Giaka. He had claimed he had watched Mr Fhimah accompany Megrahi as he carried the suitcase which housed the bomb through Luqa airport.

Mr Giaka also gave evidence that Mr Fhimah had often been in Megrahi's company in the 24 hours he was in Malta. Yet the two men were friends and colleagues at LAA - and the crown withdrew the accusation that Mr Fhimah was a member of the JSO.

In the end, Mr Fhimah may have played a part in realising Megrahi's task of getting the bomb on board Flight 103. But there was no evidence to say he did so knowingly - to suggest that he did was an inference too far.

fields.headline: Peace for the town that glimpsed hell
fields.standfirst:
Nightmares linger but residents build new lives

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Nightmares linger but residents build new lives.
fields.body:
Lockerbie was preparing for Christmas the night the sky fell. Ordinary people in an ordinary town busy with early evening rituals.

Above them, the Maid of the Seas was hurtling to earth from a height of 31,000 feet - a storm of flames and wreckage and bodies that engulfed the small border community and echoes in it still.

Eleven of the townspeople died when their homes were destroyed, and yesterday Lockerbie's thoughts were with them and the other victims as the verdict was handed down.

There was no triumph or bitterness; the pain of the past and the determination to move on are too strong for rejoicing or recrimination.

"We stand in the shadow of the relatives," said Marjory McQueen, a local councillor who witnessed the disaster. "It is them who have fought for this and for some it will have brought closure. All our thoughts are with them today."

Lockerbie has distanced itself from the trial and the politics surrounding it.

The town whose name was sullied by terrorism has instead become a place of memories and pilgrimage and friendships forged in grief and horror. A place of comfort.

What its people witnessed is beyond imagining. Jim Manson, a mountain rescue leader, heard the roar of the dying plane above his house and rushed to help. At Tundergarth farm, where the nose cone of Pan Am 103 came to rest, he found the bodies of 20 victims, including Yvonne Owen, the young mother he has never been able to forget.

"They had an arc light up at the scene and it was like some thing out of Hades," he said. "I found this girl lying on her own. She was unmarked; perfect, and she was the one that upset me most. She was about the same age as my daughter." Five years later he met Yvonne's mother, Betty Thomas, from Wales, and the families have kept in touch.

Listening to the verdict on the radio yesterday, Mr Manson, now 70, said: "It may mean a lot to some of those who had relatives on the plane. They are the ones that you feel for. I don't think it will be an end of anything, but I hope Lockerbie will now be left alone, to move on."

Maxwell Kerr, 64, was working in the dining room of his home in Rosebank Crescent when a large part of the fuselage slammed into the street. Stumbling outside, the former electricity worker found himself stepping over plastic cutlery and aircraft seats and the small rolls served on aeroplanes. Then he came upon the body of the girl, curled in a ball as though she were sleeping.

"Justice has been done," he said yesterday. "There is no doubt about that. However, I believe that the convicted man is just a small cog in a big wheel and there should now be an inquiry to assess all the evidence that was not dealt with in court."

The visible scars have healed. The craters have long gone and new homes have been built, new businesses opened; the schools are filled with children not born when the disaster happened.

"I think the town of Lockerbie has drawn a line under what happened here," said Marjory McQueen. "We are just the little market town that you would have found 12 years ago. Now we as a town hope there will be peace."

Of course, the curious still come and ask questions, and tour buses still swing through the town with faces pressed against the windows. At Tundergarth church, strangers still leaf through the book of remembrance and read the words of those who were lost in the tragedy and those who are left.

One page carries a poem written, prophetically, by Patricia Coyle, a 20-year-old student from Boston who was among the victims: "You learn to build your own roads/on today because tomorrow's ground is too uncertain for planning/and futures have a way of falling down in mid-flight."

Lockerbie knows the truth of her words but it does not live by them.

It heeds instead its own town motto: "Forward."

Minds fixed firmly on the future, but memories linked always to one night in the past. The night the sky fell.

fields.headline: Relatives demand public inquiry
fields.standfirst:
More answers are needed, families say

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: More answers are needed, families say.
fields.body:
For the families of the murdered, the conviction of Abdel Baset al-Megrahi does not mark the end of the story but the start of a new fight.

At a press conference this afternoon, UK Families Flight 103 will step up their campaign for a public inquiry into the atrocity. They believe serious questions remain unanswered.

Successive British govern ments have denied the families a public inquiry for fear that it would prejudice a criminal trial, but now the trial is over the families will campaign for a full investigation.

"For the past 12 years governments have refused to talk to us about a public inquiry," said Jim Swire, whose daughter Flora died in the bombing. "But in a meeting I had with Tony Blair he seemed broadly supportive of the idea. We intend to hold him to that."

The families have also met the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and it is understood that he has not ruled out their calls.

In the US a civil case for damages from the Libyan government is pending. Only the American relatives are involved in this, but the British relatives may join their action.

It is through the civil case that the relatives will have the best chance of holding Megrahi's masters to account.

Bob Monetti of New Jersey, who lost his son Richard in the crash, said Megrahi's conviction would help the action. "I'll tell you this, in a US civil court it'll be drop-dead easy to convict Libya, not just one guy," he said.

To the anger of relatives, the Lockerbie trial was never about assessing Libya's role in terrorism. Colonel Muammar Gadafy was not on trial; only Megrahi and Mr Fhimah were.

Although the relatives say compensation is a side issue, the civil action would give them a real chance of obtaining substantial compensation from the Libyan government.

"With Megrahi being found guilty, that is state-sponsored terrorism," said the American relatives' spokesman, Bert Ammerman. "That leads to the doorstep of Gadafy."

Britain urged Libya to admit that it had orchestrated the bombing. "We expect the Libyan authorities to take full responsibility for the actions of their official," said a spokesman for Mr Blair.

A public inquiry may prove embarrassing to Lady Thatcher and Britain's secret services. In the Commons in 1989, the Tory transport minister, Paul Channon, said warnings of a bombing had been dismissed because they lacked credibility. But it later emerged that the warnings had been passed to the Home Office, and that other countries had circulated them to their airlines.

webTitle: The ups and downs of big files

fields.headline: The ups and downs of big files
fields.standfirst:
Don't despair if you have problems sending increasingly large items across the internet. Andrew R Ward has some solutions
More net news
fields.trailText: Don't despair if you have problems sending increasingly large items across the internet. Andrew R Ward has some solutions
fields.body:
Sending electronic files to other people is becoming a frustrating problem for PC users, as the documents they work with are growing larger and larger. Creating a stunning but substantial PowerPoint presentation on your home PC is a bit like building a boat in your basement - how do you ever get it out?

PC files these days are frequently many megabytes. Tempted by fast processors and humungous hard drives, it is all too easy for users to end up with a file of a quite unreasonable size, whether it be a music clip, corporate presentation or video of the kids. Far exceeding the storage capabilities of the standard diskette, these files cannot simply be copied onto a disk and popped into the post. Writing CD-roms is a neat way round the problem if you have the necessary equipment, but still not particularly handy if you want to send 10 copies to people all over the world in a hurry.

Email is the most obvious and also the easiest way to pass a useful file to someone else. Unfortunately, it is fraught with problems when it comes to large files. Sometimes you cannot send messages of many megabytes in size even if you wish to, due to restrictions imposed by the internet service providers themselves. And the worst crime you can commit is to fill up someone's mailbox so they are prevented from receiving any more email. Your corre spondent may not take kindly to discover vital business communications have been disrupted by an animated birthday card.

You may have come across the expert opinion that you should use something known as FTP (File Transfer Protocol). A protocol used to copy files to and from storage repositories, FTP is fine for large organisations that have an FTP server, but hardly appropriate for dial-up home users who will not have FTP access to a disk drive, except perhaps their own web site. Fortunately, there are plenty of much more easily accessible solutions instead.

If you do have your own website and have not used up your storage allowance, you can consider placing your large files there. Then, send the intended recipients the web address in an email, which they click on to view or download the file. For example, if your website is www.deniseworme.com, and you upload a large file called homemovie.mpg to it, mail out the address www.deniseworme.com/homemovie.mpg - in theory, your file is then publicly accessible, but it is unlikely that anyone will find it without already knowing the filename. Nevertheless, do not use this method if security is important.

Some mailing programs, like Microsoft Outlook, will split a file into small parts automatically. But while this overcomes any limit on individual messages, it does not help with any of the other challenges, and makes matters more complicated for both the sender and the recipient. It will only work with some mailing programs - it certainly will not be of any use when sending to web-based email services such as Hotmail - and recombining the messages is a contest most users will not relish.

But now, widely available on the internet and free of charge, is a technique that is within the capabilities of virtually any internet user, and is scarcely more complicated than using a Hotmail account. Several companies provide what are known as free internet drives - it is like having your own disk drive storage out in cyberspace. With names like FreeDrive and WhaleMail, they are specifically designed to be used by the general internet user, and not experts. Naturally, even systems like these have limits - perhaps a time limit as well as a filesize limit - but not many people will need more than the generous 75MB that WhaleMail offers.

Some initial effort is needed before you can use these services, because you do have to register. Thereafter, it is a straightforward matter to copy files into your internet drive and send them to other users. Taking Xdrive ( www.xdrive.com ) as an example, once you have registered and logged in you just click on Upload to upload a file. You can copy up to five files at once. Selecting the files is just a matter of clicking the Browse button - just like adding attachments to a Hotmail message.

Of course, uploading a large file could take a considerable period of time. Xdrive shows you a progress bar, which is a significant improvement on some of its competitors. It also allows you to create folders, in case you have so many files you need help keeping them organised. Access to all these sites is just via your standard web browser, although Xdrive does also provide a software download that installs to give you an "X: drive" in Windows Explorer. This makes copying files, and even folders, a doddle - just drag and drop.

Sending a file to someone else is just a matter of selecting it and clicking on the Share button. Enter up to five email addresses, and they each receive a message with a URL to collect the file from. Files are only made available for a limited period of time - seven days with Xdrive, 14 days with WhaleMail and other services. Watch you do not rename, move or delete your file within that period, or they will not be able to collect it. Unfortunately, Xdrive does not inform you when the file has been collected, so you have to rely on the receiver letting you know.

In theory, Xdrive allows people to view a file before they commit to downloading what could be a lengthy and potentially expensive mistake, but I could not make this work. And when downloading, a rather confusing extra dialog box appears in which you have to select "Open this file from its current location", before you get the dialog for the file itself.

Another technique for sending large files is to use on-line chat and messenger services, such as the popular Yahoo! Messenger, MSN Messenger, AOL Instant Messenger and IRC. These all allow users to transfer files directly via the internet, and are also free. The drawback is that both parties have to be online at the same time, although if you configure the software correctly you do not have to be around when a file comes in - the action can take place overnight, or while you are out.

If you do want your email software to split large files for you, here is how to do it with Outlook. Both parties will need Outlook 98 or later, although the person receiving the mail does not need to do anything: Outlook will even combine the individual messages automatically. Select Accounts on the Tools menu, and then click the Mail tab. Select the properties for the account you want to change, and on the Advanced tab check the box next to "Break apart messages larger than_" and specify a suitable size.

Unfortunately, the process of splitting the message can take Outlook a considerable period of time. But beware: even if you do not split it up, just emailing a single large attachment can keep Outlook busy for a considerable period - so long, in fact, that you would be forgiven for thinking it had given up the ghost.

fields.bodyText: Sending electronic files to other people is becoming a frustrating problem for PC users, as the documents they work with are growing larger and larger. Creating a stunning but substantial PowerPoint presentation on your home PC is a bit like building a boat in your basement - how do you ever get it out? PC files these days are frequently many megabytes. Tempted by fast processors and humungous hard drives, it is all too easy for users to end up with a file of a quite unreasonable size, whether it be a music clip, corporate presentation or video of the kids. Far exceeding the storage capabilities of the standard diskette, these files cannot simply be copied onto a disk and popped into the post. Writing CD-roms is a neat way round the problem if you have the necessary equipment, but still not particularly handy if you want to send 10 copies to people all over the world in a hurry. Email is the most obvious and also the easiest way to pass a useful file to someone else. Unfortunately, it is fraught with problems when it comes to large files. Sometimes you cannot send messages of many megabytes in size even if you wish to, due to restrictions imposed by the internet service providers themselves. fields.headline: EU allies bond over dinner
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: An appropriately bicultural menu of foie gras, brioche and choucroute - or sauerkraut - awaited French and German leaders last night at a dinner aimed at easing tensions between the two countries.
fields.body:
An appropriately bicultural menu of foie gras, brioche and choucroute - or sauerkraut - awaited French and German leaders last night at a dinner aimed at easing tensions between the two countries.

Elysée palace sources said no decisions would be made at the meeting, billed as an "informal brainstorming session" between the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, the French president, Jacques Chirac, and prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and the two countries' foreign ministers.

The meeting was called after last December's acrimonious European Union summit in Nice. Its main objective -besides soothing hackles raised by what Berlin sees as Paris's reluctance to adapt its foreign policy to the redrawn map of Europe that has emerged following German reunification - was to make a start on reconciling the two countries' diverging views of where the EU should go next and at what pace.

A more formal summit is planned in Freiburg in June.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Bad day
fields.body:
Bad day

Farmers. Official figures revealed that farm incomes fell by a quarter last year. The depressing revelation sparked a Tory attack on Labour. Agriculture minister Nick Brown said the fall was "largely" due to the rising strength of the pound against the euro. Shadow agriculture minister Tim Yeo said the figures proved farmers could "ill afford another term of this arrogant and metropolitan Labour party".

Quote of the day

"The prime minister has been rubbishing the former Northern Ireland secretary while the rest of the cabinet dine out on crocodile tears and champagne." Tory leader William Hague taunting Tony Blair at question time, a week after Peter Mandelson's resignation over the Hinduja passport affair.

Today

Commons: Agriculture, fisheries and food questions. Opposition debates on the government's "failure to run an efficient and humane asylum system" and the "crisis in agriculture".

Lords: Social security fraud bill, committee.

webTitle: Air traffic sale frontrunner 'should be barred'

fields.headline: Air traffic sale frontrunner 'should be barred'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Opponents of the government's part-privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system last night called on ministers to bar the frontrunner for the contract after its bankers withdrew from the consortium before binding bids were filed yesterday.
fields.body:
Opponents of the government's part-privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system last night called on ministers to bar the frontrunner for the contract after its bankers withdrew from the consortium before binding bids were filed yesterday.

The Nimbus bid, dominated by Serco, the facilities management group, is widely suspected by MPs and trade unions of being favoured by officials in both John Prescott's transport ministry and the Treasury. As bids closed yesterday it was revealed that PPP Ventures, the private equity arm of the Prudential insurance group, had left the Nimbus consortium.

The IPMS union, which represents air traffic controllers, said: "We believe they [Serco] should be debarred because of what has happened, and will be putting our case to ministers in the next few days."

Serco is also suspected of winning support in Whitehall by making the highest bid for 46% of the system, £800m according to some estimates, though it has far less experience than the rival bidders, Novares and Airline Group.

fields.headline: Tories call for Campbell's head
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday called for the dismissal of the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, claiming he had breached civil service guidelines by describing Tory economic policy as an insult to Mickey Mouse.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday called for the dismissal of the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, claiming he had breached civil service guidelines by describing Tory economic policy as an insult to Mickey Mouse.

After raising the issue at question time yesterday, William Hague accused Mr Campbell of riding roughshod over the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, who had told a Commons select committee in 1998 that the No 10 press secretary should not go over the top and attack the opposition with with "bricks and bottles".

Sir Richard told the public administration committee in October 1998: "Alastair Campbell is able to point out how the government and the policy may differ from that of his predecessors in a way that civil servants would feel inhibited from doing."

Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office spokesman, said: "The prime minister seems happy for his press secretary to ride roughshod over the strict guidelines which govern what Mr Campbell can do and and cannot do. It is in my view totally unacceptable for the taxpayer to fund Mr Campbell's engagement in wholly partisan activities like this".

"The time has come for Sir Richard to defend the civil service's valued reputation for impartiality and to seek Alastair Campbell's resignation as a civil servant."

Mr Campbell's civil service deputies are not allowed to brief on party matters, for instance this week's special meeting which discussed election planning at No 10 on Tuesday.

The "Mickey Mouse" remark about Mr Hague's economic policies was made in response to reporters' questions last week and passed without comment at the time. Mr Campbell also called the policy "an insult to an envelope because it has a back-of-an-envelope feel". His most controversial alleged remark was calling Gordon Brown "psychologically flawed" in a private conversation . He has denied this.

The Conservatives also used the attack on Mr Campbell yesterday to claim that he had been instrumental in bringing about the downfall of Peter Mandelson.

Mr Campbell made a series of critical remarks about the former Northern Ireland secretary at a briefing with a Sunday newspaper last Friday. He insists his remarks were deliberately over-interpreted.

The Tory leader told Mr Blair at prime minister's questions: "The government has spent the last week in civil war. You have been rubbishing Mr Mandelson while the rest of the cabinet dine out on crocodile tears and champagne."

Mr Mandelson's hopes of salvaging his reputation will largely depend on the recollections of two civil servants in his private office in the Cabinet Office in 1998, as well as any written material inside the Home Office concerning any call Mr Mandelson made to the Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien. The Neill committee on standards in public life may be asked to review the ministerial code of conduct in the light of the row.

webTitle: Hindujas distribute DVD souvenir of Blairs' visit

fields.headline: Hindujas distribute DVD souvenir of Blairs' visit
fields.standfirst:
Video: See Tony Blair meet the Hinduja brothers

Special report: Peter Mandelson

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It is the Christmas present that Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz must wish the Hindujas had never sent to hundreds, perhaps thousands, of friends, acquaintances and influential figures.
fields.body:
It is the Christmas present that Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz must wish the Hindujas had never sent to hundreds, perhaps thousands, of friends, acquaintances and influential figures.

Starring the prime minister (rattled), Ulster secretary (retired hurt) and Europe minister (clinging on) indulging in a round of mutual backslapping with the billionaire brothers, the film is a video nasty for the government.

Downing Street has attempted to distance the premier from the Hindujas since the passport row was added to a charge sheet that already includes allegations of bribery in an Indian arms deal.

But the lavishly-produced 15-minute film made by the Hindujas and obtained by the Guardian - sent out on a DVD by Srichand Hinduja with his Christmas cards - suggests a familiarity beyond that required by a politician at formal occasions.

Smiling Tony and Cherie Blair are shown being greeted by the four brothers - Srichand (SP), Gopichand (GP), Prakash (PP) and Ashok (AP) -- at Alexandra Palace during the November 1999 Diwali celebrations hosted by the Hindujas. One brother jokes the premier was "a man who needs no introduction" while another thinks he does. "Hello Lord Rama, you look like Lord Rama," he says. Lord Rama is a Hindu god and Mr Blair makes no claim to be a diety, rather laughing nervously, and when he is introduced to "the younger brother" PP says: "Yes, we've met before, didn't we?"

The DVD is expensively made, featuring a specially recorded message from pop star Michael Jackson lauding SP and GP. Mr Blair's entry on the stage triggers applause, confetti, fireworks and classical music. SP Hinduja says: "May I request all of you to join us in voicing our support for the PM's initiatives for the next millennium."

After repeating a traditional Hindi greeting, Mr Blair outlines his New Labour vision for the 21st century, before he thanks his hosts: "This is a proud moment for me as a British prime minister. And so my friends, thank you for coming, thank you the Hindujas for having organised this evening ..."

In a more comic moment the master of ceremonies, Sir David Frost, then introduces Mr Vaz who does not miss an opportunity to ingratiate himself with his close friends, Britain's richest Asian family.

"Can I in particular mention Vinoo, the eldest daughter of the next generation of Hindujas, who has worked tirelessly over the last few months to make this evening possible. Thank you, Vinoo, for what you have done." As the camera pans to the audience where she is sitting, Vinoo is seen talking on a mobile phone rather than listening to Mr Vaz.

Where does the decision of water regulator Philip Fletcher to allow the proposed restructuring at Glas (formerly Welsh Water) leave other water companies?

Judging by the performance yesterday of Kelda, up 16.25p to 350p, Pennon, 10p stronger at 615p, and AWG, 12p better at 567p, with carte blanche to carry out their own restructuring. But was the reaction an overreaction? Deutsche Bank seems to think so.

It reckons Mr Fletcher does not want other water companies following Glas. In both the published statement and at the analysts' meeting, Mr Fletcher was, Deutsche says, keen to point out that approval for Glas was not a precedent for other schemes. He pointed to four factors that made Glas a special case.

Without restructuring, Deutsche sees little to get the share prices of smaller companies such as Pennon and Kelda moving.

webTitle: Comment: no strategy, not much authority

fields.headline: No strategy, not much authority
fields.standfirst:
Keith Harper on the false start for a new railway era

More about transport
fields.trailText: Keith Harper on the false start for a new railway era.
fields.body:
Almost two years after it was set up as a shadow body, the strategic rail authority finally limps into Platform 1 today, without a strategy. It is a sad reflection on the state of the railways that Labour's only innovative idea for the industry in four years has got off to such an unimpressive start.

Standing as the government's bulwark against the problems of privatisation, it is supposed to carry the hopes of the industry, provide money from the taxpayer for schemes, and under extreme circumstances to take train companies into public ownership if they underperform.

Its overarching aim is to work out a strategy, to offer guidance and help for those who work in railways and use them and to turn the industry into a "world class railway" - John Prescott's words - over the next 10 years.

So we might have expected something special from Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, yesterday, when he delivered a speech in London to record officially the arrival of the SRA through an act of parliament. Some of his words would have had thousands of passengers throwing up their hands in agreement. "We will get funded to deliver the service the public want, at the time and place the public wants it, and in the form and to the standard wanted."

There was no mention of a strategy, only a strategic agenda. We may get a strategy in the summer after the election or it may be later than that. The SRA's words are like a needle stuck in an old gramophone record. They have not changed for more than a year.

The strategy should have come before the government's 10-year transport plan, then it got delayed to last summer, then it was delayed again because of the rail regulator's review of Railtrack, then again because of the Hatfield rail disaster. The excuses are limitless.

If the SRA produced its strategy it would relieve uncertainty among some train companies planning to apply for a renewal of their franchises with no idea of the shape of a future railway map.

The SRA's answer, and presumably Sir Alastair's, is that the market decides and the SRA provides - but the market has already decided. Railways are in vogue again, or were until the Hatfield crash. Passengers have increased by 30% in the past four years and an increase of 50% is expected in the next 10 years.

The train companies say they would like some direction from the SRA but they are not getting it. One frustrated operator said: "We wish we had some guidance, but there is no evidence from the SRA as to what we should be doing."

Even Sir Alastair's preferred method has not resulted in quick solutions. So far only two franchise issues have been resolved since the authority was set up as a shadow in March 1999. Chiltern Railways, the least complicated franchise, which runs a good commuter service between Birmingham and London, was given a further vote of confidence, and French-owned Connex has been stripped of its south central franchise in London's commuter belt.

A crucial decision is awaited on who gets the franchise to run the east coast main line between Edinburgh and London. Here the SRA has exposed itself to a flawed approach and deep internal divisions. The team that examined the bid recommended a Virgin/Stagecoach scheme to Sir Alastair with its new 120-mile track linking the north and south, capable of carrying trains at speeds of 200mph. The option would cost £1.5bn less than the bid by the incumbent, GNER and was regarded as better value.

Sir Alastair ignored the advice and backed GNER. Virgin is furious because Sir Alastair has made matters worse by seizing on the idea of a high-speed line and promising to investigate its potential. So the only new piece of strategy is one promised by a rail company which it may be prevented from achieving.

The decision is being held up while the Treasury examines whether the Virgin scheme does give value for money. Any attempt by the government to force him to reconsider the bid would put Sir Alastair under considerable pressure and he is one of rail's star turns. Sir Richard Branson is understood to have instructed counsel.

This mounting crisis on strategy ignores more fundamental issues of overcrowding and fares. When negotiating new franchises, it will come under public pressure to make sure companies have to justify fare increases. The SRA may be moving out of the shadow into the light, but in doing so it will be exposing itself to far more public scrutiny and criticism.

webTitle: Comment: Lockerbie -  the truth may never be known

fields.headline: Business as usual
fields.standfirst:
The Lockerbie verdicts do not convince us that justice has been done, but the truth may never be known

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The Lockerbie verdicts do not convince us that justice has been done, but the truth may never be known.
fields.body:
The Lockerbie verdicts will not convince the majority of Arabs, the community of Middle East watchers and most of the victims' families that justice has been done, or that anyone but a footsoldier, as one of the victims' representatives described Abdelbaset Al Megrahi, has been made a scapegoat. The speed of the verdicts' arrival and the judges' decision to stretch their judicial brief specifically to rule out any wider involvement in the bombing other than that of Libya will further inflame legions of conspiratorial critics.

The Lockerbie affair has, after all, been a triumph of realpolitik over all the evidence and questions of motive. Suspicion must still focus on Iran, Syria and the dissident Palestinian armed-action squad, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (General Command) and the likelihood that Lockerbie was a revenge for the downing in July 1988, of an Iranian airbus by the USS Vincennes (a guided missile-destroyer) in the Gulf of Hormuz.

This cynicism is triggered by the immunity seemingly granted by western governments to these suspects for reasons of the greater good. There are excellent reasons why American and British politicians, policemen and diplomats would have rather seen isolated, feeble and irritating Libya in the frame than the Palestinian dissidents, Iranians and Syrians, at whom the accusing fingers first and so convincingly pointed.

When the bombing of Lockerbie happened in December 1988, the western shaping of the Middle East for the 1990s and even 2000s was already beginning.

The Iran-Iraq war had ended, with Iran diminished, if not defeated. Iran and the US, and the west in general, were extending tentative feelers towards one another, nearly 10 years after the Iranian revolution, in the shape of an American unfreezing of many Iranian financial assets and Iranian compensation for American individuals and Amoco's damaged oil interests.

Both Britain and the US, after the death of Ayatollah Khomeini in 1989, saw a practical and canny man they could deal with in the new president, Hashemi Rafsanjani. He promised, for example, to try to mitigate the fatwa against Salman Rushdie. Both countries had hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. The west Europeans and the US wanted Iran's help in their release and, in Europe's case, its peacetime business.

Syria, Iran's only Arab ally during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, was emerging from an era of darkness. Britain had broken off diplomatic relations with Syria in 1986, over the attempt by a man connected with spooks in the Syrian embassy, Nizar Hendawi, to plant a bomb on an Israeli airliner at Heathrow Airport. Syria was also reviled by its Arab cousins for its support of Iran.

But Syria, with its vast intelligence network in Lebanon and its close relations with Iran and the pro-Iranian guerrilla groups, like Hezbollah, that flourished - with Syrian help - in the fastnesses of southern Beirut and south Lebanon, was also indispensable to the release of western hostages and to any hopes of a wider regional peace.

Most importantly, after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August 1990 - while Britain and the Americans were apparently unearthing evidence implicating the Syria-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (General Command) the rehabilitation of Syria and an almost benign tolerance of Iran clouded the scene. Syria was vital to the allied coalition assembled to force Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.

In September 1990, the Americans (and Israel ) gave the green light to Syrian forces to impose their military discipline on Lebanon and its incoherent, warring Christian Maronite forces; in November, Britain reopened diplomatic relations with Syria. In the next year or so, all the western hostages would be released with Iran's and Syria's help, and the British and the Americans were fulsome in their praise. In 1991, Iran released the British academic Roger Cooper, who had been imprisoned in 1986 on trumped-up charges of spying.

In the Middle East of 1991, the sky was dark with quid pro quos. Syria-again crucially - agreed to attend the Arab-Israel peace conference in Madrid, which in turn spawned the ongoing American inspired attempts to bring Middle East peace.

It was at this time that the focus shifted to Libya. And there it has stayed, pace the critics consistently written off by the Foreign Office and the British/Scottish judicial system as conspiracy theorists and nutters.

Whether such cynicism and suspicion is justified will not be known in my or Jim Swire's lifetime, if ever. The likelihood of a rigorous inquiry at which key American and Arab, British and Iranian players will tell all, in all honesty, is far lower than that of a handsome pay-off to the victims' families and the uninterrupted march of Britain's and the US's coincidental interests in the Middle East.

Tim Llewellyn is former BBC Middle East correspondent.

fields.headline: The anti-socialist has gone, but is the project still rightist?
fields.standfirst:
Labour may be keen to rewrite the script, but it still sounds the same

Special report: Peter Mandelson
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour may be keen to rewrite the script, but it still sounds the same.
fields.body:
Playing into the Labour mind après-Mandelson, the occasion could hardly have been more piquant. The chancellor's residence was given over yesterday to a breakfast seminar on moral purpose in government. The timing, though accidental, was perfect. Yet the signals were conflicting.

On the one hand, here was high seriousness sweeping aside the sense of squalor, which reached a new high this very morning, when Labour registered more bleakly on the sleaze-scale, according to opinion polls, than the Major government. The meeting was very Scottish. The invitation said it would be "timeous", a word southerners need to look up ("timely") but which turned out to be truer than anyone foretold when the summons went out weeks ago.

The seminar could also be said to represent what might have been. The organisers were the Smith Institute, set up to keep alive the work and thought of John Smith, high-minded and presbyterian, whose untimeous death put Tony Blair where he is today. Smith was a reluctant convert to spin, and sacked Mandelson from his job as Labour's media controller. Gordon Brown himself presided here, and warmly introduced the speakers. He couldn't have wished for a better milieu in which to mark a return to politics as he used to know it: earnest, visionary, unflinchingly solemn.

On the other hand, it didn't entirely fit. The main speaker proposed a social analysis seemingly so far from Brown's or Smith's as to be worthy of the epithet Mandelsonian. James Q Wilson, a well-known conservative American professor, made a speech that had nothing to do with socialism, which is supposed to be the creed saved for Britain by Mandelson's departure. As the most senior Labour politician to regularly use this old term, Mr Brown seemed undismayed by the Wilson analysis which directly challenges it.

The professor's message is that modern social ills can be cured only by a revival of individual morality. He's a prophet of the innate moral intuition of humanity, a faculty which, he argues, the state has done much to diminish if not destroy. He has examined the moral decline of advanced societies, and makes a case for the intervention of voluntary agencies to revive the family and reverse the trend. That's a shorthand account of some large work. Wilson's biggest recent triumph is the arrival of a former pupil at the head of George Bush's new programme of faith-based initiatives to restore "values" to American society.

This is not a nonsensical proposition. There's a dangerous chasm, in both halves of Anglo-American society rather more than in some continental countries, between the riches of economic advance and the poverty of social order. Crime levels, teenage pregnancy rates, alienated youth, evidences of social disaffection, all are troubling to any sentient observer, and have proved pretty immune to conventional political responses. If faith groups had a significant presence in British society, they might have a role to play. Such an approach fits the ideologically cross-dressed politics that Tony Blair half-espouses and Peter Mandelson represented.

It's a long way, though, from Gordon Brown's. Or so one thought. It argues for subcontracting from the state some of the problems he now feels freer than before to define as public problems with public solutions. The Mandelson v Brown contest always had a political as well as tactical content. It may have been partly about issues of personal ascendancy. But it also bit deeply into the strategic question of how New Labour should define itself, with Mandelson, from his Belfast outpost, still trying to insist that this was no longer a socialist party.

Anyone who heard Brown at the Fabian Society conference last weekend thought they saw how far he has rowed back from that position, which as founders of New Labour all these characters once shared. His speech was a proclamation for the benign state, and a promise that state economic power, handled by Labour true believers, would eliminate child poverty, advance universal education, and rectify the defects of an unequal society. It was an old-fashioned tub-thump, of Bevanite passion, for the duty of the enabling state to deliver the promised land.

The waters are closing over Mandelson now. The original message-man finds every Labour politician on message to write him out of the script. It's uncanny to converse with half a dozen random figures from the party, MPs and advisers alike, and see how completely the former minister is already relegated to irrelevance. Some people might think a torrid time awaits the government, as its conduct of the Hinduja passport affair comes under intimate scrutiny via the Hammond inquiry. An objective observer could still regard the verdict on Mandelson's conduct as not proven, and the outcome for his future life as remaining to be justified. I have yet to meet a single Labour politician who gives such fastidiousness the slightest credence.

This is partly because they disliked the former minister, and saw his methods as creating endless trouble. They are glad to see the back of someone so thoroughly divisive. The more charitable say he should never have become an MP at all, but remained a backroom fixer, perhaps deploying his organisational talents as general secretary of the party. Harsher judges, including one-time close allies, venomously blackguard every aspect of his character, as well as muttering against Blair's judgment for letting him get anywhere near the top - twice.

But another attack is against the content of the politics he advanced, as the black prince of anti-socialism. On this account (Clare Short is a representative voice) he betrayed the party. Good riddance to this running dog of the rich and famous, distracting Labour from its progressive destiny. Long live the true faith.

Yet that's not quite how things sounded in 11 Downing Street yesterday, where Professor Wilson got a quite admiring audience for his treatise on the politics of personal salvation. Key to his thesis is the proposition that the state has failed, and is never likely to succeed. It's a plausible if contentious line, not original but worth discussing. What it is, indisputably, is conservative: the acme of an individualism which is to be mediated, if at all, by non-state bodies. It's what William Hague is feeling for, with his wishful faith-based imitations of Dubya Bush.

The fact that Gordon Brown hosted the seminar doesn't mean he has to agree with the main speaker. Intellectual curiosity shouldn't be stigmatised, even in a chancellor. Wilson's theories offer an escape-hatch for politicians who have been fought to a standstill by problems of human behaviour they've been unable to master. An irony begins to inch its way over the horizon. The Rasputin of Labour's rightist phase has been disposed of. But the Lenin of its modernised socialism is getting ready to have second thoughts. webTitle: George Monbiot: I'm a menace to society

fields.headline: It's official: I'm a menace to society
fields.standfirst:
Simply carrying copies of my book is enough to get you banned

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Simply carrying copies of my book is enough to get you banned.
fields.body:
I'm beginning to feel unwelcome. On Monday a letter in the Guardian revealed that staff from the Bookmarks bookshop trying to reach the World Economic Forum were refused entry to Switzerland. Their offence? Carrying copies of my book, Captive State, and Naomi Klein's book, No Logo, which were deemed too dangerous to be allowed into the country at such a sensitive time. Now I discover that, alongside such threats to civilisation as the World Development Movement, Jubilee Plus, Friends of the Earth and the human rights lawyer Louise Christian, my presence has become a "security risk", which major venues around the country have been asked to forestall.

On Friday, a speaking tour called Globalise Resistance begins in Glasgow. Organised by greens, socialists and student activists, it brings together liberal and radical critics of globalisation. It involves no demonstrations, no rallies, no riots: it is simply a series of conferences. Yet almost everywhere we're going, people have called for the tour to be restricted or banned.

On Friday, the Scottish Conservative party asked the Home Office to review its decision to grant a visa to a speaker from the US. The SNP warned that our conference in Glasgow "must be closely monitored". In Manchester, we were booked to speak at the university. A few weeks ago, it cancelled the booking. Having spoken to the police, it had decided that we were "a potential security risk". So the organisers hired a hall in the Co-op's headquarters instead. A fortnight ago, the security company running the hall annulled the contract on the advice of the police. After some discussion, the firm, to its credit, reversed its decision.

The tour's organisers encountered similar problems when they tried to hire a venue in London. They had agreed a price with Imperial College, but it backed away just as the contract was about to be signed. So instead they booked the conference facilities at Goldsmiths College, whose principal is the Labour historian Ben Pimlott. On January 22, Goldsmiths wrote to confirm a booking for 1,000 guests. Soon afterwards, the college pulled out.

I have spent much of the past week trying to find out why. When, after days of trying, I managed to raise Ben Pimlott, he insisted that I shouldn't quote him. This wasn't hard, as he refused to answer most of my questions, such as whether the event had been cancelled because of its political complexion. An administrator told me that the conference was too big for the college, and had been booked in error. But Goldsmiths' brochure reveals that the two main auditoria alone seat 1,040 people, and "over 50 additional rooms" are available for hire. The organisers offered to restrict the number of guests; but the college refused to negotiate. The conference had to find another venue.

So what on earth is going on? Nobody knows, but when the Socialist Alliance, which is one of the groups involved in the current tour, booked rooms from Brighton and Hove Council for a meeting coinciding with the Labour party conference last September, the council tried to cancel on the grounds that it would "offend our major customer": namely the Labour party. It backed down only when the press began phoning.

It is certainly becoming harder to challenge the neo-liberal consensus to which nearly all the world's major political parties now subscribe. The global deregulation which allows big business both to seize trade from smaller companies and to dump its costs on to people and the environment can proceed only if it is accompanied by the reregulation of the people it threatens. All over the world, governments are trying to stamp out peaceful protest and dissent.

In Britain, the new terrorism and investigatory powers acts enable the security services both to characterise protesters as terrorists and to ransack their communications without a warrant. In the US, peaceful demonstrators are now being arrested en masse before their protests begin. After the demonstrations in Seattle in 1999, some of us took bets as to where the next world trade talks would be held. Someone suggested Burma, another Bahrain. Someone else hazarded Qatar. Sure enough, last week we heard that November's trade talks will be held in Qatar. New market "freedoms" will be implemented with the help of old-fashioned authoritarianism.

Institutions behave like this when they are frightened. The more the politics and economics of globalisation are exposed to public scrutiny, the more they are found wanting. When power has to hide from the people, you know it's illegitimate.

 To book tickets for the Globalise Resistance tour, telephone 07956 681328.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: At long last, we come to my friend Richard Littlejohn's endearing conduct at Simon Heffer's Essex home the night when Tory education minister John Patten and his lovely wife Louise came to stay.
fields.body:
 At long last, we come to my friend Richard Littlejohn's endearing conduct at Simon Heffer's Essex home the night when Tory education minister John Patten and his lovely wife Louise came to stay.

Students of Richard's protesteth-too-much gay obsession will not be surprised to learn how he once leapt into another man's bed himself. When the godfearing Patten went up at 10pm, Richard stayed up drinking with Louise and others until, having drained the cellar, the lovable Sun columnist retired in the early hours.

When later he awoke, he zig-zagged off to the loo, and then back to bed - but not, alas, his own. Awoken by the bulbous, utterly naked form nestling up to him and his wife, John yelped in horror and kicked Richard out. Off he staggered again to find a bed which, although again not his (it being a spare room) was at least devoid of cabinet ministers.

When his wife Wendy rose the next morning and went down to breakfast she was baffled to hear discussion of her absentee husband's antics. Could you make it up? Could ya? Any other men who have shared their bed with Richard should call in strictest confidence.

 News, meanwhile, of Richard's host, Simon H. Not content with just the one portrait of himself (done by Gail Lilley, wife of Peter), the Milanese catwalk model commissioned a second from hip New York-based painter Susannah Ffienes to celebrate his 40th birthday. We ring Susannah, an absolute charmer, at her studio and she says she is coming over in March and the painting will take two weeks. Excellent. But is there any additional pressure, we wonder, in painting a subject of extreme physical beauty? "It's nothing to do with beauty," she observes, "It's a very complex thing. The real difficulty is putting across the subtlety of their intelligence. I have to somehow make sense of what I see." Well, best of luck.

 I am intrigued by an outpouring of poison in the News of the World, which reported from Brazil that Reinaldo's family blame Mandy for "corrupting their lad". Why they would say this knowing that he had other boyfriends first is one of several oddities. Another is Stuart White's reference to how sister Claudia "spat in Spanish", rather than Portuguese, a reference to "a British government official" - a weird formulation for a cabinet minister, although it would fit Reinaldo's former lover Hywel James, John Major's one-time adviser. Could the paper, in its innocent excitement, have mis-applied the quotes? Reticent NoW editor Rebekah Wade is unable to call back, so we must investigate further on our own.

 The mystery of the missing fuses at the Times deepens. We now gather that the person removing the fuse from the microwave plug, fed up of the smell of cooking food, was not countryside editor Val Elliot. It may even be that she was deliberately framed. The finger of suspicion now turns to political journalist Andrew Pierce. "It's a man who's often there at night," is the cryptic hint that reaches us. Meanwhile, following Ruth Gledhill's email announcing that the microwave plug had been cut off, a new plug was wired on. At time of writing the machine was working perfectly. Yes, but for how long?

 A fan letter arrives. "I am an elderly (70 next year) journo," begins Michael Grosvenor Myer. "In my day we were trained that the one thing no decent journalist ever did was to try to be funny about someone's name: we'd sooner have used 'nigger' or 'yid' than your persistently unfunny 'Bumley'." Oh dear. Is there any point explaining that Bumley is the correct phonetic version of Bottomley, on the Cholmondely/ Chumley model? Probably not. "Stop it for Christ's sake. It's a disgrace to the paper and to yourself. You should be ashamed." Many thanks for that, and do keep reading. And don't do yourself down, Michael. These days, 70 is no age at all.

webTitle: AOL Time Warner downloads sing for only 30 days

fields.headline: AOL Time Warner downloads sing for only 30 days
fields.standfirst: All the latest internet news is at netnews
fields.trailText: AOL Time Warner yesterday promised to increase revenues by more than 12% to $40bn (£27bn) this year after revealing a loss of $1.09bn in the last quarter.
fields.body:
AOL Time Warner yesterday promised to increase revenues by more than 12% to $40bn (£27bn) this year after revealing a loss of $1.09bn in the last quarter.

Wall Street welcomed the upbeat comments from the company in its first results presentation since the ground-breaking merger of internet group AOL with Time Warner, the media and entertainment company.

Overseas subscribers to its online services also passed the 5m mark for the first time last quarter, putting its total subscriber base at 27m. More than 23,000 people signed up every day during the past three months.

The company also announced it will introduce a web service that will allow downloads of songs by more than a dozen Warner Music artists - such as the Corrs and REM - from the America Online service, as well as its two music properties, Winamp.com and Spinner.com.

The music files would have software embedded in them that would prevent songs from being played after 30 days.

Analysts were pleased that the company reiterated the growth targets set at the time the deal was announced just over a year ago.

Since then, a slowing economy and downturn in the value of internet companies had prompted many to question the value of the merger, the largest in history.

AOL's shares were 3% higher at $56 at midday yesterday, a 69% increase since the start of the year.

A year ago, the company said that revenues would increase to $40bn and earnings before interest, tax and depreciation would reach $11bn in 2001. Michael Kelly, AOL Time Warner's chief financial officer, said yesterday: "The guidance that we made one year ago remains unchanged."

Jessica Reif Cohen, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that the recent job cuts announced at Time Warner combined with an expected price increase at AOL proved that the company was aiming to reach its target in spite of the economic uncertainties.

The combined company's pro forma loss of more than $1bn in the three months to the end of December was struck after a $2bn goodwill charge for the merger.

Earnings before tax, interest and depreciation for the two firms last year were $8.4bn on $36.2bn of revenues.2424

fields.headline: Vocalis baffles investors
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Vocalis, the speech recognition firm that has seen its share price slump by 90% over the past year, yesterday left investors baffled when it issued a profits warning just hours after releasing an upbeat statement about a new business division.
fields.body:
Vocalis, the speech recognition firm that has seen its share price slump by 90% over the past year, yesterday left investors baffled when it issued a profits warning just hours after releasing an upbeat statement about a new business division.

Shares in the group, which changed hands at £10.80p last year, fell a further 32% to 70p last night after the optimistic statement was "retracted" and replaced by a downbeat trading update signalling that a delay to the signing of new business contracts could hit profits.

The first announcement, about the creation of a division called The Talking Network and carrying enthusiastic quotes from both Vocalis' chief executive and chief operating officer, prompted a 6.5p rise in the firm's shares.

The company later retracted it, however, because "it was not authorised by the board", prompting a slump in the share price which the stock exchange might require Vocalis to explain.

A spokesman for the stock exchange declined to say whether it had been in contact with the company but added: "As a matter of policy we investigate all unusual share price movements."

A spokesman for Vocalis said he was unable to explain the sequence of events, while chief executive Charles Halle and the company's stockbroker, Credit Lyonnais, failed to return telephone calls.

Vocalis blamed the possible profits shortfall on its failure to sign contracts worth around £4m and said that unless they were sealed soon it is likely to record a loss for the year to March 31, 2001.

Of the Talking Network it said: "The board are reviewing a number of strategic options to maximise The Talking Network's potential." The earlier statement said it was to become "a separate business entity".

Investors have endured a torrid time over the past year as the price of the shares has slumped from its former high. In August, Vocalis raised £5m by placing 2.2m shares at 230p each. Five months on, the stock is worth less than a third of the price it was sold at.

However, Vocalis yesterday reiterated its confidence in the "marketability of the group's core speech-recognition technology".

Technology experts have for some time had high hopes for speech recognition software, which enables people to telephone call centres, ask a machine a question, such as requesting the price of a share or asking about the weather forecast for a particular area, and hear the response without at any time speaking to a person.

Mobile devices which allow users to search the internet by asking them questions are seen as the big growth area for firms such as Vocalis but so far they have failed to take off.

Analysts believe that it is still a product waiting for a market.

The company later retracted it, however, because "it was not authorised by the board", prompting a slump in the share price which the stock exchange might require Vocalis to explain. A spokesman for the stock exchange declined to say whether it had been in contact with the company but added: "As a matter of policy we investigate all unusual share price movements." A spokesman for Vocalis said he was unable to explain the sequence of events, while chief executive Charles Halle and the company's stockbroker, Credit Lyonnais, failed to return telephone calls. Vocalis blamed the possible profits shortfall on its failure to sign contracts worth around £4m and said that unless they were sealed soon it is likely to record a loss for the year to March 31, 2001. Of the Talking Network it said: "The board are reviewing a number of strategic options to maximise The Talking Network's potential." The earlier statement said it was to become "a separate business entity". Investors have endured a torrid time over the past year as the price of the shares has slumped from its former high. In August, Vocalis raised £5m by placing 2.2m shares at 230p each. Five months on, the stock is worth less than a third of the price it was sold at. However, Vocalis yesterday reiterated its confidence in the "marketability of the group's core speech-recognition technology". Technology experts have for some time had high hopes for speech recognition software, which enables people to telephone call centres, ask a machine a question, such as requesting the price of a share or asking about the weather forecast for a particular area, and hear the response without at any time speaking to a person. Mobile devices which allow users to search the internet by asking them questions are seen as the big growth area for firms such as Vocalis but so far they have failed to take off. Analysts believe that it is still a product waiting for a market.

webTitle: Sega to end production of Dreamcast console

fields.headline: Sega to end production of Dreamcast console
fields.trailText: The battle for control of the video game market claimed its biggest victim yesterday when Sega announced that it will dump its loss-making Dreamcast console in March.
fields.body:
The battle for control of the video game market claimed its biggest victim yesterday when Sega announced that it will dump its loss-making Dreamcast console in March.

The Japanese firm, the world's third-biggest game hardware maker, said it would take an 80bn yen (£471m) hit to close its assembly lines and dispose of 2m unsold consoles.

But Sega said the short-term pain was necessary to shift its focus towards the company's more lucrative software operation.

"Maintaining the balance between our hardware and software enterprises while securing profits has become extremely difficult," the company said. "We will rapidly shift our focus to the content business."

Sega has already begun talks to design and sell games to its former rivals. According to Japanese reports, Sony will acquire four titles including Virtua Fighter 4 for use on its PlayStation 2 console.

By the end of the year, Nintendo is expected to purchase at least three games, including Sonic the Hedgehog, Sega's most famous character, for its Game Boy Advance hand-held console.

Sega is also in negotiations to supply content for two consoles due to reach the market later this year; Microsoft's XBox and Nintendo's GameCube.

The cost of setting the business reset button is expected to result in a record loss of ¥58.3bn for the year ending on March 31. This is despite an injection of ¥85bn from the pocket of Sega president Isao Okawa.

Ignoring the flood of red ink, investors and analysts welcomed the move, saying Sega could return to profitability as early as next year. The company's stock price has jumped 60% since rumours began circulating last week of Dreamcast's demise. Since its debut in late 1999 as the world's first 128-bit, internet compatible game console, the Dreamcast has turned into a nightmare for Sega.

Despite a costly marketing campaign and hefty discounting, sales of the console are well short of the levels needed to cover the costs of developing and producing such sophisticated technology, with total sales a mere 5.9m units.

According to the Daiwa Institute of Research, Sega loses £30 to £60 on every Dreamcast it sells. This pushed the company about ¥40bn into the red last year, its third successive annual loss.

webTitle: Letsbuyit close to deal with Schmitz

fields.headline: Letsbuyit close to deal with Schmitz
fields.standfirst: All the latest internet news is at Net news
fields.trailText: Letsbuyit.com, the struggling online retailer, yesterday formally announced that 200 of its 350 staff are to lose their jobs, but added that it was very near to closing a €40m (£25.5m) funding round which would allow the company to resume trading.
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com, the struggling online retailer, yesterday formally announced that 200 of its 350 staff are to lose their jobs, but added that it was very near to closing a €40m (£25.5m) funding round which would allow the company to resume trading.

John Palmer, Letsbuyit's founder who stepped into the role of chief executive following a management exodus, would not reveal how many of the company's 14 European operations would close, but many offices are thought to have been unstaffed for some time.

Mr Palmer said Letsbuyit, which remains under supervision of Dutch court-appointed trustees following a debt moratorium, had commitments from a number of investors interested in the business, which pools consumer power to cut prices. He refused to say whether any interest had been shown by major institutional investors.

Mr Palmer denied that efforts to raise funds had been made impossible by a damning report from trustees which called management practices at Letsbuyit deplorable. He said news of staffing cuts would help attract investors who might have been put off by the trustees' report of a cash burn rate of €10m a month. "The cuts have been necessary for some time," he said. "We will be saving a huge amount."

The embattled company narrowly avoided bankruptcy earlier this month. Management secured a €4m bank guarantee at the 11th hour, with the help of the German company Kimvestor, which is run by Kim Schmitz, a convicted computer hacker.

An investigation by Industry Standard magazine, published today, suggests that Mr Schmitz has wildly exaggerated claims about his hacking past and raises questions over his ability to provide the €50m.

He has claimed to have hacked into computer systems at Nasa and the Pentagon, and boasted that he managed to reduce the credit rating of former chancellor Helmut Kohl. Many in Germany dispute these claims.
