fields.headline: Spring clean your hard drive
fields.trailText: Start here...
fields.body:
Hard disks are cheap, and by far the best way to increase the disk space on any computer is to add a new drive. With big EIDE drives that plug straight into a PC, the cost is now around £4 per gigabyte. There is a lot to be said for cleaning up the drive already fitted, especially if it is a small one. However, even the most vigorous spring clean is unlikely to save more than £2 worth of disk space.

Still, in the spirit of good housekeeping, it should be possible to clear up a lot of the rubbish that some programs leave around. And with luck, the result should be a cleaner and (very slightly) quicker computer.

The first problem is identifying files that are not needed. In MS-DOS (the Disk Operating System from the original IBM PC) and Microsoft Windows, files are usually identified by a three-letter extension. Thus txt is used for text files, doc for Word documents, exe for executable files (ie programs), jpg and gif for images, avi and mpg for movies, and so on. Microsoft now hides these extensions, so the first task is to open Windows Explorer, go to the View menu, and select Folder Options. Click on the View tab, and select the radio button that says Show all files, and also make sure there is no tick in the box that says Hide file extensions for known file types. Now the extensions are visible.

In this case, we are interested in two other naming conventions: calling "temporary files" tmp, and back-up files bak. Many programs, such as Microsoft Word, use temporary files while they are working, then delete them when the file is finished with. However, if the system crashes, orphan tmp files may be left behind. Some programs also keep back-up copies. You may be glad to find them if you have lost work, but if not, you may have lots of bak files you do not want.

Before you start deleting things, it is important to back-up the files you want to keep, eg by copying them to a CD-R or removable disk or tape. Accidents happen. When you have done that, restart your PC. That way you can be sure that any temporary files are not in use.

To begin the clear out, highlight My Computer in Windows Explorer and press F3. This will pop up the Find dialogue box. Next to Named, type *.tmp and press Return. This will find all the temporary files on your computer. You may think you don't have any, but it is not unusual for this routine to find 50-100, and sometimes many more.

Since you have already backed up the files you want, you can delete all these tmp files. Press Ctrl-A to select them all, and hit the Delete key to send them to the Recycle Bin.

Now you can do the same thing to dispose of unwanted back-up files by searching for *.bak names. However, I suggest that you do not delete the ones in C:\Windows and C:\Windows\System; they don't take up much room anyway.

There are other files that can usually be deleted safely. These include files with the extensions 001, 002 (etc), and any files ending in chk, such as file000.chk, file0001.chk (etc).

If you are not sure whether it is safe to delete a file, don't delete it. Instead, select the file in Windows Explorer, press F2, and rename it by adding .wait to the end of the name. (Thus vital.abc will become vital.abc.wait and so on.) Wait a couple of weeks to see if any programs break or produce error messages saying they are unable to find that file. If they do, you can rename it back to what it was. If not, it is probably safe to delete it.

Another useful convention is that programs should keep their temporary files in a particular directory. The main one is C:\Windows\temp but C:\temp may also be used. It should be safe to delete any files found in these directo ries, but check them carefully first. Bear in mind that some programmers are stupid.

Another directory that may contain unwanted files is C:\Windows\Spool, where Windows stores files sent for printing. Unless you have something waiting to be printed, this folder should be empty.

Finally, run a Microsoft utility called Disk Cleanup, which is found in Start| Programs|Accessories| System Tools. This lets you choose to delete files from Temp directories, the Temporary Internet Files folder and the Recycle Bin.

This completes the first stage in cleaning up a hard drive. However, if you use the mouse to right-click the Temporary Internet Files folder, you may be surprised to find that it still contains numerous files. Even if it appears to be empty, Windows 98 and Me may reveal that it is still using a lot of disk space - sometimes more than 100 megabytes. I will explain how to delete these files next time.
fields.bodyText: Hard disks are cheap, and by far the best way to increase the disk space on any computer is to add a new drive. With big EIDE drives that plug straight into a PC, the cost is now around £4 per gigabyte. There is a lot to be said for cleaning up the drive already fitted, especially if it is a small one. However, even the most vigorous spring clean is unlikely to save more than £2 worth of disk space. Still, in the spirit of good housekeeping, it should be possible to clear up a lot of the rubbish that some programs leave around. And with luck, the result should be a cleaner and (very slightly) quicker computer. The first problem is identifying files that are not needed. In MS-DOS (the Disk Operating System from the original IBM PC) and Microsoft Windows, files are usually identified by a three-letter extension. Thus txt is used for text files, doc for Word documents, exe for executable files (ie programs), jpg and gif for images, avi and mpg for movies, and so on. Microsoft now hides these extensions, so the first task is to open Windows Explorer, go to the View menu, and select Folder Options. Click on the View tab, and select the radio button that says Show all files, and also make sure there is no tick in the box that says Hide file extensions for known file types. Now the extensions are visible. In this case, we are interested in two other naming conventions: calling "temporary files" tmp, and back-up files bak. Many programs, such as Microsoft Word, use temporary files while they are working, then delete them when the file is finished with. However, if the system crashes, orphan tmp files may be left behind. Some programs also keep back-up copies. You may be glad to find them if you have lost work, but if not, you may have lots of bak files you do not want. Before you start deleting things, it is important to back-up the files you want to keep, eg by copying them to a CD-R or removable disk or tape. Accidents happen. When you have done that, restart your PC. That way you can be sure that any temporary files are not in use. To begin the clear out, highlight My Computer in Windows Explorer and press F3. This will pop up the Find dialogue box. Next to Named, type *.tmp and press Return. This will find all the temporary files on your computer. You may think you don't have any, but it is not unusual for this routine to find 50-100, and sometimes many more. Since you have already backed up the files you want, you can delete all these tmp files. Press Ctrl-A to select them all, and hit the Delete key to send them to the Recycle Bin. Now you can do the same thing to dispose of unwanted back-up files by searching for *.bak names. However, I suggest that you do not delete the ones in C:\Windows and C:\Windows\System; they don't take up much room anyway. There are other files that can usually be deleted safely. These include files with the extensions 001, 002 (etc), and any files ending in chk, such as file000.chk, file0001.chk (etc). If you are not sure whether it is safe to delete a file, don't delete it. Instead, select the file in Windows Explorer, press F2, and rename it by adding .wait to the end of the name. (Thus vital.abc will become vital.abc.wait and so on.) Wait a couple of weeks to see if any programs break or produce error messages saying they are unable to find that file. If they do, you can rename it back to what it was. If not, it is probably safe to delete it. Another useful convention is that programs should keep their temporary files in a particular directory. The main one is C:\Windows\temp but C:\temp may also be used. It should be safe to delete any files found in these directo ries, but check them carefully first. Bear in mind that some programmers are stupid. Another directory that may contain unwanted files is C:\Windows\Spool, where Windows stores files sent for printing. Unless you have something waiting to be printed, this folder should be empty. Finally, run a Microsoft utility called Disk Cleanup, which is found in Start| Programs|Accessories| System Tools. This lets you choose to delete files from Temp directories, the Temporary Internet Files folder and the Recycle Bin. This completes the first stage in cleaning up a hard drive. However, if you use the mouse to right-click the Temporary Internet Files folder, you may be surprised to find that it still contains numerous files. Even if it appears to be empty, Windows 98 and Me may reveal that it is still using a lot of disk space - sometimes more than 100 megabytes. I will explain how to delete these files next time.

fields.headline: Pace softens Sega blow
fields.standfirst: Sonic fans will get a kick out of a set-top box, says  Chris Price
fields.trailText: Sonic fans will get a kick out of a set-top box, says Chris Price
fields.body:
As troubled games maker Sega prepares to announce its official withdrawal from the unprofitable games console market, Pace hopes to soften the blow to die-hard Sonic fans with the launch of the world's first digital set-top box with integrated Sega games console.

Set to hit the streets later this year, the new generation set-top box will combine conventional digital TV services with full Sega Dreamcast functionality. The only difference is that the innovative Pace unit will download games directly on to its integrated 40GB hard drive and will not incorporate a CD-rom drive for loading games from disc. However, the original Dreamcast handset will be provided for full interactive gaming.

Up to 60 games can be held on the set-top box's hard drive but additional games could be downloaded either via a conventional integrated dial-up modem or a broadband ADSL/digital cable connection in minutes. Any Sega Dreamcast game could be played on the set-top box but, unlike today's console-based market, the line-up will depend on the broadcaster. Demonstrated in New York this week was a prototype box with Sonic 2, Crazy Taxi and Ferrari 355 games stored on its hard drive.

Pace is in talks with broadcasters in the US and Europe and hopes to roll-out Sega Dreamcast-equipped boxes later this year. UK satellite broadcaster SkyDigital and cable giant Comcast in the US have announced plans to introduce Pace-manufactured advanced personal video recorders with built-in hard drives, although neither has committed to online gaming.

When gaming services are launched later in the year it is expected that digital TV viewers will be able to access them on pay-per-play basis, like the pay-per-view arrangement for watching Hollywood movies on SkyDigital or ONdigital. It may be possible to buy a "season ticket" to play certain games for a longer period or buy them outright. Importantly, users will be able to choose games "on demand" from the set-top box's hard drive using the integrated electronic programme guide in much the same way as watching a digital TV programme.

According to Pace's marketing director, Andrew Wallace, the Sega gaming set-top box will have wider appeal to users than today's games consoles. "It will attract a new market of casual gamers who typically spend less on gam ing than today's enthusiasts." However, he admits that saving money is a prime motive behind companies such as Sega switching to direct distribution via the TV set.

"Online gaming also benefits games companies because it is a cheaper means of games distribution than selling the discs." Sega already offers online gaming for PC owners via its Sega.net website.

But Pace insists the move isn't just about cost-cutting and will benefit enthusiasts. These include multi-player gaming between set-top box owners and the integration of TV broadcasts with interactive gaming. "Imagine if you could show motor racing on TV, then invite viewers to play the game on their TV set for £3 a time. You could offer prizes to gamers who achieve the best times," says Wallace.

Also under development is a new generation gaming set-top box that will incorporate full home networking functionality. Using conventional digital electronic cordless technology (DECT) from home telephones, games will not be confined solely to the TV set but will be distributed wirelessly to any peripheral device in the home such as a web pad or personal digital assistant.

The Sega set-top box represents the latest move by the games maker to shift its business from the unprofitable hardware market. The company also announced that it intends to develop games for other platforms, including rival Sony and Nintendoconsoles and GSM and third-generation mobile phones. Later this year Sega plans to licence its Dreamcast architecture to set-top box manufacturers across the world.

For Pace the official announcement of a non-exclusive partnership with Sega is welcome. Last week a UK cable operator, Telewest, announced it is to end its exclusive two-year set-top box contract with the Shipley-based firm in March and look for an additional set-top box supplier. Developed over a 12-month period, the Pace-branded Sega set-top box is the result of collaboration with two UK companies: Imagination Technologies and the Sega-owned Cross Products Limited.

fields.headline: Chalking up hits on cue
fields.standfirst:
Snooker is a big success on the internet. Julie Welch reports
More net news
fields.trailText: Snooker is a big success on the internet. Julie Welch reports
fields.body:
Here's a question for sports trivia buffs. Who was the first snooker player to clinch a maximum 147 break live on the net? Answer: Marco Fu, Regal Scottish Masters, October 25, 2000. That month, thanks to its pathfinding showing of BBC Scotland's pictures supported by their own studio coverage, www.tsnsnooker.com recorded a huge number of visits from around the world, from Taiwan to Tonga.

For some, the prospect of watching live non-stop snooker is roughly equivalent to having to listen to a loop tape of the speeches of Sir Geoffrey Howe.

On the other hand, there's no denying the potential compulsiveness of being able to check in every 10 minutes at the office for the latest score in a thrilling quarter final between Ronnie O'Sullivan and John Higgins.

TSN stands for The Sportsmaster's Network; it's based in East Kilbride and the 5-man board includes Ian Doyle, manager of world champions Stephen Hendry, Mark Williams and Ronnie O'Sullivan. As soon as the site came online last April it received 600,000 hits, not only from traditional snooker-watching countries such as China, Australia, Canada, Thailand and Holland, but from newer customer bases in the Middle East, the Balkans and South America.

"We're now averaging just over a million hits a week which is not bad at all given that we're not advertising," says managing director Gerry Sinclair.

What seems obvious is that TSN will drive online betting. "We're not a gaming or betting company per se," says Sin clair, "but companies that are think this is a highly lucrative market. It encourages people to bet who wouldn't necessarily go into betting shops." Sinclair cites older people and women as a new market, and it is certainly an appealing vision - the little old ladies who currently make up a large portion of snooker's TV audience using the net for a flutter.

Sinclair reckons that snooker has an advantage over faster-moving sports such as football or rugby. "The beauty of it is that you hit a ball, it rolls and stops, and the player thinks about his next shot, giving the technology the chance to catch up. In 12-18 months, bandwidth will have improved and the faster-moving sports will get a look in, but in the meantime darts, bowls and golf all lend themselves to this coverage."

The site is exciting, colourful and fast - more Jimmy 'Whirlwind' White than Steve 'Interesting' Davis. As well as live pictures when available, it offers strong news and feature content, up-to-date results and scoring, online magazine On-Q, chat rooms to post questions to players, and analysis from players and pundits.

Currently, the webcam is backstage at the Nations Cup, showing players chatting, a bit like Big Brother with waistcoats and bow ties.

Belated competition is provided by www.worldsnooker.com - the governing body's own site. It is well done, if more formal than its rival, and might suffer from its late arrival. Fans should also check out www.snookerscene.com, the online version of Snooker Scene, the sport's paper of record.

"Ours is more of a news operation," says Sinclair. "When radio first started in the US, all these little independent radio stations were set up, and we see ourselves like that, a small broadcasting station for snooker, and your first port of call. And the beauty of the internet is that you can do the stuff more cheaply than anywhere else."

webTitle: Sketch: PM tries to take the Mickey

fields.headline: PM tries to take the Mickey
fields.trailText: Only 10 prime minister's question times before the election! It's getting more tense and edgy than ever.
fields.body:
Only 10 prime minister's question times before the election! It's getting more tense and edgy than ever.

My colleagues and I - ever anxious to snuffle out the truffles of trivia rather than the boiled potatoes of serious issues - sometimes rank Hague versus Blair like judges at a boxing match. Yesterday two of us gave it to Hague, three reckoned a draw.

The prize, of course, is not a giant belt dripping with what look like horse brasses, but a 10 second slot on the early evening news - and a monster boost in morale for the backbenchers.

Mr Hague opened with an inconclusive argument about asylum seekers. He says there are more than ever; Tony Blair claims the processing is now catching up with the caseload. As usual they are both right, and also both wrong.

In the end, Mr Hague declared victory by saying: "It's a good job he doesn't give answers like that to his press secretary, or he'd get the sack himself."

Tories cheered merrily. Forget Lockerbie, forget Alder Hey, and kiss goodbye to asylum seekers. There's one topic on their minds, and it's Mandelson.

Minutes later Mr Hague was back to twist that knife. Had the No 10 press secretary, Alastair Campbell, been speaking with prime ministerial authority when he gave his briefing against Peter Mandelson last Friday?

A tricky one. Once again Mr Blair was caught in a grisly Sophie's choice, having to choose between his two boys, Ally and Pete. (Pete has been sent to his room for being horrible to Ally, but we assume forgiveness will follow because it always has.)

With an almost audible shudder, the paterfamilias replied that Ally always spoke for him, but you shouldn't believe what you read in the press. This is a favourite formulation for politicians; given half a chance they would use it about the football results.

The Tory leader smelled weakness. When Alastair Campbell had said that Mandy was "detached", "lacked focus" and was in the same mental state as Ron Davies had been on Clapham Common, was this meant to be complimentary?

The prime minister then produced what I think is the feeblest reply I've ever heard him make. "He also paid tribute to the former Northern Ireland secretary," he said limply. (I was reminded of a colleague of mine who refused to give a job to someone else, "because he is a lazy, lying, incompetent, two-faced little bastard. And I speak as a friend of his".)

Mr Campbell, who had been sitting in the press gallery glowering at the carpet, permitted himself a wintry smile.

Next Mr Hague got himself dangerously steamed up. The government was locked in civil war. The cabinet was "dining out on crocodile tears and champagne". He then read out the usual charge sheet (cronyism, spin not substance, etc) each followed by the one word, "Guilty!"

It almost worked, but not quite.

The prime minister tried a joke. What had really offended the Tories, he said, was that Mr Campbell had compared their economic policies to that of Mickey Mouse. (Why? Mickey Mouse has a nice home and clearly saves prudently. "The Mouse" is slang for the Disney corporation, one of the world's most successful companies.)

"He [Mr Campbell] has been reprimanded very strongly. We are a fan of Mickey Mouse!" (Echoes of Margaret Thatcher's notorious "we are a grandmother" - from the banal to the ridiculous.)

What made this feeble mock barb against the press secretary so wince-worthy is that the press secretary probably wrote it himself.

At that point this judge decided that if Hague hadn't won it, Mr Blair had almost certainly lost it.

webTitle: G2: Pret a Manger goes global

fields.headline: Mine's a McLatte
fields.standfirst:
They started with a £17,000 loan and a name borrowed from a boarded-up shop. Now the college friends who founded Pret a Manger have global ambitions - and £25 million from Ronald McDonald. Andrew Clark reports on a sandwich success story, while our restaurant critic Matthew Fort pops in for lunch

Special report: globalisation
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: They started with a £17,000 loan and a name borrowed from a boarded-up shop. Now the college friends who founded Pret a Manger have global ambitions - and £25 million from Ronald McDonald. Andrew Clark reports on a sandwich success story, while our restaurant critic Matthew Fort pops in for lunch.
fields.body:
Fabric, the trendy nightclub opposite Smithfield Market in London, was packed as usual on Tuesday evening. But this was a night with a difference - the club, which boasts celebrity members such as Kate Moss and Mel C, was full of Pret a Manger managers.

The sandwich chain's 400 supervisors had been invited to listen to a speech by its founders, Sinclair Beecham and Julian Metcalfe, both fresh from banking multi-million pound cheques. The company, which makes much of being "passionate about people", wanted its staff to be the first to know about a new investor - McDonald's had snapped up a 33% stake.

For a firm which prides itself on its "heart and soul" and constantly stresses its fresh, healthy food, the arrival of the golden arches marked a very rapid change in culture. Pret a Manger took its name from a shop in Hampstead - the genteel suburb which battled for years to keep out McDonald's.

The sandwich chain has made its name as an environmentally friendly trader, banning genetically modified foods and sourcing chickens from humane cages in Seville. For many staff, the idea of a link with McDonald's, which has been demonised by the green lobby, was horrifying.

It also spelt the end of the brilliantly constructed illusion through which Pret seemed to offer a taste of sophistication for little more than the cost of a greasy spoon bacon sarnie. In its early days, the chain's brushed steel stools, magenta labels and immaculate chrome bars seemed the ultimate in industrial chic. Its French name and comparatively adventurous menu all helped create an aura of exclusivity - instead of ham and tomato sandwiches, Pret offered Brie, tomato and basil baguettes.

The origins of Pret's classy three-quid lunches lie in the mid-1980s, when its two creators met at the Polytechnic of Central London (now the University of Westminster), where they were studying property law.

Nine months after graduating, Metcalfe was working as a surveyor in Jermyn Street, getting increasingly fed up with "soggy sandwiches and mush" for lunch, often served with a snarl, from local sandwich shops. Deciding he could do better, he got together with Beecham to open the first Pret a Manger in Victoria, with a kitchen in the basement.

Things got off to a slow start. Metcalfe recalls: "It was a lot harder than it looked."

Although they began with a loan of just £17,000, the pair resolved to offer only high quality, fresh food: "Half the battle was getting preservative-free, chemical-free food. And it was an immense logistical challenge to get the ingredients delivered every morning."

Initially, the pair shopped themselves at local markets. Metcalfe used to go in on Sunday evenings to cook 25 chickens, ready to stuff sandwiches the next morning. For inspiration, they recalled the first meal they had shared - "warmed-over pork and vegetables" at a college canteen called the Blue Lagoon - with its blue walls and carpet tiles, the antithesis of what they wanted Pret to be.

It was three years before a second Pret opened and at that point, the concept took off. Healthy eating had become a fad in the early 90s and hurried commuters liked the idea of fresh food, prepared daily on the premises, which they could pick up off the shelf.

Jim Winship, a director of the British Sandwich Association, says: "Pret was in the right place, at the right time. There was a revolution going on in sandwiches - packaged sandwiches were finally taking off in a big way, mostly thanks to Marks & Spencer."

Pret has always been clear about who its customers are - at £1.20 for a tiny bottle of orange juice, it is targetting urban professionals with little time on their hands. The chain now has just over 100 shops in Britain, and one in New York. Last year it sold 25m sandwiches, baguettes and wraps and just over 14m cups of coffee. Pret sandwiches are still made on the premises, at every store. Shops receive fresh deliveries in the evenings, which are refrigerated every night until cooks arrive at 6.30am to prepare the day's sandwiches.

While Beecham holds the purse-strings, Metcalfe looks after the food - he spends Thursday afternoon with a recipe committee, sampling different ideas. He goes for exotic mixtures, once remarking: "The English respond to strong tastes - look at curry." Recent additions include Scotch beef with crispy onions, "More than mozzarella" sandwiches and Peking duck wraps.

Metcalfe admits he has little patience for the money side of the business - he jokes that he suffers from ADHT, the hyperactivity disorder diagnosed among American children, and colleagues say he has a tendency to hang up during important conversations if he finds them boring.

By 1998, the chain had 65 shops and the pair needed help - they were arguing, and struggling to control their rapidly growing empire. They recruited a former Pepsi executive, Andrew Rolfe, as chief executive. That freed Beecham, the more businesslike partner, to explore overseas expansion. For the past 18 months, he has been in New York, managing the firm's embryonic US operation.

It is this transatlantic venture which has led to McDonald's involvement - the two men realised that if they wanted to take their concept to another country, they needed heavyweight backing. Metcalfe says: "As a private company it's very difficult to set up abroad. We didn't know where to begin in New York - we ended up having all the equipment for the shop made here and shipped over."

There were cultural problems - the company claimed it had great difficulty finding New Yorkers to work in the shop who were prepared to offer Pret's required level of friendliness. British staff had to be sent out to run the new outlet. Critics sniped that it would never take off, because Americans liked bespoke sandwiches prepared before their eyes. Against the odds, the shop, located just off Wall Street, does seem to be working.

Another seven are planned in Manhattan this year. McDonald's will help, by providing contacts, a food distribution network and expertise in finding sites. "Pret creates handmade, natural food, avoiding the obscure chemicals, additives and preservatives common to so much 'prepared' and 'fast' food on the market today," declares the rubric plastered all over Pret a Manger outlets, packaging, bags and walls. What could such an ethically righteous organisation have in common with McDonald's? Well, perhaps more than you might think.

Perhaps Pret a Manger customers represent the McDonald's customer 10 years down the line, grown health conscious and gastronomically sophisticated and a slave to the desk. The naff colours, melamine and spotty youths serving up the burgers, buns and bags have given way to the shiny metallic surfaces, high,small, round tables with bar stools and spotty youths serving up the lattes, cappuccinos and, oh yes, the bags made of the same recycled paper against a background blur of discreet funk.

Of course the basic food products are widely, if not wildly, different. In place of the queue 'n' serve Big Mac, Chicken McNuggets, beanburger and milk shakes, Pret a Manger brings us the self-service 'n' queue BLT, chicken jalfrezi wrap, sushi and a blackberry, pear, banana and orange drink for the fanatically figure conscious.

I was not in a particularly figure-conscious mood when I stormed into the Pret a Manger in Bristol, (complete with bespectacled man reading the Guardian at a table in the window), and slunk out with a vegetarian sushi, a chicken club sandwich, a tuna Niçoise wrap, a chocolate passion pot and a double-strength latte by way of quality control, and discovered that Pret a Manger had more in common with McDonald's than I had thought possible.

Vegetarian sushi is a bizarre concept. Vegetables have neither the neutrality nor the texture of raw fish. Their cause was not aided by dry and solid rice wrapped up in double strength nori with the chewability of damp cardboard. Whoever had handmade these sushi had also gone rather light on the wasabi and the slices of pickled ginger were withered.

The tuna Niçoise wrap was another grazing compound, owing more to fashion than good taste. It tasted like fish paste wrapped in chamois leather, with a bit of floppy Webb's wonder lettuce, tomato, raw french beans and slices of hard-boiled egg. Any connection with a real salad Niçoise was entirely notional.

The chicken club sandwich was rather good; a wholesome (well, the bread was granary), properly balanced meal in a mouthful. True, most of the flavour came by way of the excellent mayonnaise, but at least there was flavour.

For pudding I had the chocolate pot, for which I have nothing but praise, almost. It is quite solid and very smooth, with the consistency of ready mixed Polyfilla. The quality and intensity of the chocolate is carefully judged to give some measure of pleasure to the chocolate connoisseur without frightening off the Dairy Milk devotee.

The latte was not a success. Bitterness should not be confused with strength; that's what you get from over-roasting substandard arabica beans.

Still, for just over a tenner, you can't really complain. Can you?

fields.headline: Letter: Michael Williams
fields.trailText: James Stevens writes: The actor Michael Williams (Obituary, January 13) had a delightful singing voice. He had a supporting role in the very first production, many years ago, of my musical Mam'zelle Nitouche at the Nottingham Playhouse.
fields.body:
James Stevens writes: The actor Michael Williams (Obituary, January 13) had a delightful singing voice. He had a supporting role in the very first production, many years ago, of my musical Mam'zelle Nitouche - a comedy centered on the double lives of novices at a French convent - at the Nottingham Playhouse. He stood out immediately as a very special actor with an indefinable sparkle. But above all, as the composer, the thing that struck me immediately was his singing voice, a wonderfully melodious, free-flowing, thankfully untrained voice. Therefore, as a last minute inspiraton, I wrote an a cappella male chorus with Michael as soloist. It always went down a treat, es pecially as it had a couple of laughs in it.

A short while after the show closed, I was able to insinuate him into a human interest TV series using his unaccompanied voice as theme music. It was in the early days of commercial television - it had certainly never been done before, and I doubt if it has been since. It took some persuading, but as soon as the producer heard Michael sing he fell for it enthusiastically.

Mam'zelle Nitouche is to be revived this year in the West End under its new title of Meanwhile Back At The Convent. What a pity neither he, nor its writer, Donald Cotton, who died last year,

webTitle: Two years to save Iceland, chief admits

fields.headline: Two years to save Iceland, chief admits
fields.standfirst: After 30 years, founder bows out amid financial shambles
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Iceland yesterday delivered its second profits warning in a week and announced two boardroom resignations.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Iceland yesterday delivered its second profits warning in a week and announced two boardroom resignations.

New chief executive Bill Grimsey, who joined the company five weeks ago, admitted he was "surprised and shocked" by what he had found at the company and laid some of the blame for its predicament on his predecessor, Stuart Rose, who quit to join fashion group Arcadia last November.

Iceland confirmed that chairman Malcolm Walker, who founded the group 30 years ago, is to retire. His departure comes in the wake of a £13.5m share sale just before Christmas. He unloaded 4m shares - most of his stake. At 339p he sold short of the group's five-year high, but since the sales figures were released the shares have tumbled. Yesterday they lost an other 38.5p at 149p - their lowest level for three years.

Mr Grimsey launched an attack on the company's lack of internal controls - describing them as "not of a standard that I would have in my business", and said it would take two years to undo the damage done to the company in the past six months since it merged with cash and carry group Booker and committed itself to organic produce.

Mr Rose hit back at the criticism, maintaining that his systems "gave an accurate picture of trading and profitability" when he left the company. He said the management received daily sales figures and there was "no suggestion" targets would be missed.

Mr Grimsey was speaking as he revealed the conclusions of a review of the business and warned investors that profits would be "significantly below expectations and not likely to exceed £62m".

Until last week analysts had expected the group to make £135m this year. The bottom line will be much lower because the group is taking a £34m one-off hit to cover unexpected costs.

Mr Walker maintains he did not know Iceland was falling so far short of targets when he sold his shares, and the sale was ratified by the board. It is being investigated by the financial services authority.

At the time of the Booker merger, Booker's chief executive, Mr Rose, was installed as chief executive of Iceland and the merged group promised £20m of savings in the first year, with ultimate savings of up to £50m.

Yesterday Mr Grimsey said Iceland would only achieve "merger synergies" of £8m this year and he was going back to square one to put the two companies together.

He remained "fully behind the strategic rationale of the merger" but laid some of the blame for the shambles on Mr Rose. Mr Grimsey had "initiated a complete review of internal controls".

Former finance director Andrew Pritchard, who was responsible for internal controls, has resigned. He is expected to claim compensation.

fields.headline: Ofwat approves Welsh Water sale
fields.trailText: Philip Fletcher, the water industry regulator, yesterday approved an innovative form of ownership for Welsh Water but warned English companies not to rush to adopt a similar structure.
fields.body:
Philip Fletcher, the water industry regulator, yesterday approved an innovative form of ownership for Welsh Water but warned English companies not to rush to adopt a similar structure.

The plan given conditional approval by Mr Fletcher is for Western Power Distribution to sell its Welsh Water subsidiary to Glas Cymru, a non-profit company run on behalf of customers, for £1.8bn.

If the deal is completed, it will be the first privatised water company to switch from equity financing to bond financing. Its critics claim that the new arrangement will leave management with little incentive to improve efficiency.

Mr Fletcher, director general of Ofwat, said he would continue to use comparative pricing to set new price limits for Welsh Water.

The regulator's approval is dependent upon conditions including Glas announcing reductions in customers' bills.

Mr Fletcher has told managing directors of all the English water companies not to follow the Welsh example before the model had been tested.

But he denied that the Welsh Water proposal was an experiment. He said that the project had a number of unique features - WPD wanted to get out of the water business, Glas was buying the assets at a discounted price and the proposal had the backing of the Welsh assembly.

fields.headline: Day 89: an offer with little substance
fields.standfirst: Lloyds banks on escape clauses
fields.trailText: For a moment yesterday morning it seemed that our glorious takeover panel had finally wheezed into action, telling Lloyds TSB bank that it is unfair to leave an open-ended threat of hostile takeover hanging over its smaller, weaker rival Abbey National, and instructing the undeclared predator to put up or shut up.
fields.body:
For a moment yesterday morning it seemed that our glorious takeover panel had finally wheezed into action, telling Lloyds TSB bank that it is unfair to leave an open-ended threat of hostile takeover hanging over its smaller, weaker rival Abbey National, and instructing the undeclared predator to put up or shut up.

But it appears that the panel is still out to lunch on this particular three-pronged £20bn phoney bid, now on day 89.

Instead of an unfettered offer from Lloyds for Abbey, which shareholders could compare with Abbey's own plans to merge with Bank of Scotland (on which we still lack any real detail) within the confines of the traditional City takeover timetable, we have another piece of ultra-cunning from the Lloyds corporate finance team: an offer document that looks and feels like a real offer document, but which carries enough pre-conditions to ensure it is actually nothing more than a marketing pitch. It also includes Lloyds' profits for 2000, released early, under the unusual banner of "business as unusual operating profit".

Chief executive Peter Ellwood and his team will now spend February formally selling their case for a takeover to Abbey's major shareholders, while at the same time retaining the right to bin the whole idea if the proposal is either packed off to the competition commission or (don't laugh) if the Abbey board fail to recommend the terms. Recommendation from Abbey would seem a tad unlikely in the short term, especially when Lloyds is proposing to "co-locate" 600 of Abbey's 722-strong branch network.

It is a strange phrase, "co-locate". Lloyds disputes the suggestion but for customers and for the staff working in these 600 branches, and the 300 others which will go as the Lloyds integration with TSB grinds on, the phrase will simply mean "shut".

On ice

If it weren't so serious, the Iceland saga could be amusing. Yesterday we had the unedifying spectacle of "friends" of the men who have overseen the shocking business of the food group's fall from grace fighting like ferrets in a sack.

"It was Stuart Rose's fault," say those close to the new Iceland boss, Bill Grimsey. "He just didn't do the job. Barely showed up on the premises, etc, etc."

"Complete nonsense," says the Rose faction. "Everything was in order when our man quit."

But it is a serious business. First there is the substantial matter of Malcolm Walker's £13.5m share sale. Did he know that Iceland's sales were collapsing and that the share price would surely follow suit? Groups like Iceland have daily sales updates, and it must have been apparent that they were falling way short of expectations.

Then there is the matter of the lack of progress in integrating the Booker Cash & Carry business.

Mr Walker maintains that he was getting ready to step down, that problems weren't apparent and that the board ratified the deal. But he held an analysts' meeting just before he sold his shares, and even a chairman preparing to step down should surely have checked the figures and the progress of the merger before meeting the City's finest? But there was no hint then of the problems just around the corner.

And the old Iceland guard cannot lay the blame for that on Mr Rose, who was out of the door six weeks earlier.

The FSA is now investigating, and if that is the case, it is a dreadful indictment of the way Iceland was being run.

Then, of course, there is Mr Rose, so highly regarded in the City that Arcadia's shares have tripled from 45p since the day he was appointed purely on his potential.

Yesterday, as doubts suddenly emerged about his golden touch, Arcadia's shares also recoiled.

Finally, there is Mr Grimsey.

He did a kitchen sink job at Iceland yesterday, lumping in a shedload of provisions, bad news and dire warnings to reduce expectations and create a low base from which to make progress.

Analysts like Mr Grimsey. They saw what he did at Wickes and he is now regarded as one of retailing's elite.

The shares are probably now a buy.

E-tail saga

The Letsbuyit.com saga goes from bad to worse. Yesterday's job cuts were a last ditch effort to inject some life into the e-tailer and stop it haemorrhaging cash.

We have all been entertained by the size and colour of Letsbuyit's would-be saviour, German hacker Kim Schmitz and his Kimble organisation. But shareholders and many of those losing their jobs still do not understand quite why the firm has imploded so spectacularly.

Anyone with the inside story should feel free to contact us through city@theguardian.com.
fields.bodyText: For a moment yesterday morning it seemed that our glorious takeover panel had finally wheezed into action, telling Lloyds TSB bank that it is unfair to leave an open-ended threat of hostile takeover hanging over its smaller, weaker rival Abbey National, and instructing the undeclared predator to put up or shut up. But it appears that the panel is still out to lunch on this particular three-pronged £20bn phoney bid, now on day 89. Instead of an unfettered offer from Lloyds for Abbey, which shareholders could compare with Abbey's own plans to merge with Bank of Scotland (on which we still lack any real detail) within the confines of the traditional City takeover timetable, we have another piece of ultra-cunning from the Lloyds corporate finance team: an offer document that looks and feels like a real offer document, but which carries enough pre-conditions to ensure it is actually nothing more than a marketing pitch. It also includes Lloyds' profits for 2000, released early, under the unusual banner of "business as unusual operating profit". Chief executive Peter Ellwood and his team will now spend February formally selling their case for a takeover to Abbey's major shareholders, while at the same time retaining the right to bin the whole idea if the proposal is either packed off to the competition commission or (don't laugh) if the Abbey board fail to recommend the terms. Recommendation from Abbey would seem a tad unlikely in the short term, especially when Lloyds is proposing to "co-locate" 600 of Abbey's 722-strong branch network. It is a strange phrase, "co-locate". Lloyds disputes the suggestion but for customers and for the staff working in these 600 branches, and the 300 others which will go as the Lloyds integration with TSB grinds on, the phrase will simply mean "shut". On ice If it weren't so serious, the Iceland saga could be amusing. Yesterday we had the unedifying spectacle of "friends" of the men who have overseen the shocking business of the food group's fall from grace fighting like ferrets in a sack. "It was Stuart Rose's fault," say those close to the new Iceland boss, Bill Grimsey. "He just didn't do the job. Barely showed up on the premises, etc, etc." "Complete nonsense," says the Rose faction. "Everything was in order when our man quit." But it is a serious business. First there is the substantial matter of Malcolm Walker's £13.5m share sale. Did he know that Iceland's sales were collapsing and that the share price would surely follow suit? Groups like Iceland have daily sales updates, and it must have been apparent that they were falling way short of expectations. Then there is the matter of the lack of progress in integrating the Booker Cash & Carry business. Mr Walker maintains that he was getting ready to step down, that problems weren't apparent and that the board ratified the deal. But he held an analysts' meeting just before he sold his shares, and even a chairman preparing to step down should surely have checked the figures and the progress of the merger before meeting the City's finest? But there was no hint then of the problems just around the corner. And the old Iceland guard cannot lay the blame for that on Mr Rose, who was out of the door six weeks earlier. The FSA is now investigating, and if that is the case, it is a dreadful indictment of the way Iceland was being run. Then, of course, there is Mr Rose, so highly regarded in the City that Arcadia's shares have tripled from 45p since the day he was appointed purely on his potential. Yesterday, as doubts suddenly emerged about his golden touch, Arcadia's shares also recoiled. Finally, there is Mr Grimsey. He did a kitchen sink job at Iceland yesterday, lumping in a shedload of provisions, bad news and dire warnings to reduce expectations and create a low base from which to make progress. Analysts like Mr Grimsey. They saw what he did at Wickes and he is now regarded as one of retailing's elite. The shares are probably now a buy. webTitle: President wins battle for attorney general

fields.headline: President wins battle for attorney general
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The American Senate is set to approve the nomination of John Ashcroft as the new attorney general today, marking a significant early victory for President Bush and for Christian conservatives who backed Mr Ashcroft's strong anti-abortion views.
fields.body:
The American Senate is set to approve the nomination of John Ashcroft as the new attorney general today, marking a significant early victory for President Bush and for Christian conservatives who backed Mr Ashcroft's strong anti-abortion views.

Mr Ashcroft's success was assured after a Senate vetting panel voted by 10-8 to allow his confirmation to go before the whole chamber.

A single Democrat, Russell Feingold, joined the nine Republicans on the Senate judiciary committee to cast the deciding vote, saying that his reluctant support for the nomination was "an olive branch" to the new administration, not "a white flag".

After the committee vote, Mr Ashcroft's fiercest congressional critic, Senator Edward Kennedy, withdrew his threat to stage a filibuster against the nomination. The Republicans would have had to muster 60 votes in the evenly divided 100-seat Senate to counter the delaying tactic, but needed only 51 votes to approve the nomination, in a ballot which could come as early as today.

Despite claims that Mr Ashcroft's record proved he was too partisan to be a credible attorney general, all 50 Republican senators were expected to back the nomination along with a handful of Democrats.

Democratic leaders were still hoping that as many as 40 senators would vote against Mr Ashcroft to issue a warning that his actions would be subjected to close scrutiny.

Mr Ashcroft was the only Bush nominee to face serious opposition in the Senate. The other controversial appointment, of Gale Norton as interior secretary, sailed through on Tuesday with a 75-24 vote, despite claims she had failed to control pollution in her home state of Colorado.

As a senator and former attorney general in Missouri, Mr Ashcroft had sponsored legislation which would have outlawed abortion even in cases of rape or incest. His opponents claimed his record casts doubt on whether he would enforce federal laws guaranteeing the right to abortion.

Senator Herb Kohl, a Democrat, said that he believed Mr Ashcroft "will push and prod the law to conform to his own strongly held beliefs. Because I believe his views are far out of the mainstream of American life, my vote will be no".

webTitle: Lloyds: Walker goes home to roost

fields.headline: Walker goes home to roost with his chickens as butcher's boy moves in
fields.trailText: Bill Grimsey, the man now in the hot seat at Iceland, could not be more different to his predecessors - but he is a man with a record of success in handling serious corporate problems.
fields.body:
Bill Grimsey, the man now in the hot seat at Iceland, could not be more different to his predecessors - but he is a man with a record of success in handling serious corporate problems.

First there was Malcolm Walker - the Mr Green of corporate Britain and founder of the Iceland group. A Greenpeace-supporting Margaret Thatcher fan, he tried to make Iceland a one-stop organic shop. But now he has been forced to spend more time with the chickens he keeps in his back garden, amid mounting controversy about timing of a £13.5m share sale just before Christmas.

Then there was Stuart Rose - a debonair fashion retailer much loved by City analysts. He paused at Iceland only briefly after merging his Booker cash and carry into the Deeside company - before heading back to the more glamorous world of high street fashion with the Arcadia group.

Mr Grimsey, on the other hand, is a plain-speaking Londoner who learnt his trade under former Tesco chief Sir Iain MacLaurin.

Yesterday he said he had no idea of the mess he was inheriting at Iceland. "I am surprised and shocked at what I have found", he said. "I thought I was getting into a FTSE 250 company to hold the tiller. But the boat has capsized and I've got a leak. I've got to turn it over and tack back into the wind - but I am used to it."

Indeed he is. His last job was at the helm of DIY retailer Wickes, where he inherited a company beset with what City accountants like to call "financial irregularities".

Mr Grimsey moved in, rescued it from near bankruptcy - and lost his job only when Wickes was the subject of a £290m bid. His departure, however, was eased by a £2m share options payout.

He is a hands-on retailer who likes to work in the stores. When he joined Iceland he spent his first days out on the road with a home delivery driver.

"Often people in our industry, when they get to director level, start divorcing themselves from the real action," he said recently. "People who create conditions for failure get paid a lot of money, and the people who have to deal with that failure get paid £4 an hour."

The son of a builder, he left school at 15 and became a butcher's boy in a St Alban's supermarket. After a brief flirtation with college and civil engineering he went back to retailing, working for Bishops food stores, and was a director at the age of 30.

Then came Tesco and two years running a Hong Kong supermarket chain, a brief flirtation with Kingfisher before the Wickes rescue job came up. Now Iceland - and more problems. But Mr Grimsey is undaunted. "We will attack it with vigour."

webTitle: Conductors proved to have sharper ears

fields.headline: Conductors proved to have sharper ears
fields.trailText: Powerful, charismatic figures - orchestra conductors seem a breed apart. Now German scientists have proved it.
fields.body:
Powerful, charismatic figures - orchestra conductors seem a breed apart. Now German scientists have proved it.

Research in today's Nature magazine shows that conductors have reordered the neural pathways of their brains to help them pick out flat cellos from the sound produced by the orchestra as a whole.

Instead of rats, the team led by neuropsychologist Thomas Munte of Magdeburg University, used seven conductors, seven pianists and seven "non-musicians".

The subjects were placed next to loudspeakers broadcasting bursts of "pink noise", a sound like an untuned television makes, and compared their ability to identify sudden changes of frequency.

Conductors and non-conductors showed equal skill when the sounds were coming head on. But conductors were dramatically better than pianists or non-musicians at pouncing on deviant sounds from the periphery.

Analysis of brain activity showed conductors used the same parts of their brain to analyse the sounds but had retrained a zone called the second auditory cortex to be better able to pick out individual sounds from the general din.

 Toronto scientists may have pinpointed the part of the brain that sets humans apart from apes. The region, the size of a billiard ball, could be where humans operate a "theory of mind" - feel empathy, enjoy humour, detect sarcasm or deceit and distinguish between what happens and what others might think is happening.

webTitle: GM lobby takes root in Bush's cabinet

fields.headline: GM lobby takes root in Bush's cabinet
fields.standfirst:
Biotech firms could have undue influence, say critics

Special report: GM debate
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The strength of the genetically modified food lobby in George Bush's new cabinet, and its links with the GM global leader, Monsanto, are greater than anything that came before, it has emerged.
fields.body:
When Bill Clinton was president, it was an open secret that his government favoured agricultural biotechnology and actively promoted it as a potential US global money-spinner.

But the strength of the genetically modified food lobby in George Bush's new cabinet, and its links with the GM global leader, Monsanto, are greater than anything that came before, it has emerged.

The secretaries of defence, health and agriculture, the attorney general and the chairman of the House agriculture committee all have links with the firm or the wider industry.

The most active GM advocate is expected to be John Ashcroft, the proposed attorney general, who received $10,000 (£6,800) from Monsanto in the recent elections, the most the company gave to any congressional candidate. Mr Ashcroft led calls to the Clinton administration to promote GM crops in developing countries and to persuade Europe to accept them.

If the appointment of Tommy Thompson, the former governor of Wisconsin, as secretary of health and human services is confirmed, he will be given overall responsibility for food safety, pharmaceuticals and the Food and Drug Administration, which licenses biotechnology in the US.

Mr Thompson is a GM supporter and has accepted money for his campaigns from Monsanto. He used state funds to set up a £200m biotech zone and was one of 13 state governors to launch a campaign, partly funded by Monsanto, to persuade Americans of the benefits of GM crops.

Ann Veneman, the new agriculture secretary, was a director of the GM company Calgene, now owned by Monsanto, and has been active in world trade talks which would favour US companies exporting GM crops to developing countries.

Donald Rumsfeld, the defence secretary, was president of Searle Pharmaceuticals when it was bought by Monsanto.

Larry Combest, a Texas Republican who will chair the powerful House of Representatives agriculture committee, received $2,000 from Monsanto in last year's elections. He is known as a strong supporter of GM food.

Clarence Thomas, the judge whose vote for Mr Bush in the supreme court helped decide the election, was a Monsanto lawyer from 1977 to 1979. His views on GM are not known.

Charles Lewis, director of the Centre for Public Integrity, said: "It looks like Monsanto and the biotechnology industry has the potential to bring undue influence on the new government."

A spokesman for the charity Christian Aid said: "This does not bode well. We should be proceeding cautiously with GM. We fear even greater pressure on poor countries to introduce the technology, to the detriment of poor farmers and consumers who may further lose control of their food security."

Loren Wassel, Monsanto's director of public relations, declined to comment yesterday.

fields.headline: Reed named for Bafta award
fields.trailText: Oliver Reed has been nominated for a Bafta for the first time - two years after his death.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Oliver Reed has been nominated for a Bafta for the first time - two years after his death.

Reed, who died during filming in Malta in 1999, has been nominated as best supporting actor for Gladiator, the epic set in ancient Rome and directed by Ridley Scott. The work he had done was regarded as so powerful that instead of scrapping it, computer technology was used to complete his role.

Born in 1938, Reed was seen as a dazzling screen presence who squandered his genius in drinking bouts and punch-ups. He suffered a heart attack in a bar in Malta, where he had been drinking rum by the bottle and arm wrestling fellow customers.

Gladiator received 14 other nominations, including one for best film. It is up against Billy Elliot, director Stephen Daldry's first film, Erin Brockovich, Almost Famous, and the surprise international hit Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - which received a record highest number of nominations for a foreign film.

There were no British nominations for best actress, which is between Julia Roberts for Erin Brockovich, Juliette Binoche for Chocolat, Kate Hudson for Almost Famous, Hilary Swank for Boys Don't Cry, and Michelle Yeoh for Crouching Tiger.

fields.headline: Don't try this at home
fields.trailText: Living By The Book | Confidence Lab
fields.body:
Men are from Mars, women are from Venus, and Stephen Covey is from another planet altogether.

Covey was the main beneficiary of the last in the series of Living By The Book (Channel 4). The Lemmons from Cambridge and The Lunns from Harrogate both wanted better family lives, and had chosen Covey's tome, The Seven Habits Of Highly Effective Families, with which to improve their lives. It had worked for Covey himself, after all. He had a big house in a nice bit of Utah, the nearest neighbours some majestic pine trees and a rather impressive mountain range. He also had nine children and 33 grandchildren. This suggested that he was far too effective for his own good, so it's probably just as well that he'd sold 15 million books worldwide, otherwise the Covey clan would have been living in the trailer park next to the Osmonds.

Family life, said Covey, was like a high wire trapeze act with no safety net, though one imagines that any circus metaphor will do (lion taming, juggling chainsaws, Papa Lazarou's freak show).

Over in Cambridge, for example, it was like juggling lions on a high wire. Mum Tracy wanted daughter Sarah and son Andrew to get along with her, with each other, and with her boyfriend Richard. Being a teenager who desperately wanted her bellybutton pierced, Sarah kept shouting and stropping out of the room, unable to get along with anyone, while Richard looked like Roy from The Cops. Not a good start. Up in Harrogate, mum Julie Lunn was sick of being the bad guy while all her children adored husband Ian. Nikki, their daughter, found Julie too controlling.

From a rocking chair in Utah, Covey advised them all to open emotional bank accounts into which deposits ("Thank you for making me dinner") could be made. Unfortunately, the Lunns and the Lemmons seemed to be over their overdraft limits from the off.

Despite Julie and Tracy's willingness - Julie even had a flipchart - Sarah continued to strop and Julie's children thanked dad for his loveliness while ignoring their (admittedly slightly uptight) mother's efforts. Covey's advice of "hitting the pause button" and "having meaningful one-on-one time with each of the family" was akin to sticking an Elastoplast over a gunshot wound when their problems could have been resolved by being much more direct. To wit, Sarah Lemmon should have been locked in a cupboard until she was 25. But did Covey say that? Nope. He was far too busy uttering banalities like, "We must never cease in striving and, at the end of all our striving, we will be where we began and see the place for the first time." Translation: "Congratulations. You have just wasted £12.99 on a cheesy self-help manual. You could have had a bottle of vodka for that."

Busy with that and counting his money. And his grandkids.

Confidence Lab (BBC2) is really rather uplifting - and not just because of Dawn French. The latest subjects of this genuinely thoughtful programme were Linda, whose weight and preoccupation with it got her down, and John, a Glaswegian whose lack of stature drove him to aggression and unnecessary kilt wearing. Curiously, his Glaswegianness - a bigger problem in my book - gave him no trouble at all. Being a bit of a shortarse myself, I envied John's height-related self-consciousness - his drove him to the gym, mine drives me to Jaffa Cakes - but once he burst into tears, I envied him no longer.

John followed rules of society that he didn't really believe (men shouldn't cry), felt exposed (as well he might in that nasty vest) and didn't like cuddles. Well, I wept like a baby when Adric died in Dr Who, I don't wear vests and I love cuddles. Proof, methinks, that you don't know what you've got until you witness someone else suffering.

With the help of Sandra, Roy and Ros (her again), both John and Linda got to grips with their problems and were in high spirits at the group reunion, as well you might be if you'd aired your neuroses at the luxurious Babbington Hall. It sure beats the cupboard under the stair with only a Hoover for company. Sometimes, television is so therapeutic.

webTitle: Scientists list mental risks from smoking cannabis

fields.headline: Scientists list mental risks from smoking cannabis
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Cannabis smoking - besides causing harm to heart, lungs and the immune system - can lead to temporary bouts of mental illness.
fields.body:
Cannabis smoking - besides causing harm to heart, lungs and the immune system - can lead to temporary bouts of mental illness.

Scientists report today in the British Journal of Psychiatry that regular use may make things worse for people who have mental health problems, and lead to panic attacks and anxiety in those who do not.

Andrew Johns of the Institute of Psychiatry at the Maudsley hospital in south London surveyed a number of recent studies. One found that 15% of users identified psychotic symptoms or irrational feelings of persecution. Other reports suggested the drug could induce psychosis in people with no history of severe mental illness.

Those with mental illness - living in the community, and as likely as anybody else to get hold of the drug - were even more at risk. "People with major mental illnesses such as schizophrenia are especially vulnerable, in that cannabis generally provokes relapses and aggravates existing symptoms," Dr Johns said.

"Health workers need to recognise, and respond to, the adverse effects of cannabis on mental health."

Researchers are testing cannabis as a potential medicinal drug - there are claims that it can quell nausea during chemotherapy, relieve glaucoma and stifle the pain of multiple sclerosis - but smoking marijuana also imposes a price.

Last year US researchers showed that squirrel monkeys found the drug addictive, and a Boston team reported that, an hour after inhaling, the risk of heart attack increased fivefold.

Heather Ashton, of the University of Newcastle, reports in the same journal that besides producing severe anxiety, panic, paranoia and psychosis in high doses, cannabis impaired memory and concentration.

There could be heart problems for people with pre-existing cardiac disease, and the drug also suppressed the immune system. Cannabis cigarettes could be as addictive as nicotine, and the tars from cannabis cigarettes contained higher levels of some cancer-causing chemicals than tobacco.

Smoking three or four reefers a day produced the same risk of bronchitis or emphysema as 20 or more cigarettes.

Chronic use might also cause complications in pregnancy and childbirth.

fields.headline: Snow on the tracks
fields.standfirst: Wolsingham, Weardale
fields.trailText: Wolsingham, Weardale.
fields.body:
Just enough snow had fallen to creak and groan under every footstep, but the snowflakes were swirling down faster, filling fresh rabbit tracks ahead of us. No wind, so the flakes settled with picture postcard perfection: neat little cones on dead umbels of hogweed; precariously balanced fillets along hazel twigs; slanting heaps on brackets of razor strop fungus around birch trunks. Something - probably greenfinches - had been shredding the rose hips in the hedge to reach their seeds, and the snow under the briars was flecked with scarlet. The woodland was drained of colour, as graphic as charcoal on white paper.

We came to a fallen willow, undermined by the River Wear's scouring winter flood water. All around the roots were fresh footprints - almost certainly from a stoat - which told a story. In and out of every crevice, then over the trunk and weaving through the roots on the far side. It must have been searching for a sheltering rabbit or mouse, in the methodical, relentlessly lethal way that stoats do. The tracks could only have been made in the last minute or two, or the falling snow would have covered them, but now there was no sign of the hunter, whose trail vanished under the tangle of alder roots along the riverbank.

Slipping and slithering along the edge of the wood, we followed a chattering flock of redwings until the path turned back into the trees and past a small pond, its black mirror surface rippled by dissolving snowflakes. A familiar aroma of garlic was rising from the ground. I brushed away some of the snow with my boot, and uncovered a forest of yellow-green shoots of ramsons, already spearing through last year's decaying willow leaves.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Performance On 3 | Emerald In The Crown | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
Mstislav Rostropovich takes the London Symphony Orchestra through two wildly disparate works in a live relay from the Barbican Centre in London. Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) opens with Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker Suite. And then comes a startling shift of tone with Shostakovich's searing Eighth Symphony. He wrote it in 1943, while Stalin's commissars were still denouncing him.

As part of the BBC's commemoration of the Victorian age, Declan Kiberd looks back on England's ever-chequered relations with Ireland. As he notes in Emerald In The Crown (8.0pm, Radio 4), the potato blight which killed millions soon after Victoria's accession led nationalist politicians to dub her The Famine Queen. The English man's reciprocal contempt for the Irish was demonstrated by a stunningly racist commentary published in Punch. Yet when the Queen visited Dublin the streets were filled with vast, flag-waving crowds.

Many more people now seem to suffer allergic reactions to such triggers as dust or peanuts. Every second person in this country is apparently suffering some sort of medical response, either to where they live or what they eat. Current research shows that food allergies are increasingly common among pre-school children, though many grow out of them in time. In Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4) Alex Kirby talks to some of the researchers in the field.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Hunchback Of Notre Dame | Supermatch - Reserve Match - Live! | I, Claudius
fields.body:
Films

The Hunchback Of Notre Dame
(William S Dieterle, 1939)
6am, 2pm, Sky Cinema

An exemplary screening of Victor Hugo's gothic classic: aside from the beauty-and-beast romantic horror story, there's a tangible sense of a grotesque medieval world. Brilliantly conceived by Dieterle, and beautifully acted by the likes of Cedric Hardwicke as Frollo, Maureen O'Hara as the gypsy girl Esmeralda and, best of all, Charles Laughton, who somehow expresses the selfless nobility of the misshapen Quasimodo through the monster make-up.

The Taking Of Pelham One, Two, Three
(Joseph Sargent, 1974)
9pm, Carlton Cinema

Enough to keep you off the tube for life. Four masked gunmen hijack a New York subway train and demand $1m, or the passengers start dying. Robert Shaw as the ruthless gang boss and the late great Walter Matthau as the transport cop try to out-gruff each other in a relentlessly grimy, gloomy thriller. Main problem is Sargent's direction, halting even when the train's brakes are off.

Against All Odds
(Taylor Hackford, 1984)
10pm, FilmFour

Gritty remake of Tourneur's labyrinthine noir classic, Out Of The Past. The cast fairly sizzles in the California/Mexican sunshine: James Woods is a club owner employing crooked footballer-pal Jeff Bridges to bring back his girl, Rachel Ward, who's gone awol. The latter pair fall in love, of course, precipitating blood and mayhem.

Sliding Doors
(Peter Howitt, 1998) 11.45pm, Sky Premier

Likeable comedy that cleverly sustains its parallel-futures conceit. Basically, sacked PR agent Helen (Gwyneth Paltrow, of the great English accent) either finds true love and happiness with the irritating James (John Hannah), or she doesn't, depending on whether or not she catches a particular tube train. Howitt plays the alternative strands of fate deftly, although the central couple's slightly cloying sweetness is overcompensated by the sour infidelity of her boyfriend (John Lynch) with nasty ex Jeanne Tripplehorn.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Supermatch - Reserve Match - Live!
6.15pm, MUTV

Want to see top-class internationals and the cream of young British talent facing off with the added zing of a Yorkshire v Lancashire derby? Sadly, if the answer is yes, then your only hope lies with the subscription-only MUTV, who broadcast Manchester United's match against their arch-rivals Leeds. The fact that it's a reserve fixture shouldn't put off anyone who has read this far.
Simon Burnton

Drama

I, Claudius
9pm, UK Drama One

of the great defining moments of British TV, though it's a tad more wordy than we're used to now, and the shaky sets leave a little to be desired. Still, not every show has Brian Blessed muttering "As quick as boiled asparagus, I'll have you out!"
Richard Vine

webTitle: The quake, the mourning and the long wait

fields.headline: The quake, the mourning and the long wait
fields.standfirst:
The aid pouring into Gujarat is failing to reach some of those most in need

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: The residents of Dinara have a harsh life at the best of times. The village lies on the edge of a vast expanse of desert. Nothing much grows apart from diminutive babul trees. Only camels seem at home, plodding among the shimmering salt flats.
fields.body:
The residents of Dinara have a harsh life at the best of times. The village lies on the edge of a vast expanse of desert. Nothing much grows apart from diminutive babul trees. Only camels seem at home, plodding among the shimmering salt flats.

And these are not the best of times. Last Friday the earthquake that levelled much of the Indian state of Gujarat left seven dead in Dinara, including an eight-month-old baby. As the tremors subsided, the villagers shook themselves and waited for help to arrive.

Yesterday - thirsty and desperate - they were still waiting. "We have had no water for four or five days. All of our wells have been destroyed. We have been forced to drink salt water," villager Omar Sama said. "We are not getting grain. Nobody has come to help us."

The village teacher, Sama Mirmama, added: "We are looking for bread. People living here believe that God is angry with us."

Aid has cascaded into Bhuj, the historic town close to the epicentre of last week's quake, but none of it has yet reached the remote and stricken interior 50 miles to the north.

Here 32 isolated villages, including Dinara, have been flattened. At least 75 people have died - with the total death toll for the region, the Rann of Kutch, put at 1,000. And yet ours was the only vehicle to have reached Dinara, apart from a solitary relief truck that doled out only biscuits and sweets. We gave the villagers our chapattis. It was not much of a contribution.

Almost all the big structures in the village have collapsed. But the traditional conical mud huts, made from cow dung and roofed with babul branches and grass, have survived. The rural people who live in this barren earthquake-prone desert have benefited from their ancestors' wisdom.

"We have had no relief. Maybe we have not received anything because we are Harijans [untouchables]," Mr Sama mused.

Dinara's prospects in the coming months are poor. The village women have traditionally made a decent living from selling exquisitely embroidered clothes to tourists.

There were also few signs of relief in Khavda, five miles to the south. The town has been turned to rubble, with some 90% of buildings destroyed, suggesting that the quake's arc of destruction has, if anything, been underestimated.

At Ishmail Khalifa's barber's shop, the clock ticked on and the poster of Bombay was still on the wall. But the barber's chair was full of jagged bricks.

"There were three customers in my shop. Two were inside and one was outside. The customer Mukim, was having a shave when the earthquake arrived. He rushed outside and he died," Mr Khalifa explained.

"Seven people were killed here, including two two-year-old boys," said Khavda's feudal chief, Lataji Thackar. "The earthquake was like a bomb. There was shaking everywhere. All of my six houses have been destroyed. But my family is safe."

The town's 3,000 homeless residents have given up waiting for aid, choosing instead to build their own tents in the grounds of Khavda's school.

A medical team finally arrived yesterday and set up a field hospital. Within an hour of opening, it had treated 71 patients. Most were from remote villages like Dinara. Some had been hobbling round with untreated broken legs and arms since Friday.

The earthquake has transformed the region in different ways. Locals say that a tributary of the Indus river, sealed by a previous earthquake, has started flowing again.

The subterranean geology of the area has changed too. "There are three streams of water suddenly. One is muddy, one is salt water and one is sweet," said Ajay Bora, who runs Bhuj's defunct three-star Prince hotel.

Two were inside and one was outside. The customer Mukim, was having a shave when the earthquake arrived. He rushed outside and he died," Mr Khalifa explained. "Seven people were killed here, including two two-year-old boys," said Khavda's feudal chief, Lataji Thackar. "The earthquake was like a bomb. There was shaking everywhere. All of my six houses have been destroyed. But my family is safe." The town's 3,000 homeless residents have given up waiting for aid, choosing instead to build their own tents in the grounds of Khavda's school. A medical team finally arrived yesterday and set up a field hospital. Within an hour of opening, it had treated 71 patients. Most were from remote villages like Dinara. Some had been hobbling round with untreated broken legs and arms since Friday. The earthquake has transformed the region in different ways. Locals say that a tributary of the Indus river, sealed by a previous earthquake, has started flowing again. The subterranean geology of the area has changed too. "There are three streams of water suddenly. One is muddy, one is salt water and one is sweet," said Ajay Bora, who runs Bhuj's defunct three-star Prince hotel.
