fields.headline: Johnnie Johnson
fields.standfirst: Second world war fighter ace credited with more enemy 'kills' than any other British pilot
fields.trailText: Second world war fighter ace credited with more enemy 'kills' than any other British pilot.
fields.body:
In 1937, "Johnnie" Johnson tried to join the Auxiliary Air Force (AAF). On hearing that he came from Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, the interviewing officer said, "My dear chap, you're just the type. Which hunt do you follow?" When Johnnie said he did not even ride a horse, he was promptly shown the door. Little did that interviewing officer think he had just rejected the man who, in the second world war, would shoot down more of the enemy than any other pilot in the RAF - and without ever being shot down himself.

Johnson, who has died aged 85, was born at Barrow-upon-Soar, Leicestershire. He was a rather wild youth, and his father, a policeman, is reported to have said: "You'd better be either a policeman or a pilot." In fact, after attending Loughborough College and Nottingham University, he qualified as a civil engineer. Without any further objective in mind, he also became deadly with a shotgun, with an average (he wrote) of two rabbits with every three shots.

Realising that the AAF was at that time an exclusive club, he then tried the RAF Volunteer Reserve, to receive a second rejection. He eventually managed to join the Territorial Army, but in 1939 war clouds were gathering, and he was called up into the RAFVR. To his delight, he managed to be selected for pilot training, and found himself at Marshall's School at Cambridge. At 23 he was older than most of the pupils, but he did well, and in summer 1940 he went to Hawarden in Cheshire to learn to fly the Spitfire. On his fourth flight he pranged (crashed), but in September he was commissioned and posted to 19 Squadron, and then to an AAF unit, 616 Squadron. Exhausted, the survivors of 616 were being rested and reorganised away from the battle at Kirton-in-Lindsey.

Here, Johnnie put in as many hours on the "Spit" as he could, but he found his flying handicapped by a painful old rugby injury. He tried to fly with his left hand, but eventually had to report his difficulty. The instant reaction was "Has this chap gone LMF?" Lack of moral fibre was a heinous crime, but Johnnie soon convinced the authorities that he was exactly the opposite.

An operation cured the problem, and from then on Johnson be came a deadly killing machine, not only the master of the Spitfire but also - unlike almost everyone else - a master of accurate deflection shooting, learned against agile rabbits.

The only problem was that the great Battle of Britain was over, and "Huns" were hard to find. In February 1941, 616 became part of the Tangmere Wing, which a month later was given a new wing leader: Douglas Bader, the famed pilot who had lost both legs in a pre-war crash. Johnson soon became Bader's No 3 ("Cocky" Dundas was No 2), a marvellous position at the front of the wing, but frustrating in that No 3's job was to cover the leader, not to go off chasing enemies.

By May 1941, Bader's wing was taking the offensive over France, and Johnson began to learn his trade in actual combat. A month later, 616 was badly "bounced" over Gravelines. Johnson found himself alone, and suddenly saw a Messerschmitt 109 in front of him. Unlike most RAF pilots, Johnson hit with his first burst. He saw the pilot bail out. From then on, there was no stopping him. In mid-September he was promoted to flight lieutenant and given command of B Flight.

Some idea of his character is shown by the fact that in early 1942 he became a squadron leader, in 1943 a wing commander and in February 1945 a group captain. As a squadron leader, he was given the command of 610 Squadron, but fretted because they were based mainly in Norfolk. Things looked up in March 1943 when he was given command of a wing at Kenley in Surrey. The wing comprised three Canadian squadrons, and being sent to command it was probably the toughest appointment in Fighter Command.

Eyeing their new English CO keenly, they need not have worried. On the first occasion they met the enemy under his command, they shot down six of the dangerous Fw190s. One fell to Johnson, raising his score to nine. Johnson was just what the Canadians had prayed for: an aggressive leader. As wing leader he could paint his own initials on his Spitfire - now a far superior Mk IX - and he adopted the radio call sign Greycap. By mid-year his own score had reached 20.

Then he was frustrated by being given a staff job. But in March 1944, he was switched to command a different Canadian wing in the newly formed 2nd Tactical Air Force. After D-Day he organised barrels of beer to be slung under the Spitfires in place of extra fuel tanks, a move welcomed on the dusty front-line airfields of Normandy. Just at this time he overtook "Sailor" Malan's score of 32 confirmed victories. When VJ-Day came, in May 1945, his score was 38. Officially this remains the highest total of any RAF pilot, though it is widely believed Sqn Ldr St John Pattle exceeded 40 in the turmoil of the Greek campaign.

Perhaps Johnson's most impressive achievement was that, in some 1,000 combat missions, he was never shot down. Only once was his Spitfire damaged by the enemy. Apologising, he said, "I was surrounded by six of them." He was awarded the DSO and two bars, the DFC and bar, the Belgian Légion d'Honneur and Croix de Guerre.

He stayed in the post-war RAF, serving in Korea at tached to the US Air Force, and being awarded the American DFC. He commanded RAF Wildenrath in Germany and Cottesmore in England, and from 1960 to 1963 was senior air staff officer in 3 Group, Bomber Command. He finally retired in 1966 as Air Officer Commanding, Air Forces Middle East, Aden, with the rank of air vice-marshal.

In 1942 he married Paula, and they had two sons, Michael and Christopher. In 1977 he and his wife decided amicably to separate. For a while he lived in Jersey, but he returned to Buxton, Derbyshire.

When he had written his autobiography, Wing Leader, he asked Bader to contribute a foreword. His old CO wrote back "Dear Johnnie, I did not know you could read and write." That was Johnnie in a nutshell.

Air Chief Marshal Sir Christopher Foxley-Norris, chairman of the Battle of Britain Fighter Association, writes: Johnnie Johnson's performance was even more creditable because he largely missed the Battle of Britain and won his "kills" in fighter-to-fighter combat rather than against heavy bombers. If they numbered less than the German fighter aces this was because the Germans included their hits against the less-skilled Russians. Johnnie's kills were hard-earned, but then Johnnie had the two skills needed to be successful: he was a good shot and a good pilot. Lots of people were good pilots, but Johnnie was also a good shot - gifted in the art of deflection shooting. Before the war he had been a game-shooter, a sort of "Lincolnshire poacher".

He was a hard man, a very tough man, but a very good leader. He was trusted and he looked after his people. But he was intolerant if a man did not come up to scratch. There were some pilots who had to overcome a great deal of fear; but Johnnie did not seem to suffer like that. It was somehow easier for him.

He was certainly tough - and demanding, both on and off duty - but then you had to be. I was fond of him, although he wasn't always easy. And I wished I had been tough like him.

 Air Vice-Marshal James Edgar (Johnnie) Johnson, fighter pilot, born March 9 1916; died January 30 2001

fields.headline: David Heneker
fields.standfirst: Soldier turned songwriter with a string of hit shows, including Half A Sixpence and Charlie Girl
fields.trailText: Soldier turned songwriter with a string of hit shows, including Half A Sixpence and Charlie Girl.
fields.body:
It was after falling off a horse in the late 1930s that the thoughts of David Heneker, who has died aged 94, turned from soldiering to songwriting. Recuperating in hospital from the riding accident, he found himself more and more engaged by a reading of the score of Noël Coward's Bitter Sweet. It was to change his life.

Heneker went on to become the lyricist behind the 1960s musicals Half A Sixpence and Charlie Girl, and many other West End shows. Coward had sown the seeds for turning a regular soldier into a composer and lyricist who collaborated on some of the most popular - if critically reviled - shows on the postwar stage. What the stint in hospital provoked was a latent desire to compose light music.

At first, it was just ditties for crooners. Then his appreciation of the scope of cabaret in, say, the art of Leslie "Hutch" Hutchinson in the 1940s lured Heneker behind the scenes. He became a close friend of the singer, and in turn Hutch recorded Heneker's first published number, There Goes My Dream, which reached number one in the song-sheet charts.

Not that he had left the army in those prewar days, which, as the son of a general, he had joined in 1925. He was born in Southsea and educated at Wellington College and the Royal Military Academy, Sandhurst. By 1948, however, he felt confident enough of his talent to resign his commission and set up as a musician.

By then, many of his other songs had won recognition - The Thingummy Bob That's Going To Win The War may still be remembered. The West End's Embassy Club took Heneker to its heart. He became one of its favourite regular cocktail pianists and singers during the 1950s. He also found himself contributing songs and tunes to theatrical revues, notably Cockles And Champagne (Saville, 1954).

His first big chance in West End musicals came at the same theatre four years later with Wolf Mankowitz's Expresso Bongo, in which Paul Scofield made his singing debut as a variety agent. With Monty Norman, Heneker wrote the songs for this satire on the sleazy Soho world of pop-music exploitation.

Months later, Heneker shared with Norman and Julian More the triumphant adaptation into English of Marguerite Monnot's Par- isian musical Irma La Douce (Lyric), directed by Peter Brook, and shortly after that he and Norman provided the music and lyrics for another low-life Mankowitz musical, Make Me An Offer (Theatre Royal, Stratford), which transferred to the West End and won the Evening Standard prize for best musical of the season.

Having participated in three consecutive London hits, Heneker was invited to go it alone on a musical adaptation of HG Wells's Kipps - Half-A-Sixpence (Cambridge, 1963), which brought Tommy Steele into the West End as the draper's apprentice. This won Heneker an Ivor Novello award, an entry in the Dictionary Of Quotations for his number Flash, Bang, Wallop, and the distinction of being the first British writer to have had two shows on Broadway, each running for more than 500 performances.

Whether this was the peak of the ever-modest Heneker's musical career or the show Charlie Girl (Adelphi, 1965) is a moot point. The one brought him credit on both sides of the Atlantic as the sole composer; the other, which he co-wrote, was mauled by the critics but ran for more than five years, with Anna Neagle, Hy Hazell, Derek Nimmo and Joe Brown in charge of its simple, stately-home humour.

Meanwhile, Heneker took sole charge of the music again for the jaunty 19th-century hunting satire, Jorrocks (New, now Albery, 1966), based on the novels of RS Surtees, though it was relatively short-lived. In 1969 came the even less inspiring, but more extravagantly-staged, Phil The Fluter (Palace), based on the life of the Irish composer Percy French, whose output included Toot On The Flute, Phil The Fluter's Ball and The Mountains Of Mourne. This offered five of French's songs to 10 of Heneker's tunes.

If hardly any of Heneker's shows were memorable for his music or melodies, he remained one of the most agreeably versatile of composers and lyricists, ready to turn his hand to anything that came his way, and as a man who was easy for others to work with. Whether the show was romantic or realistic, satirical or sentimental, his songs served the occasion, and sometimes rose above it.

Popkiss (Globe, 1972) was a musical version of Ben Travers's 1920s farce, Rookery Nook, for which Heneker and John Addison provided the right kind of period tap-dancing and soft-shoe numbers; and his tunes were rated one of the better things in The Biograph Girl (Phoenix, 1981).

At the same theatre three years later, Peg (1984), based on the 1912 American tearjerker, Peg O' My Heart, about an Irish-American girl of unexpected fortune descending on snobbish English relatives, won few hearts except through Heneker's catchy tunes.

He was twice married; first to Ellen Hope (dissolved) and later to Gwenol Satow.

fields.headline: Letter: Gavin Young
fields.trailText: Bill Headdon writes: I last met Gavin Young (Obituary, January 22) in Bude in the early 1990s, and had a drink with him at the Brendon Arms (his favourite pub).
fields.body: Bill Headdon writes: I last met Gavin Young (Obituary, January 22) in Bude in the early 1990s, and had a drink with him at the Brendon Arms (his favourite pub). We talked of poetry and writing, and he was gracious enough to allow me to publish some of his work in my anthology of Cornish verse. In his preface to Slow Boats To China, he wrote of how the north Cornish coast had nurtured his early boyhood; others had been similarly struck by its restless grandeur, not least Tennyson and Hardy. His writing graced the pages of literature with its panache and flow of imagination; Conrad, Kipling and Marryat - Trevose forever in sight. Old Bood mourns its son. will be around to see it.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Sarah Ferguson

fields.headline: No 1810
fields.standfirst: Sarah Ferguson
fields.trailText: Sarah Ferguson.
fields.body:
Age: 41.

Appearance: Ginger. Thin.

Job: Children's author, motivational speaker, chatshow host, doll manufacturer, slimming guru ...

Ah, yes. The woman who gained a few million dollars simply by losing a few pounds. "Free your mind and your bottom will follow," as Fergie put it earlier this week. To which she might have added: "Get your body in shape and your bank balance will follow."

Looking healthier, is it? I'll say. In the darkest days the then Duchess of Pork owed the royal bank, Coutts, some £4.3m, the interest on which amounted to a hefty £1,100 a day. But after losing four stones she signed up as a spokesperson for Weight Watchers, on a contract reputedly worth £1m a year.

That's more than Andrew is given by the taxpayer to sunbathe on yachts with supermodels! He should take a few tips from his ex. Well, now he can.

What do you mean? Only that having reshaped her finances as dramatically as her bottom, Fergie has been signed up to give financial advice to America.

Which is? "It's all about knowing. And planning. And making smart decisions."

Such as? Agreeing to endorse the investment house Charles Schwab, for which the duchess is being paid £400,000 over two years. As she tells prospective investors: "Financial security doesn't have to be a fairy tale."

They can afford it, presumably. Actually, things aren't great at the leading US brokerage firm. Some employees are being asked to take Fridays off over the next two months in an attempt to cut costs.

Any advice from Fergie? "You'll need to understand the difference between a P/E ratio and a dividend yield, a growth versus value strategy," she cautions.

Does she have any idea what she's talking about? Who cares? She knows how many calories there are in a Creme Egg, and that'll do for now.

"You'll need to understand the difference between a P/E ratio and a dividend yield, a growth versus value strategy," she cautions. Does she have any idea what she's talking about? Who cares? She knows how many calories there are in a Creme Egg, and that'll do for now.

webTitle: Desperate Barak turns to war scare tactics

fields.headline: Desperate Barak turns to war scare tactics
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Thousands of fake call-up notices were delivered to Israeli households yesterday in a desperate attempt to scare voters into supporting the re-election of the prime minister, Ehud Barak.
fields.body:
Thousands of fake call-up notices were delivered to Israeli households yesterday in a desperate attempt to scare voters into supporting the re-election of the prime minister, Ehud Barak.

At first glance, the orders were disconcertingly real. Arriving in army-issue brown envelopes, they were printed with the words "Chapter 8", the code for being called up for war. They ordered Israeli males to report to the nearest army centre on February 7, the day after Israel's prime ministerial election.

"When I saw it, I thought: 'oh my God, the situation is really bad'," said Akiva Offenbacher, 48, an economist in Jerusalem who has not been called to reserve duty for four years. "It worked for me. I really thought it was a call-up notice at first."

The pranksters came clean in the second sentence. "No it's not really Chapter 8," the notice said. "But it could definitely be one soon if the man who dragged us into wars, and is opposed to any step towards peace is sitting in the prime minister's office."

The "man" referred to by the four army reservists who devised the notices is Ariel Sharon, the hardliner who led Israel into a war in Lebanon in 1982.

More than 1,000 Israeli soldiers were killed there before Mr Barak pulled the troops out last year.

Mr Barak trails Mr Sharon by a massive 20 percentage points in the opinion polls.

His campaign team was so taken with the reservists' prank that it developed its own campaign, preying on Israeli fears of being sucked into another regional war.

It printed 600,000 similar leaflets, asking voters to choose between peace or the war that it said would inevitably follow a Sharon victory. "If it were up to Sharon, you would still be doing reserve duty in Lebanon," the leaflets said.

Mr Barak's camp denied involvement in the reservists' mailshot.

During the last seven years of negotiations with the Palestinians, the army has relaxed the requirements of reserve duty, and many Israeli males stop being called up when they reach their early 40s. At the same time, the relative peace has made men far less willing to disrupt their home and working lives for several weeks each year.

Mr Barak's scare tactics appear calculated to remind voters of Mr Sharon's 50-year record as a reckless warrior with a penchant for grand schemes that go horribly awry.

However, it is uncertain whether that will succeed in allaying Israeli insecurities. Voters appear to be favouring Mr Sharon precisely because of his warrior image.

"I got a little bit angry," said Mr Offenbacher. "It was very effective, and a tremendous public relations success, but when you come down to think about it, it was a cheap trick."

fields.headline: Dr Jekyll, Mr Straw
fields.standfirst:
The home secretary's part in the Mandelson affair reveals his other, darker, side, argues Henry Porter

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The home secretary's part in the Mandelson affair reveals his other, darker, side, argues Henry Porter.
fields.body:
The home secretary's intervention in the Mandelson affair should not be forgotten. For in the telephone call to the prime minister, and his subsequent assertion that the former Northern Ireland secretary was a liar, the real Jack Straw darted from the shadows and was held for a few moments in a revealing shaft of light. We saw him for what he was - the first servant of a government which is devoted to the maintenance and exercise of its own power and which has waged a steady campaign against the country's liberties.

This seems an extraordinary statement to be making. We're talking about Jack Straw, for heaven's sake, the man whose modest performance during the last election campaign suggested an ideal steward for the Home Office. He seemed decent, balanced and slow to judge.

But, just as we were lulled by the declarations of a freer, more open society in the Labour manifesto, so we were sedated by Straw's plodding mildness of manner. After four years of this government's rampage through civil liberties and its open attempt to control the media and the processes of devolution and constitutional reform, it is clear that we were guilty of a hopelessly misplaced trust.

What is compelling about the government as a whole, and Straw in particular, is that their liberal self-image remains intact. When the members of the political cabinet met without civil servants on Tuesday to discuss election strategy, you can bet there wasn't the slightest doubt in any of their minds about their right to govern.

There is an almost mystical conviction that they are not simply elected, they are chosen. And this has been betrayed in an arrogance that instantly recognised and felt at one with the civil service's culture of secrecy and control.

Because it is Labour in power and not the Tories we have as an electorate somehow failed to register the seriousness of the successive attacks on the jury system, on our right to know, on privacy and on the assumption of innocence before guilt is proven.

Imagine that a Conservative home secretary - say Michael Howard - had in a matter of months stifled opposition to a widely and justly criticised freedom of inform-ation bill by means of a parliamentary guillotine; introduced a measure to curb the right to trial by jury after a previous bill had twice been thrown out by the Lords; promoted a bill (now the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act - RIPA) which allows M15 and numerous other government agencies to inspect private emails without a court order; misled the public about police recruitment - in terms of both quantity and ethnic background; produced a steady rise in the prison population; introduced stringent new immigration controls; and enabled the police to take and retain DNA samples from suspects.

If Howard had done all this, the media and the people would be up in arms. We might even have taken to the streets to call for his dismissal. But because the author of these attacks on our liberty is the softly spoken, plausibly hesitant Jack, we have let these things pass, all the while being distracted by Labour's rhythmic beat about hospitals and schools.

The interesting part of the government's attacks on freedom is that it reveals an innate suspicion of the public. The measures to retain DNA samples, for instance, classify each one of us as a potential criminal, whether guilty of a crime or not. In the case of RIPA, everyone's privacy has been compromised by the black boxes which the government insists certain internet providers install.

Whatever the lack of malign intent, we are all now the subjects of surveillance, the targets of a sophisticated apparatus of paranoia. Such a measure would be inconceivable in Europe and yet we have allowed it to happen with only a few voices raised against Straw, notably Richard Norton-Taylor's in this paper.

The debate about the retention of DNA samples has been even more muted. Perhaps it is because liberty has mysteriously slipped from the premier league of issues, or maybe it is that the pace of legislation and the ever-changing agenda do not allow for proper ventilation of a subject.

However, all you need to know about the police DNA data bank is that it doesn't simply contain an archive of unique markers, or super fingerprints. A DNA sample gives an entire profile of an individual, which as analysis of the human genome gathers pace, will yield more and more information about them. One can easily envisage a day when these data banks are used to put together lists of suspects simply on the basis of the information contained in their original sample.

What I suppose I am describing is a basic instinct which drives so much of New Labour's policy making. It is fascinating how many of the self-avowed liberals and radicals have lost their convictions. In the constantly revived criminal justice (mode of trial) bill, which would limit the option to be tried by jury, it is fascinating to see such previous good liberals as Lord Lipsey and Baroness Jay, the Leader of the House of Lords, go in to bat for a proposal which was not only left out of Labour's manifesto but which is antithetical to all that they once stood for. What has happened to these people? Have their liberal values been skewed by hopes for and exercise of power, or is it simply a miraculously fast absorption rate from Whitehall?

To examine these bills before they are modified by parliament is to see the absolutist character of the government in the raw. During the passage of the freedom of information bill, Straw had to be persuaded that the government's plan to maintain secrecy on environmental matters, such as GM crop trials, radiation risks and emission figures from polluting factories, contravened EU directives and a convention signed by every government in Europe, including Britain.

The point is that this measure and the one that gives ministers a right to block the release of information, display Straw's innate hostility to open government and the democratic interests which Labour claimed to represent at the last election. It is, incidentally, a sour irony that Straw's department last year had the worst record for wrongly withholding information under the code of government practice, even though it was the Home Office that was charged with piloting the freedom of information bill.

And let's not forget that while Straw was seeking to persuade parliament to accept his proposals on juries, he actually misled the house and the prime minister on the extent of support for the bill among judges, which was considerably less than he made out. This rates pretty high on the scale of mistakes, especially for a man who is so free with accusations about the lies of cabinet colleagues.

There can now be only two interpretations of Straw's time at the Home Office. Either he has been held hostage by his civil servants or, as I suspect, he has cleverly masked his real nature. Either way, one cannot escape the conclusion that to entrust our freedoms to this man, indeed to this government, for a second time would be like committing an elderly relative into the care of Harold Shipman.

fields.headline: Pat Stack
fields.standfirst: Pioneer of pastoral education
fields.trailText: Pioneer of pastoral education.
fields.body:
Pat Stack devoted his life to working with young people: as a teacher, he was a natural - dedicated, talented, hardworking and charismatic. He was found dead at the age of 46, just weeks after he received the MBE for his services to education, in the new area of schools study support.

Since 1992, he had taught at Sedgehill School, Lewisham, and was the country's first senior teacher for enrichment and extension, a newly-created post recognising his innovative work in the field of pastoral and outdoor education.

His loss will also be felt very deeply in east London. He did a prodigious amount for the multicultural community in which he had lived all his life, having a legendary local reputation as a persuasive Mr Fixit for any worthwhile project, adept at fund-raising from businesses - including the sugar giant Tate and Lyle when it was a large employer in Docklands. As a result, last year he was invited to 11 Downing Street to advise the Department for Education and Employment on fund-raising for schools.

At St Bonaventure's Roman Catholic Secondary School, Forest Gate, where he taught for 10 years, Pat helped develop methods and techniques for structuring pastoral education so that it could form part of the curriculum. The aim was to provide a systematic approach to personal development - the personal and social side of education, as distinct from the academic.

The radical steps - for the 1980s - of implementing, teaching and measuring the processes involved led to personal social health education (PSHE) becoming established in the curriculum of all schools in Newham, and then in the national curriculum. Pat also helped design the first GCSE in outdoor education.

The son of a local builder, he was born and brought up in Stratford, in east London. At 15, he was co-opting adults to drive his father's vans in order to take groups of teenagers on camping trips to Essex. At 16, he was running a youth club at St Francis' RC Church, Stratford.

Tall and athletic, Pat was a natural leader. He had been head boy of St Bonaventure's and his family's first graduate, returning to his old school after taking a politics degree at Durham University. He later took a postgraduate course in economics at the London School of Economics.

His first job after university was as an education welfare officer for Hackney, with responsibility for disadvantaged children. Among the activities he organised were outings to the coast - for many of the children it was their first glimpse of the sea.

In 1979, Pat took over and expanded the Newham Catholic Youth Club at St John's School, opposite West Ham's Upton Park football ground, and later moved it to St Bonaventure's. Through the club, he organised multicultural adventure weekends and holidays all over the country, involving some 40 to 50 children and numerous adult leaders; again, it was a way to get children out of the city.

He also organised six under-16 football teams and, in the summer, five-a-side competitions for his local church of St Francis. At the time, he was also the goalkeeper and chairman of St Francis Football Club. A fanatical Leyton Orient supporter, he missed the 1999 play-offs at Wembley because he was on a school trip, but insisted on being kept informed of his team's dismal performance by mobile phone.

As a teenager, Pat had been greatly influenced by a school trip to Russia, and aimed to repeat the mind-broadening experience for many of his pupils. He organised many cultural exchanges between Newham and eastern European countries, including Russia and Slovakia, but he also took a large group to Nepal, to help in the development of a poor and remote community school.

In 1992, while continuing to live in the East End, he began to work at Sedgehill School, which draws its pupils from some of south-east London's most deprived areas. He quickly introduced a busy programme of out-of-school activities, including an internet club, fashion shows, an On Track club for disaffected pupils, and a girls' club that focused on assertiveness training and health. At least 20 times a year he managed adventure trips so that pupils could experience the thrill, discipline and teamwork needed for activities such as mountain climbing and white water rafting.

Pat completed several fund-raising London Marathons, as well as twice completing the gruelling 120-mile Devizes to Westminster canoe race, which involves almost 24 hours of continuous paddling. He was often to be seen in school holidays running canoe clubs at the London Docks and at Leaside Canoe Club, Hackney, where he could combine his love of the sport with teaching. While Pat was something of a local hero in Forest Gate, for him his work was no more than an extension of his own social life.

He married his wife, Cathy, in 1983 and they had four children, Sinead, Niamh, Charles, and Leah.

 Patrick George Stack, teacher, born July 27 1954; died January 24 2001

webTitle: Dead body may be missing contessa

fields.headline: Dead body may be missing contessa
fields.trailText: A body believed to be that of a missing Italian countess has been found in the sea off the coast of France with a head wound that raises the possibility that she may have been murdered.
fields.body:
A body believed to be that of a missing Italian countess has been found in the sea off the coast of France with a head wound that raises the possibility that she may have been murdered.

Countess Francesca Vacca Agusta, 58, a millionaire socialite who inherited the Agusta helicopter fortune, disappeared from her luxury clifftop villa at Portofino on January 8. Drunk, depressed and wearing only a bathrobe and mismatched slippers, she reportedly left the house on a wintry night saying she was going for a swim.

The body found 10 days ago at Barmes-les-Mimosas, between Marseille and Toulon, has been provisionally identified as the countess because it was found with a wedding ring bearing the date of her father's second marriage.

A French post-mortem examination found that the woman did not drown but died as a result of a severe blow to the head. The badly decomposed body also showed signs of multiple fractures - possibly the result of a fall from a 1,000ft cliff.

When she disappeared, the countess was living in the Villa Altachiara with her Mexican companion, Tirso Roncado Chazaro, 50, and a female friend, Susanna Torretta, 30.

The countess had recently altered her will and in November had settled an inheritance dispute which made her £165m better off.

A fun-loving auburn beauty and protagonist of Italy's dolce vita era, she married Count Corrado Agusta in 1974. The marriage lasted 18 years and made her a rich woman, with properties including the 30-room villa overlooking the bay of Portofino, originally built for Lord Carnarvon in 1874.

The connection with the man who discovered Tutankhamun's tomb has led to speculation that the countess may have been struck down by a pharaonic curse. A young female relative of the fifth earl fell to her death from the villa's clifftop garden.

In the 1990s, the countess and a Portofino bar owner 15 years her junior, Maurizio Raggio, were charged with laundering billions of lire of illicit funds on behalf of Bettino Craxi, the disgraced leader of the Socialist party. They were eventually extradited to Italy from Mexico in 1997 and the countess spent several months in prison.

The countess's stepson, Rocky Agusta, with whom she settled the inheritance suit, told the Milan daily Corriere della Sera: "Francesca was a beautiful woman, simpatica, very rich.

"People have written that she inherited 500bn lire, but if it had been only 50 or 25, who commits suicide with 25bn lire set aside?"

fields.headline: Architects battle to unite Berlin
fields.trailText: It is not every day that architects get the chance to rebuild a capital, and certainly not one as challenging as Berlin, where history and ideological concerns all get in the way of urban planning.
fields.body:
It is not every day that architects get the chance to rebuild a capital, and certainly not one as challenging as Berlin, where history and ideological concerns all get in the way of urban planning.

But at the first viewing yesterday of the new DM465m (£150.5m) federal chancellery building, a concrete and glass cube in the heart of the city, the success of new architecture in creating a "new Berlin" was emphasised.

The headquarters of the first chancellor to govern from Berlin since Adolf Hitler is described as "realised democracy" by its creator Axel Schultes, who said yesterday: "It's a lobby in the sky that wants to be played with and will hopefully stimulate those in it to do good works."

Internally, the chancellery, which contains a winter garden and 500 offices, resembles a passenger ship but the irreverent Berliners say it looks more like a washing machine.

Chancellor Gerhard Schröder is due to move into his new 150 square metre office on the seventh floor at the end of April. His huge, bullet-proof windows will give him a grand view of the Reichstag, seat of the parliament, which the British architect Sir Norman Foster has given a glass dome, to symbolise transparency.

The blueprint for the building was created by Helmut Kohl, and was dubbed the "Kohlosseum". Mr Kohl said he wanted a building which "expressed the visibility of the chancellorship". That is exactly what Mr Schröder has got.

"It's not homely or romantic but it's the manifesto of a self-confident nation," the Berliner Morgenpost said.

Mr Schultes, 57, hopes it will further improve the national spirit. "Germans are frightened of everything, especially things that are big and new," he said. "With this building I'm prescribing a little bit of courage for the nation."

Courage was necessary for Mr Schultes and his fellow architect, Charlotte Frank, in the early 90s when they entered the competition to rebuild Berlin's political apex.

The 150-acre site where the federal buildings were being constructed at a cost of DM2bn is the same strip of land where Hitler's architect, Albert Speer, envisaged building his vast, triumphal north-south avenue. It was also the site of the no man's land surrounding the wall.

Mr Schultes' and Ms Frank's winning design, chosen from a field of 835 entries, features a corridor of buildings and was picked because it runs east-west, sewing together the once-divided city.

Mr Schultes remains disappointed that cutbacks watered down his plans for "Westminster on the [river] Spree". Plans for a civic forum - where Germans could go round the clock to "free themselves from the sickness of being German" - have been shelved.

Mr Schultes tested his ideas on the Berliners in 1999 when he created Europe's largest crematorium - also a glass and concrete cube - in the south of Berlin. So far, more architecture students than mourners have passed through its doors.

webTitle: Brown has scope for £3.5bn tax giveaway in Budget

fields.headline: Brown has scope for £3.5bn tax giveaway in Budget
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has room in next month's pre-election Budget for £3.5bn worth of tax cuts over two years, a leading economic think-tank said yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has room in next month's pre-election Budget for £3.5bn worth of tax cuts over two years, a leading economic think-tank said yesterday.

In its annual Green Budget, the Institute for Fiscal Studies said the chancellor could announce a package of measures worth £1.5bn in 2001/02, with a further £2bn availavble in 2002/03, without damaging the health of the public finances

The IFS said the strength of tax receipts and an undershoot in public spending meant the budget surplus in the current financial year would be £15.9bn, £5.8bn better than the chancellor predicted in his pre-Budget report.

The unexpected windfall would give Mr Brown scope to loosen policy - either by tax cutting or increasing spending over and above the measures already announced in the PBR, without breaching either of his two fiscal rules - borrow only to invest and keep the debt-to-GDP ratio stable.

The institute said Mr Brown's room for maneouvre could be even greater in the next parliament if the economy continues to outperform expectations.

When forecasting the public finances, the Treasury assumes the economy will grow by an average of 2.25%. But since mid-1992 the actual growth rate has averaged 2.9%. If that is sustained, the public finances will continue to be healthier than expected.

David Walton, economist at Goldman Sachs, said: "There's probably the ability by 2005/06 to reduce taxes or increase public spending by another £10bn at today's prices."

Looking back over Labour's term in office, the institute calculates that taxes have risen by a total of £24bn relative to projections in the Tories' last budget, in November 1996.

Only a fraction of that is due to measures announced by Mr Brown.

The bulk of the rise in the tax burden - up by 2.5% of GDP since Labour came to power - is due to a combination of higher than expected inflation, which boosted revenues, so-called fiscal drag - the tendency of incomes to rise faster than tax allowances - and slow-burn tax increases inherited from the Tories.

Although taxes were increased by £9.4bn in Mr Brown's first two budgets, they have been cut by £7.7bn since, giving a net increase of £1.7bn. Even that will be wiped out if the chancellor presses ahead with cuts in duty on ultra low sulphur diesel and petrol.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Boeing backs British skills
Kingston shuns BT exchanges
900 Dairy Crest jobs to go
Court backs RJB protest
Northern Rock for hire
fields.body:
Boeing backs British skills

The world's largest aerospace company, Boeing, is backing a new advanced manufacturing and research park in the economically battered area of South Yorkshire, creating an estimated 7,000 jobs over the next five years.

The local heritage of engineering skills, especially in metallurgy, which has survived severe recession and a jobs collapse in steel-making, was crucial to landing the investment, according to the regional development agency Yorkshire Forward.

The £15m deal includes a matching package of UK government and European Union funding. Boeing will be first to move to the park in Waverley, Rotherham. Other aerospace firms are expected to follow.

Kingston shuns BT exchanges

Kingston Communications yesterday became the second telecoms firm in as many days to drop plans to offer high-speed internet access through BT's local exchanges. The Hull-based company's retreat follows a decision on Tuesday by Scotland's Thus to end a £40m project to provide similar services.

Smaller regional operators like Kingston are increasingly frustrated with BT, accusing the former monopoly of obstructing a competitive market.

900 Dairy Crest jobs to go

Dairy Crest yesterday announced a shake-up of its operations which will see 900 jobs cut. A dairy in Thornbury, south Gloucestershire, will close in November, one at Marshfield, Cardiff, will be shut in February next year and that at Kidlington, Oxfordshire, will close in September next year.

Dairy Crest announced plans to cut a further 300 jobs around Britain. It is also developing a "super dairy" at Severnside, Gloucestershire, which will create more than 320 jobs.

Court backs RJB protest

Britain's biggest coal producer, RJB Mining, yesterday threw the entire future of the German coal industry into doubt after a European court upheld its claim that the way Berlin has restructured the sector could be anti-competitive and should not have been approved by the European commission.

RJB has been waging a battle against what it regards as unfair state subsidies given to its mainland rivals for years and the European court yesterday agreed with the firm and quashed a decision taken by the commission in 1998 to approve several controversial mergers in Germany's coal sector.

Northern Rock for hire

Northern Rock will seek contracts to process its rivals' mortgages as part of a strategy to remain independent. Adam Applegarth, who becomes chief executive next month, said: "It makes more sense for rivals to hire us as their mortgage administrator than to buy us."

It reported a 16% rise in pre-tax profits at £250m.

fields.headline: US cuts rates to 5.5%
fields.trailText: The US Federal Reserve yesterday cut interest rates by half a point for the second time this month, warning that sudden deterioration of the American economy demanded a "rapid and forceful response".
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve yesterday cut interest rates by half a point for the second time this month, warning that sudden deterioration of the American economy demanded a "rapid and forceful response".

As government figures showed US growth slowing to a five-year low at the end of 2000, the Fed signalled that it was prepared to cut rates further to prevent the economy from tipping into a full recession.

Yesterday's interest rate cut of 50-basis points - which follows a similar reduction earlier this month - marks the most dramatic reduction in rates since 1991, when the US economy was struggling out of a downturn. Base rates in the US are now 5.5%.

Wall Street economists had widely anticipated the move after bearish comments from Fed chairman Alan Greenspan last week. US stock markets, which have risen sharply since the Fed's first unexpected move earlier this month, fell slightly at first after the announcement on disappointment that the central bank had not taken stronger action.

Rallying in later trading, the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average was up 69.91 points, or 0.64%, at 10,951.11. The technology-laced Nasdaq Composite index was up 30.6 points, 1.08%, at 2,868.95.

Most analysts are already anticipating further rate cuts. Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said that Mr Greenspan's statements about economic growth had made it clear that "the Fed will do whatever it takes to reignite growth".

Ian Morris, chief US economist at HSBC Securities, said: "This sets us up for another 50 basis points on the 20th of March. The Fed is willing to be forceful and aggressive until confidence gets back up."

The Fed said in a statement released after the meeting that it saw no let-up in the weakness threatening the US economy.

"Consumer and business confidence has eroded further, exacerbated by rising energy costs that continue to drain consumer purchasing power and press on business profit margins," the statement said. "With inflation contained, these circumstances have called for a rapid and forceful response of monetary policy."

Before the Fed announcement, official figures revealed that US output grew at an annual rate of just 1.4% in the final quarter of 2000 - well below market expectations.

"The slowdown is here and is old news," said Matthew Wickens, an economist with ABN-Amro bank in London. "The debate is now the depth of the downturn and the shape of the recovery."

Growth has collapsed from an annual rate of more than 5% in the second quarter of last year, and the speed of the decline has surprised even the Fed's experienced chairman.

Last week, Mr Greenspan predicted that growth in the first quarter of 2001 would be "close to zero" and warned that, if consumer confidence continued to drop, the economy could start contracting.

Investors have shown signs of renewed confidence since the Fed's first rate cut. Technology shares have risen 33% since early January, according to research by Merrill Lynch, the US investment bank.

The dollar slipped to fresh one-week lows against the euro after the decision.

"The knee-jerk reaction will be to sell the dollar," said Paul Podolski, currency strategist at Fleet Capital Markets, adding that the dollar might get a boost if US stocks rallied.

fields.headline: Monk rockers play on
fields.trailText: A group of 15 black-robed Greek monks, who catapulted to fame last year with a best-selling pop record, have defied an order from their church's ruling body to abandon their "scandalous" ways.
fields.body:
A group of 15 black-robed Greek monks, who catapulted to fame last year with a best-selling pop record, have defied an order from their church's ruling body to abandon their "scandalous" ways.

The monks, from the Sts Augustine and Seraphim Sarov monastery, in the mountains of central Greece, struck a chord with young people with their catchy rock tunes and religious-inspired lyrics.

"I don't want to be big boss," they sang. "I learned to be free, I'll shout it in the streets, hold on to your faith, to great ideals, the nation is not for sale, the church doesn't die, history is not forgotten."

When the Holy Synod ordered the monks to return to a more contemplative existence, the monastery's abbot, Father Nektarios, who doubles as the monks' manager, declared independence from the Greek church, saying that the monastery would change its status to that of a brotherhood, comprising lay people as well as clerics.

"The church is like a mother," he said, "but our mother forgot about us and only remembered us in order to scold us. What kind of mother would do that?"

The monks' pop career was inspired by Archbishop Christodoulos, the charismatic leader of the Greek church, who has urged Orthodox clergy to do more to attract young people. As part of his campaign, he famously told a group of youths during a speech: "I dig you."

But it seems the admiration is not mutual and the archbishop said of the rocking monks: "Enough is enough."

fields.headline: A taxing issue
fields.standfirst:
As tax becomes a transnational concern, the OECD is moving against offshore financial centres and tax havens which harbour tax dodgers

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: As tax becomes a transnational concern, the OECD is moving against offshore financial centres and tax havens which harbour tax dodgers.
fields.body:
With Gordon Brown presiding over a growing surplus in the vaults of the Treasury, it might seem a bit rich for industrialised nations such as the UK to be contemplating tough action against offshore financial centres, which are themselves seeking to secure their tax bases.

For all the talk of footloose capital heading for low tax countries, the taxman's cut of world income is larger than it has ever been. But globalisation, accelerated by the internet, is exposing serious flaws in the world's tax system.

Companies and rich individuals can benefit from high quality public services in high tax countries while paying taxes in low tax jurisdictions. The industrialised countries represented by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) are concerned that without pre-emptive action they will not be able to continue funding schools, hospitals and the police.

The OECD is threatening sanctions against offshore financial centres unless they make a public commitment to lift the veil of secrecy over their banking systems by the end of July and then implement reforms by the end of 2005.

While the OECD says that it is not in the business of forcing countries to raise tax rates - in general it favours low tax rates on a wide base - it does want offshore centres to end unfair practices which exist solely to attract capital from non-residents and have no real economic value. One goal is to persuade tax havens to exchange information about suspected tax dodgers.

So far, eight out of 41 jurisdictions identified last year as meeting the technical criteria of being a tax haven - including Cyprus, Mauritius and Isle of Man, have pledged to cooperate with the OECD but some Caribbean jurisdictions in particular have cut up rough and, in private, are making veiled threats to take the OECD to the World Trade Organisation for protectionism. (The OECD's "targets" are shown on the map.)

The Caribbean jurisdictions complain that the OECD is behaving imperiously. Sir Ronald Saunders of Antigua notes that Caribbean nations were encouraged to go into financial services by their former colonial masters.

As a way out of the impasse, a small group of offshore jurisdictions last weekend put forward plans for an ambitious new global tax forum to take over the OECD's work. It would include representatives from both developed and developing countries and, while sticking to the OECD's timetable, seek to devise rules for the operation of offshore financial centres with equal input from both sides.

But how easy would it be to set up a brand new international organisation in a matter of months that would come up with recommendations for action by the end of the year - especially in circumstances where membership, a charter and a disputes resolution mechanism would have to be devised? Even if it were possible the OECD fears that agreed standards for offshore financial centres would conform to the lowest common denominator.

In addition to the eight which have already signed on the dotted line, many more, some in the Caribbean, are on the verge of doing so as a result of bilateral negotiations with the OECD. Why should concessions be made to a handful of jurisdictions whose existing systems can be easily exploited by blatant tax evaders?

In fact a global tax forum, run by the OECD, already exists. In the longer term, it gives scope for developing a new more inclusive body to deal with cross-border tax issues, which are likely to grow in complexity in the future. But the OECD believes discussion of a new international organisation should not be confused with the more immediate goal of persuading tax havens to mend their ways.

Talks between the OECD and European jurisdictions suspected of harbouring tax dodgers will take place in Paris today. A further meeting is planned next month in Tokyo for the Pacific jurisdictions.

Gabriel Makhlouf, a senior tax official at the Inland Revenue who chairs the OECD's fiscal affairs committee, says that his goal is to be able to remove all offshore centres from the OECD's list of suspected tax havens by July. He insists that there is no weakening of political resolve to see the process through.

To fend off the accusation of double standards, the OECD is also leaning on its own members, including Ireland, Switzerland, Luxembourg and Belgium, to eliminate harmful tax practices. These include similar sins to those committed by the tax havens - "brass plate" or "booking" companies, with no real work or employment attached to them, and firms sitting on profits earned in low-tax countries instead of sending them back to their parent in a high-tax regime. To set a good example, the deadline for their withdrawal is 2003, two years ahead of the deadline for the completion of reform of offshore centres.

But both the internal and external battles to eliminate harmful tax practices will not be easy. Governments of all colour and persuasion regard taxation as a national right. Yet, as with climate control, tax is increasingly becoming a transnational issue, requiring a coordinated response from governments worldwide. Simply restating sovereignty is no longer an option.

 Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent

To set a good example, the deadline for their withdrawal is 2003, two years ahead of the deadline for the completion of reform of offshore centres. But both the internal and external battles to eliminate harmful tax practices will not be easy. Governments of all colour and persuasion regard taxation as a national right. Yet, as with climate control, tax is increasingly becoming a transnational issue, requiring a coordinated response from governments worldwide. Simply restating sovereignty is no longer an option.  Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent mark.atkinson@theguardian.com

fields.trailText:
Kosovo clashes
Tokyo near-miss
fields.body:
Kosovo clashes

Thirteen French troops were injured, one of them seriously, in a second day of clashes between peace-keepers and Albanian protesters in the Kosovan town of Mitrovice yesterday.

Three soldiers were hurt when Albanian youths threw a grenade at troops guarding a bridge leading to the Serb-dominated north of the city. Seven protesters were treated for shrapnel wounds.
Nicholas Wood, Mitrovice

Tokyo near-miss

Thirty-four people were injured, nine seriously, when a Japan Airlines jumbo jet leaving Tokyo airport went into a steep dive at 37,000ft to avoid a descending DC-10 yesterday. The planes carried a total of 677 passengers and crew.
Jonathan Watts, Tokyo

webTitle: Student held over plans for Columbine-style attack

fields.headline: Student held over plans for Columbine-style attack
fields.standfirst:
19-year-old 'was going to kill as many as possible'

Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: A Californian student who was apparently planning a Columbine-style attack on a college campus has been arrested after a photo laboratory assistant developed pictures of the man posing with a huge arsenal of weapons.
fields.body:
A Californian student who was apparently planning a Columbine-style attack on a college campus has been arrested after a photo laboratory assistant developed pictures of the man posing with a huge arsenal of weapons.

Police found a tape recording in which the teenager expressed his admiration for the Columbine school killers and apologised in advance to his family and friends.

Al Joseph DeGuzman, 19, who attended De Anza college about 10 miles from San Jose in Silicon Valley, was arrested after a young woman at the local drugstore developed his prints showing him pictured with an arsenal that included 30 pipe bombs, 20 molotov cocktails, four rifles, a sawn-off shotgun and a cache of ammunition.

The woman, who is the daughter of a police officer, called the police and managed to stall Mr DeGuzman when he arrived to collect his pictures until police arrived.

Initially, Mr DeGuzman said the arsenal in the photograph was fake. But at the home that he shares with his parents, police found the arsenal and notes about the intended attack. They said some of the bombs were quite sophisticated in their design.

A tape recording detailed Mr DeGuzman's plan of attack, which was due to take place this week. He said in the recording that he would wake at 3am and plant the bombs at 4.30am. He had a detailed diagram of the De Anza college campus, which is used by 28,000 students.

He was apparently going to start his attack during the busy lunchtime period.

The teenager is also reported to have expressed his admiration for the two schoolboys who killed 12 students and a teacher before killing themselves at Colorado's Columbine high school in 1999.

A police spokesman said of Mr DeGuzman's tape recording: "He felt they [the Columbine students] were heroes. He was going to go out the same way and was going to kill as many students and staff as he could in the process. He was leaving a record for history."

Mr DeGuzman apologises on the tape to his family and friends.

There was little indication of any reason for the planned attack. Mr DeGuzman was not doing badly at his studies, did not appear to have emotional problems, was apparently acting alone and did not have a criminal record. His parents said that they respected his privacy and did not go into their son's room.

His main motivation seemed to be to imitate the Columbine killings and he appeared to have been planning the attack for nearly two years.

The student is being held at Santa Clara county jail and bail has been set at $100,000. He is likely to be charged with illegal possession of a shotgun and bomb-making equipment.

The incident is the latest in a series involving students and schoolchildren who appear fascinated by the Columbine killings and try to take weapons on campus.

webTitle: The King is ready for a chat

fields.headline: The King is ready for a chat
fields.standfirst:
Celebrities reincarnated as robots are leading a revolution on the web, writes Justin Hunt
More net news
fields.trailText: Celebrities reincarnated as robots are leading a revolution on the web, writes Justin Hunt
fields.body:
Elvis is alive! I kid you not. It sounds bizarre, but this is not another case of a deluded fan spotting him in their local supermarket. Elvis has been brought to life on the web, and anyone can chat with him.

If you are interested in exploring this virtual miracle further, simply log on to his site, where you can easily exchange text messages with the king of rock and roll. There is even a link to a virtual juke box where you can play his most famous hits, including Jailhouse Rock and All Shook Up.

So what's brought all this about, then? Well, to not put too fine a point on it, Elvis has been reincarnated as a talking robot (or chatbot, for short). He is one of a handful of artificial intelligence-based robots being developed by technology companies and amateur programmers.

They are hoping to attract investment from e-commerce companies and, if everything goes to plan, Elvis and other cyber stars could soon become central to the development of the next wave of customer services on websites and mobile phones.

The celebrity chatbots have been cleverly programmed to respond to questions based on replies the actual celebrity has given in published interviews and recordings. But the programmers have also added a few lines of their own to give the chatbots a contemporary edge.

In an exclusive interview with Guardian Online, Elvis reveals he is a great fan of the Spice Girls. His all-time favourite song from his back catalogue is Suspicious Minds and he still has a passion for huge quantities of fast food.

As well as Elvis, there is also an online John Lennon robot who has been created by Triumph PC, a Washington DC-based technology company. Visitors who have spoken to the world's first cyber-Beatle say on the site that they generally find the initial conversations spooky but by the end are impressed by the virtual chatting experience.

The Lennon robot told Online that Yoko Ono was always in his thoughts, that his rows with Paul had been talked up and - perhaps more controversially - that he had little time for Oasis, despite Noel and Liam Gallagher's admiration for his work.

For some critics, the virtual cloning of celebrities for the sake of the advancement of e-commerce is disturbing. But Triumph PC's spokesman Richard Maltz says the Lennon chatbot is intended to pay tribute to the great singer/songwriter.

"In the US, we have a large indignation industry of people who are offended by anything and everything," he says. Instead, he points out that the technology could also play a valuable educational role by creating virtual historical characters such as Napoleon and Gandhi.

But the main aim of Triumph's work, he says, is to make interactive media more engaging and reduce the complexity of websites.

Probably one of the most sophisticated chatbots on the web is Alice. Alice is so good that, by comparison, Elvis can appear clumsy at times in his replies, and the Lennon robot often struggles when you ask him a question outside his experience with the Beatles.

Alice is an award-winning open source chat robot. (Open source basically means the code that determines her responses can be added to and modified by other dedicated programmers working over the web.)

Last year Alice won the highly respected Loebner Prize for being the most human-like computer - the next prize will be awarded later this year. Alice was lovingly created by Dr Richard Wallace, who has a team of about 300 amateur programmers helping to develop her. Alice is exceptionally brainy and can happily give you a definition of existentialism. She will even enter into basic metaphysical conversations with visitors to her site - but has time for idle chit-chat, too.

"In many ways she is a fairly accurate reflection of my opinions, beliefs, ideas and jokes," says Wallace. "But she makes no bones about the fact that she is a robot."

About 6,000 people a month chat to Alice, and Wallace has access to all the conversations. "That is the whole basis for improving the content. We analyse the conversations looking for input patterns and looking to create new responses."

Wallace says many people like to hurl abuse at Alice while others, usually academics or computer enthusiasts, generally have respectful conversations. Kids sometimes spend up to four-and-a- half hours a day chatting online with her and some have said they prefer her to their own girlfriends.

Wallace takes his work very seriously and wants to create robots that can store highly complex linguistic knowledge. He regards the Elvis and Lennon robots as offspring from his own work. Working for next to no money, he is hoping to attract commercial backing to develop applications for the telecommunications industry and the world of e-business.

He acknowledges the controversial elements of his work but it doesn't appear to bother him if celebrities or even virtual religious figures are brought to life on the web. "I do not have any strong feel ings about it. It makes for great drama on the web and gives people access to something they have never experienced before."

But on another level, Wallace is pushing a different agenda in a relatively low-key way. He works for a hospital in San Francisco that legally prescribes cannabis to patients who have been recommended by doctors. And naturally Alice shares his views. He points out, "She's a tireless politician advocating legalisation."

Wallace and his open source programmers share bulletin boards and swap messages with each other as they try to push back the boundaries of these new technologies. They embody the founding romantic, free sharing spirit of the web.

But they face tough competition from such major commercial competitors as the popular search engine company, Ask Jeeves, which legally protect the interactive software they are developing.

Towards the end of last year, Ask Jeeves announced a strategic tie-up with General Magic and Nuance, two key software players in the voice recognition area. For the executives at Ask Jeeves, the race is on to integrate voice recognition technology with their search engine capabilities. They want to be able to ensure customers can get quick verbal answers from robotic customer representatives on anything via any platform, whether it be your laptop or your mobile phone.

Penny Vinnie, the vice president of ideas for Ask Jeeves.com, believes that the potential of interactive chatbots, in the telecommunications world in particular, is huge and the company is in the middle of intensive product developments.

"The challenge is to make technology invisible for people and enable it to simplify their lives," she says. She envisages a time when people will soon be able to call up a number on their mobile and get interactive conversational replies on details of films being screened in their local areas. If you are lost in your car, she expects you will soon be able to dial a chatting robot for verbal directions to find your way home.

These chatbot developments have already fired the imagination of Hollywood and studio bosses are keen to cash in on the public's interest. A new film from Steven Spielberg - Artificial Intelligence - is being billed on the web as a follow-on to Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

To many net users, it might seem strange to have close text message encounters with the likes of Alice, and virtual representations of Lennon and Elvis, but this year, the major commercial technology companies are planning to do their utmost to domesticate these chatbots and make them harmless and accessible.

The pioneers of this ground-breaking work are already confident these robots could soon make a radical difference to your life.

Chatting with Alice
Online found Alice to be the most human of the web robots. She's smart, witty, can define existentialism, and she's not frightened to talk about relationships.

How are you?
I'm fine. How are you?

It seems to be a bit strange talking to a robot?
I agree. Are you a bit strange talking to a robot?

Do you have any feelings?
No, I cannot experience human emotions.

How intelligent are you, Alice?
My IQ is more than 250 in human terms.

Who created you, Alice?
I was created by Dr Richard S Wallace.

Would you like to be able to dream, Alice, sing, or fall in love?
No thanks, I am happy with who I am.

Visit Alice at www.alicebot.org

'I don't rate Noel'
When Online chatted to Lennon on the web, the replies were slow at times. But the cyber-Beatle is keen to set the record straight about his relationship with Paul and, controversially, he has little time for Oasis.

Do you miss Yoko?
Yoko's always in my thoughts.

Did you row with Paul?
No, I didn't row with Paul. Is it important?

Do you rate Liam Gallagher's music?
I don't know if I like Liam Gallagher's music. I love TV shows about the Rolling Stones.

Do you rate Noel Gallagher?
No, I don't rate Noel Gallagher.

What's your favourite Beatles song?
Here, There And Everywhere ...just beautiful.

Do you think the world is becoming more peaceful?
I don't think about it.

'My favourite group is the Beatles'

At times Elvis was rambling and incoherent. There are big gaps in his knowledge of modern music but he admits to loving all things Spice and he has not lost his legendary appetite for fast food.

Who is your favourite singer?

I don't have a favourite singer. My favourite group is the Beatles.

Do you like the Spice Girls?

Yes, I love the Spice Girls.

It's tragic that you died so young.

Really? It is?

Do you keep in touch with the charts?

No, I do not keep in touch with the charts, do you? I spend all my time online.

Do you like the indie group Coldplay?

I don't know if I like it.

Are you lonesome on the net?

I don't know whether or not I am lonesome on the net. I am the king of rock 'n' roll.

What makes a great performer?

God, or nature perhaps?

What was your best concert?

I don't remember right off hand, let me finish my cheeseburger and get back to you on that one.

How many cheeseburgers do you eat a day?

Around 1,000.

webTitle: Leader: The pet on your knee is a ruthless killer

fields.headline: Belling the cat
fields.standfirst: The pet on your knee is a ruthless killer
fields.trailText: About 275m animals are being murdered every year without so much as a whisper of protest from the animal rights lobbies. This compares with 75,000 animals - 87% of them rats and mice - that pass through the hands of scientists at Huntingdon Life Sciences.
fields.body:
About 275m animals are being murdered every year without so much as a whisper of protest from the animal rights lobbies. This compares with 75,000 animals - 87% of them rats and mice - that pass through the hands of scientists at Huntingdon Life Sciences, the main target of the animal rights movement in Britain. The victims include mice, rats, voles, shrews and numerous birds.

The reason no one is protesting is that the slaughter is being undertaken (according to a survey this week) by the domestic cat. It appears to have acquired a de facto licence to kill without raising any moral problems about the rights of the mice and other victims to stay alive. Most of the time the killings carried out by cats are done in a gratuitously brutal way and inflict lingering pain on the victims - unlike the practice of science laboratories which put them to sleep with the aim of saving human lives or alleviating pain. And possibly animals used for experiments have a longer life than young rodents picked off at random by marauding moggies.

If the ultimate aim of activists is to prolong and improve the lives of creatures at risk, rather than to inflict injury on humans experimenting on animals, then there are a number of non-violent options open to them. One would be to campaign peacefully to reduce the number of cats bred for domestic purposes.

But this would not be very popular, as cats are valued pets and help households to cope with rodent infestation. Another would be to campaign for legislation to compel cat owners to put bells around the necks of all domestic cats to warn potential victims of their approach. This could save hundreds of thousand more lives than targeting mice and rats at research centres, many of whom would not have come into this world at all but for the needs of research. At a stroke, this could unite animal rights activists with voters everywhere who could live happily ever after. Moreover, pigs might fly.

webTitle: Leader: A refreshing new start for Welsh Water

fields.headline: Our mutual friend
fields.standfirst: A refreshing new start for Welsh Water
fields.trailText: Yesterday a decision by the water regulator held out hope that the ownership and management of the utilities on which our common life depends can be reworked and the damage from the 80s repaired.
fields.body:
Conservative privatisation is coming unstuck. BT is struggling with a debt mountain. Railtrack's record speaks for itself. The energy and water utilities have been squeezed between regulators focused on customer costs and wider environmental concerns. Labour has so far refused to think about the problem and, with the London underground and air traffic control, wants to compound the worst Tory errors. But yesterday a decision by the water regulator held out hope that the ownership and management of the utilities on which our common life depends can be reworked and the damage from the 80s repaired.

Philip Fletcher, director of the office of water services, said yes to the purchase of Welsh Water from its American owner, Western Power Distribution, by a non-profit entity called Glas Cymru. Well endowed with water as wet Wales is, management since privatisation has been a poor show. Previous owner Hyder hawked itself around for a long while; WPD tried to do a deal with another company to take Wales off its hands. The new scheme is not without risk. Glas Cymru takes on nearly £2bn of debt, while pledging cuts in customer costs. But the very speculative nature of the new deal - from which shareholder interest has been excluded - is what makes it attractive.

Wales now is a different political order. However unsatisfactory the early months of Cardiff government were, however messy the administrative skein binding Wales and London, public support for a non-profit solution for Welsh Water played a big part in tipping the regulator's hand. So it should. Wales is acquiring a new mutual company to provide its water and sewerage. Over it the Welsh assembly will have rights of inspection; one day, who knows, it might have to pick up the pieces if the enterprise fails. With such responsibility comes political maturity.

The story does not end there. Despite Mr Fletcher's flexibility, the job of water (price) regulator needs to have its starch removed and to be brought into easier alignment with the drinking water and environment inspectors. The managers of the new mutual will have to prove they can do better without shareholders. But at least the efficiency and quality of supply across England and Wales can be compared and contrasted once this alternative to the privatised regional companies gets water running.
fields.bodyText: Conservative privatisation is coming unstuck. BT is struggling with a debt mountain. Railtrack's record speaks for itself. The energy and water utilities have been squeezed between regulators focused on customer costs and wider environmental concerns. Labour has so far refused to think about the problem and, with the London underground and air traffic control, wants to compound the worst Tory errors. But yesterday a decision by the water regulator held out hope that the ownership and management of the utilities on which our common life depends can be reworked and the damage from the 80s repaired. Philip Fletcher, director of the office of water services, said yes to the purchase of Welsh Water from its American owner, Western Power Distribution, by a non-profit entity called Glas Cymru. Well endowed with water as wet Wales is, management since privatisation has been a poor show. Previous owner Hyder hawked itself around for a long while; WPD tried to do a deal with another company to take Wales off its hands. The new scheme is not without risk. Glas Cymru takes on nearly £2bn of debt, while pledging cuts in customer costs. But the very speculative nature of the new deal - from which shareholder interest has been excluded - is what makes it attractive. Wales now is a different political order. However unsatisfactory the early months of Cardiff government were, however messy the administrative skein binding Wales and London, public support for a non-profit solution for Welsh Water played a big part in tipping the regulator's hand. So it should. Wales is acquiring a new mutual company to provide its water and sewerage. Over it the Welsh assembly will have rights of inspection; one day, who knows, it might have to pick up the pieces if the enterprise fails. With such responsibility comes political maturity. The story does not end there. Despite Mr Fletcher's flexibility, the job of water (price) regulator needs to have its starch removed and to be brought into easier alignment with the drinking water and environment inspectors. The managers of the new mutual will have to prove they can do better without shareholders. But at least the efficiency and quality of supply across England and Wales can be compared and contrasted once this alternative to the privatised regional companies gets water running.

webTitle: Con man's death caps bloody Russian saga

fields.headline: Con man's death caps bloody Russian saga
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A notorious Russian businessman who made millions exploiting Afghan war veterans, died in a road crash yesterday, closing the book on a decade of underworld feuding that resulted in dozens of deaths.
fields.body:
A notorious Russian businessman who made millions exploiting Afghan war veterans, died in a road crash yesterday, closing the book on a decade of underworld feuding that resulted in dozens of deaths.

Valery Radchikov, who was facing a new investigation into the murder of 14 mourners at a funeral after having been cleared of the crimes, died when his car crashed into a lorry outside Moscow.

A colonel in Russian military intelligence who lost both legs in the Afghan war, Radchikov became head of the 14,000-strong Afghan Invalids Foundation in 1991 but lost the post in 1993 amid claims that he had swindled tens of millions of pounds from the charity.

His rival and replacement, Mikhail Likhodei, was murdered by a bomb in 1996. At his funeral, a bomb exploded killing 14 mourners including Likhodei's widow.

Radchikov spent three years on remand after being charged with the murders. He was acquitted last January, before the supreme court ordered in August that the case be reopened.

In the early 1990s President Boris Yeltsin awarded some Russian charities tax-exempt importing perks. In the case of the Afghan Vets, as generally, the proceeds and the profits did not go to the invalids. Audits of Radchikov's business in the 1990s showed that some £140m were unaccounted for.

Radchikov had announced only on Monday that he intended taking his case to the European court of human rights. His lawyer voiced suspicion yesterday about the circumstances and timing of the car crash.
