fields.headline: Halifax throws lifeline to Equitable
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life's beleaguered policyholders were thrown a lifeline yesterday when Halifax emerged as a surprise bidder for the troubled mutual fund group.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's beleaguered policyholders were thrown a lifeline yesterday when Halifax emerged as a surprise bidder for the troubled mutual fund group.

Although the price tag on Equitable, which closed its doors to new business in December, is far below the £5bn first mooted, Halifax is believed to be in negotiations which could result in a price of around £1bn.

Sources stressed last night that an agreement between Halifax and Equitable had not been sealed but that Halifax was the strongest hope yet for a better deal for policyholders after a string of other bidders all walked away. These include Prudential, CGNU and the Australian group AMP.

Halifax told the City yesterday that its talks with Equitable would not involve it taking over the long-term fund which is saddled with the troublesome guaranteed annuities that were at the core of Equitable's problems. The law lords ruled in the summer that Equitable had acted unfairly in cutting the bonuses to holders of guaranteed annuities, leaving the insurer with a bill of at least £1.5bn and little option but to put itself up for sale.

While the first sale process was abandoned because of concerns about the true size of the bill to repay these guarantees, the process reopened when fresh attempts were made to put a cap on these annuities.

fields.headline: Medea's modern slant - and rant
fields.standfirst:
Medea
Queen's Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Medea
Queen's Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Why is Medea the most revived of all Greek tragedies? Because, I suspect, Euripides confronts the ultimate horror: maternal infanticide. Deborah Warner's production, which hails from the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, left me with mixed feelings. While no one could accuse it of shirking the play's violence, it banishes the rhetorical formality of antique tragedy to replace it with a contemporary rhetoric of its own.

Visually, the production is full of sharp intelligence. In Tom Pye's excellent design the action seems to be taking place not outside a Corinthian palace but in some bleak adventure playground, a place of brutal concrete and glass walls where children's toys litter a raised pool. The calculated banality of the setting reinforces the play's cruelty. Where Euripides offers his murdering heroine mythical flight, Warner allows Medea no such consolation; instead of gazing down on Jason from a dragon-drawn chariot, she here enters bearing her two blood-soaked children and confronts her treacherous husband in a state of vindictive exhaustion.

All this is fine: it takes the play out of the rarified world of Attic tragedy and brings it closer to the milieu of Edward Bond. But, having elected to give the play a harsh modern feel, Warner then allows her actors to roar and rave - and the first victim is Fiona Shaw's Medea.

The infuriating thing is that Shaw's performance is full of intelligent insights, not least the contradiction that allows her to compulsively clutch Jason even as she curses him, or to momentarily doubt her use of the children as poison-bearing emissaries when she thinks they might be saved from banishment. But Shaw's emotional hyperactivity leads her to over-colour every line or to indulge in a gestural frenzy.

Of course, Medea is a woman in extremis but Shaw's performance is all storm and no calm. Only once did she move me - when she cried, in the beautifully limpid lines of Kenneth McLeish and Frederic Raphael's translation, "My lovely life is lost."

The high-decibel style also afflicts Jonathan Cake's Jason, who is encouraged to deliver every line as if it were the play's climax. The smug chauvinism of the man is there in the language; he doesn't need to stand at the footlights and bawl "You come from God knows where to Greece", as if to advertise his nationalist arrogance.

The actors who come off best are Struan Rodger as Kreon and Robert Hines as the Messenger, in that they allow the emotion to emerge through the words instead of adding it as a top-dressing.

It is heartening to find Euripides in Shaftesbury Avenue alongside Eugene O'Neill, and at times Warner's production is genuinely chilling, not least in the cheap transistor music that plays even as murder is committed. But the production's downbeat realism and exploration of Medea's muddled motives sit oddly with its indulgence of emotional rant.

 Until April 14. Box office: 020-7494 5040. A version of this review ran in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.body:
Pleasure and perversity were both present in this wildly uneven concert, in which Canadian tenor Ben Heppner joined forces with Christian Thielemann and the Royal Opera House Orchestra for a programme of Wagner chunks with arias by Beethoven and Weber thrown in. Once associated with a formidably wide repertoire embracing Mozart, Janacek and Britten, Heppner has gravitated towards heroic German roles of late, often with hair-raising results.

His voice is not quite that of a traditional Wagnerian Heldentenor. A colossal sound, it is capable of cutting through the densest of orchestral textures and soaring upwards with a noble, ringing ease. There's a fluency of movement and brightness of tone far removed from the almost baritonal quality of many Wagner interpreters.

He is often vividly dramatic, though his chosen format occasionally hampers him. Wagner extracts provide opportunities for spectacular singing, but you sometimes miss the spacious exploration of character and the sustained probing of the human psyche.

Walter's Prize Song from Meistersinger, hurled out in almost visionary ecstasy, perhaps showed Heppner's Wagner at its best. Siegmund's Winterstürme was urgently sexual, though its abrupt ending leaves you hanging in emotional mid-air. Tristan's delirious ravings were painful in their intensity, but Lohengrin's narration revealed a weakness in Heppner's method - in place of genuine soft singing, you're conscious of a scaling-down of tone, which leads to an absence of genuine mystic fervour.

The excerpts from Weber and Beethoven, which analyse character with comparative brevity, were very much the high points. Florestan's monologue from Fidelio was viscerally done, the contrast between physical suffering and nobility of soul superlatively captured. The swivelling between elegance and terror in Max's aria from Der Freischütz was equally riveting.

Thielemann was an unfailingly sensitive accompanist, though things got rather strange when he was left to his own devices in the orchestral numbers that separated the arias. He took the prelude and Liebestod from Tristan so slowly that it seemed to be not so much about orgasm as chronic detumescence. Only in the Lohengrin prelude - real mystical-erotic stuff - did he really strike form.

The encores, however, were fabulous as the pair plunged into Richard Tauber territory. Heppner sang the closing scene of Korngold's Die Tote Stadt with exquisite beauty, while Thielemann exposed every shivery, erotic flicker of the remarkable orchestration. After that, You Are My Heart's Delight from Lehar's Land of Smiles brought the house down. Thielemann finally abandoned his Prussian prancing for relaxed, echt-Viennese sexiness.

fields.headline: Kubrick the snapper
fields.standfirst:
Stanley Kubrick
Inverleith House, Edinburgh
***
fields.trailText:
Stanley Kubrick
Inverleith House, Edinburgh
***
fields.body:
Stanley Kubrick once said that to make a film entirely by yourself, as he did in his early career, "you may not have to know very much about anything else, but you must know about photography". It sounds like a truism, masterful and meaningless. But Kubrick knew what he was talking about.

Before the films, before the powerful moving images in 2001: A Space Odyssey, A Clockwork Orange and Eyes Wide Shut, Kubrick produced more than 800 photographs - still images through which he made a living in his late teens. Floundering at school, he took up photography after his father gave him a camera for his 13th birthday.

At 15, he took an image that seemed to define a moment of national loss - a newspaper vendor at his stall, crumpled and sad, as front pages around him related the death of President FD Roosevelt. Kubrick sold it to Look for $25; the magazine then hired him and he toured the US in his late teens, capturing postwar society for Look's photo-stories.

This exhibition, Still Moving Pictures 1945-1950, presents more than 100 of these images for the first time in Britain. The main interest is biographical: what the young Kubrick did as a job while he dreamed of making films. But there is a rigorous compositional eye in the best of these photographs, and the framing of subjects in a handful of them shows a talent beyond the photo-journalism he was engaged in.

An elegant portrait of debutante Betsy von Furstenberg, reading in a window seat, legs raised and toes pointing away; several stills from the series What Every Teenager Should Know About Dating; the best of the small-scale studies of boxing - in these we see an eye for what to shoot and how.

That said, the exhibition's only raison d' tre is that Kubrick took these shots. The changing social and built landscape of late-1940s and 1950s America is familiar to us because it was so heavily photographed, often for newly popular magazines such as Look. There is nothing to mark these images as the work of the same talent that would later bring us Dr Strangelove or Full Metal Jacket.

I'm not sure, either, that removing the photographs from their commercial context works. Sure, the photo-stories were "pretty dumb", as Kubrick once commented, and they constrained his imagination far more than they stirred it, but to reify these images as fine art strips the life from them, particularly because their creator went on to do other, great work.

It's a revealing exhibition for Kubrick fans, not least because it shows him producing unchallenging work for the mainstream market. That, more than any one image, is the shock here.

 Until April 1. Details: 0131-248 2943.

webTitle: How do I get a day of rest?

fields.headline: How do I get a day of rest?
fields.trailText: 1 February: I am a shop worker and my employers want me to work two Sundays a month.
fields.body:
The problem

What is the legal situation on Sunday work? I am a shop worker and my employers want me to work two Sundays a month. For this I will get two days' pay and a day in lieu, which will be taken at the manager's discretion.

I do not wish to give up my Sundays for such small gains. Is there any defence against such brutal managements?

The solution

The Sunday Trading Act 1994 provides legislation that gives shop workers the right not to be dismissed, selected for redundancy or subjected to other detrimental action for refusing to work on Sundays. There are some exceptions, so if you are not a member of a union, contact your local ACAS (number in your phone book) for advice.

Your employers should not apply pressure on you and if they do and you are forced to leave (or they fire you), you will have a very strong case for unfair or constructive dismissal. I suggest that you keep notes of anything said to you in respect of Sunday working (for example threats made or pressure put on you). Once ACAS have fully briefed you, you might want to compose a letter outlining your rights. Your employers would be very foolish to do anything other than leave you alone once they realise that you are aware of your rights.

However, from a psychological point of view, I would advise you to attempt to negotiate some sort of compromise (since your reasons for not wanting to work Sunday are not due to religious conviction). Perhaps you could offer to work one Sunday each month, or suggest a more acceptable renumeration package in line with that offered by other companies. If a mutually beneficial agreement can be reached, all well and good. If not, don't work the Sundays!


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: At this price?  ARM
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Should investors arm themselves with ARM shares? That was the question analysts were wrestling with yesterday despite the microchip designer's better-than-expected full-year results and some watchers upping their profit forecasts for next year.
fields.body:
Should investors arm themselves with ARM shares? That was the question analysts were wrestling with yesterday despite the microchip designer's better-than-expected full-year results and some watchers upping their profit forecasts for next year.

In the 12 months to December 31, revenues breached the £100m mark for the first time, while pre-tax profits almost doubled to £35.4m. ARM shares bounced around all day and closed up 30p at 530p, making it the best performing FTSE 100 stock.

Yet hardly anyone in the City thinks that is the shares' true value. House broker Morgan Stanley believes they are grossly underpriced and should be changing hands at £10 each. It argues that ARM is on course to achieve its aim of getting its designs into the microchips that power every mobile device in the world, from cellphones and digital cameras to MP3 music players and set-top boxes.

ARM, led by founder Robin Saxby, has one of the highest rated management teams in the business, has partnered almost everyone who matters including Intel and Motorola, and is starting to see its chips shipped in serious volumes. The big and unanswered question is: Can ARM continue to grow at this rate?

Mr Saxby says future business orders look very strong, yet Goldman Sachs analyst Charles Elliot says the shares are valued at 140 times their forecast earnings for 2001 and 100 times what he believes the firm will make in 2002. "I love the company but that valuation is overdemanding," he said. The slowdown in global manufacture of microchips might also hinder growth.

The lack of bad news in the results, particularly the absence of management concern about slackening demand in the mobile phone market, reassured many who fear the firm is over-valued.

The shares look fully priced at the moment but in a torrid technology sector ARM is as safe a haven as any. Hold, and be prepared to buy on any weakness in the price.

fields.headline: DiFranco's subtle songs
fields.standfirst:
Ani DiFranco
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ani DiFranco
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
Without a hint of mainstream chart or media attention over a decade-long career, without a new record to promote and without any discernible music industry "buzz", Ani DiFranco and her tightly drilled, multi-instrumental five-piece band can undertake an extensive tour of Europe. Moreover, they can sell out - and it's a genuine, sweating-walls, packed-to-the-rafters sell-out - one of London's more prestigious mid-range venues.

In a sense, the crowd - the vast majority women - gather for what the New Jersey art school graduate sings about, rather than how she sings it. She is a self-contained cottage industry, railing against injustices within the US. Encapsulating the eternal howl of the disenfranchised, she touches on urban decay, the electric chair, pollution, self-control ("Drugs and guns? You choose"), gay liberation, racism and smoking."Please do not smoke," says a notice taped to every pillar and post. "One of Ani's band has asthma." Towards the end she suggests that the myriad movements "doing so much good work" might be more effective were they to unite. It seems safe to assume she did not vote for George Bush.

Yet DiFranco rarely hectors. Despite her issues, her music is complex and subtle. She never needs to raise her voice. Her stream-of -consciousness lyrics are underpinned by a staccato, almost free-form, backdrop, as disciplined but as left-field as Talk Talk.

DiFranco's voice has the tearful catch of Odyssey's Lillian Lopez, but invariably she is tempted to embrace the tangential. Thus she will sing her introductions, read prose, insert a snatch of KC and the Sunshine Band's Get Down Tonight and ad-lib during one of the quieter passages about the joys of not having a major label distribution deal. Yet for all her frustrating near-pretension, she is an engaging, breathless, sometimes giggly, hostess. And when she impersonates a cow she is laugh-out-loud funny.

The set is packed with new material (the announcement that she will perform three unheard songs in succession is greeted with wild applause), but even the vaguely anthemic fare fails to provide a truly memorable chorus. Still, Ani was never meant to be easy.

fields.headline: £20bn bid ends phoney war
fields.standfirst:
Abbey National agrees to talk to Lloyds TSB about deal that would cost 9,000 jobs and 300 branches

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hundreds of bank branches across the country are likely to be closed under the £20bn takeover bid tabled yesterday by Lloyds TSB for Abbey National.
fields.body:
Hundreds of bank branches across the country are likely to be closed under the £20bn takeover bid tabled yesterday by Lloyds TSB for Abbey National.

Although Lloyds pledged to keep the Abbey brand and its 722 branches for two years after any successful takeover, it then intends to "co-locate" the 600 branches within a quarter of a mile of each other. At least 9,000 jobs - almost 10% of the combined workforce - will be lost over four years.

Only after two years will Lloyds decide the fate of a potential plethora of Abbey brands, including Cheltenham & Gloucester, Scottish Widows, Scottish Mutual and Scottish Provident.

After a phoney war which has simmered for almost two months, Lloyds TSB yesterday issued a formal bid for Abbey although made it conditional on approval from its prey's reluctant management and clearance from the competition authorities.

The chairman and chief executive of Abbey National, who rejected the informal approach in December, yesterday agreed to meet their counterparts at Lloyds TSB this weekend to discuss the deal which offers shareholders 1.5 Lloyds shares and 260p in cash for each Abbey share.

Abbey's agreement to the bid is by no means certain because the company would prefer to merge with Bank of Scotland, allowing its management to retain their jobs.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, refused to indicate what roles if any would be offered to Abbey's top management. He now intends to embark on charm offensive of Abbey's shareholders to encourage them to put pressure on his target's management to agree to the deal.

But Lloyds shares fell by almost 5% yesterday - reducing the value of the deal from just under £20bn to less than £18.5bn. The abandonment by Lloyds of its much-heralded goal to keep its costs-to-income ratio - a measure of efficiency - to 35% was cited as one reason for the decline.

One senior fund manager described the City's response to the approach as "lukewarm" because many investors had expected Lloyds TSB, which has expanded rapidly through acquisition in recent years, to make its next move in mainland Europe. Mr Ellwood insisted yesterday that was still possible. By taking over Abbey, Lloyds aims to achieve annual cost and revenue savings of £950m, at the expense of a one-off charge of £1.1bn, and boost its profits by £900m. These projections made Mark Thomas, bank analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton, enthusiastic about the deal.

Lloyds also released early its annual profits for 2000, showing a rise to £3.8bn for the year after a £80m charge related to stakeholder pensions.

Even though investors might have expected Lloyds to move in mainland Europe first, they appear to agree that Lloyds TSB will put a higher price on Abbey National than any deal with BoS. However, regulatory hurdles still need to be cleared and the decision from Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, on whether to give the bid the go-ahead on competition grounds might not be made until February 23.

Clearance for the bid is not a foregone conclusion as Lloyds, combined with Abbey, could have close to a 30% share of the current account market.

Bank of Scotland faces the uncomfortable prospect of havng lost out in two merger attempts. A year ago, its attempt to takeover NatWest failed.

Yesterday is was saying little about its stalled talks with Abbey National. BoS faces speculation about an approach from other institutions, particularly National Australia Bank or Barclays.
